Title: Rakshit Shetty and Charlie take a ride together in scenic Goa
Content: Actor Rakshit Shetty has resumed shoot for the Kiranraj K directorial,. The filming commenced earlier this week in Goa, and the movie team has shared a heart-warming picture of Rakshit riding a motorcycle, while Charlie accompanies him in the sidecar, as they soak in the sylvan locales of the state. “This part of the shoot concentrates on Dharma (Rakshit’s character in the film ), who goes out on a road trip to North India. A montage song unveils the emotions that Dharma feels, along with some adventure thrown in. And Goa is where it all begins,” says Kiranraj. The road trip is also about Dharma bonding with Charlie. “We shot some beautiful sequences against the coconut-fringed backgrounds in the by-lanes of Parra and the scenic beach of Arambol. Each of these locations evoke specific emotions in you and add further depth to our story,” the director sums up.

Title: Malgudi Days is about real-life experiences: K Rathnakar Kamath
Content: After finding their footing in Tulu cinema with the 2018 film, Appe Teacher, the team behind it is taking a plunge in Sandalwood with Vijay Raghavendra-starrer Malgudi Days. Backed by Swayam Prabha Entertainment and Productions , the upcoming Kannada film is touted as a no-frills, content-oriented project.“After months of brainstorming, we decided to work on a film that brought out stories from two different generations. The narrative focuses on people’s life experiences, with the aim to create a sense of nostalgia among the audience. We wanted to keep the story relatable and not much indulge in artistic pursuits,” says producer K Rathnakar Kamath , adding, “We have received a lot of support from filmmaker Chinne Gowda sir throughout our journey. He was also instrumental in getting Vijay on board, who is the protagonist in the film.”

Title: Yashasvi Jaiswal is Indian cricket’s new poster boy
Content:
Yashasvi hails from Uttar Pradesh, where he was born into a family that owned a small hardware store.

It was his interest in cricket that made him move to Mumbai when he was just 10 years old. He lived in a tent and took up odd jobs, including selling Pani Puri, to save up enough money for his cricket training.

He first came under the spotlight in 2015, when he scored a triple century and took 13 wickets in a record-breaking feat in a school tournament.

Following that, he found a place for himself in the Mumbai Ranji Team as well as the India Under-19 Team.

Yashasvi has also bagged a plum contract from the Rajasthan team in IPL, where he was bought for over Rs 2 crore.

On Tuesday, he became not just the highest run-scorer in the Under-19 World Cup, but also the second Indian batsman to score a century against Pakistan in the history of the tournament.

On Tuesday, the Indian Under-19 team beat team Pakistan to enter the finals of the Under-19 World Cup. This win was extra special as the Indian openers led the team to a 10-wicket victory. Yashasvi Jaiswal, who currently plays for Mumbai in Ranji Trophy, won the hearts of cricket lovers by scoring a century. But that’s not all about the young sportsman. His has been an inspiring journey so far…- Compiled by Sunayana.Suresh@timesgroup.com

Title: Stressed while watching the news? Could be compassion fatigue
Content: “Guys, keep sharing, keep posting!” “Are you seeing this?”“What the F***”“cannot. even.”“sigh”~ No posts to show ~These lines (above) often float on our social media feeds and most of us inadvertently end up reading them all. The intention behind this, in most cases, is to evoke empathy. But, in reality, many people are falling prey to compassion fatigue. The horrifying world events and the subsequent news updates that follow are making us either numb or too tired to respond. ‘Secondary traumatic stress’ is, thus, a real concern. The term compassion fatigue is associated with burnout often experienced by those are consuming news 24X7. American writer-comedian Hasan Minhaj spoke about it recently on his show, saying, “We are exposed to all the news, all the time, which makes us feel like we have to care about everything, all the time.” This has put the focus back on compassion fatigue...We’re exposed to all the news all the time, which makes us feel like we have to care about everything all the time... But we can’t possibly care about all of them all the time. There’s even a word for it — compassion fatigue. It’s like we have 50 tabs open in our mental browsers. And we’re about to crash — something’s got to change— Hasan Minhaj, comedianFor 2020: Give yourself a break. Just pick a couple of things to not care about for your sanity. I’m not saying shut down your browser. Just close a couple of tabs.... Especially if it helps you double down on the issues that really matter to you54% of Indians use social media for news updates. This includes 49% of 18 to 25-year-olds, 55% of 26 to 33-year-olds and 58% of 34 to 45-year-olds21% of people constantly feel the urge to stay updated, which is one of the major reasons Indians do not log off from social media accounts. This is followed by the fear of missing work-related communication (12%), to stay active on social media all the time (10%) and to stay connected with friends (9%)*Source: A study conducted by a research and consulting firm and a Chinese smartphone companyUsually, news updates on social media are followed by a fair amount of viewpoints. But with no one around to cross-check this information, what people eventually end up believing in might be way different from ground reality, says filmmaker-activist Kavitha Lankesh. “When you have a face-to-face interaction with someone, you will always have a better and holistic understanding of the issues that you wish to discuss online. Having said that, news alerts may still remain disturbing and fatiguing for many,” she explains.Again, there are times when one feels that a worthy cause is not being discussed enough. “So, one needs to keep going, both online or offline. For instance, if Greta Thunberg had not demonstrated every Friday in front of her school, a global movement on climate change awareness would not have taken place,” she says.People who have a huge follower base on social media should be more judicious about what they post on their pages, according to social media influencer Yamini U. “Some influencers avoid posting about or commenting on burning issues, as they fear losing their followers. But when you have an audience that pays attention to what you say, it is important to speak up,” explains Yamini, stressing the need to do a thorough research before posting anything online.One also needs to ensure that they don’t get emotionally strained while trying to prove a point, she adds. “If you are popular on social media, your followers’ expectations and peer pressure can prove stressful at times. So, it’s important to maintain the balance without affecting your own well-being,” she says.People who are in the public eye are expected to be up-to-date with current issues, and also respond to them from time to time. This, however, can be very taxing, says actor Gulshan Devaiah. “One is constantly expected to be vocal about his/her take on issues concerning the world. But actors have other things to do as well. They also have their personal lives to attend to. One should not succumb to such pressure and share posts on social media just to prove a point. I speak up only when I want to lend my voice to a cause that needs steam, or when I have a genuine opinion to share,” he explains.“Choose causes that you want to support and set realistic goals when working towards them. Setting the bar too high will lead to disappointment and guilt when goals are not achieved,” says Vikram Prabhu, mental health expert. Although compassion fatigue has come under the radar now, mostly after people started complaining about stress due to 24x7 news consumption, this has always been an occupational hazard for caregivers. “Doctors, for instance, are constantly involved in caring for people, and despite being trained to deal with the same, their work can take a toll on them,” says Vikram.

Title: Sudha and team set three Guinness Records in a day
Content: February 2 was a Guinness Records day for feted Carnatic singer, Padma Bhushan Sudha Raghunathan . “It was an idea mooted by a television channel devoted to classical music and dance, and their trust,” she begins to tell us about it.“The founder, saxophone exponent ER Janardhan (fondly called Saxophone Janardhan), was the brain behind this initiative. He wanted to do something different for popularising Carnatic music , and for the community, for the state’s art and culture. Initially, it was a working idea, and we got in touch with the Guinness officials, but finally, it all came together beautifully, in the form of music and dance, and we managed to set three Guinness Records in one day! The officials from London came, and certified the records we set,” adds Sudha.What it was: A mega event at the Ramachandra Convention Centre in Thiruvanmiyur that “underlines the reason why Chennai has been hailed as the Heritage Hub for fine Arts by the UNESCO”, in Sudha’s words.What happened: A hat-trick of setting records in the Guinness Book of World Records. “We feel proud, it’s a great thing to have achieved,” says Sudha.The records setThe largest Carnatic band — a performance by 700 singers, musicians and instrumentalistsThe largest Kuchipudi dance lesson — with 1,183 Kuchipudi dancersThe largest Bharatanatyam dance lesson — with 436 Bharatanatyam dancers dancing in sync at one go

Title: Get Fit with Nakkhul: Fitness is about a lifestyle and not just six-pack abs, says Nakkhul
Content:
Favourite workout: Strength training and leg workout

Strength training and leg workout Guilty pleasure food: Biryani and sweets. But since my wife Sruti is a baker, the temptation is tougher to overcome (laughs).

Biryani and sweets. But since my wife Sruti is a baker, the temptation is tougher to overcome (laughs). Best food alternatives: Keto desserts

Keto desserts A workout pet-peeve: I am still very scared of yoga. It is easy to do a few sets in the gym, but it is tough to hold a pose. It is like being calm in the storm.

I am still very scared of yoga. It is easy to do a few sets in the gym, but it is tough to hold a pose. It is like being calm in the storm. Strict no-nos: Overdoing cardio and aerated drinks

Actor Nakkhul ’s physical transformation is arguably one of the most heartening glow ups the Tamil film industry has seen. From a size 42 in the 2000s, the actor now rocks a size 32. Ask what fitness means to him, and the actor responds with an answer that is as interesting as his journey. “Working out at the gym is almost meditative for me. I go into a zen mode whenever I begin exercising,” the actor says as we pulled him aside for a chat in the middle of his Sunday afternoon workout.The actor, who believes in inch-loss over weight-loss, explains how his perspective about fitness has changed over the years. “For Kaadhalil Vizhindhen, I had to lose ten kilos. But I lost it in a stupid, brash way. I reduced intake of calories and carbs and focused a lot on cardio, which was not ideal. Metabolism crashes are not good. Back then, we did not have the kind of exposure we have today. Now, everything is detailed on the internet. If I, the laziest person on the planet can do it, anybody can,” the actor says with a laugh. Here’s his routine...While dieting and fasting methods might work for a few, it is important to understand that it might end up causing metabolism crashes and even disorders in rare cases. “I would recommend taking up diets that you can follow for life and not just for three months just to take that nice photo and put it on the ’Gram. Because you would be back to square one soon. It is bad for the system. Priorities are important. People should not set unrealistic goals by looking at the bodies of Instagrammers. Fitness is about a lifestyle and not just six-pack abs,” Nakkhul notes.Nakkhul calls himself a glorious gourmet and his ‘Joey Tribbiani’ tee rests his case. “Back then, my food pattern used to be a big bhel puri of things (laughs). But now, I try to eat a very balanced meal. I prefer vegetarian food, which is deviod of any masala. I am also trying to include simple, fibrous food in my diet. It is all about eating sans calorie — you put in more energy, you burn more energy. A lot of people fail to realise that fitness is about 20 per cent gym and 80 per cent nutrition,” he explains.Many women might diss weight training fearing bulkiness. But weights are the way to go, the actor informs. “Athletes do cardio because it is their profession. But weights build muscle and challenge your body. Women think they become bulky if they workout with weights. But they won’t. Run for 10 minutes on the treadmill and do a weighted squat for 10 minutes. The latter is going to make your heart race, making the calorie-burn more effective. Protein-binging is another trend that people catch on to, which is bad. Everything should be done with moderation,” he says.

Title: Dabbawalas, Gateway of India, Old Lady’s shoe recreated at flower show
Content: Mumbai’s annual flower show, which took place between January 31 to February 5, turned out to be a big hit with Mumbaikars. A Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation 's (BMC) initiative, the flower show in its 25th year was held at Veer Mata Jijabai Bhosale Udyan and Zoo, aka the Byculla Zoo. People from all over the city, including celebs from the television and film world were spotted at the show. These include Raveena Tandon , Shreyas Talpade, Padmini Kolhapure, Varsha Usgaonkar, Shivaji Satam , who were spotted at the flower exhibition.Since the theme was centred around Mumbai, the city’s historical monuments and symbols — like the Old Woman’s Shoe from Hanging Gardens, trams, double deckers and butterflies — were recreated through fresh and colourful floral installations. It also paid an ode to the iconic dabbawalas by depicting a man carrying a rack of dabbas; it was made of beautiful white flowers. The event got a patriotic tinge with the flower installation of the Gateway of India, which was made of orange and white flowers and green plants. The exhibition also featured 25,000 species of shrubs, flowering plants, fruit-bearing trees, bonsai trees, exotic vegetables and spice shrubs.

Title: Biopic on Murthys to be in Kannada too
Content:

Filmmaker Ashwiny Iyer Tiwary recently revealed that her upcoming biopic on Bengaluru's tech entrepreneur-philanthropist couple, NR NarayanaandMurty, will be made as a trilingual film, in Kannada , Hindi and Tamil. When we contacted her, the filmmaker said that while she is thrilled to begin work on this film, it is too early to disclose more, as the team is still working on the final draft of the script. She added that she will be making further announcements about the film once the final script is locked and the casting choices have been made. In her social media post, Ashwiny wrote, “Every once in a while we get opportunities that are beyond the art of storytelling. I am blessed to be telling Mr Narayanaand MrsMurty’s story through cinema. Because I feel making movies is a way of strengthening my belief in humanity and self growth adding value to society. #in Hindi, Tamil & Kannada. (sic)”

Title: suni: A birthday treat for Sharan’s fans
Content: Director Suni ’s first film with Sharan, Avatara Purusha , has evoked curiosity among audiences, right from the announcement of their collaboration and the title. And today, the filmmaker is ready to give audiences a sneak peek into the film with the first teaser launch, which coincides with leading man Sharan’s birthday. Moments before he took off on his annual temple visit ritual for his big day, Sharan said that the highlight of the teaser is that it marries multiple factors. “Producer Pushkara Mallikarjunaiah ’s production values, Suni’s classic style of filmmaking and Sharan’s brand of comedy have come together in a story that is set in the backdrop of black magic. This kind of cinema is a first for me, and the teaser will give audiences an idea of what to expect when the film hits theatres in the summer,” said the actor.

Title: Shoot at Site: The making of Thalaivi
Content: The world inside the set of Thalaivi in Prasad Labs is very different from the one outside. It, in fact, belongs to a different time period — the glorious 80s. The roofs are lit up with chandeliers, there’s a flower-patterned stage in the middle, with installations of peacocks adorning the sides. There are small pools filled with water, and wax flowers are floating on them. At least 100 dancers, clad in pristine white, are sitting on the steps surrounding the stage. There’s a lot of hustle and bustle — director Vijay and cinematographer Vishal Vittal are working out the camera angle, choreographer Gayathri Raghuram and her assistants are planning the next moves, and a few of the crew assistants are cleaning up the stage for the next shot. Amidst this hullabaloo is Kangana Ranaut , seated on a chair, dressed in a rich red-and-green ensemble.Kangana has drowned out all the sound except for the lines of the song, composed by GV Prakash, that she had learnt by heart. It’s a classical song, and is being shot in Tamil and Hindi one after the other. The shot is called for, and Kangana, as J Jayalalithaa, took to the stage. She isn’t hesitant to ask for multiple takes — after all, the idea is to give a perfect shot.And when the team finally took a break to set up the next sequence, we spoke to them about what it takes to make a biopic on one of the most celebrated actresses and politicians...The film is set in different time periods and it allows me to play with lights. The kind of lights I use for the 60s will be different from the ones I’ll use for the 80s. I can get to show the glamour of the film industry and also the rawness of the political scenario. I have also shot some black and white recreations.— Vishal Vittal, cinematographerWe all know Amma was a good classical dancer. Kangana is doing this style for the first time. She first learnt the basics of Bharatanatyam to get the body language right. My parents, who had assisted Thangappan master, have worked with Amma, and now, I’m working on her biopic. So, it’s a special moment for me.— Gayathri Raghuram, choreographerI have worked with artistes of that generation. So, I am aware of the style that was in vogue then. I have taken inspiration from that and also used my creativity.— Pattanam Rasheed, makeup artisteThough I’ve worked with south actresses like Bhanupriya and Gautami in Bollywood, this is my first Tamil film . I’ve worked with Hema Malini also and have done her hair for her dance shows. I’ve got some references for this film, but I create styles out of my imagination. Kangana is an easy artiste to work with.— Maria Sharma, hairdresserTo get the look right, we spent a lot of time watching Jayalalithaa’s footage. There was a great difference between her look as an actress, and when she started her political journey. So, it’s a challenging task.— Neeta Lulla, costume directorWe spent time researching not just the characters in the film, but also the time period. Like, even if someone is using a pen, we’ll have to carefully use the kind of pen that existed in that period.— Ramakrishna Sabbani and Monika Nigotre, art directorsOn the day we were on the Thalaivi set, Kangana had a special visitor — Ashwini Iyer Tiwari, who directed her latest release Panga. “We really didn’t get time to celebrate the response our film was getting. So, Kanagana called me over here,” Ashwini, who was on the set through the evening, told us. When Vijay asked if she wanted to check the monitor, she told him, “No, no, you are the director, and you are doing a great job.”

Title: I have never won anything in my life before this: Shine Shetty
Content: Actor-entrepreneur Shine Shetty has returned home a winner after a 114-day stay in the Bigg Boss Kannada house. Getting through to him, though, turned out to be easier said than done. After nearly four months of living without access to technology, including his mobile phone, Shine tells us he’s forgotten the passwords to his gadgets, so much so that he’s relying on his parents to connect with the outside world. Eating home-made goodies, catching up on sleep and replying to messages on social media are on Shine’s mind at the moment. But all that he has been able to do is meet fans who come to congratulate him and cut cakes with them. And it is amid all this that we caught up with the winner. Excerpts...“Winning this season of the show is truly unbelievable. I never imagined that I would get such response. The one thing everyone talks to me about now is how inspiring my journey has been, beginning with serials, turning to F&B with a food truck when the going got tough and my win now. This is the perfect ending to my story,” he states.For Shine, this trophy is extra special for another reason. “I have never won anything in my life and this is the first (and probably the heaviest) trophy I have got. I’m very grateful for all the love and support that I have got so far,” he adds.So, what was his first thought when he got into the house? “I had told myself one thing, which was to be honest and true to myself and not to lose my temper. It is something that I’ve always lived by in life. On a show like this, where everything about us would be monitored and shown, I felt it would be best to present my true self,” says Shine, adding that adjusting to the environment in the house was hard at first. “I just looked at everyone as a joint family that I would be living with and that it was inevitable for one member to leave every week. It would only be rational to treat each of the members as family. There were times when I did lose my temper, but it was when I felt it was justified. But I did curse myself a lot for that later on. Barring those times, the stay in the house was fun,” Shine adds.One worry that Shine had was about holding his own in a house full of established names. “While I have done serials and some films, I realised I was not as popular as others in the house. While on one hand there were names like Jai Jagadish Kuri Prathap and Harish Raj , all of who have are known names in films, there was Vasuki Vaibhav , who has composed and sung big hit numbers. It was only later on in the show, when the percentage of votes I had received was revealed, that I gained confidence and shed my insecurities,” he admits.His game plan for the tasks on the show, he adds, was to play smart to win. “I’d never done anything like that in my life, but thankfully, none of the others had either. Assessing all my losses in games, I realised that I had to play smart to win. The ‘Kalla-Police’ task was my favourite. I was the inspector, while Vasuki and Harish were the social worker and fighter, respectively; Raju Talikote was my head constable. We all had some great conversations in the makeshift police station that was set up in the house,” he remembers.Shine, who has not had the time to check his social media accounts and respond to the good wishes personally, says that thanking fans will be his priority. “I also want to ensure I pursue my dream of making it in cinema. I’ve already had a few offers from filmmakers now. I will soon sit with them and see which would be the best to commence with soon,” he signs off.

Title: This A capella band aims at breaking barriers with music
Content: No doubt A cappella is a popular genre of music, but when it comes to bands dedicatedly following and practising it in India, the numbers are few. Chord 7 is trying to bridge that gap. Formed in January 2019, the group comprises Anish Bruce, Anish Varghese Tony Daniel , James Paul, Jibu John and Shiju Mathew . Based in three different cities, all the artistes have their regular careers to follow, but their passion for music has helped them keep the band alive. We recently caught up with Bengaluru-based Anish Bruce about their latest music and more. Excerpts from the chat:We wanted to dedicate our first song to the strings that bind us — choir music and being Malayalis. It took us around three days to rehearse and record the track. Back then, A cappella was something we were also trying out for the first time. Again, adjusting the work schedules of six professionals was a challenge. But the hard work and coordination paid off and it brought us where we are today.In the early days of the band, we used to connect with each other and even conduct jamming sessions on online platforms such as WhatsApp and Skype. Technology has played a huge role in our musical journey — be it in terms of recording tunes or working on different A capella versions of a song. The digital mediums have made it easier for us to manage our day jobs and make music.All the members of Chord 7 are hugely inspired by music composer AR Rahman . And we are dedicating our third single — a A capella mashup that comprises his five memorable Hindi tracks — to the legend. We have collaborated with playback singer, Jyotsna, and Rahman’s sound engineer, Hentry Kuruvilla, for the new track. Singer Benny Dayal has launched the new song. We are also hoping to be able to perform this tribute track in front of him some time soon.

Title: Anjana Sukhani: Jaipur is my refresh button
Content: For some hailing from this beautiful city, Jaipur never loses its charm. No matter where they are settled then, these Jaipurites, such as Anjana Sukhani, find reasons to come back to the town and relax. Anjana, who also hails from the Pink City, was recently in town on a brief vacation.Anjana was in town for a brief vacation"My heart is in Jaipur. There is a certain amount of peace here, which we miss in the hectic life of Mumbai. When I am here, I am in no hurry to rush to the gym or to any official meeting. Here, I can just chill and relax. Jaipur is my refresh button," says Anjana. So what was her itinerary like this time around? Anjana tells us, "I met my family members, went out with school friends and visited some new places to check out the all-new look of my city. Generally, I go bonkers when I am in Jaipur and then by the time I return to Mumbai, I have a few extra kilos on. So this time, I held myself back from over-eating.""During my school days, there were very few places in C-Scheme and Raja Park areas to hang around with friends. But now I see a lot of fancy restaurants and hang out places here," she adds.The actress visited some new places tooAnjana began her Bollywood career with the multi-starrer Salaam-e-Ishq in 2007 and was recently seen in Akshay-Kareena-starrer Good Newws, after a sabbatical of almost two years. "Yes, it was a two-year sabbatical. I lost my aunt to cancer. I was depressed as I was deeply attached to her. After a period of emotional turmoil, it's not easy to move on in life and feel happy. But now, that period is over and I am back to the grind," she explains.The actress also saw Shaheed Smarak during her recent visit to the cityTalking about her latest role, Anjana says, "It was a great star cast to work with. I really have no qualms about playing sister to the hero. Also, Indian cinema has evolved so much now. There is so much scope for everyone. There is no point taking a substantial role in a flop film. It's better to do a smaller but an important role in a blockbuster hit."

Title: FIR filed against Joy Mukherjee for allegedly hitting his co-star
Content: Joy Mukherjee, the lead actor of Jiyon Kathi , has allegedly hit co-star Aindrila Sharma on the sets of the TV show. Recalling the incident, the actress told us, “I was giving close-up shots when my mother started calling me. Even though I answered her call only after completing my shot, Joy started yelling abuses at me and also said nasty things about my parents. He created a ruckus on the set.” “When I was stepping out to talk to my mother, he pulled my right arm forcefully and tried to stop me. I got badly hurt but he still continued to use filthy language and kept charging at me,” said the actress. After the incident on Monday, Aindrila filed an FIR at the Regent Park Police Station. Taken aback, Aindrila rushed to the makeup room to compose herself but Joy allegedly kept charging at her. “He was stopped by rest of the unit members but kept charging at me. I immediately informed the police but by the time they arrived, Joy had already left the set. Later, I, along with my unit members, went to the West Bengal Motion Picture Artists Forum to register a complaint. We talked to Forum officials Saptarshi Roy and member of the caretaker committee, Bharat Kaul. Other crew members shared similar instances of misbehaviour by Joy. I believe that Joy too complained against some actress to the Artists Forum” added Aindrila.Meanwhile, Joy, who initially refused to make any comment on the incident, said, “It’s too early to say anything. I heard that Aindrila has lodged a police complaint against me but no one from either Kolkata Police or West Bengal Police has contacted me yet. I will give a clarification to them first and then clear all other doubts by holding a press conference.” This is not the first time Joy has been accused of such harassment. The actor, who is known to be temperamental, was arrested in 2018 for harassing and physically abusing his former girlfriend, actress Sayantika Banerjee The serial Jiyon Kathi has been on air for the past four months and according to the lead actress, Joy keeps abusing someone or the other on the set. “I can’t ever imagine a man raising his hand against a woman. I was shocked to the core. In the four months that Joy and I have been working together for Jiyon Kathi, I have seen him get into tiffs with many members of the serial unit. I hope proper action is taken against him so that no has the audacity to behave in this horrible manner in future,” added Aindrila.West Bengal Motion Picture Artists Forum ex-secretary Saptarshi Roy said such incidents are harmful for the reputation of the film and TV industry. “We always want a peaceful work atmosphere. I am aware of the incident that took place on the sets of Jiyon Kathi and an internal committee will be set up to further probe the matter and come up with a solution,” he said. For now, the production house is planning to replace Joy with some other actor.

Title: 'If there’s any negativity, it’s outside the team'
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Margao: Sergio Lobera may have parted ways with FC Goa but the Spanish coach has left his style and philosophy behind. It was quite evident as the league leaders defeated bottom-placed Hyderabad FC 4-1 at the Nehru Stadium, Fatorda, on Wednesday.

On paper, this should have been an easy game against the bottom-placed side but off field tensions made it the most intense in the campaign. Some fans stayed away, a section chanted Sergio’s name and there was no escaping a Tifo which said 'In Lobera we trust'.

Slow but steadily, though, the mood changed. There were cheers for the players, appreciation for the club and the unmissable ‘Forca Goa’.

It helped that Hugo Boumous scored in the 19th minute. His second goal proved that this team’s focus is certainly on the top spot, even though the attendance was recorded at 10,212, a marginal drop of 2,000 spectators compared to previous games.

“I don’t see any negativity in the team. May be whatever is there, it is outside the team. I could not see any sort of problems or difficulties inside the team. We are all professionals and you could see from the performance,” Goa’s interim coach Clifford Miranda told reporters after the emphatic victory.

Goa had some anxious moments in the initial minutes but slowly settled into their flow. Miranda and technical director Derrick Pereira fielded familiar faces in the starting lineup and the players responded well.

“It is a process, and can we forget what Sergio had done? No. He build this team and we cannot forget his contribution, not me nor the club. He made sure we played how we wanted to play as per our philosophy,” said Miranda.

Hyderabad interim coach Javier Lopez was also impressed with Goa’s performance.

“For me it’s not about the coach but the players always. FC Goa played much better and this is the work of Sergio Lobera over the last three years. There is a new coach and he continues the same job,” said Lopez.

Title: Vartika Singh: I’m obsessed with chai and specially the tandoori chai: Vartika Singh
Content:
Vartika had tandoori chai at the eat street at 1090 Chauraha (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

She also tried her hands at making tandoori momos at an eatery in Gomti Nagar (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Vartika Singh (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

While Vartika Singh , Miss Diva Universe 2019, has spent most of her life in Lucknow, she misses the winter season when she’s living in Mumbai. In town recently, the model-actress revealed, “Just how people gear up for battle, I gear up for winters. I need to constantly have chai, hot water and I so love bonfires too. Something that I really look forward to is dressing up for winters because you get to wear boots, jackets, shawls, coats, etc and it’s great fun. Also, sitting outside in the sun with your family and friends during winters is a very special thing and I find it extremely cute and often miss it back in Mumbai.”Vartika, who was here on a professional commitment, further added, “One of the hardest things in winters, back when I was in college, was when you had to write exams in that cold weather. I remember I used to sit behind my friend on a bike and while she would ride it, I would be busy with my last-minute revisions and stuff. By the time we would reach the examination hall, my hands would be so numb that I used to rub them to warm them up so I could write the paper. I really miss those days.”She also tried her hands at making tandoori momos at an eatery in Gomti Nagar (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)The beauty also spoke about her love for tandoori chai and winter food. She said, “I’m almost obsessed with chai and specially the tandoori chai that I tried at 1090 Chauraha this time in Lucknow. It was so good. I’m rather shocked though that I didn’t quite know about it as yet. Also, I tried the momos at a popular momos place in Gomti Nagar and I think the food was just fabulous. Chikki is another one of my winter favourites.”Vartika, who recently represented India at the Miss Universe contest, couldn’t make it to the top 10. “Representing India at the Miss Universe level is a lifetime opportunity that you get, which you can’t miss. So whether you win or not, you always want to cherish this because you were the one who represented India at Miss Universe 2019 and no one in the world can take that away from you. Also, I’m very happy that I managed to make it to the top 20. I know one thing for sure that I did everything possible from my side, as a person, as an individual, as a candidate and as a representative of India. There are certain things that are destined and if it isn’t, then honestly I know there are better things in store for me and I’m looking forward to them,” she said, adding, “Having said that, I feel disappointment is a very natural thing that comes alongside as you put your heart and soul into it and you’ve been working for it non-stop, throughout to make it happen. However, when they did not announce my name for the next round, it did not really hit me in a bad way. I wasn’t like ‘oh my God! What has happened,’ because I knew one thing that I had given my best and that feeling of security from your end about your performance is very important. Therefore, I do not have any regrets nor any kind of disappointment about the results.”Vartika Singh (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)The stunning beauty also confessed that although modelling didn’t seem like a very convincing career to her parents initially, they were with her at every step of the way rooting and cheering for her. “Many people were rooting for me and just like myself they also thought that I’m going to win but it didn’t really happen. My dad would pray longer and slightly more. My mother told me how he (my dad) was awake early in the morning to watch the pageant. It meant a great deal for me considering my parents never imagined me to be in this profession and today they are really supportive and standing beside me at every step. It’s quite amazing and that’s what I discovered through this. It couldn’t have been any better,” said the diva.— Yashi Agarwal

Title: I try to maintain a balance between singing and school: Sugandha Date
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Sugandha Date (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Singing reality show winner Sugandha Date, on her first visit to Lucknow, tried the famous basket chaat along with the kulfi. “I absolutely love this city. The hospitality here is second to none. In the evening I have plans of shopping, specially since the chikan kurtas are famous here, I really want to check them out,” said the young singer.

The Nagpur-girl spoke about her musical journey and said, “It has not been a very easy journey, we all faced many ups and downs. My guiding light throughout my musical journey has been my guru Anand Sharma sir. Its been almost six years since I have been learning classical music from my guruji. Had it not been for him and my ever so supporting family, I don’t think I would’ve won the coveted trophy.” The Lil’ Champs winner also revealed that her mother completed her MA in music but doesn’t sing anymore. “Mummy ka gaana peechhe chhoot gaya meri wajah se. She unfortunately doesn’t practice it anymore. In fact, my entire family shifted from Nagpur to Mumbai so I could pursue my singing career. I lack the words to define the amount of love and respect I have for my family.”

There are many reality shows these days centred around kids. Speaking about the trend, Sugandha said, “I can’t say for all, but as for me, I have enjoyed my musical journey at every step. The only pressure I felt was the pressure to work harder and get better, which I would say is the case in life also. One needs to constantly work on oneself, keep enhancing their skills and get better with every passing day. It’s about how well a kid manages his or her time and studies. I try to maintain a balance between singing which I’m very passionate about and school. Luckily for me, my school was very supportive too, so that really helped.”

— Yashi Agarwal

Title: Sara Ali Khan: I will hopefully work with my father sometime soon
Content: After impressing the audience with his stellar performance in 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' as Udaybhan Singh Rathore, Saif Ali Khan is all set to step into the shoes of another negative character. The talented actor will be going face-to-face with Prabhas in Om Raut's upcoming film 'Adipurush'.Saif, who started his career with 'Parampara' in 1993 has gone on to deliver several blockbusters on the silver screen. The versatile actor, who is known for taking up challenging and entertaining roles, has always managed to do justice to his characters. While the news of Saif stepping in as Lankesh in Adipurush' has got fans excited, we take a look at the dark and negative characters which the skilled actor has essayed on the silver screen.

Title: Vishal Aditya Singh: Uss ghar mein aisa koi hai hi nahi, jisne rishton ka tamasha na banaya ho
Content: More than his game, Vishal Aditya Singh was in news for his volatile relationship with his ex, Madhurima Tuli , on ' Bigg Boss '. While Madhurima was asked to leave the show a few weeks ago after she got violent with him inside the house, Vishal was evicted three days back. In a chat with BT, he spoke about his stint in the house and his messy equation with his former girlfriend. Excerpts...Not at all. I retaliated only when she treated me badly, insulted me or abused me. Given our past, I wasn’t ready to meet her again on the show because I knew that if Madhurima entered the house, we would have fights. She would get aggressive, hit me and, like always, I would take it quietly, which is exactly what happened. I regret the fact that I didn’t mention that she should not be a part of the show in my contract. I believe that before entering the house she said that she had moved on, which she says all the time, while I have always maintained that I have a soft corner for her and I am in love with her. Par ab kuchh nahi hai. I won’t call our relationship a mistake, but we were two incompatible people trying to be together. We were wrong for each other. Having said that, uss ghar mein aisa koi hai hi nahi, jisne rishton ka tamasha na banaya ho, be it Rashami-Sidharth, Sana-Sidharth or Paras-Mahira.If that was true, she would have said it earlier. I have never done that. Maine life mein kabhi bhi unke upar haath nahi uthaya hai. Our relationship ended because she was abusive and violent. If you look at her Bigg Boss journey, she has been aggressive and irritated towards everyone, especially when it came to work. There were many instances when I helped her, and she fought with me over it. Everyone has seen her true nature on TV, so what more can I say about it?My feelings for her were as genuine as my fights with her. I did not do anything for the game. I requested her several times to not indulge in useless fights, as we and our relationship would end up becoming a joke. I had even told her that my game was suffering because of our fights.Mahira (Sharma). She gets involved in Paras (Chhabra), Sidharth (Shukla) and Shefali’s (Jariwala) fights without any reason. Woh unnecessarily mudda banati hain.

Content: Meanwhile, BT also got in touch with Madhurima, and here’s what she had to say about Vishal’s eviction. Talking about her equation with Vishal and if they could ever reconcile their differences in the future and she replied, “I have nothing to say about that. I’m done with Vishal, the relationship is over from my side. I was real with him in the house and I wanted to be with him, but it looked like he wanted only one of us to stay there. He kept provoking me to ensure that I was out of the show, and I eventually did something that got me out. I have never done something like that with anyone. That shows that he is not meant for me. I don’t want to be with a person, who cannot see me happy and do well in life.”

Title: Ayodhya Ram Mandir: Govt forms trust in major step towards building Ram temple
Content:
Representational image

यह ट्रस्ट मंदिर से सम्बंधित हर निर्णय लेने के लिए पूर्ण रूप से स्वतंत्र होगा और 67 एकड़ भूमि ट्रस्ट को हस्तांतरित… https://t.co/KBjKpljuzV — Amit Shah (@AmitShah) 1580884443000

NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Wednesday announced the formation of a trust for the construction of a Ram temple in Ayodhya, following the Cabinet clearing a detailed scheme for the shrine and its surrounding complex. The announcement came just four days before the threemonth deadline set by the Supreme Court was to end.“The government has, as per the directions of the SC, paved the way for the construction of a grand Ram temple at the Ramjanmabhoomi site. The issue pertains to sensitivities and faith of crores of people in the country and it is my good fortune that I am making this announcement,” the PM told the Lok Sabha amid thumping of desks in BJP benches with home minister Amit Shah leading the way. BJP members also raised “Jai Shri Ram” slogans. The decision, coming days before polling in Delhi, lent itself to political interpretations, but the opposition steered clear of such allegations, perhaps keeping in mind the emotive nature of the issue.In fact, Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said, “Some people are asking about the timing. There is no right time for good work.” The PM said the government has transferred to the trust 67.7 acres of land for what he called a “grand and divine” Ram temple.The formation of the trust marks another important step towards the implementation of the Sangh Parivar’s agenda and BJP’s poll pledge for the construction of Ram Mandir . Modi said the SC verdict had been met with great maturity and that Indian culture and tradition are based on the philosophy of “Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam” and “Sarve Bhavantu Sukhinah”.In a message of unity, he said all faiths in India — whether Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs, Christians, Buddhists, Parsis or Jains — are members of one large family. “My government is moving ahead with the mantra of ‘Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas and Sabka Vishwas’ so that every member of this family develops, remains happy and healthy, becomes prosperous and the country progresses.” Political circles noted that the announcement had been made by the PM, who in the case of two earlier eventful decisions of his second tenure — voiding of Article 370 and bifurcation of J&K, and the passage of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act — had opted to take the back seat, letting his trusted colleague and home minister to pilot the two initiatives.Shah took to Twitter to congratulate the PM emphasising the provision to ensure that at least one member of the 15strong temple trust will be a Dalit. The trust will be called “Shri Ram JanmabhoomiTeerth Kshetra” and the PM said it will have full autonomy to construct a “magnificent and divine Shri Ram temple at the birthplace of Bhagwan Shri Ram in Ayodhya and take decisions on matters connected with it”.In Video: #RamMandir: Narendra Modi announces formation of Sri Ram Janmabhoomi Teerth Kshetra

Title: Nirbhaya: Avail of all options in one week: Delhi HC to Nirbhaya convicts
Content: NEW DELHI: Putting a lid on delaying tactics by the Nirbhaya death row convicts, Delhi high court on Wednesday gave them seven days to avail their remaining legal remedies while asserting that all four must hang together.The court dismissed the Centre’s plea to allow separate hanging of the four convicts, observing that no matter what stage of the case, all procedures “must be fair, just and reasonable”. Meanwhile, President Ram Nath Kovind had rejected the mercy petition of one of the convicts, Akshay Kumar Singh, who had filed the plea last week. The HC order means that Pawan Gupta, the only Nirbhaya convict who hasn’t filed a curative petition in the Supreme Court or a mercy plea with the President, now has a week’s time to exercise these options. The four can be hanged only after 14 days from the rejection of the last mercy plea.While ruling that the four must hang together, Justice Suresh Kait agreed with the central government’s argument that Delhi prison rules allow separate hanging of a convict once his mercy plea stands rejected. But the court stressed that the fundamental rights guaranteed under Article 21 of the Constitution were “as much relevant at the stage of execution of the death sentence as they are in the interregnum between the imposition of that sentence and its execution”. The court said all the four convicts have to be executed together since they were handed down the death penalty by a common judgment. “It is not in dispute that the trial court convicted all the accused by common judgment and was confirmed by this court vide common judgment and the Supreme Court thereafter confirmed it vide common judgment. Thus, from trial court up to the Supreme Court, all the convicts/accused were dealt by common order and judgment,” high court observed, noting that “I am of the considered opinion that death warrants of all the convicts be executed together and not separately”.Justice Kait noted that, by their conduct, the convicts had “frustrated the process by using delaying tactics” but then added that “so long as life lasts, so long shall it be the duty and endeavour of the court to give to the provisions of our Constitution a meaning which will prevent human suffering and degradation”.The high court also faulted the authorities concerned for not taking steps to issue death warrants after rejection of appeals of the convicts by the Supreme Court in 2017 and noted that the men have been found guilty of “a horrible, dreadful, cruel, abominable, ghastly, gruesome and heinous offence of rape coupled with a bone-chilling murder of a young woman, which shook the conscience of the entire country”. The Centre and the Delhi government had challenged the trial court’s January 31 order staying “till further orders” the execution of all the four convicts in the case — Mukesh Singh (32), Pawan Gupta (25), Vinay Sharma (26) and Akshay Thakur (31) — who are lodged in Tihar Jail.In Video: Nirbhaya case: All convicts will be hanged together, says Delhi HC

Title: Better schools, not CAA, will build 21st-century India: Arvind Kejriwal
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

File photo

NEW DELHI: Pitching for his development agenda for the city – even as BJP tries to corner him on the anti-CAA protests at Shaheen Bagh – chief minister Arvind Kejriwal told TOI in an exclusive interview on Wednesday that “21st-century India will not be built by CAA and NRC but by having better schools, colleges and hospitals”.

He accused Union home minister Amit Shah of letting the Shaheen Bagh blockade of a critical road fester for one-and-a-half months only for electoral gains. “He is India’s home minister and the most powerful man in the country. Nobody is going to believe that Amit Shah cannot get a road opened,” he said. The CM said BJP had no explanation for its non-performance in corporations and had failed to counter the work done by his government despite many attempts. So, finally, it had to attempt a Hindu-Muslim polarisation.

Read: Arvind Kejriwal's full interview

Kejriwal said he stayed away from Shaheen Bagh, Jamia and JNU because these are law-and-order issues and he had a different responsibility. It was up to Amit Shah to tackle it. But he blamed the Centre for the situation in universities, saying party politics should be kept away from university campuses.

Such politics was making parents insecure about their children, he said. Claiming that he had cordial relations with lieutenant governor Anil Baijal, Kejriwal said earlier he had been pushed into a confrontation with the Centre against his wishes. When the newly elected Delhi government felt it was unable to do anything, it made them restless. But the SC judgment clarifying the separation of powers restored peace.

Asked about Nirbhaya’s parents blaming him for the delay in hanging of the convicts, Kejriwal said they were simple folk and were being misled. He said the AAP government had no role to play in the entire process since the police were not under the city government.

Title: Throw squatters out on roads in two weeks, says HC
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Cracking the whip on the Centre for permitting 576 government accommodation units to be illegally occupied by retired officials and ex-MPs, the Delhi high court on Wednesday gave it two weeks to start eviction proceedings.

A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar said the government must recover all pending dues from such occupants and rapped it for not initiating recovery proceedings against them, some of whom have overstayed for over a decade and racked up dues of over Rs 95 lakh. “If someone is overstaying in government accommodation, you do not need a five year plan to vacate them? Nearly 600 government accommodations were not vacated. Why have (you) not vacated them? Why no notice for recovery issued to them?” the bench demanded from the UD and housing ministry.

“If no stay (from a court or tribunal against their eviction), put their belongings, bag and baggage on the road within two weeks if they do not vacate on their own,” the court remarked, stressing that people are paying taxes “and you are giving free housing, electricity and water to them (illegal occupants) for years. In some cases, original allottee has died and their legal heirs are in occupation of the residence. This is nothing but your (ministry’s) inefficiency. This casual and lethargic approach indicates con nivance by your officials and connivance for such a long period amounts to conspiracy under the Indian Penal Code ,” the bench said slapping a cost on the ministry for being unable to inform it what steps have been taken to evict and recover dues.

HC’s directions came after going through an affidavit filed by the ministry indicating that 11 government residences were illegally occupied by ex-MPs, who had together run up dues of around Rs 35 lakh, while 565 units remain under occupation by retired babus. Referring to the huge amount of unrecovered dues, the bench said, “Prima facie the impression is you (ministry/officials) are making money from this. Someone is happy with this.”

Title: Bodh Gaya shrine: Government agencies conduct security audit
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Mahabodhi temple in Bodhgaya. (ANI photo)

GAYA: A security audit of Mahabodhi Temple conducted by government agencies has identified vulnerable points and recommended a more robust security mechanism to ensure the shrine’s security. Following the audit, the govt has recommended a slew of measures to tighten the shrine security.

The Bodh Gaya shrine , it may be recalled has twice been attacked by two different terrorist organisations. The first attack was engineered by a Ranchi based sleeping module of Indian Mujahedeen in July’2013. A couple of monks were injured in the low-intensity blasts. Again, in January’2018, Jamiatul Mujahedeen of Bangladesh was involved in planting explosives in the shrine vicinity.

According to highly reliable sources privy to the govt advisory, 17 different aspects of the shrine security have been dealt with, the most important being the effective handling of door frame metal detectors and scanning of all items being taken inside the shrine including cameras.

The advisory said that for a more effective checking mechanism, the BMP personnel engaged in shrine security should get training from the CISF. It may be recalled is the specialised force to provide security to vital installations including airports.

Following the request by the then governor RS Gavai and CM Nitish Kumar after the July’2013 attack, the then Union home minister Sushil Kumar Shinde agreed to provide CISF cover to the shrine. But as the state govt wanted the centre to bear the cost of CISF cover and the Union Home ministry insisted on payment based CISF cover, the shrine security was ultimately handed over to the Bihar Military Police.

While evading the issue of advisory on shrine security, DM Abhishek Singh, the Gaya DM cum chairman of the Bodh Gaya Temple Management committee said that the shrine security was a dynamic process and need-based improvements are periodically made to strengthen the security mechanism. Asked what measures are being taken to make the security more effective, the DM said that an additional watchtower would be constructed in the nearby JP Botanical garden.

More lights are being installed to improve all-round visibility during the dark hours, the shrine outer walls have been made impregnable and entry and exit points have been separated.

Asked about reports that special passes for carrying items like mobile phones and cameras and vehicle passes to move in the no vehicle zone are being liberally issued without proper verification of the antecedents of the special pass recipients, the DM said that some relaxation has to be made during occasions like special prayer sessions but the BTMC Secretary exercises due caution in the issuance of special passes. The DM also said that police verification of shop keepers and those living in the shrine vicinity is periodically done.

Being a living temple attracting visitors from across the globe, the shrine can not be converted into a police camp, said Singh.

Title: Mahathir Mohamed: Is Pakistan-Malaysia joint statement a sign of Mahathir climbdown?
Content:
Reuters photo

NEW DELHI: Even as Malaysian prime minister, Mahathir Mohamed , refrained from mentioning the Kashmir issue in a joint press statement with Pakistan PM Imran Khan , the MEA told parliament on Wednesday that on both Kashmir and CAA , India “expects these countries to not comment on the internal affairs of India; respect India’s sovereignty and territorial integrity; and develop a proper understanding of the issue.”A joint statement issued by Malaysia and Pakistan at the end of Khan’s visit merely recorded that Imran Khan had raised the issue of Kashmir during his talks with Mahathir. The statement did not specify that both sides had agreed on Kashmir. The statement said, “The Prime Minister of Pakistan briefed the Prime Minister of Malaysia on the illegal and unilateral actions of the Indian Government of 5 August 2019…”It could be a sign that Mahathir may be climbing down from his earlier strident position on Kashmir and CAA. After India hit out at Malaysia with a virtual ban on palm oil imports from that country, Mahathir surprisingly said he would not retaliate. In the past weeks, Malaysia has raised its sugar imports from India as a sweetener.Meanwhile, the MEA in a written reply to Parliament Questions in Lok Sabha said, the government had briefed members of the international community “on the facts relating to Jammu & Kashmir and also shared perspectives on the Citizenship Amendment Act, 2019”.Trouble with Malaysia had started when Mahathir told the UN general assembly in September last year that India had “invaded and occupied” Kashmir. Despite some strongly worded pushback from India, Mahathir had refused to back down. This led to India putting curbs on imports of palm oil from Malaysia. Imran Khan promised to buy more palm oil from Malaysia to offset the gap created by India. However, according to official figures, India imported 4.4 million tonnes from Malaysia in 2019, while Pakistan had taken just over 1 million tonnes.Interestingly, Khan’s visit to Kuala Lumpur also saw Malaysia agreeing to maintain the “centrality” of the OIC as the premier global Islamic countries’ organisation. Malaysia, along with Turkey, Iran and Pakistan were trying to build an alternative Islamic countries grouping, which was scotched by Saudi Arabia when they persuaded Pakistan to stay away.Meanwhile, the MEA told Parliament countries have “shown understanding … that matters related to Jammu & Kashmir, which is an integral part of India, are internal to India; and that Pakistan sponsored cross-border terrorism has been posing a grave threat and affecting the lives of the people of India, including in Jammu & Kashmir.” In the face of criticism by global media and civil society, the government said the Indian position on the CAA is that it is “an affirmative action meant to address the long standing predicament of the vulnerable sections living in India; and that it does not impact in any manner on the status of any citizen of India or deprive any Indian of any faith of her or his citizenship.”The UN Human Rights Commissioner had on December 13 criticised the CAA, which the government described as “inaccurate and unwarranted”. “Government immediately registered its protest with the office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights and clearly conveyed that the legislation is a humanitarian measure and is in line with India’s international human rights obligations.”

Title: Income Tax Return: You may get pre-filled I-T form with capital gains data
Content:
(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: The government is looking to introduce pre-filled forms with your capital gains data on mutual fund and share sales in time for you to file the income tax returns by the end of July. While the government has introduced amendments to the Income Tax Act through the Finance Bill, which will empower it to seek data on the annual financial statement, sources said work has already begun on implementing the changes in the next few months itself.“We have held discussions with brokerages and other participants and suggested that the data should be made available to us so that taxpayers can get them in their pre-filled return forms,” a senior official in the tax department told TOI.Regulators such as the Securities & Exchange Board of India (Sebi) have also been consulted to include dividend income within the ambit. In any case, the proposed amendment for tax deducted at source (TDS) on dividend income beyond Rs 5,000 will be captured in the 26AS form and will help in pre-filling the returns forms.On August 19 last year, TOI was the first to report about the move to expand the pre-filled forms to include details other than interest accruing to the bank account that is mentioned in the returns to get a tax refund. The idea is to expand the scope to cover all bank accounts, which can easily be done using Aadhaar and permanent account number (PAN).Last year, the government had introduced pre-filled forms, which had faced some glitches initially. But the tax department believes that they have been more or less resolved, paving the way to expand the scope.Officials said that the idea is to simplify things for an average taxpayer, which reduces the need for visiting a chartered accountant and makes the process seamless. The government proposing for a new tax regime, allowing people to give up exemptions in return for lower tax rates, is aimed at easing the burden further.

Title: UP govt allots 5 acres for mosque in Ayodhya, 25km from temple site & near Lucknow highway
Content: LUCKNOW: Hours after Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the formation of a 15-member trust to oversee the construction of a Ram temple in Ayodhya , the UP cabinet on Wednesday cleared a proposal to give the UP Sunni Central Waqf Board a five-acre plot located 25km from the Ram Janmabhoomi site to build a mosque.“As advised by the Supreme Court in its verdict on November 9, 2019, five acres of land have been allotted for the mosque at a place 18km from Faizabad district HQ,” government spokesperson Shrikant Sharma said. “Located at Dhannipur village in Ayodhya’s Sohawal tehsil, the plot is barely 200m from the Lucknow-Gorakhpur highway, which will ensure easy access to a mosque. The proposal has received the cabinet’s nod.”Faizabad district was officially renamed Ayodhya on November 13, 2018, although many people continue to refer to it by its old name. The adjoining city of Faizabad officially retains its original name.UP government spokesperson Shrikant Sharma said three options had been presented to the state cabinet by district authorities. “The government forwarded a shortlist of plots near highways passing through Ayodhya to the Centre, which picked the one at Dhannipur village on Lucknow-Gorakhpur highway.”According to the official, the proximity of the plot to a highway and a police station (Raunahi) swung the decision in its favour. “Proximity to the highway means pilgrims can reach the mosque easily. A police station in the vicinity makes it an even better choice since maintaining communal harmony and law and order is also a priority,” he said.Sources in the government said the Hindu litigants demanded that land for the mosque be allotted outside the “panchkosi parikarma”, the traditional 15km route that devotees take to pay obeisance to Lord Ram in Ayodhya. “Dhannipur made the cut in this respect, too. It is 18km from the Faizabad district headquarters and 25km away from the temple site,” an official said.In Video: #RamMandir: Narendra Modi announces formation of Sri Ram Janmabhoomi Teerth Kshetra

Title: Well, well! Liquor flows from kitchen taps in Kerala town
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

THRISSUR: Wishing wells may exist only in folklore, but one in Kerala almost proved a tippler’s wildest fantasy come true. It all started when residents of Solomon ’s Avenue apartment complex in Chalakudy town of Thrissur district noticed brownish water with an unmistakable smell gushing out of their kitchen taps a couple of days ago. Turns out the sober, dependable neighbourhood well had overnight turned into a watering hole — literally — and started serving up a cocktail of beer, brandy and rum through kitchen taps.

The mystery was solved after some residents approached the municipality authorities, who traced the “hiccup” to an excise department operation in the area a few days earlier. The excise team had apparently dumped more than 4,500 litres of seized liquor into a pit, unaware that most of it would flow into a nearby well that is the main source of potable water for Solomon’s Avenue residents. Joshy Maliyekkal, who was among the first to spot brownish water coming out of taps, said he initially suspected a rusting pipe had something to do with it.

“I had barely switched on my water pump to fill the overhead tank on Sunday afternoon when the sight of the water got me really scared. And the smell was unmistakable and the taste confirmed that someone mixed copious amounts of alcohol with the water,” Maliyekkal said. When all 18 families living in the complex had the same experience as Joshy, they decided to contact the Chalakudy municipality Ward councillor VJ Joji told TOI on Wednesday that alternative water-supply arrangements had been made for the affected families. “These families had been using water from the contaminated well for several years. It was their only water source,” he said.

Deputy excise commissioner TK Sanu said the well had been “cleaned” at least eight times already to remove all traces of liquor in the water. “Till the water becomes completely clean, we will provide drinking water to the affected families.”

According to Sanu, the excise department had decided to “destroy” the seized liquor because storing the bottles had become a challenge. “These bottles had been seized from bars whose licenses had been cancelled six years ago. We couldn't have known that our operation would raise such a stink,” he said.

Title: House panel lets any ‘willing woman’ to be surrogate mom
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A parliamentary select committee on Wednesday recommended key changes to the Surrogacy (Regulation) Bill, 2019, including allowing a “willing woman” and not just “close relative” to become a surrogate mother, omission of fiveyear wait period before opting for surrogacy, and allowing single women – either divorcee or widow – in the 35- to 45-year age group and persons of Indian origin (PIOs) to avail of surrogacy.

The panel also recommended increasing the insurance cover for surrogate mothers from 16 months to 36 months. While endorsing the ban on commercial surrogacy, the panel, led by BJP MP Bhupender Yadav, suggested keeping an option for compensating the surrogate mother beyond medical expenses and insurance coverage.

The House committee, led by BJP MP Bhupender Yadav, suggested keeping an option for compensating the surrogate mother beyond medical expenses and insurance coverage that includes taking care of her nutritional food requirements, maternity wear, etc. that is vital for the well-being and upkeep of the surrogate mother.

The Rajya Sabha select committee that examined the bill argued that restricting the surrogate mother to a “close relative” potentially affects the availability of surrogate mothers. “A willing woman shall act as a surrogate mother and be permitted to undergo surrogacy procedures as per the pro visions of this Act,” the committee said in its report submitted onWednesday.

Regarding the requirement of five years as the period of inability to conceive before opting for surrogacy, the committee said that there may be certain proven medical conditions like absence of uterus by birth, non-functional uterus, removal of uterus due to cancer, fibroids etc or patients with chronic medical condition where normal pregnancy is ruled out and it is medically proven beyond any doubt that surrogacy is the only option.

The panel further observed that the requirement of obtaining certificate of proven infertility is not at all justified in such cases.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: Rejected by hotels, China tourist lands in Kerala hospital
Content:
Representative image.

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: A Chinese youth, who is on a trip to India, was quarantined at the General Hospital in Thiruvananthapuram following the intervention of police. The 27-year-old from Sichuan province, around 1,300km from Wuhan, the epicentre of coronavirus outbreak, had arrived in Kerala on Tuesday afternoon.He was admitted to the isolation ward of the hospital after he approached the city police commissioner’s office seeking help after hotels refused him entry as he could not furnish any health documents clearing him. According to sources in the commissioner’s office, the youth had set off from his country for a solo trip in the last week of December, before the novel coronavirus outbreak was reported. Sri Lanka was his first destination. From there, he reached Delhi on January 22. After spending a few days there, he reached Bengaluru and from there he arrived in the city by flight on Tuesday afternoon.“I was not in the office when he turned up. However, the officers acted responsibly, alerting hospital authorities to quickly shift him to the isolation ward for observation,’’ said city commissioner Balram Kumar Upadhyay.Police said as per his visa, he is eligible to stay in India till April. They are in the dark about how a foreigner, that too a Chinese national, could exit the airport despite health desks functioning there to screen passengers.

Title: Joblessness rate is 6.1%, says mantri
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NEW DELHI: As members raised concern over unemployment rates and cited previous labour force surveys to drive home their point, minister for labour and employment Santosh Gangwar informed Parliament on Wednesday said that an attempt is being made to improve the data collection by adding various parameters and provide more authentic data.

The minister said it will take time for collection of data as households have to be visited on the ground for authentic data collection in rural areas also. “As per the Periodic Labour Force Survey , the labour force participation is 36.9% and the rate of unemployment for 201718 is 6.1%,” he said.

Replying to supplementaries during the Question Hour , the minister said the report of this survey is very different than the surveys conducted in previous years.

Title: Staff crunch hits IP panel, cases pile up
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NEW DELHI: There is a logjam in adjudication of thousands of pending appeals against grant or rejection of patents, copyrights, trademarks and orders on plant varieties protection as the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) lacks adequate number of judicial and technical members to decide them.

Chairman of IPAB, Justice (retired) Manmohan Singh, has been functioning on extension as directed by the SC on December 18. Appearing for petitioner NGO ‘Protection of Intellectual Property (India Group)’, senior advocate Arvind Datar told a bench of Chief Justice S A Bobde and Justices B R Gavai and Surya Kant that no patent appeal has been taken up by IPAB since May 2016, which is a serious situation.

The CJI-led bench, which on December 18 had said “appointment process of the new chairman of the said Board according to law is likely to be complete soon”, conceded on Wednesday that attempts to persuade a retired judge to take up the assignment as IPAB chairman have not borne fruit as no one wants to go to Chennai, where the Board has its headquarters.

“This (selection of IPAB chairman) is something which I have to do. problem is relating to finding a retired judge who is willing to shift to Chennai,” CJI Bobde said. He had on December 18 asked attorney general K K Venugopal to obtain “instructions from the government about relocation of the Principal Bench of Madras or location of a new Bench to a central place in the country such as Nagpur, Jabalpur, Bhopal”.

On Wednesday, the CJI again pushed afresh for relocation of the principal IPAB bench to Nagpur, his home town. “Nagpur is central to India. It is equi-distant from Kashmir and Kanyakumari . It is also well connected,” he said. When AG said the government is ready to consider setting up a IPAB bench at Nagpur, the CJI said, “Nagpur itself will not have sufficient litigation for the IPAB bench as the industrial areas of Maharashtra were in Mumbai, Pune, Thane and Nashik. Unless the principal bench is shifted to Nagpur, the purpose would not be served.”

But the AG said Tamil Nadu should have some central institutions. The CJI said, “Chennai does not seem to be a right place for its head-quarters. It is unprecedented. No one wants to go there because of its location.” He asked AG and other counsel to suggest names of suitable candidates for the post of IPAB chairman without informing the candidates to facilitate making a proper choice.

Title: Air India almost stopped the wrong Kunal Kamra from flying
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

File photo

NEW DELHI: High school reunions are magical and this one has made “Kunal Kamra” board an Air India flight followed by another one on IndiGo in the last three days. Before you think these airlines have lifted their controversial ban on the standup comedian, the person who flew — with some difficulty to be sure — is his NRI namesake who is in India to attend his reunion.

“I was booked on Air India’s Jaipur-Mumbai flight this Monday. At the airport check-in counter, I was told my PNR had been cancelled as I was on their blacklist,” Boston-based Kamra told TOI. Once he convinced AI that he is not the Kunal Kamra banned by them, the airline issued him a boarding card for Mumbai on AI 612.

AI spokesman Dhananjay Kumar said: “(Standup comedian) Kunal Kamra is barred from flying Air India. That is mentioned in our system. Due to this, (NRI) Kunal Kamra’s name was automatically rejected (for issuance of boarding card). After we verified credentials of this passenger (to ensure he is not the comedian Kamra), we allowed him board to board the flight.”

Having learnt his lesson, “Kamra” went to IndiGo counter at Jaipur airport itself as he had booked Wednesday’s 6E 174 from Mumbai to Delhi. “I told them that the same thing should not happen in Mumbai with me as I am not that Kunal Kamra,” he told TOI after flying into Delhi on the IndiGo flight.

In fact when standup comedian Kamra confronted TV anchor Arnab Goswami on IndiGo’s Mumbai-Lucknow flight last Tuesday and then got banned from flying by IndiGo, AI, SpiceJet and GoAir, this NRI namesake was preparing for the upcoming India trip. “My friends told me to be careful as I could be mistaken for the other Kunal Kamra since I had booked flights on these airlines. But I felt airlines would know how to differentiate between two people with same name,” Kamra, an insurance professional in Boston , said.

Assured of that, NRI Kamra landed in Delhi last Friday (Jan 31) and same day left for Ranthambore by train to attend his high school 20-year reunion. From there he went by road to Jaipur. The first flight on the India trip was from Jaipur to Mumbai on Monday when he realised what it is to be Kunal Kamra booked on an airlines that have banned the comedian.

Indian carriers had got a lot of practice of spotting blacklisted names trying to book tickets when in summer of 2017 when an MP was blacklisted by all Indian carriers after he threatened to beat up an AI staffer onboard an aircraft. The politician tried to book tickets under different names on various airlines but they all managed to spot him and cancel the tickets till the ban was lifted following an order from the aviation ministry.

Asked how he felt about this episode, the NRI Kamra said: “I feel really bad for the comedian for what he has to go through to go from place to place. For me it was a minor inconvenience that got sorted out. I hope my story is a warning for other people that they may have to go through the same experience.”

Comedian Kamra has legally challenged IndiGo’s controversial decision.

Title: Private players to run 500 trains, 750 stations by 2025
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NEW DELHI: In its bid to open up the railways for private investment, the railway ministry has prepared an ambitious plan to allow private players to run 500 passenger trains, manage 750 stations and even buy rolling stock from private players.

This has been included in the National Infrastructure Pipeline, which has been prepared for the next five years. So far the railway ministry has stated publicly that the government is keen to allow private players to run 150 trains on 100 identified routes.

The ministry on Wednesday said the draft request for qualification and the draft concession agreement have been uploaded on the websites of Niti Aayog and Indian Railways for seeking feedback from the stakeholders. Ministry of railways has planned for redevelopment of railway stations through Indian Railway Stations Development Corporation Limited ( IRSDC ), Rail Land Development Authority (RLDA) and other central government agencies, through simplified procedures and for longer lease tenure.

Accordingly, IRSDC and RLDA are undertaking the socio-economic feasibility studies of stations. Based on the outcome of the feasibility studies, the stations are planned to be taken up for redevelopment, in phases. The facilities proposed in a redeveloped station include congestion free non-conflicting entry/exit to the station premises, segregation of arrival/departure of passengers, adequate concourse without overcrowding, among others.

Title: SC gives Rs 1cr to accident victim
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NEW DELHI: A decade after a 12-year-old girl met with an accident which led to 100 per cent physical disability and left her with the mental age of a nine-month-old for the rest of her life due to brain injuries, the Supreme Court on Wednesday came to her rescue awarding compensation of more than Rs one crore including interest.

Kajal, a bright young girl, was travelling on a tractor with her parents on October 18, 2007 when it was hit by a truck. She suffered serious injuries resulting in damage to her brain and was left with a very low IQ besides severe weakness in all her limbs. As per the medical report, her mental age will remain that of a 9-month old child throughout her life. This means while lying on the bed, she will grow with physical and biological attributes of an adult woman, including menstruation etc, but remain a 9- month old child in her mind.

Noting that the pain and suffering which Kajal , who has turned 24, has to go through the rest of her life, a bench of Justices L Nageswara Rao and Deepak Gupta said this is a case where departure has to made from the normal rules to do justice and assuage her suffering. The court awarded a compensation of Rs 62.27 lakh to her along with interest at the rate of 7.5 percent per annum on that amount since 2007.

“This child will remain bed-ridden for life. Her mental age will be that of a nine-month old child. Effectively, while her body grows, she will remain a small baby. We are dealing with a girl who will physically become a woman but will mentally remain a 9-month old child. This girl will miss out playing with her friends. She cannot communicate; she cannot enjoy the pleasures of life; she cannot even be amused by watching cartoons or films; she will miss out on the fun of childhood, the excitement of youth; pleasures of a marital life; she cannot have children who she can love let alone grandchildren.
