She will have no pleasure. Hers is a vegetable existence,” the court said.

The court passed the order on an appeal filed by Kajal’s father who approached the SC through advocate Dhruv Gautam challenging the Punjab and Haryan HC order for granting compensation of Rs 25.78 lakh. The bench agreed with his submission and enhanced the compensation by almost four times.

The court granted compensation on different counts of which Rs 21.6 lakh was given for attendant charges as she will be need two attendants for the rest of his life . “We must remember that this little girl is severely suffering from incontinence meaning that she does not have control over her bodily functions like passing urine and faeces. As she grows older, she will not be able to handle her periods. She requires an attendant virtually 24 hours a day. She requires an attendant who though may not be medically trained but must be capable of handling a child who is bed- ridden. She would require an attendant who would ensure that she does not suffer from bed sores,” it said.

“It is impossible to equate human suffering and personal deprivation with money. However, this is what the Act enjoins upon the courts to do. The court has to make a judicious attempt to award damages, so as to compensate the claimant for the loss suffered by the victim. On the one hand, the compensation should not be assessed very conservatively, but on the other hand, compensation should also not be assessed in so liberal a fashion so as to make it a bounty to the claimant. The court while assessing the compensation should have regard to the degree of deprivation and the loss caused by such deprivation, ” it said.

Title: Ram Mandir trust to have 15 members, including one Dalit
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The Shri Ram Janmbhoomi Teerth Kshetra Trust will have 15 members, one of whom will be from the Dalit community, Home minister Amit Shah said on Wednesday, soon after Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the cabinet decision to set up the Trust in Lok Sabha.

The Trust’s registered office will be at R-20 in Delhi’s Greater Kailash Part-I, also the residence-cum-office of K Parasaran, former Attorney General and senior advocate who had argued on behalf of the deity Ram Lalla Virajman in the Supreme Court. The 93-year old Parasaran will also be one of the trustees in Shri Ram Teerth Kshetra.

The trustees include Jagatguru Shankaracharya Jyothishpeethadheeshwar Swami Vasudevanand Saraswati, Prayagraj; Jagatguru Madhavacharya Swami Vishwa Prasannatheertha, Pejawar math, Udupi; Yugpurush Paramanand Maharaj, Haridwar; Swami Govinddev Giri Maharaj, Pune; Vimlendra Mohan Pratap Mishra, Ayodhya; Dr Anil Mishra, homoeopathic doctor, Ayodhya; Kameshwar Chaupal, Patna; and Mahant Dinendra Das, Nirmohi Akhara, Ayodhya. Mishra is included as a descendant of Ayodhya rulers.

The district collector of Ayodhya will be ex-officio trustee and shall be a practising Hindu. If the incumbent collector is not a practising Hindu, the additional collector will need to be one, making the trust an all-Hindu affair. There will also be a representative to be nominated by the Centre, an IAS officer not below the rank of joint secretary. One representative will be nominated by UP government. A chairman of a committee for development and administration will be appointed by the Board of Trustees.

Voting in the Board will be limited to a set of 10 trustees, mainly religious figures associated with the Trust. These trustees will essentially be members till they pass away or choose to resign.

Soon after the Supreme Court pronounced the Ayodhya verdict on November 9, 2019, RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat and senior Sangh leader Suresh Bhaiyaaji Joshi had visited Parasaran — a Padma Vibhushan and Padma Bhushan awardee — to thank him. He later visited the makeshift temple where the idol is currently placed.

The gazette notification issued by the home ministry on Wednesday stated that it had approved the scheme, as directed by the Supreme Court, that makes necessary provisions in regard to functioning of the Trust including matters relating to management of the Trust, powers of the trustees, including construction of the temple, and all necessary, incidental and supplemental matters.

It stated that possession of inner and outer courtyards of the disputed site — or the 1,500 square yards area over which the Babri Masjid was built — shall be handed over to the Trust.

On why the home ministry notification called the 1,500 sq yard site — which SC had held to be in ownership of Ram Lalla Virajman — as ‘disputed’, an officer explained it was referred as such in the Supreme Court verdict of November, 2019. It had stated that “possession of the disputed property shall continue to vest in the statutory receiver under the Central Government until in exercise of its jurisdiction under Section 6 of the Ayodhya Act of 1993, a notification is issued vesting the property in the trust or other body”.

The Centre said it had decided, in consultation with the UP government, to allot a suitable 5-acre plot at a prominent place in Ayodhya, outside the land acquired under the Acquisition of Certain Areas at Ayodhya Act, 1993, to Sunni Central Waqf Board for building a mosque.

The decision, it said, had taken into account past history of communal disturbances and possible scenarios relating to public order and considering the large number of pilgrims visiting the land acquired throughout the year. It also kept in mind essential amenities that would require to be provided for the increase in number of pilgrims from all across the world in future.

The allotment letter of five acres of land in Ayodhya to the Sunni Waqf Board was issued by the UP government on Wednesday.

The SC had also ruled that the central government was at liberty to make suitable provisions in respect to the rest of the acquired land by handing it over to the said Trust for management and development. On Wednesday, the Centre said that upon being satisfied that the Trust is willing to comply with terms and conditions, it “directs that all rights, title and interests in relation to the entire area acquired under the Schedule to the said Act, including the inner and outer courtyard of the disputed site, shall vest in the said Shri Ram Janmbhoomi Teerth Kshetra”.

Title: Congress: Politics over Lord Ram must end now
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NEW DELHI: A day before Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the formation of a trust for a Ram temple and sent BJP on a Hindutva messaging overdrive, Congress experts on NPR-NRC heard concerns that the party needs to craft a political message to blunt the saffron offensive of painting the opposition as “pro-minority”.

The opposition to the new citizenship measures, felt a section of Congress, exposes the party to being too closely aligned with a cause that might alienate sections of Hindu opinion. The thinking encapsulated worries in Congress ranks that unceasing protests against CAA , though they may have rattled BJP for a while, have led to a saffron response that is potentially polarising and effective.

If fears of Hindutva pitch exist on CAA, the renewed BJP push on Ayodhya only compounds the pre-existing concerns in Congress, eager to avoid the return of political confrontation to “secular versus communal” battle lines. At a function in Mumbai in March, 2018, Sonia Gandhi had said BJP had persuaded voters to see Congress as a “Muslim party”.

Ayodhya as such may not be the worry for Congress and other parties, which feel the Supreme Court order settling the vexed issue in favour of a temple removed a contentious plank that lends itself to mobilisation. It was this hope that prompted most in the anti-BJP axis to welcome the apex court verdict.

But its revival as a public development poses a challenge if BJP uses it to stoke its majority base against the CAA-NRC, by clubbing the two sensitive subjects as part of “minority politics” of rivals. The matter is made more problematic with Congress even opposing the national population register, an exercise mandated under the census, on the grounds that it will be a precursor to a national register of citizens.

When asked about the Ayodhya trust, Congress said it welcomed the Supreme Court decision on the temple issue and respected it. In the same breath, they also said the party hoped this would now put an end to “politics over Lord Ram”.

“When Supreme Court delivered its verdict, we welcomed it. The government is merely following the rules laid down by the apex court. We want that politics over Lord Ram should end and seeking votes in his name should end. It is a matter of faith,” said Congress MP and spokesperson Gaurav Gogoi.

“If people want to practice their faith they will go to the new Ram Mandir to do that. We don’t need the BJP government to tell us about religion,” Gogoi said. He also claimed Congress practices faith “much better than BJP”. “BJP practises fake nationalism and fake religion,” he said.

The party appears alive to the need to redirect the debate to NPR-NRC being inimical to “all the poor”. As a party functionary explained, Rahul Gandhi started by drawing a parallel between NRC and “demonetisation”, arguing both hurt the poor. “If the poor stood in queues for days to exchange their old currency and withdraw money, they would now have to run from pillar to post to produce documents to prove their citizenship,” he said.

Rahul’s decision to embark on a string of rallies on the economy are also part of the plan to refocus on the plank of “have-nots” and the youth. Congress is likely to launch a campaign to sensitise the people on how the “poor, SC/ST, migrants” and not just Muslims, would be hurt by the NRC. Congress believes this can put a political cost on BJP’s Hindutva overdrive, even as the saffron party argues protests as essentially led by Muslim groups.

At an in-house briefing on Tuesday, Congress flagged eight “superfluous” questions in the NPR questionnaire that it wants should be deleted, underlining that NPR would form the basis of NRC in future.

Title: Amit Shah welcomes move to set up temple trust
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

PTI photo

NEW DELHI: Union home minister Amit Shah on Wednesday welcomed the decision over the formation of the Shri Ram Janmabhoomi Teertha Kshetra Trust, citing the inclusion of a permanent Dalit member as an unprecedented move towards strengthening social harmony.

Shah’s statement came soon after PM Narendra Modi announced in Lok Sabha about the constitution of the trust. “There will be 15 trustees in the Shri Ram Janmabhoomi Teertha Kshetra Trust out of which one trustee will always be from the Dalit society,” Shah tweeted. He said the trust will be independent to take every decision related to the temple and 67 acres of land will be transferred to it.

“I fully believe that the waiting of millions of people for centuries will be over soon and they will be able to pay obeisance to Lord Shri Ram in his grand temple at his birthplace,” hesaid. Shah thanked the PM for his commitment for construction of a temple dedicated to Lord Ram, “who is a symbol of faith and unwavering reverence of India”.

Defence minister Rajnath Singh hailed the announcement saying the representation of scheduled castes in the trust will strengthen social harmony. “PM Modi has honoured the spirits of crores of citizens of this country by announcing the formation of Ram Temple Trust. With the representa tion of Dalit community in the trust, social harmony has been strengthened. I heartily congratulate the PM for this decision,” he said.

Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath hailed the decision saying that this trust will be completely independent and capable of making decisions related to temple construction. BJP functionary Uma Bharati on Wednesday said the move will silence critics who have been accusing the saffron party of demanding votes on the Ayodhya issue.

Title: Cabinet nod for Maharashtra deep port that will be among world’s top 10
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Union Cabinet on Wednesday gave its “inprinciple” approval for setting up a major port at Vadhavan near Dahanu in Maharashtra and it will become the thirteenth major port in the country.

With 20 metre draft (depth), it will come up as one of the top 10 ports across the globe to receive mother ships, which currently come to Colombo or Singapore to offload the cargo to be transferred to Indian ports. This is the first project to be approved by the Cabinet, which was included in the Infrastructure Projects Pipeline.

Union shipping minister Mansukh L Mandaviya said the project will involve approximately Rs 64,545 crore investment. “The Centre will have 51% of share of the special purpose vehicle, which will be set up to develop the port. Maharashtra Maritime Board and private players can have the rest of the share in the SPV,” he said.

He said there will be hardly any requirement to acquire land for developing the port. Vadhavan port will be developed on “land lord model”. The SPV will be formed with Jawaharlal Nehru Port Trust as the lead partner and it will develop the port infrastructure including reclamation, construction of breakwater, besides establishing connectivity to the hin terland.

All the business activities would be undertaken under public private partnership mode by private developers. Currently, JNPT is the biggest container port in India and is ranked at 28th position globally with a traffic of 5.1 million TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units). Even after the completion of fourth terminal at JNPT with a capacity increase up to 10 million TEUs by 2023, it will stand as the 17th largest container port in the world. Mandaviya said development of Vadhavan port will enable call of container vessels of 16,00025,000 TEUs capacity, giving advantages of economies of scale and reducing the logistics cost.

Title: 5-acre land offer draws sharp reactions from Muslim side
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW/DELHI: The UP Sunni Central Waqf Board on Wednesday withheld an official response to the Yogi Adityanath cabinet's offer of a 5-acre plot for the construction of a mosque till at least February 24, but its counsel and Babri Masjid Action Committee convener Zafaryab Jilani made no secret of his disappointment at the government choosing a location 25km away from the Ram Janmabhoomi site.

Jilani claimed the location of the 5 acres allotted at Dhannipur village in Ayodhya ’s Sohawal tehsil does not conform to what the Supreme Court mandated in its November 9 ruling in the Ram Janmabhoomi-Babri Masjid title suit.

"In all court documents that were part of the title suit, Ayodhya was a small town — a qasbah of Faizabad. This Ayodhya cannot be equated with the new district created by the government," Jilani said. "Merely renaming a town and extending its municipal limits does not prove that the land offered is still in Ayodhya."

Iqbal Ansari, whose father Hashim Ansari was one of the original litigants, said the land that the government had offered for the mosque should be used to build a dharamshala for devotees coming to Ayodhya, "with the facility of free boarding and lodging".

Sunni waqf board chairperson Zufar Faruqi, who is currently abroad, was unavailable for comment. The board’s CEO, Syed Mohammad Shoeb, told TOI that the members would decide on a response and an action plan at a meeting on February 24.

"A meeting of the Sunni waqf board is scheduled for February 24, where issues pertaining to waqf properties and legal matters were to be discussed. Ayodhya was not on the agenda, but given the recent events, the issue of land allotment might also be discussed in the meeting," Shoeb said. "The board might also convene an emergency meeting before February 24 once the chairperson returns to the city."

On November 26 last year, a meeting of eight members of the Sunni waqf board decided not to file a review petition against the Ayodhya verdict.

In Delhi, the All India Muslim Personal Law Board termed the UP government's offer "unnecessary", saying that accepting the 5-acre plot to build a shrine there in lieu of the Babri Masjid would be like "rubbing salt on our wounds".

Maulana Arshad Madani , president of the Jamiat Ulama-i-Hind, said the site where the Babri Masjid existed "is a mosque as per Shariah and it would remain a mosque till the day of resurrection, no matter what form and name it is given, because no individual and party has the right to withdraw his claim from any mosque to any alternative".

"Accepting land in the name of a mosque is against the principles of Islam laid out in the Shariah. So, this allotment of land by the UP government is unacceptable. Though the Sunni waqf board is free to take its decisions, in our opinion it should not take the offer. This is unacceptable," Madani added.

Muslim personal law board secretary Saifullah Rahmani said that "as law-abiding citizens", the Muslim side had chosen "silence" after the Supreme Court verdict rejecting its claim to the disputed site. "However, on the issue of an alternative plot, we have always maintained that the Sunni waqf board should not accept it as this case was never about an alternative mosque".

Rahmani confirmed this to be the "official position" of the Muslim personal law board.

Lawyer Jilani, who is also an executive member of the Muslim personal law board, said the allotment of land was not in conformity with the Acquisition of Certain Area at Ayodhya Act of 1993 and the Ismail Farooqi case of 1994. "In both the Act and the case, it has been clearly mentioned that the 67-acre plot will be used to develop in a planned manner a temple, a mosque, a library, a museum and amenities for pilgrim. Whatever area is left will be given to the owners. The Supreme Court had upheld this in the Farooqi case of 1994."

Title: Truck cleaner shot dead in Rohtas
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

SASARAM: Criminals shot dead the cleaner and seriously injured the driver of an empty truck on Dinara–Dehri state highway near Mogara village under Natwar police station in Rohtas district late Tuesday night. The deceased was identified as Sunil Yadav (25) from Azamgarh .

The driver, who received four bullet injuries, was battling for his life in a private nursing home at Bikramganj .

Bikramganj DSP Raj Kumar Singh said the gang involved in the crime has been identified and raids were on to nab them.

Police sources said the incident happened when the truck was on its way to Dehri-on-Sone for loading sand. The driver, identified as Vidya Sagar Yadav (35), smelt foul play and accelerated the speed of the truck. Then the criminals started firing and the bullets hit the driver and cleaner. The driver lost control of the truck which dashed against a tree.

Incidentally, this is the second such attack on trucks coming from neighbouring Uttar Pradesh (UP) in the last three months. In the previous incident, a cleaner of a sand-laden truck was shot dead on Pali road under Dehri-on-Sone police station area in Rohtas district on November 10 after he refused to pay extortion at a government checkpost.

Locals claimed that there has been a spurt in different types of crime in Rohtas district. Police are still clueless in Rs5 lakh loot case in Sasaram even after four days of the incident. The criminals had looted the cash from an automobile spare parts trader near Sasaram court on Saturday evening.

Title: Delhi polls: JD(U) pulls out all the stops to win over Bihari voters
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

PATNA: With electioneering for Delhi assembly polls coming to end on Thursday evening, Bihar ’s ruling JD(U) on Wednesday pulled out all the stops to win the hearts of ‘Purvanchali’ voters to ensure victory of its candidates from Burari and Sangam Vihar.

JD(U) is contesting two out of total 70 assembly seats in Delhi where polling will be held on February 8 and counting of votes on February 11. Shailendra Kumar , who has roots in Sampatchak of Patna district, and former BJP MLA Dr Shiv Charan Lal Gupta are the JD(U) candidates from Burari and Sangam Vihar, respectively.

Besides fielding seven Bihar ministers to address mohalla-level events in the two constituencies, the party has deputed its 35 MLAs, MLCs and former legislators in the two constituencies for door-to-door contact programme with the help of local BJP and JD(U) cadres.

Moreover, JD(U)’s 16 Lok Sabha members and four of the six Rajya Sabha members visited the two constituencies. “As Budget session of Parliament is going on, all our MPs are in the national capital. Except two Rajya Sabha members — one is deputy chairman while other is sick — all our MPs are visiting the two constituencies on a regular basis to campaign for the party candidates,” JD(U) national general secretary Afaque Ahmad Khan told TOI over phone on Wednesday.

“Burari has six wards of Municipal Corporation of Delhi. We have lined up one legislator or former legislator for each ward. While Morwa (Samastipur) MLA Vidya Sagar Nishad has been made incharge of ward no. 6 and former Amnaur MLA Mantu Singh is conducting door-to-door campaign in ward no. 7. Similarly, Bagaha MLA Dhirendra Pratap Singh alias Rinku Singh has been deputed in ward no. 8, Agiaon MLA Prabhu Ram in ward no. 9, Kargahar MLA Bashishtha Singh (ward no.10) and former Bihar MLC Rudal Rai in ward no.11,” JD(U) MLC Ranbir Nandan, who is overall incharge of Burari constituency, told TOI.

At least 35 JD(U) legislators and former legislators are campaigning in the two constituencies.

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar has already addressed three election rallies in Delhi on Sunday and Monday and seven JD(U) ministers from Bihar have been touring the two constituencies for the last six days. “On Wednesday, Bihar’s rural development department minister Shravan Kumar addressed an election rally in Burari and IPRD minister Neeraj Kumar in Sangam Vihar,” Nandan said.

State's building construction minister Ashok Choudhary, who is campaigning in the two constituencies, said the winnability of JD(U) candidates had improved remarkably after the joint rally of Nitish and Union home minister Amit Shah on Sunday. “The issue of permit having been denied to Bihar buses up to Delhi by the Kejriwal government has become a topic of discussion in every Bihari house after Nitish raised it during the joint rally of the NDA leaders,” Choudhary said.

Title: Cossipore-BK Pal route autos resume services
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Autos ply on the Cossipore-BK Pal Ave route on Wednesday

KOLKATA: Commuting between Cossipore and B K Pal Avenue, which had turned nightmarish since Saturday morning after cops stopped autos from plying on that stretch, eased on Wednesday. Passengers who had braced for another day of travelling on over-crowded buses or walking long distances were surprised to see the three-wheelers back at the stand.

Anticipating that the Tallah Bridge shutdown would force light vehicles — that have been taking the bridge — to clog roads along the auto route from the 4B terminus to B K Pal Avenue, cops had barred autos from plying on this route. Commuters were forced to take buses on routes 242, 30A and 43, which were over-crowded with the extra passengers. People were seen clinging to the overhead rods at the gates of the buses with their feet barely touching the footboards. With complaints piling up, cops eventually allowed autos to resume services on the route.

Many, like Prasenjit Bera, had decided not to board the over-crowded buses and chose to walk. “I have to take my daughter to school from our home in Cossipore to Bagbazar. With autos on this route staying off the road, I had to walk with her all the way. We also returned on foot. I couldn’t have boarded those buses as it would be impossible — and dangerous — for my daughter to get into them,” he said.

Since the auto services were suspended, however, buses had been doing brisk business since Saturday morning. Since heavy vehicles were barred from plying along Tallah Bridge from last September, buses were re-routed along an additional 8km route. Bus operators’ unions have been complaining about the increased costs on account of the increased distance covered.

Title: West Bengal: Traffic islands planned to make crossing roads easy
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: The traffic police are mulling the construction of pedestrian islands — spaces that will allow pedestrians crossing a busy intersection to wait safety. The move will ease the problems of pedestrians who use Chitpore bridge, those trying to cross over at the RG Kar Hospital gates and commuters at Paikpara . It will also ensure that cops can keep traffic flow towards the Chitpore Lockgate Bridge normal.

A pedestrian island is mostly found in the centre of roads without dividers. Pedestrians can cross the first half of the road and take refuge at an island while they wait for cars to clear before attempting to cross the second half. “The pedestrian islands will help decongest the area and ensure that signals are violated less,” an officer said.

Besides these islands, cops have decided to put up dedicated channels for pedestrian movement. They will also mark out spots for buses to stop across Chiria More, Indra Biswas Road and RG Kar Road. Any driver who stops the bus beyond the scheduled stops — thus holding up traffic — will be penalized.

Similarly, more civic volunteers will be deployed to ensure school children do not stray on to Cossipore Road.

Title: Bihar man who laid first brick is now trustee of Ram temple
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Kameshwar Chaupal

PATNA: On November 9, 1989, the BJP’s Dalit leader Kameshwar Chaupal had laid the first ‘Ram sila’ (brick) at Ayodhya as part of the legion of Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP) volunteers gathered there for it. And, 31 years later on Wednesday, he said no one could fathom the ‘aanand’ (bliss) that he was feeling now that the temple dedicated to ‘Ram lalla’ would come up. The Centre on Wednesday formed a board of trustees for its construction, as asked by the Supreme Court.

Chaupal has also been made a member of the 15-member Trust constituted by the Centre on Wednesday to oversee the construction of Ram temple on 67 acre land at Ayodhya. The names of eight members have been disclosed so far.

“My appeal to all sections of society, whatever their religion, community and creed, is that they all should come forward and lend their support to building the temple. It would be a magnificent temple. It would also express the spirit of the country that is rooted in social harmony and well-being of all,” Chaupal said.

“If Mahatma Gandhi were alive, even he would have expressed the same feeling. He talked about ‘Ram raj’. Only after the temple dedicated to Lord Ram comes up, can there be any talk of ‘Ram raj’,” he added.

Chaupal, who belongs to Supaul district in north Bihar bordering Nepal, has been in Delhi for the last some weeks to campaign for the BJP-led NDA candidates in the assembly election to be held on February 8. At the time of reporting in the evening, none of the BJP bigwigs had personally informed him about his inclusion in the 15-member board of trustees.

“Around seven media persons came to me to have my take on the occasion,” Chaupal said, adding: “I am a widower. My two daughters and one son did call me on my phone. They are very happy at the inclusion of my name in the panel of trustees. Now I am free to work further for the cause of temple and ‘Prabhu Ram’. My children are all married and well settled.”

He was made to quit the VHP and become a member of the BJP in 1991, because the party fielded him to contest the parliamentary election that year which he lost. He lost the election second time in 2014. However, he remained the Rajya Sabha member for two terms – from 2002 to 2014.

The Dalit leader had become a member of the VHP in 1982. He was made its state incharge with headquarters at Gaya in 1989. “It was from Gaya that we volunteers had carried ‘Ram silas’ to Ayodhya,” Chaupal said, adding bricks were taken from every village and each person who gave the brick also gave Rs1.25 as ‘dakshina’ (offering).

Title: Coronavirus in Surat: Second suspected case reported in Surat
Content: SURAT: After a 41-year-old man with Coronavirus symptoms made headlines by his disappearing act from the isolation ward at New Civil Hospital (NCH) on Tuesday, a second symptomatic case has been reported in the city on Wednesday.While the businessman from Varachha area returned to the hospital on Wednesday, a 21-year-old MBBS student in China has been admitted in SMIMER Hospital with complains of severe cold and cough.The Surat Municipal Corporation’s (SMC) health team has kept both patients under observation in accordance to the directives of health department. They were earlier home quarantined for 14 days after which they developed symptoms similar to the outbreak and were brought to the hospital.The businessman had gone to China on January 15 and returned on January 19. “He was under observation by SMC’s health department team and when even after 14 day observation period his cough has not subsided, he was advised to get tests done at the NCH,” said a health official of SMC.As per the rules the patient who is under test is supposed to be admitted in isolation at hospital till the test results come. “When the businessman was informed about isolation at hospital he might have disappeared from hospital in panic,” said the officer.The businessman’s family had approached the NCH officials on Wednesday and gave explanation about the disappearance. They agreed to cooperate and later the businessman got admitted in SMIMER.“The businessman got admitted in hospital and his samples are being collected and NCH will send the samples to NIV Pune. The report may take three to four days time,” said a senior doctor at NCH.The girl student had returned from China on January 29. On noticing influenza-type symptoms, she was asked to get a test done on Wednesday.“Both the patients are in normal condition right now. They have not shown any severity of coronavirus infection. But we have already informed their family members to take necessary precautions,” said a health official of SMC.

Title: Groom shot on way to wedding in Azamgarh
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Varanasi: A groom was shot dead by two miscreants on way to the bride’s house for the wedding ceremony in Devgaon police station area of Azamgarh district on Tuesday night. Police has launched a manhunt to arrest the assailants.

Police officials said marriage of Sumit Gupta, a resident of Singhpur village in Mehnagar area, had been fixed with daughter of Lalbahadur Gupta of Lalganj and the groom and his relatives were on their way to the wedding venue when two motorcycle-borne miscreants shot the groom and fled. Sumit was rushed to Lalganj community health centre where doctors declared him dead.

The shocked family and relatives started creating ruckus at the hospital, following which police reached the spot and brought the situation under control. The body was sent for postmortem. “We are investigating the matter. The motive behind the killing is not clear yet. The case would be worked out and miscreants nabbed soon,” said Azamgarh SP Triveni Singh.

Title: Trader groups create ruckus over shifting of goods at Raghuvir Textile Market
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The traders even gathered at Puna police station

Surat: Internal dispute between textile traders of Raghuvir Celeum Textile Market that was gutted last month reached a flash point on Tuesday night when two groups nearly came to blows over removing goods from the shops.

A group of textile traders owning shops in the textile market on Puna-Kumbhariya Road on Tuesday night stopped some workers from removing their textile goods from the building and accused them of stealing the stock.

They further alleged that police was helping select traders in shifting their goods. However, the police claimed that they were helping traders remove whatever was left in their shops after proper verification of ownership of goods.

However, a number of textile traders who too own shops in the same textile market alleged that a group of traders were conniving with police to shift their goods from the building that has been sealed by the Surat Urban Development Authority (SUDA).

“We caught two tempos trying to remove goods from the textile market on Tuesday night. But two other trucks managed to escape. Around 70 people were gathering goods from two shops located on the mezzanine and third floor of the market,” said one of the traders Sunil Adukia. “When questioned the workers said that they had police permission to shift the goods. If that is the case, why are we not allowed to take our goods to other places?” asked Adukia.

The traders even gathered at Puna police station to register their protest. However, an official from Puna police said, “There are traders whose two shops are gutted in fire but two more shops are safe and they wanted to shift their goods. We gave them permission on humanitarian grounds. However, when people started removing their goods, some of the traders objected because of internal rivalry.”

Police further said that majority of the traders either don’t have insurance cover for the goods or have documents to prove that amount of goods that own. “Majority of the goods has been purchased without proper billing and insurances. Traders also fear that their good could be stolen by their rivals,” said police.

Title: Hopes rise on Pal-Umra Tapi bridge project’s early completion
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The bridge will benefit nearly 20 lakh people

Surat: The possibility of early completion of Pal-Umra Tapi bridge project has become real now because Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) will be soon beginning 24-metre wide road alignment work on 1,800 square metres of ‘occupied piece of land’. SMC has issued work orders for shifting seven of the 20 families residing on this piece of land on Umra side of the bridge. These seven families have agreed to the civic body’s formula and the latter hopes others too would fall in line soon.

The bridge is 95 per cent complete since last 18 months but refusal of these families to shift has been holding up the completion of the Rs81 crore project. The bridge, which will join Pal and Umra areas, will benefit approximately 20 lakh people.

Municipal commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani said on January 27 that a few families cannot hold 20 lakh people to ransom. He said, “We will adopt means available under the law and take possession of the land. Land owners will be given compensation as per the law.”

He had said those willing to cooperate will be covered under the compromise formula approved by the standing committee of the civic body. They will be given plots of land of equal size under their possession together with cumulative construction amount of Rs2.50 crore. Each evacuee family also will be paid monthly rent of Rs12,000 till their new house gets ready.

An officer of the civic body said, “Seven families have come forward to accept our formula. We have issued work orders for them and hope the remaining families too will accept our formula.”

An officer of SMC bridge department said, “This bridge will be beneficial to at least 20 lakh people living on both sides of Umra and Pal areas. At present, a large number of people have to go all the way to Sardar Bridge or cable-stayed bridge to cross over to the other side. The bridge will save people at least 15 minutes of travel time.”

Title: 23 buildings told to remove faulty outer elevation
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Surat: The Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) has issued notices to about 23 commercial high-rise buildings located in various municipal zones to make necessary changes in the outer elevation of the buildings confirming to the fire safety standards.

These high-rise buildings have come under the scanner of the SMC after the massive fire gutted Raghuvir Celeum textile market recently. The civic body’s urban development and town planning department has ordered the survey of the commercial buildings for checking the fire safety measures.

Official sources said that the survey will cover more than 1,000 commercial high-rises. The fire officials will be checking the outer elevation at the buildings, entry and exit, parking facilities, entry gates and other fire safety norms including fire hydrant system etc.

The 23 buildings issued notices by the civic body are located in the central zone, Limbayat zone, Udhana zone, Rander and Athwa zones.

Official sources said that the devastating fire at the Raghvir market on Puna-Kumbhariya road on the early hours of January 21 could not be controlled even after 32 hours due to the presence of the outer elevation or facade constructed with aluminium material. The fire gutted more than 600 shops and caused losses to the tune of over Rs 200 crore.

Chief fire officer Basant Pareek said, “A survey of the commercial buildings across the city has been started and we found about 23 buildings having faulty outer elevation. Notices have been issued to the developers for making necessary changes in the outer elevation and conform with the fire safety norms under the National Building Code (NBC).”

Pareek added, “The survey is still going on and that about 1,000 commercial buildings will be covered.”

Title: Civic body to move HC against UDHD orders
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

PATNA: The Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) board on Wednesday passed a resolution affirming that daily wage sanitation workers will not be removed from their jobs and that the process of regularisation of Group D employees (working for 10 years) will resume soon.

The board members also decided to move the Patna High Court challenging the three directives issued by the UDHD on January 28, February 3 and February 4, respectively. The decisions were taken at a special board meeting held under the Bihar Municipal Act, 2007 to address the grievances of the sanitation workers, who are on an indefinite strike since Monday.

The move comes a day after Patna Mayor Sita Sahu met the state urban development and housing department (UDHD) minister, Suresh Sharma, to demand that PMC be authorized to make Group-D appointments in the civic body.

“We will file the affidavit on February 6. Meanwhile, we will stick to our decision to regularise workers who completed 10 years of service. At least 112 workers have been regularized and 400 are in the process, which will be completed soon,” the Mayor said, adding, “The PMC will fight against the UDHD’s decision on behalf of the daily wage workers.”

The Mayor, who chaired the meeting, said the PMC board members have rejected the order issued by the UDHD directing that the services of daily-wage sanitation workers be discontinued from March 31 and instead rope in a private agency.

“In the Lokayukta order, there was no mention of removal of daily wage labourers. It only mentions taking services from outsourcing agencies, which the PMC has already been doing,” Sahu said.

She added, “Currently, around 2,200 sanitation workers are employed with the PMC through outsourcing. Around 4,300 are daily wage sanitation workers, while 1,100 are permanent group D employees.”

The Mayor remarked that the UDHD has “misinterpreted” the decision of the Lokayukta and the civic body has been facing the wrath of the sanitation workers because of the department’s fault.

The UDHD in its letter issued on February 3 had asked the municipal body to end the services of the daily wage workers on March 31 and outsource the services to private agencies. On February 4, the department issued another letter stating that daily wage Group D employees will be given priority in selection of sanitation staff by the company to be outsourced.

PMC commissioner Amit Kumar Pandey and ward councillors were present at the special board meeting. Some ward councillors even demanded to terminate the contract of outsourced companies providing sanitation workers, but it was rejected by the PMC board members.

Title: Matrimony.com acquires 26% stake in Astro-Vision
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Chennai: Consumer internet company Matrimony.com that owns and operates Bharat Matrimony on Wednesday said that it has acquired a 26.1% stake in astrology solutions company Astro-Vision Futuretech Pvt Ltd, who are promoters of ClickAstro.com. The stake buy is significantly through fresh infusion of capital and is subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals, a statement from the company added.

Murugavel Janakiraman, CMD, Matrimony.com said, “Astrology is core to match-making and majority of our customers generate horoscope prediction using Astro-Vision’s software. With the strategic investment we see further synergies in enhancing our value-add to our customers and also accelerate the growth of Astro-Vision”.

Matrimony.com posted a 16.5% drop in net profit at Rs 5.6 crore and a 5.6% growth in revenue for the quarter ended December. Its stock price was down 2.6% at the BSE at Rs 432.1.

Title: KMDA to float repair tenders for six bridges from February 15
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: The KMDA, from February 15, is set to start floating tenders for repairing six flyovers and bridges that underwent structural health audit last year. Starting with Baghajatin rail over bridge (ROB), which the authorities have listed as the top-most priority among the six bridges, the tenders will be floated for work on Kalighat Setu, Sealdah flyover, Aurobindo Setu, Chingrighata flyover and Bankim Setu.

Officials said the reason why it was taking so much of time to float the bridge repair tenders was this was the first time the work was being done with so much attention to detail.

“The plan is to take up repair work without having to shut any flyover. Only a partial closure may be necessary if the situation demands,” said an official.

Repairs on Kalighat Setu will entail fixing the corroded pillars and boosting its load-taking capacity while 10 to 15 bearings of Aurobindo Setu need to be replaced. Additional load and bitumen layer will be removed from Sealdah flyover and Bankim Setu and urgent repair and maintenance work will be carried out on Chingrighata flyover.

Title: No breakthrough in loot case
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Police have so far failed to make any breakthrough in the loot of jewellery worth Rs90 lakh from a showroom at Jairam Bazar under Khagaul police station area in western Patna on Tuesday.

Two armed criminals had entered the showroom as customers and took owner Sujeet Kumar hostage at gunpoint before stuffing the jewellery in a bag and escaping on foot. Sujeet was made unconscious by criminals by spraying some anaesthetic agent. They even took away the digital video recorder of CCTV cameras installed inside and outside the shop. According to police, the incident took place between 2 and 3pm and they were informed at 4.42pm. Shop’s shutter was half down when some neighbours peeped inside.

Khagaul police station SHO Mukesh Kumar Mukesh said Sujeet had yet not told police everything. “He unusually opened his shop at 6am on Tuesday against his regular timing of around 10.30am. Someone reached his shop at 8.30am to get a pair of anklets cleaned. Sujeet himself had gone to a nearby shop for anklets cleaning,” he said.

He said Sujeet had received a call from that person to open shop early as he had some urgency. “Sujeet received a similar call again from another unknown person with remarkably same request of cleaning a pair of anklets. After receiving the second call, Sujeet apprehended some trouble and told another shopowner in the neighbourhood about that,” the SHO said.

“Surprisingly, Sujeet is not saying all these things. Instead, he is denying to have received any such call. Police got to know from other persons about the calls during interrogation,” he said.

Mukesh said at least four to five criminals are suspected to be involved in the crime.

Title: Series of police meetings ahead of Donald Trump’s likely visit to Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Donald Trump

AHMEDABAD: A series of high level meetings between senior police officials of the state took place ahead of the likely visit by US president Donald Trump at the end of this month.

Even as the cops said that formal word confirming Trump’s visit was still awaited, Ahmedabad city is abuzz with preparations for the likely visit. Recently, only CM Vijay Rupani had given a formal word on the issue, saying at his address at a political rally in Delhi that the US president would visit the Sabarmati riverfront in Gujarat soon.

On Wednesday, both the home department and DGP’s office were abuzz with a series of meeting between senior police and government officials. Top sources said that no US security agency has come to Gujarat as yet. “They will only come when Trump’s visit is confirmed officially” added a senior police official.

Even as official word in writing is awaited, cops are gearing up for the VVIP visit. “As far as the police is concerned, we are preparing ourselves to be fully ready for the visit of any VVIP. We are in touch with the stadium authorities as well as the officials of the construction company to know the date on which they will be able to hand over the stadium for a thorough check up to the police,” a top police official said.

Top police source said a helipad is expected to come up near the practice pitches of Ground B at the Sardar Patel Motera Stadium. “We have our men deployed discreetly near the stadium as part of our security drill. It is believed that if US president Trump’s visit to Gujarat is confirmed, senior police officials from across the state could be called in for security duty,” a top police official said.

Title: Gujarat: Road to Gate No 3 to be ready by February 10
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

AHMEDABAD: Two major access roads to the world’s largest cricket stadium at Motera is almost ready. One of these roads, which originates a little ahead of Indira Bridge in the Gandhinagar state highway near Bhat village will directly lead to the new Gate 3 of the stadium. The 24-metre wide road will be ready by February 10 ahead of US president Donald Trump’s visit later this month.

The major road touches the Gandhinagar state highway ahead of Indira bridge and turns near Koteshwar towards Dev Pride Society and then leads directly to Gate 3. The other road originates from Dev Pride and joins the Hotel Janpath Road along the metro rail route.

When TOI visited the site, about 150 metres of the road’s last stretch was left. Street lights have been erected while construction of new footpaths along both arms of the 24-metre-wide road is almost over.

“Nearly 13 of the 16 road stretches that are part of the access routes to Motera stadium have been refurbished,” says an AMC official present on site. “Work has been taking place at breakneck speeds as a number of access routes are important to prevent traffic jams,” says the official. At several places in Motera area even the drainage systems have been cleaned and spruced up ahead of the visit. Tight security is being maintained around 1km radius of the stadium.

Title: Patna stinks as sanitation workers’ strike continues
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

In just two days, the city has turned into a dumping ground

PATNA: The sanitation workers’ strike continued for the third consecutive day, leaving heaps of garbage on the streets and lanes of the state capital on Wednesday.

The Group D sanitation employees of Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) have been on strike demanding revoking of the urban development and housing department (UDHD) order to do away with the daily wage workers of PMC and outsource the sanitation work to a company after March 31.

The protesters burned tyres and blocked the road near Kankarbagh, Patliputra and Patna City circle offices. Heaps of garbage could be seen lying in most of the areas in the city. Residents were also seen burning the garbage, which is prohibited under Solid Waste Management Act.

Aniket, a resident of Anandpuri, complained that the roads are littered with garbage with animal carcasses also thrown by the protesters in some areas. “We are forced to dump garbage on the road since no one is collecting it,” he said.

Sheetal Kumari of Bhootnath Road said the animal carcasses and garbage dumped on the streets by protesters is stinking and it’s unbearable to even walk on such streets. “The carcasses of three dogs have been lying near Sabzi Mandi for the last couple of days and stinking. It is difficult to purchase even vegetable from the market,” she said.

A bank employee, Kundan Sharma, said the dustbin outside her office was also overflowing with garbage and the stink was unbearable. “There is not a single clean road in the city at present. The civic body should have a backup plan to handle such situation,” he said.

“In just two days, the city has turned into a dumping ground. I wonder how long it will take to clean the roads,” said Rashmi Ahuja, a resident of Musallahpur.

A sanitation worker, Ram Kumar, said, “We don’t want to create inconvenience to the residents but we are helpless. We are fighting for our rights.”

Patna Nagar Nigam Staff Union president Chandra Prakash said, “Our protest will continue. As soon as the PMC files an affidavit, we will hold a meeting and take the final decision on the ongoing strike.”

Indradeep Chandravanshi, a member of empowered standing committee and councillor of ward number 48 called the UDHD decision a ‘Tughlaqi Farman’. “The Lokayukta should also know how the department created havoc by misinterpreting his directives,” he said after the special board meeting of PMC on Wednesday.

“After June 26, 2018, no sanitation staff has been recruited by the PMC on daily wage. In the same year, the state government asked the municipal bodies to avail the services of sanitation workers through outsourcing. The PMC followed this directive and outsourced four companies,” Indradeep said.

Title: Coronavirus partially affects tourism in Bihar
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: The outbreak of novel coronavirus (CoV) in China has partially hit tourism sector in Bihar, especially at Bodh Gaya and Nalanda where Chinese Buddhist pilgrims and tourists from Thailand, Hong Kong and Vietnam visit in large numbers.State tourism department officials, however, said the overall tourist footfalls have not dropped much. Buddhists and people from all walks of life from across the world visit Bodh Gaya, which is considered the seat of enlightenment of Lord Buddha.Though December to February period is considered to be peak tourist season at Bodh Gaya, officials and hospitality sector experts said the footfalls have been comparatively less so far this time.Suryaketu Das, an official at tourist information centre of Bihar State Tourism Development Corporation (BSTDC) at Bodh Gaya, said: “The festive season at Bodh Gaya begins in September and reaches its peak in January-February. A large number of Chinese pilgrims visit different monasteries and the Mahabodhi Temple every year during this time. This year, pilgrims from China haven’t arrived following restrictions due to spread of coronavirus. Nevertheless, there hasn’t been much impact on tourists arrival from other countries.”A member of Bodh Gaya Temple Management Committee (BTMC) said medical teams have been deputed at the temple for check-up of every visitor. “Tourists from China, Singapore and Vietnam, who arrived at Bodh Gaya after January 15, have undergone various tests. The medical team keeps a regular check on them,” he said.Arun Kumar Ojha, member of Bodh Gaya Hotelier Association, said: “More than 500 Chinese tourists arrive at Bodh Gaya in February. But this time we are not expecting any visitor from China.”Sharing similar views, KN Jha, manager of a luxurious hotel at Rajgir, said Chinese tourists contribute to around 40%-45% of the total bookings during this season. “Since, they have been restricted from coming to India, a major part of tourism sector has been affected. The tourists made last-minute cancellation of their bookings at various hotels in Rajgir,” he said and added: “The coronavirus has also affected tourists from countries like Myanmar and Japan. At least 10% of the tourists coming from these countries have cancelled their bookings.”State surveillance officer Dr Ragani Mishra, who visited Gaya airport on Wednesday, said the outbreak hasn’t impacted tourism much as tourists from countries like Thailand are reaching there in huge numbers. “Authorities at Gaya airport are keeping a check on international tourists. From filling forms to thermal screening, several measures have been taken by the state health department to protect people from any infection. Besides, an emergency phone number has also been given to them in case they get any symptoms of coronavirus,” she said.Meanwhile, a Supaul resident, who returned from Nepal on Wednesday, was kept under observation at his home. “We have sent his sample to National Institute of Virology (NIV) at Pune. As of now, he has been kept in isolation at his home in Supaul,” said Mishra.Rajiv Sharma, an official at BSTDC’s tourist information centre in Rajgir said: “The outbreak hasn’t affected the inflow of international tourists, except from China.”

Title: Kanhaiya Kumar’s convoy attacked in Bihar's Supaul
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Kanhaiya Kumar

PATNA: Former JNU Students’ Union president Kanhaiya Kumar ’s convoy was attacked allegedly by CAA/NRC supporters at Mallik Chowk under Sadar police station area in Supaul town on Wednesday evening.

He was on way to address an anti-CAA/NRC meeting at Sisauni under Kishanpur police station area in the district before going to Saharsa. Kanhaiya has launched his yatra against CAA from Bhitiharwa Ashram in East Champaran on January 30. The yatra will culminate at Patna Gandhi Maidan on February 29.

Sadar police station SHO Sandeep Kumar Singh said Kanhaiya’s convoy slowed down due to heavy crowd in the busy market when some locals, who were said to be pro-CAA/NRC, started raising slogans against the CPI leader. However, police ensured that the convoy moved forward safely,” he said, adding that Kanhaiya wanted to divert route to address a meeting at a nearby place. But he was denied as he had no prior permission to address any gathering there.

The SHO said when almost all the cars in his convoy passed, someone threw stones on a pickup van with banner of anti-CAA/NRC slogans. Singh said there were at least 13 cars and more than 40 bikes in Kanahiya’s convoy. “The windshield of the van was shattered and the driver was injured. The convoy was later escorted up to the border of Saharsa district,” he said, adding no written complaint had been received by police.

Title: In a first, Bihar govt to table ‘green budget’ in House
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Sushil Modi

PATNA: In a first-of-its-kind initiative in the country, the state government will table a ‘ Green Budget ’ in the legislative assembly on March 15 after the general budget, which would be present on February 25 by deputy CM and finance minister Sushil Modi .

“In the green budget, the finance minister would present the gross allocation to be spent by various departments on environment conservation measures to be taken in the 2020-21 fiscal,” finance department principal secretary S Siddharth said on Wednesday.

Siddharth added, “Green budget implies that the budgeted money would be spent by various departments for the restoration of degraded ecological systems in the state and conservation of the existing ones so that the restoration of the ecological system, including its bio-diversity, is achieved over time. The aim is to improve the living conditions of human beings as well as wild life.”

Siddharth was addressing a workshop organized by the Asian Development Research Institute (ADRI) at the Old\Main secretariat. Representatives of various departments, including the principal accountant general of the accountant general’s office Nilotpal Goswami, were present.

The nodal officer for the green budget, Sanjeev Mittal, said it would be tabled in the assembly along with gender and child budgets on March 15. An overview of the expenditures made on environmental conservation activities during 2019-20 financial year would also be included in it.

“The expenditures made on environment conservation measures would be considered as positive steps taken. After a couple of years, the evaluation of the steps taken would be done,” Mittal added.

Mittal said the green budget would be prepared by separating the budgetary allotments made by various departments for environmental conservation and then the proposed expenditures would be aggregated to give shape to the green budget.

The budget would have two components —expenditures to be incurred on physical restoration of environmental degradation and non-physical investments (like publicity drives, public awareness and inclusion of environmental studies in school curriculum among others).

ADRI director P P Ghosh said, “The focus area of the green budget would be issues related to climate change, bio-diversity, restoration of natural resources and eco-system, as well as on environmental conservation and pollution control — all aimed at improving living conditions of people. It has been conceived in the backdrop of the Jal-Jeevan-Hariyali campaign.”

Two experts, who made key presentations on the occasion, included Rita Pandey, senior fellow of the National Institute of Public Finance (NIFP) and Shailly Kedia, fellow of The Energy Research Institute (TERI). “The two experts have made the environmental policy framework for Karnataka and Punjab,” Ghosh said, adding, other presentations were made by Niladri Dhar and Vivek Tejashwi.

Title: Bihar: 2 foot overbridges on New Bypass Road soon
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Patna divisional commissioner Sanjay Kumar Agarwal has claimed that the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) has proposed to construct two foot overbridges (FoB) at strategic locations on NH-30, commonly known as the New Bypass Road . The stretch of NH-30 between Anisabad and Zero Mile witnesses regular snarls, owing to movement of heavy vehicles throughout the day.

“The New Bypass Road is one of the most crowded roads in the city. We have observed that pedestrians face a lot of difficulties while crossing the road. Keeping their safety in mind, the NHAI will construct two FoBs at the busiest locations on the stretch,” Agarwal told this newspaper.

He added that instructions had also been given for the maintenance of underpasses on the stretch. “There are several underpasses on the stretch that are not being used due to lack of maintenance. Pedestrians will not have any problem in walking on the road once the underpasses are cleaned.”

Agarwal, who is also the managing director of the Bihar State Road Development Corporation Limited (BSRDCL), claimed that the New Bypass Road was one of the most accident-prone areas in the city.

“According to a survey, this road has been identified as a black spot because several accidents have occurred here. It is under surveillance and many unauthorized cuts have been removed from the road to ensure the safety of people,” he said.

Patna district magistrate Kumar Ravi also issued several instructions on Tuesday to reduce traffic congestion on the New Bypass Road . He asked the ADM (law and order) to clean the underpasses on NH-30.

With the construction of FoBs and maintenance of the underpasses, residents of localities like Ram Krishna Nagar and Anisabad now hope to get respite from the frequent snarls.

“The movement of vehicles on the New Bypass Road is more dangerous than the traffic snarls. I always avoid commuting on the stretch at night as it is really unsafe,” said Anisabad resident Sakshi Sinha.

“Crossing the New Bypass Road is very risky as there is continuous movement of trucks and buses there. Moreover, the vehicles move at a very high speed. I will be grateful to the authorities if they take measures to ensure pedestrian safety,” said Shivam Trivedi, another resident of Anisabad.

Lately, the state government has taken several measures to provide safe pedestrian movement. The city will soon get foot overbridges at Rupaspur, Rajendra Nagar and in front of Patna zoo and two underpass escalators near Samrat Ashoka International Convention Centre.

Title: Mealworms added to birds’ diet at city zoo
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

PATNA: With a view to fulfilling their nutritional needs, the winged inmates of the Sanjay Gandhi Biological Park, commonly known as the Patna zoo , are now being fed with mealworms. These live feeds, which include superworms and other types of insects, are also being cultivated on the premises of the zoo.

According to zoo director Amit Kumar, around 50 worms are kept in bird feeders every day. “The mealworms, which are being provided to pheasants and macaws as special supplements, help fulfil their nutritional needs and keep them warm. They will soon be added to the diet of other birds as well,” he told this newspaper on Wednesday.

The Patna zoo has several varieties of pheasants, including the Lady Amherst’s pheasant and the Yellow Golden pheasant.

Talking about the cultivation of worms, Amit said, “The eggs hatched by insects become larvae in three days, which in turn become pupae in almost a week and are kept in separate boxes. The pupae take three days to become mealworms. The male adults survive for two weeks and the females for four to five weeks.”

The veterinary doctors at the zoo monitor the life cycle of the insects. “Mealworms do not drink water as they absorb it from different food sources, which we provide at the zoo,” Amit said and added that approximately 125 larvae had been purchased from an online portal and over 5,000 larvae cultivated in just a couple of months.

A worm farmer pointed out that larvae, pupae, beetles, mini, moulted and large worms were kept in separate boxes, while the mature insects were kept in different trays to increase the production.

Title: ECR: Mumbai-based firm to turn crushed plastic bottles into clothes
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

PATNA: In an attempt to keep the premises of railway stations clean, the East Central Railway (ECR) has signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with a Mumbai-based firm that uses crushed plastic bottles for manufacturing garments.

According to ECR’s chief public relations officer (CPRO) Rajesh Kumar, bottle crushing machines worth Rs 5 lakh each have been installed at the Patna Junction, Rajendra Nagar Terminal, Danapur, Patna Sahib, Pt Deendayal Upadhyay Junction, Dhanbad, Muzaffarpur, Samastipur, Darbhanga, Jayanagar, Bapudham Motihari, Madhubani, Saharsa, Raxaul, Sitamarhi and Sugauli stations.

“As part of this pilot project of the railways, the firm will collect crushed plastic bottles from different stations of the ECR and make yarns, which will be used to manufacture T-shirts and caps of fine quality. One tonne of crushed bottle materials will help produce at least 10,000 T-shirts,” the CPRO said, adding that the railways had displayed samples of T-shirts made of crushed plastic bottles at the Danapur station.

Each T-shirt costs around Rs 350 and can be worn in any season. “We will ensure that these reasonable T-shirts are available at all major stations so that even railway employees can buy them easily,” Kumar said.

Scientist and Munger University vice-chancellor Ranjit Kumar Verma hailed the “eco-friendly initiative” of the railways. He said, “The railways has shown us that single-use plastic, which has been banned all over, can be put to other uses. All government and private agencies should follow in the footsteps of the railways.”

Sources claimed that the state government had also decided to use crushed plastic materials for construction of roads.

Title: ‘Bihar Expo’ begins today
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

PATNA: Road construction minister Nand Kishor Yadav will inaugurate the sixth edition of ‘Destination Bihar Expo ’ at Gandhi Maidan on Thursday. Altogether 300 stalls will be put up at the five-day event, which is jointly being organized by the state industries department and the Bihar Industries Association (BIA).

Traders and entrepreneurs from different parts of the country, including Bihar, Maharashtra and Karnataka, will showcase their products at the expo. “Not just different governments departments like road construction tourism and health, but private organizations and firms will also set up their stalls,” BIA president Ram Lal Khetan told this newspaper on Wednesday.

He added, “Our aim is to make Bihar an industrially and economically developed state. The event will showcase the state’s resources, availability of infrastructure and government policies for establishing businesses, which will help boost the economic development of Bihar.”

BIA secretary Anil Kumar Sinha pointed out that the expo would encourage the local entrepreneurs. “This is not just a fair, but an opportunity for entrepreneurs to build a network. Arrangements have also been made for women entrepreneurs, who operate small scale businesses. They will be able to showcase their products on this platform,” he claimed.

The All India Institute of Medical Sciences-Patna will also set up its stalls at the venue for providing free health check-up to the visitors. “The expo will have several blood camps and the donors will be given T-shirts and gifts as a token of appreciation,” Sinha said.

Activities like competition for kids and ‘gulab jamun’ eating contest will be organized at the five-day expo, which will conclude on February 10. Cultural programmes will also be held.

Title: Education dept to train govt teachers to improve standard of teaching
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Bareilly: The basic education department will start training teachers, instructors and shiksha mitras in Bareilly under the programme titled ‘National Initiative for School Heads’ and Teachers’ Holistic Advancement’ (NISHTHA) from February 17.

The training is aimed at improving the standard of primary and upper primary schools.

Anil Chaubey, a member of the state resource group, said, “The aim behind training the teachers is to enhance the level of education. There are 17 modules of training, which focus on activity-based learning, improving the learning outcome level of students and enhancing the leadership skills of headteachers.”

According to officials, nearly 20,000 teachers, instructors and shiksha mitras in Bareilly district will undergo training. In the first phase, 2,400 teachers of the district will attend a five-day training session.

The training programme will be organised at the level of blocks in the district.

Trainers’ teams comprising key resource persons and state resource persons have been constituted. The trainers had earlier received training at five centres in UP and they will now train teachers.

Title: BJP hails trust announcement
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

PATNA: Bihar BJP leaders hailed the formation of a trust for building Ram Mandir at Ayodhya. Union minister and Begusarai MP Giriraj Singh said the sacrifice of “martyrs” is bearing fruits now.

“Congress used to mock us when we used to raise the slogan of ‘Mandir wahin banayenge’ (we will construct the temple at the same spot). They used to ask us for the date of temple construction. Now the dates have been announced and ‘Sri Ram Janambhoomi Tirath Kshetra’ trust has also been formed. Now, there will be a grand temple of Lord Ram at Ayodhya,” Giriraj said.

BJP state president Sanjay Jaiswal said while the entire country is in festive mood with the PM Modi’s announcement, Congress is in shock. “Congress kept the matter hanging and delayed the construction of Ram temple at Ayodhya for years. Now it is obvious for them to be upset,” Jaiswal said.

Union minister of state for home affairs Nityanand Rai also hailed the announcement. “This government has proved that it does not believe only in making shallow promises but actually executes them in letter and spirit,” he said.

Bihar Congress functionaries, on the other hand, accused BJP of taking political mileage as the issue has been looked after by the apex court. “Modi government is only executing the Supreme Court judgment. Besides, the way announcement regarding the trust has been made close to Delhi assembly elections shows that BJP is aiming at polarization of votes through this move. They have always tried to deviate people’s attention from serious issues like economic slowdown,” Bihar Congress’s working president Kaukab Quadri said.

Title: SMC acts tough against nailing advts on trees
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Nails or such metal objects cause heavy damage to the trees as the bark is the skin of the tree which is alive

Surat: The garden department of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) has issued notices on Wednesday to some of the private institutions and advertisers for pinning posters and signboards on the trees.

The SMC’s garden department came into action after a citizen complained on Wednesday about dozens of trees being hurt with nails in the posh Jamnanagar area on Ghod Dod road by some private institutions and advertisers. Acting on his complaint, the garden department officials carried out inspection of the area and issued notices to the parties concerned.

Official sources said that the garden department had even earlier launched campaigns to remove illegal advertisements from the trees in the city. Advertisers are seen mainly choosing trees located on the main thoroughfares to put up their displays. They use nails to pierce the tree barks and hang their boards or flex advertisements.

Talking to TOI, SMC’s garden superintendent, SJ Gautam said, “We have been carrying out campaigns on a regular basis to protect the trees across the city. We have even issued notices to the private institutions and advertisers who put up advertisements and sign-boards damaging the trees.”

Gautam further said that the act of damaging trees falls under the damage to public property Act. “Despite our efforts to stop the menace, people are still indulging in the illegal act,” he rued.

Environment activist and tree expert, Darshan Desai told TOI, “Nails or such metal objects cause heavy damage to the trees as the bark is the skin of the tree which is alive. The bark is half inch thick and when we hurt it, we threaten the tree’s existence itself. This is why we have been witnessing many incidents of trees getting uprooted during the monsoon season.”

Title: Three injured as cooking gas cylinder explodes in Vesu
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The blast might have occurred due to leakage in the cylinder

Surat: Three persons , including a woman , suffered burn injuries in a fire that broke out after a 5kg cooking gas cylinder exploded in Vesu areas of the city on Wednesday. Three children aged 8-10 years, escaped without injuries in the incident. Fire officials said that the blast may have occurred because of leakage in the cylinder.

The explosion took place in the house of Pravin Shah (42), who lives with his wife Jyotsna and three children — daughter Sona and two sons Ansu and Sohan in SUDA Awas flat A6 near S D Jain College. Shah, who does tailoring work for a living, lives in a one-room-kitchen flat.

On Wednesday morning, when Jyotsna ignited the gas stove to make tea the 5 kg gas cylinder exploded and fire engulfed the flat instantly.

Shah’s neighbour Vinod Goswami (42) rushed to douse the fire and suffered burn injuries along with Shah and Jyotsna. All three were rushed to New civil Hospital (NCH). The three children miraculously escaped without any injury.

An official from fire department, Maruti Sonwane said, “Shah suffered 40% burns whereas Jyotsna received 20% burn injuries on her body. However, Goswami’s condition was critical as he suffered maximum 80% burns.”

Sonwane said that the explosion could have been because of leakage in the gas cylinder. “Due to winter, family had kept the windows closed and hence the leaked gas could not escape which aggravated the situation,” he added.

Title: Vegetable cooperatives help boost tribal farmers’ income by 20%
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

In Umarpada alone more than 2,000 farmers have sold over 185 metric tonnes of vegetables

Surat: Tribals in Surat district growing vegetables for a living will now be able to earn at least 20% more income with the elimination of middlemen. This has become possible through a pilot project of farmers’ vegetable cooperative on lines of the milk cooperatives functional under Gujarat Cooperative Milk Marketing Federation (GCMMF).

Under the project the forest department has started grading and collection centres for procurement of vegetables through tribal farmers’ union and joint farmers management committees.

The pilot project has been funded by the rural development agencies under Dr Shaymaprasad Mukherjee Rurban Mission.

The grading and collection centres have been set up in Umarpada, Umarogt, Pinpar, Ghanavad and Govat villages of Umrapada taluka in Surat district.

While the Umarpada center became operational in first week of December 2019, other centres will start functioning by end of February.

Surat deputy conservator of forest, Puneet Nayyar said, “The model is based on milk cooperatives, where farmers from remote areas can sell their produce locally without travelling much. This process eliminates the middlemen and the payment is also made directly to the farmer.”

In the past two months, we have seen farmers’ income go up by at least 20% under this pilot project and they also do not have to worry about the sale of their produce, he added.

At Umarpada alone in last two months, more than 2,000 farmers have sold over 185 metric tonnes (MT) vegetables worth Rs 57 lakh. The major sales came from paddy, papdi (field beans), tur, methi (fenugreek) and dhana (coriander seeds).

The Surat forest department has formed joint forest management committees in the villages and its members sell their produce at the collection centres, which has a tie up with South Gujarat Tribal Farmers’ Productivity Union (SGTFPU) for procurement.

Members get paid for their vegetables based on its grading and quality. The amount is credited in bank accounts within 10 days.

Title: Villagers protest handing over of temple room to private trust
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Surat: People in the tribal-dominated Dharampur town in Valsad have threatened to launch agitation against the administration for allegedly handing over a portion of the historic Kala Ramji temple to a religious trust.

Villagers stated the temple is 150 years old and it was built during the rule of kings of Dharampur. After Independence, Dharampur was acceded to the Indian union and that the houses and temples built by the kings came under the direct purview of the government.

Former president of Dharampur municipality, Kalpesh Kapadia told TOI: “This is a historic temple of Lord Rama and our religious feelings are attached with this temples from decades. We have learnt that the government trust of the temple is planning to hand over a house in the premises to some religious trust.”

Kapadia added, “We have demanded that the house, which was locked for all these years, should be handed to the temple for carrying out religious activities. It is unfair to let out the house to some other trust and hurt the religious feelings of the villagers.”

Kapadia said that on Thursday the villagers will be submitting a memorandum to the Dharampur mamlatdar, who is the head of the temple trust.

Temple priest of Kala Ramji temple, Jaydeep Dave said, “The house in the temple premise was given to a government officer, but it was shut for the last many years. Few days ago, the house was opened and some people were busy cleaning up the room. On inquiring, they said they were from a religious trust and the house had been handed over to them. The villagers are angry over this move and they are planning to agitate”

When contacted, mamlatdar of Dharampur, HA Patel said, “I am away for an official training programme. I will be able to give the details after few days.”

Title: Leaders demand extra cash lanes at Bhatia toll plaza
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Surat: Representatives of farmers and cooperative sector have threatened to launch an agitation against the authorities of the Bhatia toll plaza alleging that they are not providing an extra cash lane that could smoothen the passage of vehicles registered in Surat city and district.

A meeting in this connection was held in Itarwa village in Palsana taluka on Wednesday where the leaders stated that the vehicles registered in the city and district have to wait for their turn in the long serpentine queue at the single cash lane for paying the toll tax. Several representations in this regard have fallen on deaf ears.

Darshan Naik, a member of Surat district panchayat, said, “Vehicles registered in city and district have to pay Rs 20 as one-way tax at Bhatia toll plaza. For this, single cash lane is made operational. Daily more than 10,000 vehicles from the city and district use this toll plaza, resulting in huge traffic jams at the cash lane”

Naik added, “We are demanding that the toll authorities must set-up an extra cash lane to ease the long queues or the vehicles should be allowed to pass through the FASTag lanes by deducting Rs 20 as one-way tax.”

President of Parivartan Trust, Jitu Patel said, “All we want is the easy passage of the vehicles. At present, people have to wait in the serpentine queue for more than an hour”

Mohan Bhatia, cooperative leader said, “It was due to the agitation that the local vehicles were allowed free passage at the Kamrej toll plaza after the FASTag rule was implemented. If the Bhatia toll plaza authorities don’t increase cash lanes, we will have to launch similar stir.”

Title: 7 acquitted for gangster’s murder
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Surat: A local court on Wednesday acquitted gangster Surya Marathi alias Suresh Pawar and his six associates who were accused in the murder of another gang leader Manu Dahya Baraiya. Baraiya was killed in April 2016 in Gotalawadi area in the limits of Katargam police station.

Marathi and his associates Paresh Limbachiya alias Paliyo, Jayesh Paul alias Jay, Vikash Magre alias Ikiya, Jayesh Sosa, Akshay Devre and Amol Zine were acquitted by the court in absence of evidence, defence lawyer said.

During the trial, majority of witnesses turned hostile including the main witness.

Baraiya was shot dead when he was returning home from a barber’s shop at a walking distance from his house on April 17. He was shot from a close distance by two persons on motorcycle.
