The Vijayawada-Gudur 3rd line project has received the secong-highest share in the division, with an allocation of Rs 664 crore. The project was sanctioned in 2015-16 for a distance of 288 km at an estimated cost of Rs 3,246 crore. Work has been taken up simultaneously in three phases between Gudur-Bitragunta, Kovvuru-Bitragunta and Krishna Canal-Kovvuru. A sum of Rs 404 crore has been allotted for the Kazipet-Vijayawada 3rd line project that has an estimated project cost of Rs 1,857 crore.

Officials said the Vijayawada-Kondapalli section for a distance of 17.5 km of the 219-km-long line is nearing completion while the Kondapalli-Errupalem section is under progress. Vijayawada division is also expected to benefit from the construction of bypass lines at Vijayawada (19.5 km), Kazipet (10.65 km), Renigunta (9.6 km), Wadi (7.6 km) and Gooty (3.8 km), for which the Budget has allocated Rs 222 crore.

For Guntur division, Rs 294 crore has been allotted for the Guntur-Guntakal doubling project. Another Rs 6 crore has been allotted for the development of a second entrance at Tirupati railway station.

Title: Two days on, cops yet to nab prime accused
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Allahabad: More than 48 hours after a group of inmates of an Allahabad University (AU) hostel allegedly hurled crude bombs shops and vehicles near Manmohan Park, police are still struggling to find out the whereabouts of the key accused who is currently on the run.

On Tuesday, an FIR was registered against 18 persons and three were arrested over their alleged role in the violence. According to police, the key accused Nitin is native to Ballia. Traders are pressuring police to ensure the arrest of all accused. A Katra-based trader said, “We often see students getting into fights with shopkeepers over issues like reducing price of items. They sometimes even threaten us of dire consequences.”

SSP (Allahabad) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said the police are raiding at the suspected hideouts of the accused. He added that police teams have also been sent to native towns of the accused in hopes of arresting them.

Title: Jagan attack: Accused files discharge plea in NIA court
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Janipalli Srinivasa Rao, the man accused of attempting to kill chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy, on Wednesday filed a discharge petition at a special National Investigation Agency court in Vijayawada. The petition is likely to come up for hearing on Thursday.

Srinivas, in his discharge petition, said he did not commit any offence. He said he was framed to gain sympathy ahead of the general election.

The petitioner said that the prosecution filed a charge sheet under Sections 307 of IPC in addition to Section 3 A(1) of Suppression of Unlawful Acts against the Safety of the Civil Aviation Act, 1982.

Srinivasa said Dr. B Sambasiva Reddy, who examined Jaganmohan, said the wound was simple in nature and not grievous. Srinivasa said accusing him of attempt to murder was a misuse of power.

Title: Forest officials set to trap leopard on a hunting spree
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Erode: Forest officials have set a trap to catch the leopard that has been preying on sheep and goats in villagers near Andhiyur. According to them, three villagers have lost their livestock in the leopard attack so far.

The leopard had been roaming around Periyakodiveri, Dasappagoundanur and Kongarpalayam villages near Andhiyur for the past one week, spreading fear among the villagers, a forest official said. All the three villages are situated close to Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve (STR).

The villagers said they had spotted the leopard even during the day while they were working in sugarcane fields. “I have seen the leopard. I was lucky as it went into the forest as I shouted in fear,” S Govindan, a villager, said.

The villagers had then approached the forest officials, who started to monitor the animal’s movement manually, a week ago. However, they couldn’t trace the leopard. On Wednesday, they set up automatic cameras in 10 main spots in the villages. “We have placed the cameras in areas where the leopard has reportedly roamed around in the past one week,” the forest official said. He said the cameras would capture the image of the animal if that were to pass by them.

The officials have also set up cages with goats inside them at all the three villages to trap the leopard. More than 15 forest personnel have been deployed in the villages to take stock of things round the clock.

Foresters have warned the villagers not to come out of their houses at night to avoid man-animal conflict. “We are hopeful of trapping the leopard in a couple of days,” the official said.

Title: Nashik traders seek rollback of onion export ban
Content: Nashik: Onion exports from China have taken a hit due to the coronavirus outbreak, and Nashik traders want to cash in on the global demand. That is why they want the Centre to lift the ban on onion exports.The Nashik onion exporters also reminded the Union government that the wholesale onion prices have stabilised in India. The average wholesale onion prices have dropped by about 80% in last one-and-a-half months — from Rs 8,625 per quintal on December 16 to Rs 1,800 per quintal now.Bharti Pawar, the BJP MP from Dindori in Nashik district, had written to the Centre last month, urging the government to withdraw the ban. Pawar brought up the matter against during the Budget session in Parliament recently. She said that there has been an increase in the arrival of fresh onion crops across the country, and the wholesale prices are coming down.“Farmers may suffer more losses if the wholesale prices continue to drop due to the arrival of fresh onion crops in the markets. The government needs to withdraw the ban on onion exports to stop a further fall in wholesale prices,” she said.Manoj Jain, an onion trader, said that China is the major onion exporter. However, the recent outbreak has led to a drop in demand for Chinese onions in the international markets. Therefore, India is in a position to capture international markets now.“The average wholesale onion prices have already dropped below Rs 2,000 per quintal. The country needs to end the ban on onion exports. This will be a win-win situation for farmers and also the country — which will earn foreign currencies,” said Jain.On September 29, 2019, the Union ministry of commerce and industries had imposed a ban on onion exports in a bid to check the prices in the domestic market. The average wholesale onion prices had recorded an all-time high of Rs 8,625 per quintal on December 16, 2019. There was a scarcity of onions as 75% of the kharif plantations had been damaged due to incessant rainfall in September and October. But the plantation of the late kharif onions had increased to 45,000 hectare, against average late kharif plantation of 20,000 hectare. The harvest of late kharif onions started picking up from the first half of January.The average wholesale onion prices have now dropped by Rs 450 per quintal to settle Rs 1,800 per quintal on Tuesday at Lasalgaon. On Monday, the price was Rs 2,250 per quintal. The minimum and maximum wholesale onion prices were recorded at Rs 700 and Rs 2,152 per quintal, respectively.

Title: Interim order or master plan, corp to seek clarity from govt
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: As the confusion over interim development order (IDO) and sanctioned master plan (SMP) deepens, the city corporation is set to seek a formal direction from the state government regarding which provision shall be applied while approving projects in the city.

The town planning committee will present a resolution in the next council asking the government to issue a directive in this regard.

Local self-government minister A C Moideen had held two meetings on December 4 and 17 regarding renewal of permit for one building and allocation of permit for another apartment project after the officials denied sanctioning the projects citing that the sites came under green strip area as per sanctioned master plan (SMP) of 1971.

The proceedings of these meetings show that additional chief secretary (ACS) T K Jose reiterated in both meetings that IDO came as a replacement for sanctioned master plan and hence SMP of 1971 is not in effect in the city.

With regards to the renewal of permit in one case, it was ascertained that the site was marked as mixed zone under IDO and hence there was no obstacle for renewal of permit.

The points raised repeatedly by ACS in both meetings upholding IDO as a replacement for SMP however lack clarity, according to officials.

Palayam Rajan, chairman, town planning committee, said that SMP is still being followed in areas which had long been part of city corporation before erstwhile panchayats got added to the city. “We have to get clarity regarding this point from the state government and a resolution will be presented in the council,” said Rajan.

There were also concerns over the validity of IDO, which came into effect in 2017.

As per the town and country planning Act, the IDOs shall cease to operate in the event of failure to publish the master plan within the time limit prescribed for publication of the plan under the Act.

The corporation has to publish the draft master plan within two years from the date of resolution taken to prepare a master plan.

The resolution was taken by corporation in 2017, and going by the provision, IDO would cease to exist by 2019. However, in the case of Thiruvananthapuram, IDO was issued based on published master plan of 2013 and hence the time limit doesn’t apply, said town planning officials.

It is in the wake of these concerns that corporation is gearing up to take up the matter at the government level.

Title: Information on bird species at Wadhwana a finger tap away
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Cap

Vadodara: Knowing which species of the birds are visiting Wadhwana Lake every winters is now just a finger tap away. The forest department has launched a mobile application ‘Birds of Wadhwana’ that has names of the birds species that migrate to Wadhwana in winters before flying out. The app was launched on Sunday that was celebrated as World Wetland Day across the world.

“Bird lovers visiting Wadhwana will be able to upload information about different species of birds that they spot at the lake. Names of the species are already mentioned in the app. Users just have to tick on the name whenever they spot any bird in or around the lake,” said Dr Rahul Bhagwat, bird photographer who has designed the app.

Those using the app will be able to see names of birds that visit the wetland regularly. It already has names of 240 species.

Forest officials said that they are preparing proposal to make Wadhwana a Ramsar site and this app will help them in documenting birds in a better way. “We document the birds that visit Wadhwana. But sometimes we may miss out on some bird species. This app will help us in identifying many more species,” said F A Khatri, range forest officer, Vadodara.

If any bird watcher sees any new species, he or she can add it in the app that will available for people on online store from February 20.

Bhavik Patel, a marine conservationist working with Bombay Natural History Society, who is working with the forest department to convert Wadhwana into Ramsar site said, “The more information we have about birds visiting Wadhwana, the better are our chances of getting Ramsar site nod. We are trying to gather as much information about the lake, migratory birds, fishes and plantations in and around the lake.” BNHS is now conducting a first professional census of birds at the lake site.

Located at about 50km from the city, Wadhwana sees an influx of thousands of local as well as migratory birds between December and February.

Title: Murdered fish vendor fell for friend’s bait: Police
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: It appears fish vendor P Ramesh fell for a bait and walked into a trap laid by his acquaintance. Police investigating the murder of 53-year-old fish vendor, which took place in SR Nagar, found that a ‘honeytrap’ was set up by his friend Srinivas with an intention to extort money from the victim’s family. They took three persons, including two women, into custody.

Prime accused Srinivas, who was taken into custody on Tuesday night, was questioned. Police found that Ramesh and Srinivas became friends some time ago. Srinivas discovered that Ramesh’s family was rich and had reportedly bought a house for Rs 3 crore in Borabanda recently.

Sources privy to the investigation told TOI that Srinivas allegedly hatched a plan to abduct Ramesh and extort money from his family. As part of his plan, Srinivas took two rooms of a house on rent in Jawahar Nagar a month ago and allowed Ramesh to use them.

“On Saturday, Srinivas lured Ramesh to the rented house, promising to arrange a woman for him. After Ramesh reached the house and found no woman there, he got annoyed and argued with Srinivas. The accused attacked Ramesh, who was in an inebriated state, with a hammer and stole the victim’s chain and ring before he locked the place and left it,” the sources said.

Officials said that though Srinivas returned to the room with an intention to dispose of the body, he gave up the idea. He locked the room and started to communicate with Ramesh’s family on WhatsApp with the vendor’s phone from Sunday morning and demanded Rs 90 lakh as ransom for the release of Ramesh.

“The accused negotiated with the victim’s family till 7 pm on Tuesday, claiming that Ramesh was still alive,’’ the investigators said. On Tuesday night, locals discovered foul smell emanating from the house and discovered Ramesh’s body.

When police verified the victim’s phone call data record (CDR), they found the numbers of a few women besides calls made to the accused. All these women and the accused are now in police custody. Apart from Srinivas, the role of a woman was also being probed by police since they discovered she was aware about Ramesh’s murder.

Title: Andhra govt’s three-bottle rule fails to make a dent in liquor sales
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: It seems the deterrents put in place by the government to wean people away from alcohol is not having its desired effect.

While there has been a substantial dip in liquor sales in the state since the new excise policy came into force, the decline has been largely attributed to the non-availability of alcohol.

Across Vijayawada , shopkeepers explained that people are willing to visit the shops several times and stand in queues to purchase more bottles of liquor. Apart from that, adjacent pan shops have been doing a brisk business by selling paper bags for 5 to 10 depending on the demand.

“None of the customers, we found, have relented because of the rule. Many of them return to purchase additional bottles on the same day and it is impossible to keep tabs on such people,” a worker at Andhra Pradesh Beverages Corporation Limited (APBCL) said.

Other tactics used to purchase extra bottles, include taking help of other customers in the queue who are there to buy fewer than three bottles. Consequently, the given the sustained demand, the earning of liquor traders have not dipped. They are rather making a substantial profit.

Speaking to TOI, excise officials said that the new liquor policy while being stringent on belt shops, has pushed up the price of liquor considerably in the black market. A bottle of beer is sold for approximately 220 in the black market that is almost 46% more of the original MRP in belt shops.

“While there are risks involved in running a belt shop, but the high profits are helping them thrive,” a prohibition and excise enforcement official explained.

Title: Filipino who underwent skull surgery goes home
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Ramos Virgilio left for Manila on Tuesday morning

KOLKATA: The 44-year-old Filipino , who underwent a life-saving surgery in the city on January 17 after he suffered a stroke mid-air, has been sent back to his country after post-operation recovery. Doctors at Charnock Hospital, where Ramos Virgilio was treated, said he would require rehabilitation, including physiotherapy, back home .

A Dubai-bound flight from Manila made an emergency landing in Kolkata on January 15 after Virgilio felt uneasiness and developed chest pain mid-air. He was taken to the hospital on VIP Road, where doctors detected haemorrhagic and ischemic stroke. A craniotomy was carried out two days later, as the family took time to give their consent for the surgery. “In case a person suffers stroke on the right side, as did Virgilio, the left side is usually paralyzed. But Virgilio is able on walk his own though his left hand is still weak. His willpower is amazing. We have advised rehabilitation therapy for him at home,” said neurosurgeon Rohit Mishra, who operated on Virgilio. He left on Tuesday morning.

According to sources in the hospital, Vergilo was one of the most cheerful and cooperative patients, having made no fuss during his 20-day stay. After the authorities ensured regular communication with his wife, Loraine, back in Manila, the only thing he asked the doctors frequently was when he could fly home. “We are happy we could send him home in good health,” said Charnock Hospital MD Prashant Sharma. “No payment has been made for his treatment yet, but the insurance agency concerned said the dues would be cleared. We could not hold back the patient for want of payment.”

Title: Absconding murder accused nabbed from Tankara
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Rajkot: One of the two absconding murder accused was nabbed from Tankara in Morbi district on Wednesday. Police said the accused, identified as Raju Mahida along with his brother Kaju Mahida, had allegedly strangled Kailash Mavi (35) on the outskirts of Khakhara Bela village of Padadhari taluka in Rajkot district on January 31. The police are yet to probe the motive behind the murder.

According to the police, Mavi had left home for shopping in Padadhari on January 30 and returned home in the evening along with his sister Atar, her husband Raju and her brother in-law Kaju. After the dinner, Mavi took Raju and Kaju to his farm to sleep.

“The next morning, one Vanrajsinh Jadeja came to Mavi’s house to offer him some labour work. Savita went in search of him to the farm and discovered her husband’s dead body,” said R K Karamta, inspector, Amreli local crime branch. Postmortem report stated that Mavi died due to strangulation and cops booked Raju and Kaju for killing Mavi, based on Savita’s complaint. While Raju was arrested on basis of a tip-off in Tankara, Kaju is still missing.

Title: Woman robbed of chain, man of cellphone
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: Two robbery cases were registered with the Gangapur police station and the Mumbai Naka police stations. While one is a chain-snatching case, the other is related to snatching of a cellphone from a person.

The Mumbai Naka police said that a woman was robbed of her gold chain worth Rs 40,000 in the Deepali Nagar area of Mumbai Naka. The police said that the victim, a 44-year-old resident of the same area, had alighted from a city bus at the Deepali Nagar bus stop at around 7 pm on Tuesday, and was proceeding towards her home.

When she had reached the Laxmi Supermarket area in front of the Sharma Wedding Hall, a biker suddenly stopped in front of her and snatched her gold chain weighing 15 grams. The chain-snatcher then fled the scene. The Mumbai Naka police said they were investigating the case.

Meanwhile, in another case registered with the Gangapur police station, a 21-year-old youth stated that he was robbed of his cellphone, worth Rs 5,000, by two unidentified people on Monday near the Wagh Guruji Hospital.

The youth said that at around 7.30 am on Monday, two unidentified persons riding a scooter approached him and forcibly snatched the cellphone from his hand. They then escaped on their two-wheeler. The police are investigating this case too.

While the police claim to have increased patrolling all over the city and also activating more than 50 chowkeys, criminals have not been deterred from committing crimes. Chain robberies are occurring on almost a daily basis. Cases of robberies of cellphones from the hands of people too are on the rise.

Police officers said the robbery cases would be detected as soon as possible. If some new criminals have cropped up in the city, they would be traced and arrested.

Title: KSRTC reduces number of buses to Bengaluru as many opt for trains
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

MYSURU: The Karnataka State Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC) has cancelled at least 64 schedules out of 472 that operate daily between Mysuru and Bengaluru. These buses were being operated by various divisions of KSRTC.

According to sources, a variety of reasons including increase in the number of trains between the two cities, launch of air service, traffic congestion on National Highway-766 especially after Ramanagar, are the reasons to reduce the number of services.

“The decision to reduce the number of services was taken due to poor occupancy rate on the existing schedules,” said R Ashok Kumar, divisional controller, KSRTC Mysuru rural.

Besides, between Hassan and Bengaluru, 50 schedules have been cut to make the route profitable.

“For one kilometre, the operating cost is Rs 36. We are not getting enough returns due to the poor occupancy rate. So we decided to bring down the number of schedules,” said an official of KSRTC Hassan division.

According to sources, in every three minutes, at least one bus leaves from Mysuru to Bengaluru. “Now the route service has been rationalised. Efforts are being made to bring down the number of buses operated between two cities,” said another official.

According to officials, more and more people are now switching to trains due to the cost factor and traffic congestion. “The train fare is nearly half of the bus fare. Added to this, even the slowest train between Mysuru and Bengaluru takes less than 3 hours to reach Majestic area. But KSRTC buses take an average of 3.5 hours to reach Satellite bus terminus on Mysore Road. And another 30 minutes travel is required to reach the Majestic. So people are shifting from buses to trains,” said an official. “Traffic congestion can be seen in many places including Mandya, Maddur and Chennapatna. Train service is becoming more and more popular,” he added.

Meanwhile, passengers feel that increased frequency of trains between Mysuru and Bengaluru has come as a big relief for them. “The road journey has become a nightmare. If the SWR introduces more trains, it will be helpful to the passengers,” said Raghavendra Adihikar, a bank employee who travels between Mysuru and Bengaluru daily.

Title: 1.25 lakh fish seeds released in four lakes in Erode
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

ERODE: MLA Raja Krishnan released 1.25 lakh fish seeds into four lakes in Andhiyur assembly segment here on Wednesday to help local fishermen make a living.

Fishing activities had completely come to a standstill in the lakes, including Andhiyur and Ketti Samudram, as they had gone dry in the past five years due to severe drought. K R Balachandran, a fisherman, said, “Many of us had gone to neighbouring states such as Karnataka and Kerala for fishing to make a living.”

Some of the fishermen were, meanwhile, forced to work as farm labourers in surrounding villages.

The lakes, however, sprang back into life a bountiful southwest and northeast monsoon last year. Following this, the local fishermen had requested the district administration and the fisheries department to release fish seeds into the lakes.

The fisheries department subsequently issued 1.25 lakh fish seeds worth Rs 2 lakh to the district administration, which invited MLA Raja Krishnan as chief guest to release the same into the lakes.

S Kandasamy, another fisherman, said, “The fish seeds will grow within a few weeks and then fishing activities could be resumed in the lakes.”

Title: Rare IT section invoked to recover tax dues
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Rajkot: The Rajkot income tax department on Wednesday auctioned the personal assets of directors of a company to recover part of the total tax dues of Rs 55 lakh.

Department officials said that the assets were auctioned by invoking section 179 of Income Tax Act, which was used for the first time in Gujarat.

According to officials, Rudra Technocast Pvt Ltd based in Shapar had gone bankrupt and defaulted on tax of Rs 55 lakh in assessment year 2014-15. The company’s assets were attached by various banks over loan default. In order to recover the tax, the income tax department seized the personal properties of company’s three directors.

Tax recovery officer T S Tinawala said, “It’s first time in Gujarat we invoked section 179 of I-T act. This section empowers us to recover the company’s tax due from the personal assets of directors.”

The officials auctioned two two-wheelers and gold ornaments and recovered Rs 1.05 lakh out of total dues of Rs 55 lakh. The department will now attach the immovable property of the directors to recover the remaining amount.

Title: YS Jaganmohan Reddy to open AP’s 1st Disha police station
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy will inaugurate the state’s first Disha police station at Rajahmundry on February 7, director general of police (DGP) Gautam Sawang said here today. He inspected the Disha police station on Wednesday, ahead of the chief minister’s visit.

Speaking to reporters, DGP Sawang said that the station was being set up for the protection of women. He said that 18 such police stations will be set up in the state, of which five will be set up in urban police districts. He said that 2020 was going to be declared “women protection year”.

He explained that as per the Disha Act , a case will be investigated within a week and the trial would be completed within three weeks. Sawang said that the Disha police stations will be fully staffed and special labs would also be set up at these stations.

The DGP added that the CM would be releasing a special app for women at Adikavi Nannaya University on February 7.

Title: VHP leaders welcome govt move on Ram temple trust
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Allahabad: Welcoming the Union government’s announcement about the constitution of a trust for the construction of a Ram temple in Ayodhya, Vishwa Hindu Parishad ( VHP ) members on Wednesday said that seers associated with the Ram Janmabhoomi movement since 1984 should also be included in the panel.

The leaders said they are hoping that the trust would accept VHP‘s model for the Ram temple.

Akhil Bharatiya Akhara Parishad (ABAP) president Narendra Giri said, “The day is not far when a grand Ram temple would finally be built in Ayodhya.”

Talking about the demands of various outfits to be included in the trust, Giri said, “While it’s the Union government’s visheshaadhikar (special right) to appoint the members of the trust, Ramjanambhoomi Nyas chief and head of Mani Ram Das ki Chavni Mahant Nritya Gopal Das should made be the chairman of the trust.” He also said that heir of Ramchandra Paranhans should also be included in the trust.

VHP spokesman Ashwani Mishra said that the organisation’s volunteers are happy with the announcement and said that seers who have been raising their voice for the construction of a Ram temple in Ayodhya since 1984 should be included in the trust.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Car plunges into Kannauj canal, five killed
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

According to officials, nine people were travelling in the car at the time of the accident

KANPUR: Five members of a family, including two women and three children, were killed, three others suffered critical injuries while a child went missing when the car they were travelling in fell into a canal in Chatruapur village under Umarda block in Kannauj in the early hours of Wednesday.

Kannauj DM Ravindra Singh and SP Amrendra Pratap Singh, along with other officials, reached to the spot and supervised the rescue operation.

According to officials, nine people were travelling in the car at the time of the accident .

"The accident occured on Umarda-Indergarh road around 9 am. Priya (27), Mohini (23), Shubhi (2), Lado (5) and Krishna (10) died on the spot when the car lost control and fell into the Gang canal," said police.

"While a child named Harsh is missing, three others who sustained critical injuries in the accident are undergoing treatment at Tirwa Medical College,” police added.

The victims, residents of Miruan Madha village in Thatia town of the district, were on their way to Chhibramau to attend a pre-marriage ritual.

"Rescue operation is under way in the Gang canal to trace the missing child," said the SP.

Police have registered a case and ordered investigations to ascertain reasons behind the accident.

“Prima facie, the occupants died due to drowning as the canal is deep. We are awaiting the postmortem report to ascertain the exact cause of the death,” said a police official privy to the investigation.

“A crane was deployed to pull out the vehicle and locate the missing child,” he added. Sujit, resident of a nearby village, said he rushed to the spot immediately after he learnt about the incident, but did not find any policemen there. “Later, Police Response Vehicle-112 reached the spot, but the police team did not take rescue measures immediately,” he added.

Title: DMK man’s murder: Four surrender in court
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

ERODE: A four-member gang has surrendered before a local court in connection with the murder case of DMK youth wing west zonal deputy organizer Mansoor Ali, 49, who was hacked to death in Hosur early this month. All the four have been lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison under judicial custody.

A court source identified the accused as Santhosh Kumar, 22, of Muthuganapalli, G Gajendran, 22, of Santhi Nagar, D Govindaraj, 23, of Denkanikottai, C Yashwanth Kumar, 23, of Marudhandapalli.

The source said Mansoor Ali was on an evening walk when he was hacked by the gang on a playground in Hosur on February 2. “After committing the crime, they went into hiding.”

The Hosur town police registered a case and initiated inquiry. Meanwhile, the four surrendered before judicial magistrate no-1 K S Shabeena, of Kodumudi sub-court, on Tuesday evening. “They also confessed to the crime and said they murdered the DMK functionary over a previous enmity,” the court official said. The magistrate subsequently remanded them in judicial custody the same night.

Title: More funds allocated for railway projects in SWR division
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

Title: Auto drivers charging high fares to lose licence
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Vadodara: Next time, if the autowala refuses to ferry you or demands higher fare, ring up the police.

In its bid to crack down on erring auto drivers, the police decided to act against such auto driver and may even suspend driving licenses of the guilty. The drive started near the railway station and state transport bus depot in Sayajigunj. More than 60,000 autos ply in the city regularly, according to RTO data.

“We had been getting a lot of complaints from citizens against rude auto drivers, with most complaints about them refusing to ferry passengers by meter fare, especially at night. The auto drivers make excuses that their meter is not working and then demand an exorbitant amount,” said Anupam Singh Gahlaut, city police commissioner.

Gahlaut said that this prompted the police to begin a drive against such erring drivers who loot passengers. Cops will patrol the areas around railway station and keep an eye on such incidents. If any passenger is being over charged, he or she can approach the cops and complain. “We will investigate the incident,” Gahlaut told TOI, adding that if found guilty, his driving license would be suspended and also cancel the vehicle’s registration.

At night, passengers do not have too many options to ride and hence auto drivers take advantage of it. “We had called a meeting of auto drivers before starting the drive. They were explained the rules and also warned against charging fares higher than stipulated from passengers. The auto drivers agreed to charge passengers by the meter,” Gahlaut added.

The police has begun the drive at four spots including railway station’s entry and exit, Kadak Bazaar and ST depot. In the coming days, the drive will be extended to other busy areas of the city. Senior police officials said that these four spots were chosen as they got most complaints from there.

—

Photo Quotes: (given to Milap/PP)

Nidhi Sharma, homemaker

Over the last few years, many auto drivers in the city have stopped accepting meter fares. They always say that the meter is not working. I hope the police drive against such drivers helps passengers, especially at night.

Ananda Joshi, HR professional

Many auto drivers near the railway station simply refuse passengers who want to pay by the meter, or even those that want to travel a short distance. If the destination is far off, they quote an exorbitant amount. Strict action should be taken against such drivers to set an example.

Harish Rajput, auto driver

If the passenger insists on meter fare, the auto driver should agree. However, many a time even passengers haggle for a lumpsum amount. But those auto drivers who fleece passengers at night need to be dealt with firmly.

————————

BOX:

Cops get 10 complaints daily

The police control room had been getting 8 to 10 complaints of exorbitant fares daily on an average about auto drivers overcharging them. Hence, a few days ago city police commissioner decided to act against errant drivers by taking strict measures against them.

—

Team of 12 cops formed

The police department has formed a special team of 12 cops including a police sub-inspector. The team headed by a police inspector will patrol areas around railway station and ST depot. It will take complaints on the spot and investigate the matter.

Title: Traffic on Garware flyover stopped for 2 hours after truck-oil tanker collision sparks fire
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Nashik: The city police and the fire brigade department blocked vehicular movement on the Mumbai-Agra highway flyover , near the Garware Point, for nearly two hours following a major accident on Wednesday morning. The traffic was had to be diverted on the twin service roads along the highway.

A collision between a truck and a tanker carrying inflammable material had sparked a fire in the truck driver’s cabin at around 9.30 am. The brigade personnel had to douse the fire using foam and water and then cool down the oil tanker.

A collision had taken place at the very beginning of the flyover on Mumbai-Agra highway, near the Garware point. The oil tanker driver had entered the lane on the right and had a side collision with the open truck. The police said that the tanker’s rear hit the truck driver’s cabin from the side. This sparked a fire in the truck’s cabin. The police said that the truck driver and cleaner had to jump out of the vehicle.

The police said that soon after the fire broke out, other commuters on the highway called up the fire department and the police. Officials of the Cidco fire station said they got a call at 9.50 pm. Within 6 minutes, supervisor Ravindra Laad and firemen Balasaheb Lad and Avinash Sonawane reached the accident spot and began dousing the fire. The fire officials said that apart from dousing the fire, they also had to stop the dripping oil from the tanker. Further, since the oil tanker had heated up, it also had to be cooled down.

PI Kumar Chaudhary of the Ambad police station said, the oil from the tanker was dripping and the bodies of the two vehicles were also tangled with each another. That is why vehicular traffic on the flyover had to be stopped on a stretch of approximately 250 metre. Chaudhary said vehicles on both the ends of the flyover were stopped to prevent any untoward incident. After the tangled vehicles were separated with the help of a crane, the stretch was thrown open. The PI said no one was injured in the accident.

Title: Truck kills IT employee in New Town
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: A techie, who worked with an IT solutions company in Sector V, died after a truck rammed into his bike on the service road at Kadampukur crossing near Eco Park police station. The deceased, Avinash Kumar Sahu from Sundargarh district in Odisha, lived in a PG accommodation in Salt Lake .

“A local alerted us about the accident. When we reached the spot, the victim was alive. We put him inside an ambulance, but he succumbed to his injuries on the way to the hospital,” said a police officer.

One of the colleagues of the victim lodged a complaint against the truck driver, who was arrested. “The CCTV footage showed that the victim was wearing a helmet and there was no fault on his part. The truck was coming at a high speed and hit the biker. We have impounded the vehicle,” said the officer.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Three get life term for raping girl, posting video
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

Title: Uttar Pradesh: BPharma student ends life by shooting self
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: A 21-year-old student committed suicide allegedly by shooting himself at his house in Kamlapur locality under Sajeti police station of the district on late Tuesday night. Harshit Sachan, a B.Pharma student at a local institute, was reportedly under depression.

According to police, Harshit took the extreme step late on Tuesday night after dinner. “He and his mother were alone at the house at the time of the incident,” said Quan Kheda police outpost in-charge Avneesh Yadav. No suicide note was recovered from the spot, he added.

On coming across gunshot sound, Harshit’s mother Gita rushed to his room and found him lying in a pool of blood. On hearing her shrieks, his neighbours reached the spot and took Harshit to a nearby Community Health Centre where doctors at the emergency pronounced him dead on arrival. The police arrived at the CHC and shifted the body to morgue for autopsy, Yadav said.

“Harshit’s family members stated that after the death of his father, Ramakant Sachan, who had passed away a few years ago, Harshit was reeling under depression since then. They, however, feigned ignorance as to what led to sudden provocation prompting him to take such an extreme step. Investigations are underway in this regard,” said the police outpost in-charge.

Title: Explain shift of vigilance office to Kurnool, HC directs Andhra govt
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The Andhra Pradesh high court on Wednesday questioned the state government’s decision to relocate the offices of vigilance commissioner and commissionerate of inquiries to Kurnool.

The bench headed by Chief Justice J K Maheswari and Justice Ninala Jayasurya asked advocate-general S Sriram to file an affidavit stating the reasons that necessitated the decision.

Kuramanchi Indraneel Babu, counsel for petitioners, said the government decision was illegal. The HC expressed displeasure to the advocate representing the petitioners for the failure to produce necessary documents. The HC said oral arguments were not sufficient to substantiate the case.

The HC asked the petitioners how is AP Capital Region Development Authority involved in the relocation of the offices. The government should explain the procedure followed while shifting the offices from one place to another, said the HC.

The case has been posted for further hearing to February 11. The AG on Tuesday told the HC the government decided to relocate offices to Kurnool due to space constraints.

Title: 14 peafowls found dead on farmland in Erode
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

ERODE: Fourteen peafowls were found dead under suspicious circumstances on an agricultural field at Ellamadai village near Gobichettipalayam in Erode district on Wednesday.

The carcasses of nine male and five female birds were spotted by villagers, who alerted the forest department.

Officials suspect that farmers could have killed the peafowls after they damaged their crops. They buried the carcasses after postmortem. “A case has been registered under various sections of the Wildlife Protection Act. We have collected samples from the carcasses for further medical examinations. If there was any foul play, miscreants would be found and booked under the Indian Penal Code and the Wildlife Protection Act,” a forest officer said.

Title: Two more arrested in panchayat president’s murder in Erode
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

ERODE: Two more accused in the murder case of Sankarampalayam panchayat president were arrested on Wednesday. With this, police have nabbed five accused in the case. However, the search for the mastermind of the crime is still on.

An investigation officer identified the arrested as M Siva, 24, and Surya alias M Muthumari, both residents of Madurai.

The panchayat president, S Radhakrishnan alias Chinna Thangam, 48, of Unjakkadu Thottam near Velli Tirupur in Andhiyur taluk, was hacked to death by a five-member gang on February 3.

The Velli Tirupur police had earlier arrested three of the gang members. “Siva and Surya were on the run. We got a tip about their hideout and arrested them today (Wednesday). They have been lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison under judicial custody,” the officer said.

He said they had launched a manhunt for the mastermind of the crime, Arvind, who hired the five-member gang to avenge the murder of his father, who was killed by Radhakrishnan in 2013. That case is still pending with the Erode district court.

“Aravind, who is working with a private company in Chennai, have been missing since February 3. He had paid the gang Rs 3.5 lakh to murder Radhakrishnan,” the officer said.

The other arrested in the case are Saravanan, 26, Balamurugan, 26 and Rajesh 24, all residents of Pallavaram in Chennai.

Title: Road accidents in Chennai: When three is a crowd and an invitation to disaster
Content:
Nandanam

CHENNAI: “Life would have been different had I stopped her that day,” said K Sripal. He has said this several times since March 11, 2018, when his wife S Kavitha died in an accident near the Koyambedu wholesale market. Kavitha was riding with her two children.Since it was a Sunday, Kavitha had gone to the market with her two sons -- Naman and Meeth. It was not the first time she was riding the two-wheeler with her sons. But on that fateful day, Kavitha lost balance when an autorickshaw hit the scooter. She suffered head injuries and died on her way to the hospital. Her sons survived the accident but live with the trauma of having watched their mother die.Kavitha’s case is not a rare incident in the city. Every day, hundreds of parents take more than one child on a two-wheeler either to drop them in schools or to pick them up. In many cases, accidents are fatal when riders don’t wear helmets. But instead of booking violators, the traffic police empathise with the parents. They are not booked for breaking the rule and endangering the lives of children.“That’s not true,” said a senior city traffic police official pointing out data on traffic fines. More than 40,000 people were penalised in 2019 for triple riding in Chennai. “We have stepped up our vigil. There were just 10,400 cases in 2018,” the officer said.But on most occasions, cases were booked when the offenders were stopped for jumping signals or speeding, he said. “When parents plead with police that they have to drop kids in school, they are let off,” he said.Parents say they are forced to take their children on two-wheelers because other options are either expensive or unsafe or unavailable. “My son’s school is demanding Rs 2,000 a month as bus fee. I can’t send my child alone in public transport. Autos are better option but they often take too many children and are unreliable. The best option for me is to drop my kids on my way to office,” said T Santhosh, a resident of Madipakkam .Renga Prasad, a transportation activist from Satta Panchayat Iyakkam, said there should be no compromise on safety. Load tests on two-wheelers by vehicle manufacturers conclude that the maximum permissible load per ride is 140kg to 180 kg. “The vehicle will become unstable if the load exceeds 200kg. The rider’s position gets changed making it difficult to apply brakes with the foot or change gears,” he said.But what makes deaths and injuries a double whammy for the victims family is that they don’t receive entire compensation. Kin of Ganeshan and Ragu, bikers who died in an accident at Sathyamangalam , were due a compensation of Rs 1.17 lakh. But the local accident claims tribunal ordered only 50% of compensation as there were three men on the bike at the time of the accident. Last May, the Madras HC upheld the order saying the remaining compensation will be detected towards their “contributory negligence”.Advocate V S Suresh Kumar said that in most instances, a case is booked against the bigger vehicle for insurance benefits but 10% to 50% of the compensation is deducted if the chargesheet mentions triple riding.“Even if the driver of the bigger vehicle was at fault, criminal charges against him are dropped because counsel argue that the bike was unstable as there were three riders,” he said.

Title: Bhukhi restoration begins with cleanliness drive
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Cap

Vadodara: The first step towards restoration of the Bhukhi stream, otherwise known as the Bhukhi Nullah, began on Wednesday.

The department of environmental studies of M S University in collaboration with the faculty of science student association started the ‘Bhukhi kaans and bank cleaning initiative’ in order to clean up 2.82km of the non-perennial tributary of Vishwamitri river that passes through its main campus.

The current initiative is to beautify the segment flowing through science faculty premises. “There will be many components in the restoration project but solid waste has to be removed first,” said head of the Department of Environmental Studies, Prof Kauresh Vachhrajani.

“With the help of students of our department and the faculty association, we have taken the small step to remove solid waste deposited on the banks of the stretch adjacent to the faculty of science,” he said.

Vachhrajani further said that the next step will involve all other departments and faculties for which awareness has already been created. “Also, all students and teachers can clean any solid waste that is seen deposited on the periphery. The university’s construction department will have to clean the stream,” he said.

Nearly 200 students wearing protective gear took part in the initiative and collected nearly two tractors full of plastic, thermocol sheets, packaging materials and other solid waste.

Around 15 students from the department will analyse the overall biodiversity of the stretch including its plant, microbes, water quality, soil quality and sources of soil and wet waste that is dumped in Bhukhi nullah as part of their dissertation studies.

Once the analysis is completed, with the support of field experts and with the Vadodara Municipal Corporation, a plan to upgrade the nullah will be drawn up.

Title: Descendent of Pakistan migrant moves Gujarat high court for entry in records
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: A descendent of migrants from Pakistan moved the Gujarat high court demanding that his name be entered into revenue records for the piece of land allotted to his forefathers by the Gujarat government in 1966.

Justice Biren Vaishnav asked the petitioner to raise the issue before the Banaskantha additional collector, who has been ordered to take a decision in this regard.

The petition was filed by 32-year-old Dinesh Bhill, who is from Kherola village of Lakhni taluka in the border district of Banaskantha. He said his forefathers and others had migrated from Karachi in 1947 and settled in the north Gujarat district.

In 1966, 36 farmers including Bhill’s forebearer were granted agricultural land by the state revenue department under the head of ‘Migrant and Unsheltered’. For over 50 years, the families possessed the land. Based on the government’s decision, the Banaskantha district collector passed an order allotting 316 acres of land to 36 farmers as ‘New Tenure’ land on permanent basis.

In March 1974, a deputy collector passed an order cancelling the allotment on the grounds of breach of conditions as the land holders did not cultivate the land. The farmers appealed against this order and the district collector quashed the cancellation in July 1974.

Bhil submitted that his forebearer was allotted 7 acres and he is cultivating the land parcel at present. After the district collector restored the land to his forebearer, the revenue authorities have not mutated his name in the revenue records for this piece of land.

Bhil cited various government resolutions mandating revenue officials to enter names in revenue records, and argued that despite representations, the authorities have not entered his name in revenue records.

Title: Rs 1.5L worth valuables stolen from Karelibaug
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Vadodara: A dinner at a restaurant on Tuesday cost Rs 1.5 lakh to a family living in in Karelibaug.

While Kamlesh Joshi was enjoying dinner with his family, burglars made merry at his house at Sundervan Duplex in Karelibaug sometime between 7. 30 pm and 9.30 pm, decamping with valuables worth Rs1.5 lakh.

Joshi, a share broker, was shocked to find that the backdoor of his house was open and all valuables in his bedroom were lying scattered on the bed. Realizing that his house had been burgled, Joshi informed Karelibaug police about the theft.

In his complaint, Joshi, stated that burglars entered the house by breaking the lock of the backdoor and also broke the safe in the bedroom and stole jewellery including a diamond necklace and earrings worth Rs 1.1 lakh, 120 Canadian dollars, three imported perfume bottles, a mobile phone and a wristwatch.

Title: Congress leader stokes row with Savarkar remark
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Allahabad: Congress Sewa Dal (CSD) chief organiser Lalji Desai raked fresh controversy on Wednesday when he said that it wasn’t easy to decide if Veer Savarkar was indeed brave or not. CSD is one of Indian National Congress’ frontal organisations.

In Allahabad to attend CSD’s training camp at the Magh Mela ground on Wednesday, Desai said, “There were many people who fought a pitched battle against the British during the freedom struggle, but never surrendered before the government.”

“As far as Vinayak Damodar Savarkar is concerned, he had sought an apology from the British at least 11 times and nine of those were in written. The evidence of the correspondence is still available.”

He also questioned when high school teachers were being salaries in the range of Rs 7 to 12 during the British rule, why were they paying a monthly pension of Rs 60 to Savarkar.

Slamming Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) over their ideologies, Desai said, “Vinayak Damodar Savarkar was responsible for the partition of the country as he was the first person to suggest the two nation-theory.”

He also said that the organisation would soon release a 16–page booklet on Savarkar, which would contain several lesser-known facts about the right-wing leader along with proof.

He also said that the book would be distributed across the city.

Title: AP Capital News: Seek fresh mandate, Chandrababu Naidu dares YS Jaganmohan Reddy
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Chandrababu Naidu

VIJAYAWADA: Leader of opposition N Chandrababu Naidu has dared chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy to seek fresh mandate before implementing the three capital cities proposal. He said that he would retire from active politics if people supported the three capitals proposal.

Naidu visited farmers at Thulluru on Wednesday and extended his support to them.

“No force on the earth could move the capital out of Amaravati . It was decided as the capital and people donated Rs 57 crore for the capital. The money is in APCRDA account,” Naidu said.

He added that Amaravati has become a global name in the last five years. “I had several dreams for Amaravati. I had a dream for every city in the state. But, this man, Jaganmohan Reddy, is destroying everything. He is a destroyer and not a dreamer,” Naidu said.

Claiming that AP was ahead of other states in the country in the last five years, the former chief minister regretted that the state is going back on every front. “This is reverse governance. He (Jagan) has no experience and no plans to develop the State. His party is a reverse party,” the TDP chief said.

Naidu asked the farmers of Amaravati to continue their fight against the three capital cities proposal. He told them their sacrifice of giving 33,000 acres of land for the capital would not go waste. “The world is aware of your contribution. Only the CM is not able to understand your sacrifice,” he said.

Naidu asked the chief minister to prove insider trade charges against TDP leaders. “We are ready to cooperate with the government. Why are you not proving the charges and not taking action,” he asked the chief minister.

Title: No nod for anti-CAA protest yet
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Vadodara: Police are yet to lodge a formal complaint in the anti-CAA protests held in Tandalja area without permission last week.

The crime branch had summoned a couple of community leaders some days ago after the dharna but no one claimed responsibility for the dharna. On Monday, a formal application asking for permission for the protests was made.

Police haven’t granted permission for the dharna yet but every evening, a few hundred locals, mostly women from Tandalja area, gather at the plot near Saudagar Park.

“It is a political stunt and some people want to instigate the locals. We have talked with them and also explained CAA to the locals. As of now, we aren’t taking any step as we don’t want to create trouble,” said a police official.

Residents of Saudagar Park and adjacent areas had sat on dharna against CAA last week. On Sunday, the tent used by the protesters was removed by the supplier.

Title: GHMC shakes up its admin setup
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

HYDERABAD: The Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) on Wednesday transferred some officers and gave additional responsibilities to some others.

Additional director, MA&UD department, N Ravi Kiran has been posted as zonal commissioner of Serilingampally, while additional commissioner (sanitation & transport) Upender Reddy was named zonal commissioner of LB Nagar and IAS officer P Pravinya was posted as zonal commissioner of Khairtabad.

Also, IAS officers Priyanka Ala has been posted as additional commissioner (revenue, legal & trade Licence), PS Rahul Raj as additional commissioner (sanitation, C&D waste management, entomology, veterinary), Badhavath Santhosh as additional commissioner (health, registration of births and deaths, Annapurna mid-day meals, basti dhavakhanas & construction of new public toilets).

IPS officer Viswajit Kampati, director, enforcement, vigilance and disaster management (EV&DM), has been entrusted with additional responsibilities of overseeing transport, advertisement and protection of lakes, while J Shankaraiah, additional commissioner, (Electrical), has also been entrusted with subjects of urban community development . Similarly; Jayaraj Kennedy, additional commissioner (finance & elections), has also been entrusted with the subjects of informatlon technology & CSR, while V Krishna, diretor, urban forestry, would also look after the subjects of urban bio-diversity until further orders.

Title: Rajkot: Rare I-T section used to recover dues
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: The Rajkot income tax department on Wednesday auctioned the personal assets of directors of a company to recover part of the total tax dues of Rs 55 lakh.

Department officials said that the assets were auctioned by invoking section 179 of Income Tax Act, which was used for the first time in Gujarat .

According to officials, Rudra Technocast Pvt Ltd based in Shapar had gone bankrupt and defaulted on tax of Rs 55 lakh in assessment year 2014-15. The company’s assets were attached by various banks over loan default. In order to recover the tax, the income tax department seized the personal properties of company’s three directors.

Tax recovery officer T S Tinawala said, “It’s first time in Gujarat we invoked section 179 of I-T act. This section empowers us to recover the company’s tax due from the personal assets of directors.”

The officials auctioned two two-wheelers and gold ornaments and recovered Rs 1.05 lakh out of the total dues of Rs 55 lakh it had to collect.

The department will now attach the immovable property of the directors to recover the remaining amount.

Title: Chennai: Where bikers ride on footpaths
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Sterling Road

CHENNAI: Walking may be the most common form of commuting, but pedestrians are the second-most vulnerable commuter group. A total of 1,254 pedestrians, including 291 in Chennai (the second highest in the country), were knocked down by speeding vehicles in 2018.

While the absence of pavements forces pedestrians to jostle for space on the city’s busy carriageway and risk getting hit by vehicles, two-wheeler users put them in danger by riding down footpaths to bypass traffic jams. Though the practice is common on Nelson Manickam Road, Chamiers Road, Old Mahabalipuram Road and in Vadapalani, the traffic police do little to stop and penalize errant motorists.

“Many riders don’t realise that they are violating the law. Utter lack of driving sense is the prime reason for this,” said V Santhanam, a civic activist from Chromepet who has been campaigning for safe pedestrian commute over a decade. Blaming the corporation for designing footpaths that “invite bikes”, Santhanam said, “The height of pavements is so low that bikes can easily get onto them and in due course the edges of a footpath become a slope for bikes.”

But a Greater Chennai Corporation official said bollards are placed on “vulnerable stretches” to prevent bikes from entering platforms but still riders enter through gaps kept for differently abled people. The gap between two bollards in roughly two feet (0.6m) but for wheelchair access it is around three feet (0.9m), he said.

Urban experts said if walking near bus stops and railway stations became unsafe, fewer people will take public transport in the future that will result in more private vehicles on the road.

Title: Second offence lodged against robbers who tried to run over cops chasing
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Two PCR vans were damaged in the 10-km chase on Tuesday

Vadodara: An offence of dacoity was registered in connection with the robbery of betel nuts and dry fruits from a container truck following which a dramatic police chase had taken place on national highway-48 on Tuesday.

The second offence was registered on Wednesday based on the complaint by the driver of the container truck from which the valuables were robbed by around a dozen robbers.

In his complaint, Ramesh Pujar has stated that the robbers broke open the container’s lock and started siphoning off bags of dry fruits and betel nuts when he sleeping in the driver’s cabin after parking the truck in the bay on the highway. The stolen goods have been valued at Rs 8.7 lakh.

The police have already sent a team of cops to a godown in Surat where Pujar had delivered a part of the goods before proceeding towards Ahmedabad on February 3. “Our team will find out the name and details of the men who had unloaded the goods in Surat in case anyone from among them have been involved or passed on the information to the robbers,” said a police official.

Police are also scanning CCTV footage of four toll plazas where the container truck had stopped after entering Gujarat. The dry fruits and betel nuts were dispatched in the container truck from Karnataka. Police said that the truck had stopped at toll plazas in Navsari, Kamrej in Surat, Bharuch and Karjan. “The footage can give us some lead if the robbers were following them or just chanced upon the truck near Jambuva,” the police official said.

The robbers were stopped by a PCR van in the wee hours of Tuesday when they were siphoning off the goods. They, however, managed to flee on seeing the cops but were chased for several kilometres by two PCR vans on the highway. During the chase, the two police vehicles were damaged as the robbers rammed their truck with the two cars and also pelted stones at the cops.

Title: YS Jaganmohan Reddy: Andhra Pradesh govt cash-strapped; YS Jaganmohan Reddy justifies 3-capital decision
Content:
Jaganmohan Reddy

VIJAYAWADA: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy on Wednesday justified his plan to decentralize administration and establish three capitals by saying that it was the only practical approach to develop the state. He said he had chosen Visakhapatnam as the capital city because it has all the infrastructure and holds the potential to compete with big cities in south India. He, however, said Amaravati will continue to be the legislative `capital’.Speaking at a private programme here on Wednesday, the chief minister said Amaravati would require Rs 1.09 lakh crore for basic infrastructure while the government has no money to invest.“We need Rs 1.09 lakh crore to invest in Amaravati while the state’s capacity is only Rs 5,000 crore,” he said and wanted to know what any head of the family or head of the state would do with limited sources.“Is it justified to invest Rs 1.09 lakh crore in one place and get nothing in return or spend a few crore on a developed city like Visakhapatnam and compete with the neighboring Hyderabad, Chennai and Bengaluru,” the CM asked.“Amaravati is neither close to Vijayawada nor Guntur. There is not even a single approach double lane road to Amaravati. With no infrastructure, no roads and no money, when will we be able to compete with Hyderabad or Bengaluru or Chennai,” he asked.“The Centre had given Rs 1,500 crore. There is another Rs 1.09 crore to provide basic infrastructure in 55,000 acres of land. The previous government had spent Rs 5,677 crore on Amaravati. How many years will it take at this rate to develop a city to compete with Hyderabad,” he asked.He justified his decision to have three capitals in the three regions and claimed the experiment would help in the development of the three regions. “It is a conscious decision taken to distribute the fruits of development to the three regions. If we don’t take such decisions, the future generations will not excuse us,” the chief minister said.On the introduction of English medium in government schools, the chief minister said the introduction of English medium was a revolutionary step in the 21st century.“These days, every parent is dreaming of giving English medium education to the child. Some parents are sending their children to private schools by paying more, while government schools are empty. The idea is to upgrade the schools to meet the needs of society and dreams of parents,” the chief minister said.He, however, said that the government had made Telugu a compulsory subject in all schools, including private ones, where Telugu is not a subject now. He reiterated his government’s commitment to give English medium education to children and protect Telugu by making it compulsory in all schools.

Title: One-way traffic movement on service roads near Pathardi Phata to ease congestion
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The one-way traffic rule will be in effect until the police come up with other notifications regarding the tra... Read More

NASHIK: After setting things in place for a smoother flow of traffic at the Dwarka junction on the Mumbai-Agra highway, the city police on Wednesday converted the twin service roads along the highway into one-ways near the Pathardi Phata to ease congestion at that junction.

The police said the Pathardi Phata junction also sees chaotic traffic situations during the morning and evening hours. This is because it is flanked by large residential and commercial complexes on all sides. Moreover, the Ambad industrial area is also along the junction. During the morning and evening hours, there is a huge rush of industrial workers and employees to and from their workplaces. Eight roads come together at the Pathardi Phata junction. The two-way traffic along the service roads adds to the chaos.

Over the past one-and-a-half decades, a large number of residential and commercial areas have come up on either side of the highway. According to the police, the situation becomes especially chaotic when the evening shift of the industries in Satpur and Ambad MIDCs get over and people return home.

That is why the police have made the service road from the Pathardi Phata junction (Hotel Santosh) to the underpass opposite hotel Taj a one-way towards Mumbai side. Similarly, the service road from the underpass till Pathardi Phata junction has also become a one-way for vehicles going towards the junction from the Mumbai side.

The one-way traffic rule will be in effect until the police come up with other notifications regarding the traffic at the junction. Police officials said the slew of measures taken by the police at Dwarka junction have borne results. The one-way system on the service roads at Pathardi Phata would also resolve the problem here.

Title: Gujarat: Suspected man-eater lioness caged with cubs
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Foresters had to tranquilize the big cat after she jumped the cage

RAJKOT: The lioness which is suspected to have killed the five-year-old boy near Rajula on Tuesday has been captured by the forest department at around midnight of Tuesday. The cubs are also with the lioness and the trio have been sent to a local animal rescue centre for further tests.

According to forest department officials, the lioness was captured at the same place where it had allegedly dragged the child. There was a team of 20 officials engaged in the capture activity. After being caged, the lioness managed to jump out of the ring cage, but being a mother of two cubs she couldn’t desert her offsprings who were inside the cage. The officials then tranquilized the animal with the help of a veterinary doctor.

Deputy conservator of forest, Shetrunji range, Sandeep Kumar said, “We will do scat analysis and other tests to confirm that this is the same lioness that had killed and also partly fed on the little boy.”

Kishor Devipujak, 5, was attacked by the lioness in the wee hours of Tuesday while he was sleeping in the open outside his hut in a farm on the railway track opposite Pipavav port. The lioness attacked the kid and dragged him for 3km before partially feeding on the body.

The incident happened sometime between 4am and 5am, 12 km from Rajula town. Kishore was sleeping in the open outside his hut in the farm, which is located along side a railway track that leads to the port. His parents work as farm labourers.

Forest officials suspect that the lioness may mistaken the boy to be some prey as she had killed a goat at the same place around two months ago. She was familiar with the people living around and couldn’t have been a man-eater.

Title: Dist farmers oppose land pooling for housing project
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The ongoing land pooling process initiated by district officials is being met with opposition from farmers in various villages. The state government about 10 days ago released order no. 72 to pool 6,116 acres of land spread across 10 mandals of Visakhapatnam district to be distributed to the homeless and facilitate housing projects for weaker sections of the society.

Consequently, officials have started conducting village-level meetings, starting from January 29, to apprise farmers about the pooling initiative and get their nod. Even though some farmers are coming forward to part with their land, several farmers opposed the proposals during the meetings being conducted for the last one week. Even on Wednesday, the farmers of Nanginarapadu in Sabbavaram village unanimously resolved against the land pooling. Same was the situation in Sampathipuram in Anakapalli mandal on Wednesday where the farmers obstructed the meeting proceedings against the pooling. These 6,100 acre lands are primarily government lands and are enjoyed by the assignees and other tenants. As per the government order, the assignees will get 900 square yards developed land per an acre. But the encroachers or the enjoyers without any documents would only get 450 square yards or 250 square yards based on the duration of the possession of the land.

Speaking to ToI, K Ramana Rao, a farmer of Nidigattu village, said that they could eke out a bare living by cultivating the land for the last two decades. “We will be deprived of livelihood once the land is taken over by the government in the pooling. So that we have decided to fight against the pooling,” said Ramana Rao.

CPM state secretariat member Ch Narasinga Rao said that the poor peasants have been appealing to the government for years to issue them pattas for the lands under their possession for the last 20 years. “But the state government never did so in the name of urban agglomeration. Even after cultivating these lands for the last two to three decades, the poor peasants are now named as encroachers in the government order. The GO No 294 clearly mentioned that the arable land should not be a part of land pooling. But the state government skirted its own order and issued GO No 72 for the pooling. We demand the government to immediately revoke the order issued for pooling,” said Narasinga Rao.

However, the ruling YSRCP claim that the land pooling is being done only for distribution of housing sites to the homeless. YSRCP official spokesperson and Anakapalli MLA Gudivada Amarnath said that every cent of the pooled land will only go the weaker sections.

“The state government wants to make sure there is no homeless person in Andhra Pradesh. The pooled will only be distributed to eligible beneficiaries,” said Amarnath.

Title: Rayagada division allocated Rs 3 crore
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Union Budget has allocated Rs 3 crore this year for the new Rayagada division, which is part of a project for the proposed South Coast Railway ( SCoR ) zone. The total sanctioned cost for the project is Rs 170 crores.

“This sanctioned amount is for the upcoming Rayagada division. However, we would ask for more during the August review estimates and then again during the final review estimate in January 2021. Till then, Rs 3 crore is not a small amount that can be spent,” said a senior railway official.

On July 17, 2019, the ministry of railways had approved the creation of a new railway zone known—South Coast Railway (SCoR)—with headquarters at Vishakhapatnam.

For Waltair division under the present East Coast Railway zone , the Budget has announced a Wagon POH workshop at an estimated cost of Rs 28 crore and augmenting the construction of a diesel loco shed at an estimated cost of Rs 11 crores.

The Budget has also cleared decks for constructing two new lines and doubling of four existing lines at Waltair division.

Title: Why CM Y S Jaganmohan Reddy’s photos on hoardings at panchayat offices: Andhra Pradesh high court
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Andhra Pradesh high court

VIJAYAWADA: The Andhra Pradesh high court on Wednesday found fault with photographs of chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy printed on the boards of Panchayat office across the state.

While hearing a public interest litigation (PIL) filed by Muppa Venkateswara Rao, the bench headed by Chief Justice J K Maheswari and Justice Ninala Jayasurya asked the government why chief minister’s photographs were displayed on hoardings at panchayat offices.

Assistant advocate general said the chief minister’s is a constitutional post and hence the hoardings.

The HC said: “The prime minister’s is a constitutional position, but can we display his photo in front of Parliament? Similarly, the chief justice is head of the Supreme Court but his photo is not displayed at the court entrance. The state government should follow the customs and spirit of the Constitution,” said the HC bench.

In an affidavit, the state government said the YSRC party flag and the colours used to paint panchayat offices were different. The HC said it could differentiate between the colours of the party flag and colours on the offices.

The HC directed the advocate general to present YSRC flag and the colours painted on the offices.

The state election commission said it cannot direct the government to remove party flag colours on panchayat office buildings as the model code of conduct was not in force.

The HC said that it would give directions if the EC did not have the necessary powers.

Further hearing will take place on Thursday.

Title: 142 properties sealed, Rs 1.08cr tax collected
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

RMC officials seal a complex as part of the drive on Wednesday

Rajkot: On the first day of its sealing drive , the Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) one sealed nearly 142 properties and collected Rs 1.08 crore as pending property tax on the spot.

RMC teams also sealed the properties of two top retail chains to recover the tax dues of Rs 97.70 lakh and Rs 39.36 lakh respectively. The civic body also sealed the properties of Blossom School, Happy Banquet Hall, nine units of Vrunda Arcade, 31 units of Ambika Complex and some shops in Crystal Mall on Kalavad road.

The civic body has collected total tax of Rs 160 crore out of total target of Rs 257 crore this financial year. According to officials, the campaign will continue till March and a team of 300 employees has been been formed for the drive.

Title: Couple killed in accident, 2-yr-old injured in Jhansi
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Jhansi: A couple, riding a motorbike, killed in an accident under Tehroli police station in Jhansi district on Tuesday night while their infant daughter had a miraculous escape. The incident came to light on Wednesday morning when the villagers spotted the couple lying on the roadside and they informed the police.

According to reports, Gyan Singh (35) and his wife Pooja along with their two-year-old daughter Jyoti were returning from village Bhagera at about 2 am after watching Ramlila. When they came on Sitaura-Khilawari road, their motorbike dashed against a stationary tractor-trolley near the roadside from behind.

Throughout the entire night, the couple and their daughter kept lying at the accident and were spotted on Wednesday morning by the villagers, who in turn informed the police. The police sent the victims to the primary health centre where the doctors declared the couple dead due to heavy blood loss. Fortunately, their two-year-old daughter had a miraculous escape with minor bruises.

Station officer, Tehroli, Amar Singh said it is being presumed that the couple could not notice the stationary tractor-trolley due to fog and dashed the speeding bike against it. "Both of them suffered head injuries. We have sent the bodies for the postmortem examination while the girl is undergoing treatment”, the SO added.

Title: KT Rama Rao reviews JBS-MGBS Metro stretch
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

KT Rama Rao

HYDERABAD: Municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao on Wednesday reviewed the arrangements being made for launching the Jubilee Bus Station-Mahatma Gandhi Bus Station (JBS-MGBS) Metro Rail corridor by chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao on Friday.

KTR directed the Metro, police, municipal and other department officials to ensure that foolproof arrangements were in place as politicians, elected representatives and people are expected to attend the function.

Hyderabad Metro already provides east-west connectivity in the city by running services on LB Nagar-Miyapur and Nagole-Raidurg corridors. With the launch of JBS-MGBS route, another 11km of network will be added to the existing 58km. The 69km network would thus mark the completion of phase I of the Metro Rail project.

Title: Land mafias posing as DMC officials trying to displace us: Slum dwellers
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Slum dwellers, along with former Congress MLA Raj Kumar, filed a complaint with DMC commissioner Vinay Shankar... Read More

DEHRADUN: The dwellers of slum settlements, especially those situated in Mehboob Colony and Sahastradhara Road, have alleged that land syndicates are trying to grab their land by posing as Dehradun Municipal Corporation ( DMC ) officials.

The residents of these settlements claimed they found the involvement of land mafias only after they went to the DMC office, along with former Congress MLA Raj Kumar and other party members, to ask the municipal corporation officials to withdraw the decision of “displacing us from our lands”.

However, after a discussion with municipal commissioner Vinay Shankar Pandey , they found out that the DMC never sent any official with any such order to these slums.

“Some land mafia goons, who run a real estate business, are harassing the slum dwellers of Dehradun. These people have been living here for 15-20 years. Residents of two slums located in the Mehboob Colony and Sahastradhara road have reported such harassment. The slum dwellers are confused whether the people who are fooling them are DMC officials or land mafia people. We have given a memorandum to the DMC commissioner and now, we will give it to the district magistrate, and to the SSP as well. It is a very serious matter,” said Kumar.

Usha Devi, resident of Sahastradhara Road slum settlement, told TOI, “We have all documents like Aadhar card, ration card etc. Also, we pay our house tax and are due to get ownership rights too. So, the officials can’t remove us from our lands. We don’t know if the people who are trying to remove us from our land are DMC officials or land mafia men.”

She said that discussion with DMC commissioner has brought a sense of relief for the slum residents.

“After listening to the commissioner, we feel that land mafia men have been harassing us so far. There are around 150 homes in the Sahastradhara road slum and the Mehboob Colony has more than 200 homes. It would be a really big problem if all of us are made homeless,” Usha Devi added.
