Meanwhile, the DMC maintains that they never sent any team to the slums in question with any such controversial orders. “We will discuss the matter with the concerned official but we are confident that the municipal corporation has never sent its team to the two slums about which the locals are talking about. If the DMC team had gone over there, I would have known about it,” said Pandey.

Title: LRS applicable to plots registered before Aug 31
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority ( VMRDA ) conducted an awareness programme on layout regularisation scheme (LRS-2020) alongside licensed technical surveyors at its office on Wednesday.

VMRDA metropolitan commissioner P Koteswara Rao said LRS will be applicable to layouts and plots registered before August 31, 2019 as per government order dated January 8. “Interested parties should apply within 90 days from the date of the order by paying at least 50% penalisation charges. A copy of the registered sale/title deed, location and detailed layout plan, land conversion certificate etc need to be uploaded to get the layouts regularised. Civic body commissioners of Vizianagaram, Yelamanchili and Nellimarla can also regularise these illegal layouts by taking prior approval of the VMRDA commissioner. I request the public to utilise the opportunity to bring their illegal layouts into the planning fold,” he said. Penalisation, open space and conversion charges will depend on the basic price fixed by the sub-registrar office, he said.

Title: Online frauds doubles in Nashik district, detection rate falls
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The ever-rising online-fraud cases doubled last year with 50 cases being registered with the Nashik cyber crime police station.

The criminals have been coming out with unique ways to cheat people of their hard-earned money. The police, on the other hand, have failed to cope up with the criminals as only three cases were detected last year.

Total worth of Rs one crore frauds were registered with the police station last year.

In 2018, close to 20 cases were reported by the police station as a mere two cases were solved by the cyber experts.

According to the police, the detection rate in such cases is very low because most of the times these criminals submit fake documents to open the bank account. And when police contact them they have got a fake address which results in disappointment.

Devraj Borse, senior PI of the cybercrime police station said, “During an investigation, we have found out that in most of the cases the banks have not verified the home addresses of the account holders. When we reach the address of the account holder, there is no trace of the latter at the said place.”

Further fake identification documents are submitted for creating bank accounts, all these things hinder the investigation process, said Borse.

The cyber police said that the maximum online frauds are about the victims getting phone calls from the fraudsters, who speak to the victims on the pretext of being bank officials. The cybercriminals after contacting their victim, take the details of the bank, debit or credit cards of the latter and ask them the OTP they receive on their cellphone. After getting the OTP, the cybercriminals transfer the amounts of the victims to their bank accounts to withdraw money.

PI Borse said that 80 percent of all the OTP related cases are from Jamtara, a district in Jharkhand. He said that cybercriminals from Jamtara have victimised people from almost all the states of the country including relatives of top film stars and government officials.

Borse added that most of the youths of villages of this district are into cheating people by calling the victims as bank officials and taking the bank or card details, OTPs and then removing the money from their bank account.

The cybercrime police officials said that they too have cases related to Jamtara. Borse said that they would prepare a full-proof plan to detect and catch the criminals in the Jharkand district.

Title: Chinese brands gain share in refurbished phone market
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Chennai: Chinese smartphone brands are on their way to consuming a lion’s share even in the refurbished and used-phones market as price-sensitive consumers are finding it a win-win to own a phone with high specifications at a reasonable price.

Mandeep Manocha, CEO and co-founder, Cashify says that the share of Xiaomi has gone up from 12%-15% to 25% in a span of 12-15 months on their platform.

“On the other hand, Motorola and Lenovo are seeing a drop in the share. Motorola is seeing a dip from 10% to a 5% and Lenovo’s share has also dropped,” he added.

As the life cycle of a smartphone comes down to 13-15 months from 18 months within a span of a year and half, and the price of refurbished models among Chinese brands such as Vivo, Oppo , Realme, Xiaomi and One Plus at Rs 5,000 to Rs 8,000 — as estimated by the re-commerce players — these brands seem to grow at 50%-60% in that space.

With prices along the lines of entry-level smartphones , but with better specifications and almost new — since these models are used for barely over a year — smartphone users from tier 2 or tier 3 cities are purchasing the Chinese brand models.

These players are also eating into the share of former famous brands such as Lenovo, Motorola, Karbonn and Lava, companies in the space add. “Those who migrate from a feature phone find these brands perfect, since the models aren’t too heavy on the pocket and also offer the transition to first time and entry-level users at better specifications and also come with a warranty,” said Rohit Bagaria, founder, Budli.in, an online portal which offers re-commerce of gadgets. Chinese brands have seen an increase from 40%-75% in the last 2 years, while Motorola and Lenovo saw their share being halved in the same period. Even as these phones are picked up by those upgrading from a feature phone to a smartphone, the premium category — Apple and high-end models of Samsung — have their share untouched at 25%, thanks to their existing smartphone customers who upgrade to a model with higher specifications. “There is a 30% growth in purchase of One Plus and Xiaomi phones but Apple and Samsung still maintain their user base. It is only the homegrown brands like Lava, Karbonn etc which are becoming less popular,” said Yogesh Bhatia the founder of PreLoved Device.

Title: IIT-H researchers find new molecule to help cure ALS
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Researchers from Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Hyderabad have found a new molecule that could help in finding cure to Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), a rare neurodegenerative disorder that cripples the functioning of body muscles. About a lakh cases of ALS are reported in India and it gained popularity worldwide as it had affected eminent scientist and author Stephen Hawking . During 2014, ALS became a hot topic thanks to “ice bucket” challenge in different parts of the world.While Hawking overcame ALS through sheer determination and continued to postulate new theories for almost five decades, others affected by this genetic disorder remain paralysed for life.There is no known cure for ALS and the latest finding of the IIT Hyderabad team could open new vistas for a possible wonder drug. Apart from affecting the voluntary movement of muscles, ALS can cause paralysis and often death. ALS occurs when there is a change or mutation in certain genes. It is not clear what causes the genes to change but scientists blame it on factors ranging from environment to genetics and smoking to use of harmful chemicals in agriculture.The finding of the research was published in the recent issue of the leading scientific journal, International Journal of Biological Macromolecules. The research team included Dr Basant Kumar Patel, Dr Sandeep Singh and Dr Rajakumar Eerappa of the department of biotechnology and Prof Ganesan Prabushankar of the department of chemistry. Research scholars Amandeep Girdhar, Vidhya Bharathi, Vikas Ramyagya Tiwari, Suman Abhishek, Waghela Deeksha, Usha Saraswat Mahawar, and Gembali Raju were also part of the research study.Dr Basant Kumar Patel said one of the causes of ALS is the changes in the genes that are responsible for the manufacture of an important protein, TDP-43. Mutations in the genes lead to changes in the structure of this special protein. These changes in turn result in deposition of proteins on nerve cells. This leads to degeneration of nerves.According to an official statement of IIT Hyderabad, Dr Patel and Prof Prabushankar found a small molecule called ‘AIM4,’ which seemed to be better than the other related molecules that have been studied all around the world, in its ability to inhibit abnormal aggregation of TDP-43. The study was conducted in vitro (in laboratory) model. IIT Hyderabad scientists proceeded to analyse this molecule and study its action on TDP-43, to predict how it would potentially inhibit the deposition of the protein in nerve cells.The research group compared the ability of AIM4 with that of other molecules like Dimebon, an antihistamine studied for treatment of neurodegenerative disorders. Dimebon failed in clinical trials. AIM4 was found to be better than other such molecules.The IIT team said AIM4 is a promising drug for potential treatment of ALS. “This work is an important step forward in treatment of ALS as current options for ALS are minimal or even non-existent”, said Dr Patel.

Title: Vigilance team completes probe into ‘fraud’ HC order case
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

DEHRADUN: Police vigilance department has completed a probe into an alleged fraudulent court order that was uploaded on the high court website in May 2019.

The order was claimed to have been detected by a petitioner Anil Kishore Joshi who is fighting a compensation case against the railways in the HC. Joshi said, “The order was passed by a senior judge and it was cited in the annexure of the opposition party (railways) but after getting the certified copy of the same order, I found many discrepancies which were serious in nature. So the question was who uploaded a fraudulent HC order in the HC website.”

The matter was informed to the concerned judge and then Chief Justice ordered a probe into the matter. SP vigilance (Haldwani) Amit Srivastav said, “The probe has been completed and submitted to the HC.” He added that the probe report was sent to the HC last week.

During the vigilance probe, the petitioner was also called in connection with the case. Joshi said, “Changes were made in the forged order to benefit the railway authority which is contesting my compensation case.”

Title: Health ministry docs to inspect corona preparedness at airport
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A team of specialist doctors from Ministry of Health and Family Welfare Directorate General of Health Services (MoHFW) will visit Visakhapatnam International Airport in a day or two to inspect the preparedness of the airport and its hospital to address the deadly coronavirus.

The international airport had taken measures for screening of coronavirus on its premises. The central government has been taking necessary precautions to address the coronavirus issue in the country and as part of it, it has pressed a team of doctors from the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare Directorate General of Health Services Emergency Medical Relief (MoHFW) to inspect and review the preparedness measures at all 14 international airports across the nation.

Indira Gandhi International Airport at Visakhapatnam is also one of them. The team of doctors will brief respective state health departments to undertake necessary preparedness measures. A team of three doctors including epidemiologist Dr Shikha Vardhan, physician Dr Kapoor Ch Choudary and microbiologist Dr Anuradha Shulania will inspect the airport in a day or two.

The team of doctors will inspect all international airports along with their designated hospitals.

After inspection the teams will submit a report to Director General of Health Services (DGHS).

MoHFW department informed that the medical teams would report to the secretary (health) of respective state governments and brief them about all preparedness measures and regional directors (RoHFW) for respective states would facilitate inspections of airports and designated hospitals in their states.

The three cases of corona virus infections in Kerala and one in Uttarakhand has sent shockwaves across the country, with state governments scurrying to prevent infections and spot cases early to check the spread of the deadly virus.

Title: Special squad raids illegal gas filling den
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The special squad of city police on Tuesday raided an illegal gas filling centre and seized 3 domestic gas and 14 commercial LPG cylinders along with 8 vehicles and other articles worth Rs 8.43 lakh.

One man was arrested from the spot and has been booked under relevant sections of Essential Commodities Act and The Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Regulation and Supply and Distribution) Order, 2000. The owner of the place could not be traced by police, but he too has been booked.

According to police, a complaint was received at the police commissionerate about the illegal den in Bhandure Mala area of Satpur. Working on the information, the special squad raided the place on Tuesday morning and found various customers who had come to get the LPG gas for their vehicles.

“One of the suspects filling LPG gas in vehicles was arrested from the spot. As many as 17 gas cylinders (3 domestic and 14 commercial), two electric machines used for filling gas in vehicles, a weighing machine, seven auto rickshaws and one car were also seized,” a police officer said.

“More people should come forward to inform about illegal activities happening in their areas. Response from the informers is vital as their name is not disclosed to anyone,” he added.

Over the past two months a large number of raids have been conducted by the special squad all over the city. The in-charge officers of the concerned police stations are held accountable for illegal business in their jurisdiction.

“Action is also taken against the concerned police officer if illegal dens are found operating in his jurisdiction repeatedly by the special squad,” the officer said.

Title: Two jump to death in city
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Rajkot: Two persons committed suicide by jumping from high-rise buildings in Rajkot in the past 24 hours.

In the first case, Milan Mehta (55) jumped from the ninth floor of Neptune Tower on Kalawad Road on Tuesday evening. Mehta’s identity could only be ascertained from a diary found from his pocket.

“We called up different numbers mentioned in his diary and thus were able to identify him. Mehta was living alone in Vaniavadi locality of Rajkot. We are yet to probe the reason for his suicide,” said an official from Gandhigram police station.

The second case was reported from Pancheshwer Tower building on Sadhu Vasvani Road where Purvesh Vasoya (45) jumped from the third floor of Pancheshwer Tower on Wednesday morning. “Vasoya told his family members that he was going for a morning walk. Then he committed suicide. Vasoya’s family members rushed him to Rajkot Civil Hospital where he was declared brought dead. Our preliminary investigation suggests that Vasoya was passing through a financial crisis, which might have prompted him to take the drastic step,” said an official from University police station.

Title: Dabhoi man gets 10 years RI for rape
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Vadodara: A sessions court here on Wednesday sentenced a 26-year-old man from Dabhoi to 10 years rigorous imprisonment (RI) for abduction and rape of a minor girl by luring her with marriage promise in December 2015.

The convict Rahul alias Dadu Thakor from Dabhoi had abducted the 17-year-old Class XII girl in December 2015 from her school in Gorwa after promising to marry her and took her to Dediyapada in Narmada district where he raped her.

Her abduction came to light when she did not return from school and her father too could not find her anywhere. While searching, the girl’s father came to know that Thakor had abducted his daughter following which he registered a case of kidnapping at Gorwa police station. Thakor and the girl had come in contact with each other when Thakor had come to live at his relative’s home which is in the girl’s neighbourhood.

The cops tracked down Thakor and the girl to Dediyapada in Narmada district and brought them back to Vadodara after 25 days. On returning, the girl told police that she had physical relations with Thakor and later he had refused to marry her. The girl’s medical tests also revealed that she had been raped and thus Thakor was also booked for rape.

During the trial, the girl and her family members among other witnesses were examined. Additional public prosecutor H R Joshi also submitted forensic and medical evidence against Thakor which were upheld by the court of additional sessions judge K M Sojitra. The court also fined Thakor Rs 13,000.

This is the third conviction within a week wherein the accused had lured a minor girl of marriage and abducted and raped her. On Tuesday too, the same court had convicted Ikram Shah alias Akram Dewan for a similar crime. Another man identified as Babu alias Bharat Vasava was sentenced to 10 years in jail on January 30 by another sessions court in city for abducting and raping a 14-year-old girl.

Title: IIM-V leadership prog for IOCL managers
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Indian Institute of Management-Visakhapatnam (IIM-V) launched a leadership development programme for key managerial personnel of Indian Oil Corporation Limited (IOCL) on Wednesday.

Speaking to TOI, IIM-V director Prof M Chandrasekhar said the three-day programme is preceded by online assignments and projects for participants. “Classes will be conducted in the mornings, while the afternoon sessions will be dedicated to completing the live projects. Even after completing the three-day programme, IIM-V will extend it assistance for the next week for completion of the assignments and projects. The second round of the training programme for IOCL personnel will be conducted in March. Several regional managers, deputy managers and senior managers from across the country will take part in the training programme,” said Prof Chandrasekhar.

The director added that IIM-V will conduct two management training programmes for the faculty of government and government-aided engineering colleges in March. IIM-V has already conducted three such events.

Title: 2 murdered by family over disputes
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Two persons were murdered by their family in two separate incidents in north Andhra Pradesh on Wednesday. The reasons for the murders are said to be family disputes and property disputes.

In the first incident, 40-year-old P Srinu was murdered by his brother and father following a fight between him and his family at Mushalipalem area under Makavarapalem Police Station limits in Vizag district. Police said Srinu was addicted to alcohol and had a few other vices leading to him being unemployed for a year. He used to pick up fights with his family members and others after consuming liquor. On Tuesday night, Srinu fought with his mother and father in an inebriated condition. Though Srinu’s brother Sunil Kumar tried to pacify him, the 40-year-old chased his mother with a stick to attack her.

Unable to bear the harassment, Srinu’s father Sunny Babu and his brother attacked Srinu with sticks. Srinu, who sustained injuries to his head, died on the spot. Police led by sub-inspector K Ramu registered a case.

In another incident, a 60-year-old-woman was murdered by her son at Ramadasupeta village under Tekkali Police Station limits in Srikakulam district. The deceased was identified as K Anasuyamma and the accused is K Ramakrishna. The police said Ramakrishna had fought with his mother over property. Since Anasuyamma was not in favour of giving land to Ramakrishna, he held a grudge on her and stabbed her.

Title: Hyderabad: Milk vendor hacked to death over grudge
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 22-year-old milk vendor, identified as Revanth Kumar , was allegedly hacked to death by four persons at Halia town in Nalgonda district on Wednesday. The police took all the accused into custody on Wednesday and preliminary investigation suggests that personal grudge was the motive behind the murder .

Revanth’s parents were the first ones to spot his body lying on the road between Halia and Hazarigudem and raise an alarm. Hearing them, locals rushed to the spot and called the police as well as an ambulance. However, Revanth was declared dead by the ambulance staff, said Nalgonda SP AV Ranganath.

Revanth had left home at 4.30am on his two-wheeler to collect milk from Hazarigudem village and his parents left five minutes later. On their way, they saw their son lying in a pool of blood, the police said, adding that his mother Indiramma said that a few persons who had borrowed money from them were behind the murder.

During probe, the police learnt that Revanth and Hari Krishna, a garment shop owner from Halia, were not on good terms as the latter suspected him of having an affair with his wife. As per the plan, Hari and three of his friends — Mahesh, Rajesh and Ganesh — attacked Revanth with an axe and he died on the spot, police said.

Cops are probing if Hari’s brother Satyanarayana, who had borrowed Rs 2 lakh from Indiramma, was involved in the murder.

Title: Complaint filed against organiser of pro-CAA meet
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

CHARMINAR: South zone police have registered a complaint against the organiser of a pro-Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) meeting held on February 2 and the special guest on Wednesday.

Social activists SQ Masood and MA Akram filed the complaint against organiser A Bhaskar and special guest Subuhi Khan for alleged provocative speech made during the meet convened by the Akhand Bharath Sangarsh Samithi (ABSS) at Quli Qutub Shah Stadium in Old City.

“Khan had made a provocative speech during the meeting and hurt the sentiments of the people. She called Hyderabad a ‘mini Pakistan’ and named localities such as Nawab Sahab Kunta, Bhavani Nagar, Moghalpura, and Shastripuram ,” Masood told TOI.

Meanwhile, Akram said that provocative words against Old City residents were not acceptable and that is why they file a police complaint seeking probe into the matter.

“How can someone call us Pakistani? How can someone ask us to leave the place where we were born and raised. The provocative words used against Old City residents have deeply hurt my sentiments and so I have filed a complaint against Subuhi khan and A Bhaskar,” Akram said.

Title: Fraudsters siphon Rs 62,000 off victim
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A man fell victim to cyber fraudsters who hacked his Paytm e-wallet.

Ravi Shankar , a resident ofKukatpally, approached the Cyberabad police on January 23.

The victim had received a message for updating KYC details. When he called the number, the offenders asked for his Paytm details on the pretext of updating the account and asked him to transfer Rs 100. The transaction failed. The offenders hacked his Paytm account and made fraudulent transactions of Rs 62,542. Another victim from Sangareddy , stated that he lost lost a total of Rs 78,399 in a similar way.

Title: Prices of fuel plummet by almost Rs 3 per litre in less than a month
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The fuel prices in the city plummeted by almost Rs3 per litre in the past 25 days and better still, petrol might be soon available at about Rs75 per litre — the lowest in over the past 6 months.Currently, the price of a litre of petrol in Pune is Rs78.37, as against Rs81.41 on January 11 — the day since the prices began falling. The price of diesel was Rs71.22 per litre then, while it now stands at Rs67.89 per litre.A source in the All India Petrol Dealers’ Association (AIPDA) said on Tuesday the price of crude in the international market was as low as $55 per barrel. He said the sharp decline was the knee jerk reaction of the Opec (Organisation of Petrol Exporting Countries) to the steep fall in demand from China because of the coronavirus epidemic.Ali Daruwala, the spokesperson of the AIPDA, said, “The slowdown from China as well as Indian currency getting stronger against the dollars by close to 20 to 30 paise in the last week are definitely good signs and may cause further reduction of retail prices of petrol.”An oil marketing company official told TOI that retail petrol and diesel prices were changing daily and were directly linked to the international crude prices.“If crude prices continue to fall, domestic prices of petrol and diesel may fall further. It is, however, difficult to predict how much more the retail prices of petrol and diesel may fall. As of now, there is a feel in the market that the falling trend in petrol and diesel prices should continue for the next few days,” he said.

Title: Man admits to plotting father’s killing for property
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The SP with the 3 arrested, including the son (green jacket)

ROORKEE: The only son of businessman Rampal Kashyap (65), who was shot at by unidentified miscreants on January 28, has confessed before the police that he had orchestrated the assassination of his father to take possession of all his immovable property.

Police claimed that Vipin ,35, had hired shooters to kill his father, who is currently battling two bullet injuries in a higher medical facility in Dehradun . Police have arrested three accused, including Vipin, in the case and three more accused are yet to be arrested.

According to accused Vipin, his father, a widower, owns a banquet hall, 45 bigha agricultural land, many residential properties, plots, and several shops. The accused added that his father was deeply attached with his brother’s family. "He used to spend all his income on sons of my uncle and his entire family. On the other hand, I had to seek help from others for my family maintenance," said Vipin while he was presented before media persons at Civil Lines police station on Wednesday. He added that his cousin Manoj and his friend Gurvinder Rathi convinced him that if his father is eliminated, all property would automatically be transferred to him.

Manoj and Rathi arranged shooters — Shahjad, Chhota Jat, and Pramod Jat. According to the plan, the victim was shot at while he was shutting down his sweat shop for the day at about 8 pm on January 28.

“We have arrested Vipin, Shahjad, and Pramod and a manhunt is ongoing to nab Rathi, Manoj, and Chhota,” said SP (rural) Swapn Kishore Singh .

Title: ‘Hooch’ traders’ men attack police team in US Nagar
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

RUDRAPUR: Supporters of alleged illicit liquor manufacturers pelted stones at a police team in Rampura village under the jurisdiction of Kundeshwari police in Kashipur area of Udham Singh Nagar district on Wednesday.

Assistant superintendent of police (ASP) Kashipur Rajesh Bhatt said that a police team had gone to Rampura after receiving a tip off regarding illegal liquor trade. As soon as police reached the identified spot, supporters of hooch traders resorted to heavy stone pelting, which forced the policemen to retreat, healleged.

ASP Bhatt added that the police team informed the head office and heavy police force was sent to the village but the accused managed to escape.

“We have booked 50 people under section 186 (obstructing any public servant in the discharge of his public functions) and 147 (Rioting) of the Indian Penal Code and they are trying to nab the accused,” the official said.

Title: Ahead of completing 3 years as CM, Trivendra Singh Rawat to visit all districts, review development works
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Trivendra Singh Rawat

DEHRADUN: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat will camp in all 13 districts of the state and review the ongoing development projects there to mark the third year of his government, the state government said on Wednesday.

The BJP government in Uttarakhand completes three years in March this year. Rawat was sworn in as chief minister on March 18, 2017. During his visits, the CM will be accompanied by the ministers-in-charge of each district and well as the secretaries of departments concerned. The CM will also hold discussions with journalists, students, artisans and representatives of self-help groups. During these review meetings, local MLAs, Zila Panchayat heads, heads of block panchayats and district magistrates will have to be present.

Title: Honoured to have our house as trust office: SC lawyer
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NEW DELHI: K Parasaran, the 93-year-old Supreme Court lawyer who represented Hindu parties in the Ram Temple-Babri Masjid dispute, and his family could hardly contain their emotions on Wednesday as their three-storeyed house in Delhi’s Greater Kailash-1 was declared the office of the newly formed trust that would oversee the mandir’s construction on a 67-acre land in Ayodhya . “I’m just one of the trustees. There are others,” he smiled.

There are 15 trustees in all for the Ram Janmabhoomi Teerth Khsetra Trust. Parasaran’s lawyer son Mohan told TOI, “We are of course happy. But at the same time, it is a very onerous responsibility. My father has been involved in the Ayodhya matter since 1991. He, after deep thought, accepted this offer. The offer was made by the home ministry. With his experience, he will be able to manage the Trust aided by very able and distinguished trustees.” Even as Mohan spoke, Parasaran Sr went into a huddle with his team of lawyers as they discussed the upcoming hearing on the Sabarimala temple entry case that is listed in SC for Thursday. Their house, R 20 in Greater Kailash 1, buzzed with activity as his personal aide for 33 years, Muthuswami, answered the phone that rang relentlessly. Inside the house, framed photographs of Lord Ventakeshwara, Ram and Ganesha adorned the walls lined below by an extensive collection of law books and small plaques. Among them hung the Padma Bhushan citation that he received from then President A PJ Abdul Kalam in 2003. Mohan said the family would be happy to host meetings of the Trust at their house. “Meetings can be held here or in Ayodhya,” he said.

As several paramilitary and police personnel gathered on the road below, Mohan clarified that the security was not for his father. “He has never wanted security. He shunned security even he was attorney general in Tamil Nadu .” VHP functionaries, who had recently honoured Parasaran and 32 other lawyers involved in the case at a ceremony in Ayodhya, insisted they were not disappointed at being left out from the 15member trust.

“It (the group of trustees) is non-controversial. There is no disappointment. We are overwhelmed by this decision. Parasaran ji and his team members were honoured by us at a grand ceremony. We welcome the decision,” VHP vice-president Champat Rai told TOI.

Title: PCMC panel keeps tax hike proposal in abeyance
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The standing committee of the corporation on Wednesday decided to keep in abeyance the proposal for increasing the property tax largely because of the displeasure BJP was facing from residents over the decision to continue with the alternate day water supply.

The Pimpri Chinchwad civic administration’s proposal to increase the water tax for flats, tenements in slum rehabilitation projects and for slum dwellers for 2020-21 came up for discussion at the standing committee meeting on Wednesday. The proposal also sought approval for increasing the property tax by 5% every year thereafter.

Vilas Madigeri, the chairperson of the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation ( PCMC ) standing committee, said, “We shall keep the proposal in abeyance until the citizens get adequate water supply at good pressure. The civic officials stated that they expected to get Rs180 crore from the tax hike and another Rs35 crore after increasing the water tax. I pointed out that the property tax department has completed the tax assessment of newly detected 7,500 properties and the work of conducting tax assessment of another 7,500 properties is in progress. The department will be able to get Rs150 crore from these newfound properties.”

Madigeri said the property tax department was facing manpower shortage while identifying non-assessed properties in the city. “So, we have told the municipal commissioner to provide more manpower by hiring people on contract for conducting this work. It will ensure that the annual property tax income of the civic body increases every year.”

The civic body decided to start alternate day water supply for two months from November 25 to ensure equitable and adequate water supply.

Title: Nagpur News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Infrastructure project announcements are never in short supply in the city — most of them grand enough to catch the eye. But the proof is in the pudding, and the recent Sadar flyover landing mess has highlighted the broad-as-daylight gap between project planning and successful execution. Panellists at the TOI Debate discuss how and why Nagpur’s project designs are incommensurate with ground reality

The demographics, underlying cultural strands and social issues of a city, must be at the heart of its project planning studies, believes architect Sapna Vastani. The way new projects shape up though makes one seriously doubt if these aspects are accorded any attention, she feels. Citing the example of areas like Manish Nagar, where hawker zones were not a part of the plan, she wonders why the powers-that-be do not learn from their mistakes.

Chartered accountant Nimish Sutaria finds many of the city’s original master plans astute but feels that their purpose is not well understood today, due to which they are being abused (encroachment of playgrounds being a case in point). “Why do we have so many hospitals in an already congested area like Dhantoli? Why aren’t we spreading out when we have enough space?” he says.

The prime stumbling block, responds former NMC chief engineer Prakash Urade, is the road width availability. “With no scope to increase the width of roads, we are often unable to accommodate plan revisions even if we want to,” says retired public works department (PWD) engineer Jeevan Nikose. The increasing floor space index (FSI) — which is a measure of the city’s population density — further compounds matters as the plan needs to be revised repeatedly to meet the changing needs.

Width is not the only thing that is wrong with roads. The levelling of newly-constructed cement roads is a big area of concern, as per Vastani. “We never experienced severe waterlogging in Nagpur earlier. The drainage system is not being properly looked into,” she says.

Vastani also finds the process of piling layer-after-layer on roads illogical when there is the option of building new roads instead. “It is not very easy to do that, as the soil erodibility factor (also known as the ‘K factor’) gets disturbed by it,” counters Urade.

Architect Priya Nair finds potholes to be a teething issue which affects the discharge rate of traffic, with haphazard management at busy intersections adding to the woes. “Junctions like Medical Square and Ram Nagar Square have traffic coming in from all four sides at once, causing utter chaos,” says businessman Yogesh Agrawal.

Projects keep getting greenlit with scarce planning for the small, key details, according to Sutaria. “There is no provision for last-mile connectivity. Public vehicles have no designated space for parking at the airport. Parking space is not available at any of the brand new Metro stations either,” he claims.

Nachiket Kaley, founder member of non-governmental organization (NGO) Civic Action Guild (CAG), agrees with Sutaria. “The planning occurs on a broad level. We do not work on the details. There is a lot of ambiguity in the minutiae of project implementation, since the documentation is often quite flawed,” says Kaley.

Businessman Saqib Parekh feels that there is no vision to assimilate rural and urban planning, and that the city needs short, five-year-long plans more than a 30-year vision statement for development to materialize. “Rural-urban coordination is conspicuous by its absence. Civic work is concurrently undertaken by different sets of employees, with scant regard for the big picture,” says Nikose.

Sutaria believes that there is a “multiplicity of cooks” that spoils many plans. Standard operating procedures are often found lacking, chimes in Kaley.

“The Japanese allocate 90% of the project time to planning, and 10% to execution. That is what makes the difference,” states Urade. “When a project is announced, it is not just the technical team’s prerogative to work on it. Everyone, including financers, architects and hawkers need to be involved in it,” he says.

The need for connecting projects to people finds the panel’s consensus. “Planners need to make projects people-friendly,” says Nikose. Nair feels that taking feedback from common people before going ahead with the project is necessary.

“The problem needs to be discussed holistically. Pressure groups can be instrumental in driving attention towards critical issues,” Urade adds.

Managing inputs from so many stakeholders, however, comes with its own challenges. “All engineers and planners come with their own perceptions, which may not align with those of others,” says Agrawal. To add to that, change is “very drastic” in today’s times, as per Nikose, which makes it tough for engineers to stay abreast.

A solution to that could be taking up project work in patches, suggests Kaley. “This would ensure that even if the scale of a project is small, it is done well,” he explains.

The panel also has some solutions for the Sadar flyover landing mess, which includes signalling and surveillance at the flyover, with traffic police personnel to man it at all times.

Not everyone agrees with these propositions. “What is the use of a flyover if one needs to halt in between?” says Sutaria. “The flyover should be permanently divided with a non-rigid divider,” he suggests.

Vastani wants efficient routing of traffic and signage to be put up at Sadar flyover. “There should be comprehensive risk analysis of the project, after which the process of ideation should commence,” Urade signs off.

Title: Opposition leader slams NMC ruling of Rs 150 crore loan for land acquisition
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The mayor of Nashik city Satish Kulkarni and the NMC standing committee president Uddhav Nimse both denied the... Read More

NASHIK: The leader of opposition in the Nashik Municipal Corporation, Ajay Boraste, slammed the BJP for its move to seek Rs 150 crore loan allegedly for land acquisition , though the charges were denied by standing committee president Uddhav Nimse.

Boraste, of Shiv Sena, addressing the press today, said that the BJP was using the corporation funds in the interest of selected builders and developers by paying the sum for land acquisition.

“When the acquisition of land since 1993 was still pending, it is hard to understand why BJP is acting in haste to arrange the funds to clear the dues of the people whose land is to be acquired as per the 2017-development plan,” said Boraste.

Boraste said that the issues – related to the roads, electricity and water supply were taking back seats and the BJP were allegedly not interested in resolving the issues despite the former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis adopting the city when he was in the chair.

The mayor of Nashik city Satish Kulkarni and the NMC standing committee president Uddhav Nimse both denied the charges levelled against them.

Kulkarni said, “The loan was being taken for the developmental activities including the construction of ring roads, water supply and other roads. This is in tune with the demands and there is no harm in opting for the same.”

Nimse said that the NMC was taking the loan for the developmental activities and it had nothing to do with the charges made by the opposition. “The NMC has to carry out developmental activities and pay for the land acquisition. All the works are being carried out as per the priority list and there is no question of favouring anybody,” he said

Title: Rythu bazars flooded with rotten onions, only customers hotels
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The state government has dumped rythu bazars with rotten onions it procured from National Agricultural Cooperative Market Federation of India (Nafed) to sell at subsidized rates during the crisis period.

What’s more, with no potential customers, a section of shopkeepers are selling them to a few small restaurants in the city.

“On February 2 and 3 we got a huge load of onions. But they are rotten, stink and have begun sprouting. Customers are not interested in buying the onions and we don’t have the option of returning them to the government. We are in a spot of bother,” said Jagadeshwar Rao, a shopkeeper. On Wednesday, when TOI visited the rythu bazar in Pedda Waltair, a couple of buyers were spotted buying the onions in bulk. Shopkeepers said they were from food joints nearby.

“On the last two days, we received at least 5,000 kg of onions which were mostly rotten. Bigger rythu bazars have received such onions in much bigger quantities. We are selling them at Rs 20 per kg,” said KM Rao, another shopkeeper.

But how come such a large stock of onions procured during the crisis period is still with the government? Officials with the agricultural and marketing departments have different answers.

A section of officials claimed they were rationing subsidised onions so that they could use it for a longer period as they were not sure how long the crisis would last. “The crisis got over mid-January and we are still we are left with onions procured from Nafed,” an official said.

Another section said the central government sent the consignments only mid-January when the crisis was almost over.

“Since we asked for it, we cannot return the onions. These onions are not of good quality and now that the crisis is over, people are buying Kurnool variety available in the market,” another official told TOI.

Doctors TOI spoke to said whatever might be the reason, selling rotten onions is not a good idea as it can cause severe ailments. “If it smells it means there’s bacteria. Eating such onions might cause severe food poisoning. Be careful, a jaundice epidemic broke out in the USA recently through onions,” said, Surya Rao, a physician.

Title: VMC to shell out more for land compensation
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Vadodara: The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) will have to recompense for the land it used for road widening near Shastri Bridge by paying the land owners interest higher than the actual value of land.

The civic body had widened the road without acquiring the land leading to litigations in the Gujarat high court. VMC had used 487.92sqm land near the Shastri Bridge to widen the road going towards Navayard. After the land owners were not compensated for the land, they approached the Gujarat high court with a series of petitions since 2004. However, these pleas were either rejected or withdrawn by the petitioners themselves.

The matter was eventually decided in 2008 by the HC stating that owners have to be compensated according to the value decided by the valuation committee. Those who lost land were also to be given interest from March 3, 1999.

According to a proposal prepared by the VMC administration, the value of the land at a rate of Rs 8,000 per square metre stood at Rs 39.03 lakh. Along with this, VMC would have to pay an interest of Rs 40.66 lakh. The civic body will have to pay Rs 79.69 lakh for the land now. The proposal does not give any clarity regarding the reasons for the delay in disbursing the compensation earlier to avoid interest.

The issue will be discussed in the standing committee later this week.

Title: Public feedback sought to upgrade rythu bazaars
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Facilities at rythu bazaars in the city are likely to get a facelift soon as officials of the agriculture and horticulture departments chalk out plans to collect feedback from consumers. A majority of the 13 rythu bazaars in the city were set up around two decades ago by the Telugu Desam Party (TDP). Between 20,000 to 25,000 people visit the rythu bazaars every day and 7,000 to 10,000 quintals of vegetables are sold in a day.

In spite of the bulk quantity of produce sold at rythu bazaars, consumers complained that vegetables and fruits of poor quality were being sold. Most rythu bazaars also lack adequate parking space and traffic congestion in front of the bazaars is common, said Srinivasa Reddy, a resident of MVP Colony. Officials should examine the quality of vegetables before they are sold to consumers as pesticide use in vegetables has been increasing in the region, he added.

D Sudhakar, a resident of Pedda Waltair, said while prices of fruits and vegetables at rythu bazaars are 20 per cent cheaper than in other retail markets, the quality is poorer. Waste disposal, provision of drinking water for consumers, toilets and parking are also concerns, said consumers, adding that collecting feedback could help improve quality of services.

Title: Fin firm owner held, charged with duping 148 of Rs 34 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The proprietor of a finance company was arrested from his Greater Noida residence on the charge of duping 148 people from the city of over Rs 34 lakh on the promise of offering them loan since February 15, 2019.

A cybercrime police team under inspector Santosh Barge took Raoushan Kumar (44) into custody on February 1. He was produced before a local court there on February 2 and then brought to the city on transit police custody remand for conducting investigations. He will remain in police custody till February 8.

Searches at Kumar’s residence led to the seizure of a laptop, three cellphone handsets, 10 debit cards, nine chequebooks, two bank passbooks, stamp and documents of people applying for loan.

Kumar was arrested following an FIR registered by Phursungi businessman Gorakh Sapkal (36) with the cybercrime police on October 10, 2019.

Sapkal in his FIR said he was into the business of helping people to get loans from banks and financial firms. He stated that Kumar obtained his cell number from an online service provider and contacted him. Kumar offered him to work as an agent in Pune and induced him to direct clients to the latter in need of loan on a commission basis.

The FIR read Sapkal gave Kumar data of 148 people, including himself, in need of loan. Kumar then asked them to deposit varying charges for seeking loan.

Sapkal later realised that he was tricked after Kumar failed to honour his commitment of disbursing loan to the people. After the aggrieved people started making rounds of his office, he filed the complaint against Kumar.

A cyber police officer said investigations revealed that Kumar had registered his firm but did not open an office. He had created a website in the company’s name.

Title: Hyderabad: 43-year-old crushed under lorry, dies
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 43-year-old private employee died after his two-wheeler was hit by a lorry in Abdullapurmet on Wednesday.

The victim was identified as Mohammed Anwar Baig, a resident of Jnnurm Colony, Abdullapurmet. The accident occured when the victim was on his way to his work at Ramoji Film city.

According to police, a lorry travelling from Hyderabad to Vijayawada hit the vehicle from the side at 8:30am. The victim fell on the road and was crushed under the tyres of the lorry. He died on the spot after sustaining severe head injuries. TNN

Title: Telangana govt harassing anti-CAA protesters: Congress
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Congress on Wednesday said the TRS government, at the instance of AIMIM, is harassing activists taking part in protests against CAA, NPR and NRC by unleashing cops against them. “Over 1,000 cases have been booked against those who took part in various protests held in Hyderabad and other parts of Telangana against CAA, NRC and NPR,” said Telangana Congress minorities cell chairman Shaik Abdullah Sohail. Cases were also booked against a large number of women after they took part in anti-CAA protests . “Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao said he was opposing CAA. If TRS is against CAA and NRC, why is police not allowing Shaheen Bagh-type protests in Telangana?” Sohail sought to know.

The Congress leader said both TRS and AIMIM were upset over anti-CAA protests being organised by common people without the direct involvement of any political party or leader.

Title: Man dies of suffocation in bathroom with gas geyser in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A 29-year-old man was found dead in the bathroom of his flat in Kothrud late on Tuesday evening in a suspected case of suffocation due to gas geyser.Senior inspector Pratibha Joshi of the Kothrud police told TOI that the man, Ramraje Kishor Sankpal, might have died about four days ago. His post-mortem was conducted at the Sassoon General Hospital on Tuesday, primary report of which stated that he died due to suffocation, Joshi said.The case came to light after a foul smell started emanating from the flat, prompting the local residents to alert the police. After receiving the alert, the police and fire brigade officials rushed to the society at Sangam Chowk in Kothrud and broke open the entrance door of the flat.Upon inspection, it was found that the smell was coming from the bathroom, after which the police as well as the firemen broke open the bathroom door to find Sankpal lying motionless on the floor.Senior inspector Joshi said Sankpal’s bathroom had an LPG-operated geyser. “The bathroom’s window was closed,” she said, adding that Sankpal might have died due to suffocation after inhaling toxic fumes from the gas geyser .“If the bathroom would have had a proper exhaust, the death could have been avoided,” the officer said, adding a case of accidental death (AD) has been registered in this regard.Joshi said Sankpal used to give private tuitions to school students in his flat. “He used to stay alone in the flat,” she said. In this regard she also added that gas geysers emit harmful carbon monoxide.Police probe has revealed that Sankpal’s students visited the flat in the evening hours but found the front door shut from inside. “They rang the door bell few times and left without alerting the local residents,” an officer of the Kothrud police said.The gas geysers have emerged as a health hazard in India in the last one decade, experts said. “Many people have visited hospitals with the neurological effects, the after effect of keeping the gas geysers switched on in stuffy bathrooms. The gas geysers are popular as they are cheaper than electricity operated geysers,” an expert said.He said the carbon monoxide caused due to incomplete combustion of LPG in geysers can lead to neurological effects after prolonged use. “Mild dizziness, vomiting, headache and blackouts are some of the symptoms. The gas geyser syndrome cannot be even diagnosed as the blood tests, ECG EEG, MRO are normal. So, in such cases blood-gas analysis is done,” he added.

Title: PMO seeks details of Deola road accident victims
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The Prime Minister’s Office ( PMO ) has sought details of victims in the Deola road accident in which 26 people lost their lives while nine got grievously injured.

“The district administration has prepared a proposal for relief from the PMO for the kin of the 26 dead and nine grievously injured in the accident involving a Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) bus and an autorickshaw in Deola taluka of Nashik district on January 28,” an official from the district collectorate said.

A compensation of Rs 2 lakh for those dead and Rs 50,000 for the injured will be given by the PMO. The state transport corporation pays Rs 10 lakh as compensation to the family every deceased bonafied passenger. The compensation to other victims is decided by the court.

State transport minister Anil Parab, who visited the victims January 29, had announced an aid of Rs 2 lakh to the family of the victims travelling in the autorickshaw.

The district administration has got the list of the deceased and civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale has submitted the list of the nine injured in the accident.

After the collision between the bus and the autorickshaw, both the vehicles fell in a well — about 10 meters away from the road. Rescue operation was immediately launched and cranes were deployed to pull up the bus and the autorickshaw.

Pune-based National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) was also pressed into the service and it reached the accident site at 2.30 am on January 29.

Title: Tech teachers demand removal of FTE dean
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Vadodara: Technology Teachers Forum (TTF) of M S University’s Faculty of Technology and Engineering (FTE) has demanded removal of the faculty’s dean with immediate effect.

According to TTF, MSU’s syndicate members have passed several resolutions stating that no teacher against whom an inquiry is going on and pending in court, may be given any statutory position like head of department or dean of faculty.

“Since you are functioning as FTE dean from science stream in engineering faculty, your eligibility as per the All India Council for Technical Education or National Board of Accreditation (NBA) is not as per the acts. This case is already pending in the court,” Dr K V R Murthy, TTF president has stated in representation submitted to MSU officials, a copy of which has been addressed to FTE dean Dr Arun Pratap. “Hence you are avoiding to apply for NBA which is mandatory requirement for the National Institute Ranking Framework. This also blocks chances of students who are going for higher education abroad,” Murthy has claimed.

TTF has alleged that FTE dean has not forwarded 20 applications of teachers due to which the teachers are not getting opportunity of promotion. “Considering our request, the department of technical education of Gujarat government had sent the letter for grade pay movement in October 2019 and you are still sleeping on these applications,” the memorandum states.

Title: 3 years on, no sight of key road to connect Bhayli
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Differences between VUDA and SSNNL is the reason for delay

Vadodara: The construction of a key road providing connectivity to Bhayli and other areas on the city’s outskirts has not moved an inch due to differences between the Vadodara Urban Development Authority (VUDA) and the Sardar Sarovar Narmada Nigam Ltd (SSNNL).

VUDA has been demanding that the SSNNL should construct a siphon to allow a 30 metre town planning road over the Gokhana distributary canal of the Narmada project. SSNNL on the other hand wants VUDA to construct a bridge over the canal.

VUDA and SSNNL have been exchanging letters regarding the issue since 2016. VUDA wrote to the SNNL asking it to make the siphon in 2016 and, in reply, the SSNNL asked VUDA to deposit the processing fees of Rs 10,000 and the town planning scheme map for the area. VUDA completed the formalities.

But in 2018, SSNNL asked VUDA to consider making the bridge and get a detailed project report prepared for the same. VUDA got the report prepared by a consultant. It came to light that due to the height of the canal and roads running parallel to it, the bridge will be a costly affair and an estimate of Rs 55.75crore was prepared.

In 2019, VUDA again wrote to SSNNL stating that the bridge was not feasible and the suggestion of a siphon in the canal should be considered. In response, SSNNL stated in January this year that the proposal could not be accepted and bridge should be made at the site.

A letter by VUDA to SSNNL mentions all the details of the previous conversations and also states that the possibility of the bridge was examined again and this time it transpired that it would have a very steep slope.

Dabhoi MLA Shailesh Mehta, who has been raising the issue since quite some time now, said that he had discussed the issue with VUDA and in the coordination meetings of the district administration too. “I have apprised minister of state for Narmada and urban housing Yogesh Patel too about the situation and has also taken up the matter,” he said.

Patel said that he was shown the letter written by VUDA to the SSNNL. “I have asked officials to examine the possibility as per the procedures and provisions. VUDA is willing to spend for the project,” said Patel.

Title: 2 Genome Valley cos face NCLT action after defaulting on payments
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Hyderabad: The National Company Law Tribunal ( NCLT ), Hyderabad, has admitted pleas against two firms in Shamirpet mandal’s Genome Valley in Turkapally and ordered corporate insolvency resolution process (CIRP) against them for defaulting on payments.

The two firms, MN Bio-technology Private Ltd and MN Takshila Industries Private Limited, were accused of default by Delhi-based Cerestra Advisors Private Ltd. A bench of member (judicial) Ratakonda Murali and member (technical) Narender Kumar Bhola pronounced two separate orders after hearing the pleas of Cerestra. It appointed Kranthi Kumar Kedari as insolvency professional to commence CIRP against the two firms.

While MN Bio-technology had failed to clear an advisory fee of Rs 51 lakh to Cerestra, payment of Rs 4.67 crore was due from Takshila for services it had availed from Cerestra, a ‘real assets’ focussed private equity firm.

Takshila had argued that a Singapore-based fund manager firm had availed itself of services from Cerestra and that there was no creditor-debtor relationship between it and Cerestra. The bench however ruled against it after going through the records. It said invoices were raised in the name of MN company and even TDS was deducted by it under section 194J of the Income Tax Act. The bench concluded that MN company availed services from Cerestra and was trying to evade its responsibility by blaming a third-party.

“TDS was deducted in connection with an invoice which was not in dispute,” the bench said. The amount deducted as TDS was directly connected to the invoice which was raised in connection with the services availed by MN company. “Since there was no other transaction between MN and Cerestra, this TDS will show us that Cerestra’s claims are correct,” the bench contended.

It admitted the insolvency plea against Takshila and MN Bio-technology under Section 9 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016. The bench also declared a moratorium from February 4, 2020.

Title: Two stabbed over loud music
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Rajkot: Two persons were stabbed by two assailants over a trivial issue in Jhulelal Nagar locality of Rajkot on Tuesday night. Police said the accused, identified as Mustafa Khiyani and Ishubha Dal, had attacked Kamlesh Nebhani (28) and his cousin Vijay Nebhani (29) with knives.

“The accused were angry with the Nebhani brothers for playing loud music in their car which was parked near Vijay’s house in Jhulelal Nagar. The accused accosted them for playing music loudly and instead of asking them to lower the volume, attacked them with knives,” said an official from Pradyuman Nagar police station.

While Kamlesh’s wrist got slashed, Vijay was stabbed in the ribs. Both victims have been admitted to the Rajkot Civil Hospital.

Title: Telangana: 60-year-old jailed for abusing minor
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A local court on Wednesday sentenced a 60-year-old man to undergo seven-year rigorous imprisonment for sexually abusing a five-and-half-year-old girl in Secunderabad .

Nampally criminal court’s first additional metropolitan sessions judge Kunchala Suneetha , in her judgement, directed the convict to undergo seven-year imprisonment under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act ( POCSO ).

He was awarded a three-month jail term on the charge of criminal intimidation, as he had threatened the victim. However, the punishment would be concurrent.

Title: Maharashtra: Soaring demand, supply shortage to trigger rise in rose rate before Valentine-Day
Content:
A surge in rose prices is likely owing to a shortage of their supply in the market

PUNE: Planning to gift roses to the loved ones this Valentine’s Day? Well, think again as you might have to shell out Rs 30-40 per piece as against the usual Rs 8-15 — a sharp 167-275% hike.A surge in rose prices is likely owing to a shortage of their supply in the market.Praveen Sharma, president, Indian Society of Floriculture Professionals, Talegaon Dabhade, said, “We have plenty of wedding ‘muhurats’ from February 16 to 28, which will put more pressure on supply and will result in a higher price of roses on Valentine’s Day. In January, this year, cut roses were being sold at Rs150 to 200 a bunch (of 20) in the wholesale market. During the Valentine’s Day period, we expect this to price to rise to Rs300 to 400 per bunch, which translates to approximately Rs30-40 per rose in the retail market.”Sharda Bajaj, proprietor of a flower retail outlet Life in Colour said, retail prices last year, during the same period, were the same at Rs30-40 per rose.“There are many weddings this February and rose exports are likely to continue till February 10-11. Even if the domestic demand remains the same, there is a possibility of a rise in retail price due to shortage in supply since a lot of roses are exported,” said Sharma.Bajaj said due to changing climatic conditions, production of roses has fallen this year but she would still retail roses at Rs30 per rose this V-Day.“This price used to be Rs20 a couple of years ago but now Rs30 per rose is the regular retail price,” said Bajaj.Ranvijay Singh Sisodia, another florist in Kalyaninagar, said, “Two years ago, bookings for bouquets for V-Day would start by this time, but we do not have a single order or enquiry to pre-book a bouquet for this V-Day. Demand for roses and bouquets during the occasion has fallen by 50% since the past couple of years.”

Title: Two in net on charge of sharing child pornography video clip in Pune
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The cybercrime police on Tuesday arrested two men on the charge of uploading a video depicting child pornography on a website in April last year.

After tracking the Internet Protocol (IP) address of the cellphone, which was used to upload the video clip, police arrested Raj Kiran Pattilal (24) of Guruwar Peth and Manojkumar Zallar Saroj (19) of Raviwar Peth.

The police found the link to the clip on Monday and started looking into it. They took suo motu cognisance of the clip and filed the case, first such in Pune after a Union government order. The case has been registered with the Khadak police station.

Around a month ago, the Union government traced 35,000 videos depicting child pornography on various websites. The government followed up on this finding by ordering every state government to take action against people involved in uploading or sharing child pornography, the cybercrime police said.

Prima facie probe revealed that almost 150 links or video clips related to child pornography were uploaded from Pune in the past one to one-and-a-half years.

Senior police inspector Jayram Paygude of the cybercrime police station told TOI, “School dropouts Pattilal and Saroj were employed at a utensil shop in Raviwar Peth. The duo had uploaded the video clip on a website from the shop in their free time. The two men did not create the video, they obtained it from someone else.”

In a similar case, the Wakad police on Tuesday booked a man for uploading pornographic videos of women and children on a social media site.

The identity of the man has not been established yet. However, the police have launched a manhunt.

The Wakad police said the man uploaded 20-25 pornographic videos on the site through his profile in a span of six months. The videos went viral within days, the police said.

The police have invoked provisions of the Information Technology (IT) Act and the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act against the man.

The police have warned people against uploading videos related to child pornography on the Internet and sending it through Internet-based mobile messaging applications.

Anyone found in possession of digital or even computer-generated sexually explicit images that appear to depict a child will have to face punishment, as per the provisions proposed in the Protection of Children Against Sexual Offences Amendment Bill that was approved by the Union Cabinet on July 10, 2019.

Title: Telangana racing against time to set up gram nyayalayas
Content: HYDERABAD: Rushing to meet the Supreme Court-set deadline, the Telangana government has fast-tracked the process to facilitate the high court to set up ‘ gram nyayalayas ’ ( village courts ) across the state by February-end.As many as 55 gram nyayalayas would be set up in Telangana with some of them likely to come up at Keesara, Petbasheerabad, Shamirpet and Qutbullapur on the outskirts of the city. The nayayalayas would also be set up in the erstwhile districts of Karimnagar, Nalgonda, Warangal, Khammam, Adilabad, Rangareddy, Mahbubnagar and Medak.The Parliament in 2008 had passed a law for setting up gram nyayalayas to enable citizens access the judicial network at the doorstep, especially at the grass roots level, and ensure socio-economic factors do not stand as an impediment for seeking justice.Telangana law secretary Santosh Reddy told TOI that the state government has completed the exercise of financial sanction for the staff of village courts and were sending the file to the high court that would set up the nyayalayas to be headed by a junior civil judge.On the Supreme Court imposing a penalty of Rs 1 lakh on the Telangana government for its delay in filing a counter in the apex court in connection with the setting up of gram nyayalayas, Santosh Reddy said they were appealing in the apex court to exempt the state from the penalty by submitting the reasons for the delay. “There was some sort of communication gap because of which the delay occurred,” he said.The Supreme Court had a few days ago pulled up several states and Union Territories for failing to set up gram nyayalayas. A bench, headed by Justice N V Ramana, had imposed a fine of Rs 1 lakh on Telangana, Assam, Chandigarh, Gujarat, Haryana, Odisha, Punjab and West Bengal for not filing their responses.The court also further instructed these states and Union territories to notify the court about setting up gram nyayalayas within a month.

Title: Respond on contradictions in animal transportation rules, HC tells Centre, Telangana government
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Telangana high court on Wednesday sought answers from the state and Centre on contradictions in the rules framed by them on transportation of animals.

A bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy was hearing two separate pleas filed by Confederation of Indian Farmers’ Associations (CIFA) and All India Jamiatul Quresh Action Committee which questioned the anomalies in the rules. The bench sought counters from both Telangana and the Centre and posted the case to March.

When the CJ pointed out that the rules were only meant to secure safe transportation of animals, K Vivek Reddy, counsel for CIFA, said the Centre’s rules were slightly liberal while the state’s rules were rigid. Pointing out to contradictions between them, Vivek said: “The state’s rules are burdensome for small farmers.”

Rule 125-E of the Central Motor Vehicles Rules, 1989, was brought in by the central government in 2015 and notified in 2017. However, rule 253 of the Telangana Motor Vehicles Rules, 1989, imposed certain restrictions on transportation of animals. The rules made it mandatory for farmers to have specified vehicles and small vehicles like tempos cannot be used to transport animals. Also, vehicles transporting animals should not be open-ended. An attendant should be deployed with each vehicle and curbs were also imposed on number of animals that could be transported.

The Telangana government issued a memo on December 7, 2019, making it mandatory for farmers and traders to follow these rules. Appearing for CIFA, which has 30,000 small farmers as its members, Vivek said these rules would practically wipe out small farmers who transport five to six sheep or cattle to nearest village markets.

To this, the CJ said: “These rules are not prohibiting transport of animals. They (government) are only specifying the size of the contingent. All they are saying is that no discomfort should be caused to animals which are being transported. Comfortable space should be provided to them during transit time. What is wrong in it?”

However, Vivek said it was not correct for governments to insert animal welfare rules in the Motor Vehicles Act. Upon a query from the bench, assistant solicitor general Namavarapu Rajeswara Rao said he would obtain a counter from the Union ministry of road transport and highways.

The Quresh committee in its plea described the central and state rules as unconstitutional, depriving a large number of small traders and farmers of their right to work. “The entire meat industry will suffer if these new rules are implemented. Only big market players will be able to remain in the fray,” the committee said.

Title: GSI seeks drilling permission from district administration
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NASHIK: The Geological Survey of India (GSI) has sought permission from the district administration for carrying out drilling exercise across Nashik to carry out a study related to earthquake and its possibilities.

The GSI has taken up the programme of Systematic Penetration Test (SPT) for studying the seismic activity. It has submitted a letter to the district administration seeking permission for the same in the Nashik urban area.

The SPT will be carried out to determine geothermic parameters up to the depth of the bed rock in Nashik urban areas for carrying out the seismic microzonation study of Nashik.

The seismic hazard microzonation in and around Nashik city has been taken up they GSI that will create the seismic map of the area to enable the builders and developers, and even the city planners to build structures that will be earthquake resistant.

“The GSI will carry out the drilling activity in the month of February and March,” a district administration official said.

According to the official, there are two fault-lines of earthquakes emanating from Palghar in the neighbouring district to Bhuj in Gujarat and Killari in Marathwada region of Maharashtra.

Killari witnessed an earthquake in September 30, 1993 and Bhuj witnessed an earthquake on January 26, 2001. The microzonation programme has two parts – collecting data and the drilling exercise.

Started from March 2018, the first stage of the two-year exercise is completed and the second stage will end before March 2020.

Title: Maharashtra: Optometrist loses eye in road rage attack; 3 held
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: An optometrist lost his left eye after he was brutally assaulted by three men in a road rage case at Mundhwa chowk in the wee hours of Sunday. The three men were arrested on Tuesday night while an accomplice of their is on the run.

The optometrist, Satish Wankhede (24) of Aurangabad, also suffered injuries on his shoulder and back. He has been admitted to Noble Hospital at Hadapsar.

“We had to remove his left eye as it was badly damaged. He has suffered multiple injuries, including on the scalp and in the abdomen. He has been shifted to the general ward from the intensive care unit,” Noble Hospital medical director Dilip Mane told TOI.

The three arrested men, Yogesh Hanmate (24) from Solapur, and Ritesh Jadhav (21) and Avinash Gaikwad (22) from Keshavnagar, have been remanded in police custody till Saturday.

Wankhede was riding pillion on the motorcycle of his civil engineer friend Akshay Jadhav (24), also from Aurangabad. They were heading towards the new Hadapsar bridge via Mundhwa chowk.

Assistant inspector Prasad Lonare of the Hadapsar police station said, “As they reached the chowk, Wankhede chided the driver of a car for staying too close to their motorcycle. Angered at this, the car driver chased the motorcycle over 1.5km and intercepted it near a hotel at Hadapsar. The driver and the three occupants of the car attacked Wankhede with sharp weapons before speeding off. Jadhav rushed Wankhede to hospital and registered an FIR.”

Lonare said, “Jadhav had not noted down the car’s registration number but told us that the vehicle bore a Maharashtra State logo. A police team under senior inspector Ramesh Sathe and inspector Humraj Kumbhar checked CCTV cameras in the area and identified the routes used by the assailants. They zeroed in on the car and arrested the three men.”

“Investigations have revealed that Hanmate and Jadhav grabbed hold of Wankhede while Gaikwad and the absconding assailant attacked him with sharp weapons. Wankhede and Jadhav had come to Pune searching for jobs and are currently staying at Handewadi,” Lonare said.

The Hadapsar police have registered an offence under sections 307 (attempted murder), 325 and 326 (voluntarily causing grievous hurt with deadly weapons) and 34 (common intention) of the Indian Penal Code against the assailants. “Hanmate and Gaikwad work as cab drivers while Jadhav has studied up to standard XII and is currently unemployed,” the police said.
