Title: Maharashtra: Optometrist loses eye in road rage attack; 3 held
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: An optometrist lost his left eye after he was brutally assaulted by three men in a road rage case at Mundhwa chowk in the wee hours of Sunday. The three men were arrested on Tuesday night while an accomplice of their is on the run.

The optometrist, Satish Wankhede (24) of Aurangabad, also suffered injuries on his shoulder and back. He has been admitted to Noble Hospital at Hadapsar.

“We had to remove his left eye as it was badly damaged. He has suffered multiple injuries, including on the scalp and in the abdomen. He has been shifted to the general ward from the intensive care unit,” Noble Hospital medical director Dilip Mane told TOI.

The three arrested men, Yogesh Hanmate (24) from Solapur, and Ritesh Jadhav (21) and Avinash Gaikwad (22) from Keshavnagar, have been remanded in police custody till Saturday.

Wankhede was riding pillion on the motorcycle of his civil engineer friend Akshay Jadhav (24), also from Aurangabad. They were heading towards the new Hadapsar bridge via Mundhwa chowk.

Assistant inspector Prasad Lonare of the Hadapsar police station said, “As they reached the chowk, Wankhede chided the driver of a car for staying too close to their motorcycle. Angered at this, the car driver chased the motorcycle over 1.5km and intercepted it near a hotel at Hadapsar. The driver and the three occupants of the car attacked Wankhede with sharp weapons before speeding off. Jadhav rushed Wankhede to hospital and registered an FIR.”

Lonare said, “Jadhav had not noted down the car’s registration number but told us that the vehicle bore a Maharashtra State logo. A police team under senior inspector Ramesh Sathe and inspector Humraj Kumbhar checked CCTV cameras in the area and identified the routes used by the assailants. They zeroed in on the car and arrested the three men.”

“Investigations have revealed that Hanmate and Jadhav grabbed hold of Wankhede while Gaikwad and the absconding assailant attacked him with sharp weapons. Wankhede and Jadhav had come to Pune searching for jobs and are currently staying at Handewadi,” Lonare said.

The Hadapsar police have registered an offence under sections 307 (attempted murder), 325 and 326 (voluntarily causing grievous hurt with deadly weapons) and 34 (common intention) of the Indian Penal Code against the assailants. “Hanmate and Gaikwad work as cab drivers while Jadhav has studied up to standard XII and is currently unemployed,” the police said.

Title: Pune: Bhairoba Nullah concreting in PCB area awaits final nod
Content:
The project is crucial for the cantonment which witnessed a flood when the nullah overran its banks a couple o... Read More

PUNE: A proposal for construction of a reinforced cement concrete (RCC) base in the Bhairoba nullah to overcome accumulation of silt, which leads to hindering of the flow of water in the natural stream, has been approved.The Principal Directorate of Defence Estates (PDDE) of the Southern Command gave its nod after the Pune Cantonment Board sent its proposal last November.“After studying the project, the PDDE has approved the proposal and forwarded it to the Director General Defence Estates (DGDE) in New Delhi for a final sanction,” chief executive officer of PCB Amit Kumar told TOI. Work is expected to commence after the DGDE’s final sanction.The project is crucial for the cantonment which witnessed a flood when the nullah overran its banks a couple of times during last monsoon.Over the years, the nullah has become a dumping ground for housing societies which also release their sewage into the stream. A huge amount of plastic and other waste choke the nullah, cantonment authorities said.“We have decided to implement the project in four phases. In the first phase, we will focus on the area between Ganga Satellite Society in Wanowrie and Fatimanagar. The total cost of the project is Rs 84 crore. The current proposal is for the first phase work and will require Rs 22 crore,” Kumar added.The directorate took over two months to survey the stream. “Our endeavour is to begin the work and finish the first phase before the monsoon,” Kumar added.A PCB member, who did not wish to be named, said, “The DGDE will again scrutinise the project before submitting it to the Ministry of Defence for funds. Often, the ministry has queries on the proposal and the whole process becomes time-consuming. The directorate had cleared the project earlier.”A senior official from the directorate told TOI, “In this case, since it is A-1 defence land, the army authorities took extra time to complete their scrutiny and gave an in-principle approval for the project.”The ministry may take a few weeks to sanction the budget. The board will have to float a tender, finalise the agency, award the work and start it at the site. “The board needs at least two to three months and by then the monsoon will begin,” another board member said.

Title: East Central Railway gets Rs 4,614 crore, new terminal at Muzaffarpur
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The East Central Railway ( ECR ) has got an allocation of Rs 4,614 crore in the Union Budget presented in Parliament by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on February 1 for the 2020-21 fiscal.

The ECR has got this allocation for the construction of new lines, gauge conversion, doubling of tracks, safety measures and various other works being carried out at various sites in the ECR’s jurisdiction.

Giving details of the fund allocations, ECR’s chief public relations officer Rajesh Kumar said the ECR has got the allocations to carry out various development and modernisation plans of the railways in Bihar. “While railways has got Rs 459 crore for laying new tracks, it has got the sanction of Rs 173 crore to carry out gauge conversion work in Bihar,” he added.

ECR has been allocated Rs 580 crore to complete track renewal work as part of safety measures. “The ECR has already announced to increase the speed limit up to 130 km per hour for mail and express trains either originating or passing through Jhajha-Patna–Pt Deendayal Upadhaya Junction mainline route from April 30 this year,” Kumar said.

“Railways will spend about Rs 60 crore to build road over bridges or under passes at different places in the ECR‘s jurisdiction by eliminating unmanned railway crossings,” he added.

“The Union Budget has allocated Rs 191 crore for improving safety measures in the ECR while Rs 154 crore has been allocated in the passenger amenities segment,” the official said, adding, railways will spend Rs 54 crore to complete the ongoing track doubling work. Similarly, Rs 111 crore has been allocated to meet the requirements of various workshops running under the ECR’s jurisdiction while a sum of Rs 100 crore is allocated for the modernisation of signal and telecom work in the ECR zone.

The ECR has also got an allocation of Rs 99 crore to fulfil the needs of bridge maintenance work in its all five divisions, Kumar said. Besides, the budget has made provisions for development of a new terminal at Muzaffarpur at a cost of Rs 8 crore and Rs 50 lakh has been allocated for the development of Bhabhua Road passenger terminal. The budget has allocated Rs 2 crore for improving traffic movements at Barauni station while new goods terminals will be developed at Chakand near Gaya (Rs 2 crore), Kataria (Rs 1 crore) and Dumroan (Rs 62 lakh). The ECR has got an allocation of Rs 10 crore for completing interlocking work at 58 big and small stations. According to Kumar, the Dalmianagar goods depot has got Rs 38 crore for further development and the budget has also sanctioned Rs 27 crore for building a new MEMU shed at Gaya while railways will develop tourism amenities at a cost of Rs 2.5 crore at Gaya. “The budget has also made provisions for development of traffic at a cost of Rs 4.5 core at Ara and Rs 78 crore is earmarked for building new foot over bridges at different stations in the ECR as well as raising heights of platforms,” he said.

Title: Burglars steal ornaments, laptop worth Rs 6.24 lakh in Pune
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Burglars broke into the locked bungalow of an elderly woman at a housing society in Undri and stole gold and silver ornaments , and a laptop, collectively worth Rs 6.24 lakh, between January 23 and February 4.

Chanda Nandkishore Jaju (65) of Siyara Society lodged an FIR with the Kondhwa police on Wednesday.

“The woman had gone to stay with her relatives for a few days when the burglars, on finding bungalow number 22/A locked, used a sharp object to break open the locks and the main door. They stole 212g gold and 500g silver ornaments and, a laptop from the bedroom cupboard and decamped with the booty,” said sub-inspector Santosh Shinde from the Kondhwa Police Station.

The burglary came to light after the woman returned to her home and found the ornaments and the laptop stolen. A police team rushed to the spot and launched an investigation.

“Investigations revealed that the burglars sneaked into the society premises by jumping over a small compound wall from the rear side. The construction work of two-three bungalows is in progress,” Shinde said.

“The burglars escaped from the rear side of the bungalow. The lone security guard was at the main gate of the society when the incident occurred,” an officer said.

“A CCTV camera installed at a nearby place has captured images of four masked men entering and leaving the society. We are working on certain clues and hope to detect the burglary at the earliest,” he added.

Title: Over 1.5 lakh farmers qualify for Maharashtra’s crop loan waiver
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The district administration has prepared a list of over 1.5 lakh farmers who would get benefits of the crop loan waiver scheme announced by the state government.

The Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government has announced Mahatma Jyotirao Phule Farmers Loan Waiver scheme in which farmers whose total loan outstanding is less than Rs 2 lakh will get benefitted.

“In the district we have 1.52 lakh farmers, who have taken loans from cooperative, nationalised and private banks, and fall in the criteria announced by the state government. The total loan taken by them is Rs 1,560 crore,” a district administration official said.

According to him, around 1.05 lakh farmers have taken a loan of Rs 990 crore from the Nashik District Central Cooperative (NDCC) bank, while 37,645 have taken loan of Rs 473 crore from the nationalized and other financial institutions and their outstanding is under Rs 2 lakh.

At the same time, there are 9,158 farmers who own vineyards and have taken the loan of Rs 97 crore. According to the government resolution all these people qualify for the loans. However the administration is now trying to figure out how many of the farmers have more than one account and also if the account loan value exceeds Rs 2 lakh.

“If a farmer has two or more accounts with banks and if the loans taken in case of all such accounts are over Rs 2 lakh, the farmer will be disqualified. The process of finding such farmers is being carried out and we expect the number is not more than 10%,” the official said.

He added that there are 1.12 lakh farmers who have cleared their dues worth Rs 1,453 crore already and at the same time there were 32,390 farmers who owed Rs 1,183 crore to financial institutions and whose loan amount exceeds Rs 2 lakh.

“Details of the exact numbers of beneficiary would be known only after the exercise of amalgamation of the accounts of the farmers was completed,” the official said.

Title: After Article 370 move, J&K sees 73% drop in security forces’ deaths
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: There has been a 73% decline in incidents of security forces killed in J&K after the nullification of Article 370 in August, the home ministry informed the Rajya Sabha on Wednesday.

It added that detention orders were issued against 444 persons under J&K Public Safety Act since August 2019, and that 389 were still in detention under the J&K Public Safety Act.

Replying to a question, minister of state for home G Kishan Reddy said that 22 security personnel lost their lives in the 173-day period between August 5, 2019 and Ja nuary 24, 2020, as against 82 during the corresponding 173 days from February 13, 2019 to August 4, 2019. In a written reply to another related question, Reddy said the J&K government had reported that 32 terrorists were killed since August 5, 2019, 10 terrorists arrested and 19 civilians killed in terrorist attacks or during actions against terrorist.

“Regular reviews are undertaken on a case-by-case basis and accordingly, extension in detention or revocation is made based on reports of field agencies and the ground situation,” the MoS told the Rajya Sabha

Title: Pune: New airport director to focus on increasing passengers, flight movements
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Kuldip Singh

PUNE: New director of the city airport Kuldip Singh on Wednesday said he would talk to all stakeholders to identify the reasons behind the drop in the number of flight movements and passengers at the facility.

He said proper data on the load factor of the discontinued flights and the overall data available with the travel agents, airlines and hotels would be studied to know the technical reasons and find solutions.

After assuming charge, Singh said the fact that the Lohegaon airport was an Indian Air Force base must be respected for the sake of national security. “In any defence airport, which is also a civil enclave, the issue of slots remains. I plan to talk with all stakeholders so that a roadmap can be prepared,” Singh told TOI.

“As far as passenger facilities are concerned, a shed — from the arrival to parking number-2 (the pick-up point now) — will come up before monsoon this year,” he said.

Singh has been appointed the Pune airport director in challenging times.

Prashant Girbane, the director-general of the Mahratta Chamber of Commerce, Industries and Agriculture (MCCIA), stressed on the need for setting up a cargo terminal. Former director-general of MCCIA Anant Sardeshmukh said, “The main challenge of the new director will be runway extension and decongestion of traffic around the airport. Another task would be to re-establish and expand the airport’s link with international destinations.”

Singh said the issue of international connections from Pune would be looked into.

Aviation analyst and expert Dhairyashil Vandekar said, “There were issues regarding heavy penalty for parking. The director should do away with such rules.”

Title: Average January night temperature in parts of India highest since 1938
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Contrasting weather prevailed over the country this January. North India had a cold month, but the average temperature in south peninsular India touched an all-time high this year, data from the India Meteorological Department (IMD) show.Globally, the first month of the year was the warmest. As per the data, the average night temperature in south peninsular India in January 2020 was the warmest in over 80 years since 1938, 1.3 degrees above the normal, an IMD official said.The average January temperature in this geographical region was 26.3 degrees C, 1.02 degrees higher than the normal average here and the highest since 1901, beating January 2016, the warmest ever for the region. The data also showed that south India recorded its second warmest ever December in 2019.Arvind Kumar Srivastava, head of the Climate Research Division (Climate Research and Services) IMD-Pune, said December 2019 had the warmest night temperatures since 1901 in at least five cities of Maharashtra — Pune, Ratnagiri, Malegaon, Kolhapur and Dahanu. January 2020 had similar trends for south peninsular India, he added.“Climatologically, we have noticed a trend that when north India is cool during the season, south India tends to record relatively warmer minimum temperatures,” he said.As per IMD, south peninsular India includes five subdivisions of coastal Andhra Pradesh, Rayalaseema, Tamil Nadu and Puducherry, south interior Karnataka and Kerala.“We have noticed a significant amount of moisture and humidity during this winter season in parts of central India as well as peninsular India via the wind regime that persisted almost constantly. These winds were either the moist westerlies blowing form the Arabian Sea or warm and humid easterlies blowing from the Bay of Bengal. As these winds were blowing from the sea regions, they carried moisture,” Srivastava said.Humid winds tend to keep night temperatures up, and are exactly the opposite in nature to the cold, northerly winds that blow from the snow-capped regions of the Himalayas and cause a plunge in temperatures.Srivastava said while parts of central India, including Maharashtra as well as south peninsular India were on and off under the influence of warm, moist winds, the anticyclones from the Arabian Sea continued to block the flow of northerly winds into these regions. “Had the northerly winds reached these regions often during winter this year, then January 2020 would not have been this warm,” he said.The high average temperature (average of maximum and minimum temperatures) in south peninsular India in January this year was a contribution from both, the high maximum or day temperatures here as well as the high minimum or night temperatures during the month.

Title: Telangana: Income Tax lens on TRS brass’ earnings on selling ice creams, playing porters
Content:
K T Rama Rao

TRS did not show earnings: Revanth

HYDERABAD: The Income Tax department has issued notices to senior TRS leaders , including ministers, who had in 2017 collected lakhs of rupees doing petty jobs as part of a fund-raiser.On April 27, 2017, the leaders, including ministers K T Rama Rao , T Harish Rao and former MP Kalvakuntla Kavitha among others, had symbolically sold ice cream, lifted gunny bags as porters, delivered lectures in colleges and sold sarees, and in the process received donations. The money was used for the TRS foundation day celebrations at Warangal.While TRS leaders say that all activities as part of the fundraiser were transparent and no law was broken, Congress Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy, who is the complainant in the case, has a different view.“The rules state that ministers, who are paid salaries, shall not earn money by performing other tasks,” Revanth told TOI. “The Labour Act defines minimum wages for coolies. In that case, how were TRS leaders paid lakhs for lifting a gunny bag? This is a clear case of quid pro quo where businessmen, realtors, hoteliers and hospital owners paid huge sums as bribes to public representatives.”Revanth, who was TDP’s working president in Telangana when the complaint was filed, alleged, “KT Rama Rao sold ice cream to Malla Reddy who runs educational institutions. Many of these institutions have complaints pending with the municipal department for building violations, property tax default and agricultural land being used for non-agricultural purposes. Besides, according to ACB rules, undervaluation or overvaluation of work amounts to a bribe.”Former MP and state planning board vice-chairman B Vinod Kumar said, “Income Tax department issuing notices doesn’t mean the law was broken. TRS leaders collected contributions, and everything was done transparently. Based on Revanth’s petition, Delhi high court issued directions to Income Tax department which is following court orders. All party leaders will reply to the notices. There was no foul play.”Revanth has also alleged that collecting party funds in cash for an amount more than ?20,000 is not allowed. It has to be done through cheque. “TRS party didn’t show this collection in their returns filed with the Election Commission,” he alleged. “Ministers, MPs and MLAs and businessmen also didn’t show them in their returns. Almost all ministers went to establishments falling in the jurisdiction of their departments. For instance, the civil supplies minister went to rice mills, education minister went to colleges and health minister to hospitals,” he added.

Title: Form cabinet panel on new Renenue Act, says Congress
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Former Congress minister DK Samarasimha Reddy has urged chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to constitute a cabinet sub-committee to study and consult all stakeholders before replacing the existing Revenue Act with a new one.

He said the previous government had convened all-party meetings in addition to consulting the stakeholders, including holding meetings with villagers, before revising the Panchayat Raj Act. “Any revision of the Revenue Act should be done with the intention of benefiting the people. The existing Revenue Act in Telangana is comprehensive and a good one,” the senior Congress leader said at a press conference on Wednesday.

At a separate press conference, TPCC election coordination committee convenor G Niranjan demanded that state election commissioner V Nagi Reddy resign from his post. “If Congress Rajya Sabha member KVP Ramachandra Rao was allowed to vote in Nereducherla municipality, how could SEC allow TRS MP K Keshava Rao to vote in Tukkuguda municipality,” he wondered.

Niranjan also demanded that KCR talk about the fate of Metro Rail in the Old City.

Title: Union Budget lays roadmap for South Central Railway infra work
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: In the Union Budget, Rs 6,846 crore was sanctioned for South Central Railway (SCR) to carry out various infrastructure works. In a major boost to ongoing projects in Telangana, Rs 85 crore was allotted for the 85-km Secunderabad-Mahbubnagar track doubling project. Work on the sections between Shadnagar and Gollapalli (29km) is nearing completion. The project was sanctioned in 2015-16.The Manoharabad-Kothapalli new line project received Rs 235 crore. Work on its first phase, between Manoharabad and Gajwel (32km), is nearing completion, “This is a cost-sharing project with the state government and one-third of the cost will be borne by them. Accordingly, land will also be provided by the state free of cost,” said Gajanan Mallya, general manager, SCR.Sanctioned in 1997-98, Rs 240 crore was allotted to SCR for the Munirabad-Mahbubnagar new line project, where work is in progress. As part of another new line between Bhadrachalam and Sattupalli sanctioned in 2010-11, Rs 520 crore has been allotted for a distance of 54km. “After the project is taken up jointly by railways and Singareni Collieries Company Limited (SCCL), land will be provided by the railways and constructional expenditure will be disbursed by SCCL,” said Mallya.Providing a thrust to MMTS Phase-II, Rs 40 crore has been allotted for the project that was sanctioned in 2012-13 at an estimated cost of Rs 817 crore. “The pending work includes the Moula Ali-Ghatkesar and Malkajgiri-Bolarum-Medchal sections. Work on the sections between Telapur and Ramachandrapuram (5.75km) is complete and has been commissioned,” said Mallya, adding that completion of the project is dependent on financial and structural support from the state government.An official release from SCR stated that Rs 10 lakh had been allotted for Ghatkesar-Yadadri extension of MMTS Phase-II, sanctioned in 2016-17 for a distance of 33km.To speed up implementation of Train Collision Avoidance System (TCAS) on the Manmad-Guntakal via Secunderabad, and Bidar-Parbhani routes, Rs 100 crore has been allotted to SCR zone.

Title: Bombay HC seeks explanation from babu over ‘misleading’ wetlands data
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Bombay high court (File Photo)

MUMBAI: The Bombay high court said on Wednesday it was “clear that the under secretary , state environment department , filed an affidavit making an incorrect statement and misled the court as well as his advocate,” in a matter regarding identification of wetlands .

A bench of Justices S J Kathawalla and B P Colabawalla said, “We call on the under secretary of the environment department to explain why action not should be taken for making incorrect statements” which were relied on by court for action against collectors of Parbhani, Nandurbar and Nagpur “who it now appears are not at fault”.

Government pleader P P Kakde submitted three affidavits by the collectors who said there was no wetland in these districts, except for one in a forest area in Nagpur.

The “fault” or controversy was over whether there were any wetlands in three districts or none, as the district collectors mentioned. On January 29, the HC had seen the under secretary’s affidavit. That affidavit said wetland sites were “verified’’ and set out the number in a table. The HC had noted the official had said “while in previous affidavits it was mentioned that there were no wetlands in Nandurbar, Nagpur and Parbhani districts, this was based on the reports received from the respective district collectors; however, after the ‘ground truthing’ was carried out, the actual number of wetlands observed” were set out.

The court is hearing two PILs, one by NGO Vanashakti filed in 2013 for preservation and identification of wetlands. In 2013, the HC had passed orders for identification of wetlands based on 2010 rules. Last December, state lawyer G W Mattos said the rules had changed in 2017 with a new definition of wetlands. HC had then slammed the state for “dragging its feet’’ for eight years, in preparing the “brief document” to identify wetlands and frame a policy.

Gayatri Singh, counsel for Vanashakti, said in Thane the expert panel report found 114 wetlands out of 132 sites. In the brief document given in court, though, only eight were identified and alleged the wetlands were being excluded. Mattos said no experts panels were formed. He said any discrepancy can be raised before the wetlands authority’s grievance redressal committee. To this, Justice Kathawalla, in a lighter vein, said, “There is no better grievance redressal than us.”

Title: Two Maharashtra students ‘prefer’ to stay in Wuhan: Collector
Content:
The government evacuated more than 600 Indians from China

NASHIK: The Dhule district administration has said that two local students studying in Wuhan are in good condition and that they prefer to stay in the Chinese city that is the epicentre of coronovirus.Girish Patil and Chandradeep Jadhav, both 29 years old, are pursuing higher studies at Wuhan University of Science and Technology.The students, who ere selected by the university under its fellowship programme, completed their masters in science before travelling to Wuhan in November last year.They chose to stay back when the Union government had sent two special Air India flights to evacuate Indians from Wuhan. The government evacuated more than 600 Indians.Dhule district collector Gangatharan Devrajan told TOI that he spoke to both the students a couple of days ago. “They told me that they are in good shape and although the city is under lockdown, they have sufficient stock of food and other essentials.”Devrajan quoted the students as saying that there is nothing to worry about. “I told them that in case of any emergency, they must get in touch with me immediately, without any hesitation,” said the district collector, who has shared his contact number with the students.While Girish is a resident of Dhule town, Jadhav is from Simkheda taluka of the district.Tejpal Girase, a social worker from Dhule, said that he is touch with the two students and their family members. “Both of them told me that they do not want return as their studies would suffer. They share one room in the university hostel and the local authorities at Wuhan city are taking proper care. They believe that there is no reason to panic,” he said.Girase added that the students’ and their families are in constant touch.

Title: Youth killed in Gwalior celebratory firing
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: A youth was killed during a celebratory firing at a wedding in Gwalior on Tuesday night.

Three people have been booked and a hunt has been launched by police to arrest them. The incident took place at Bilara village under Hastinapur police station of the district.

The deceased has been identified as Udal Singh Kushwaha, resident of Bilara, said police. “Three people have been booked and a hunt has been launched to arrest them. The accused received bullet injuries and died on the spot. The celebratory firing was being done by relatives of the groom. Most probably, the accused were in inebriated condition. We are hopeful of arresting the accused soon, as they have been identified and a case has been registered against them,” Kushwaha said.

Title: Skiing course restarts in Uttarkashi after 7 years
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The course is being run in the picturesque Dayara meadow by NIM

UTTARKASHI: After a gap of seven years, Uttarkashi-based Nehru Institute of Mountaineering ( NIM ) has restarted its snow skiing course at Bharnala region of Dayara meadow in Uttarkashi district.

As many as 30 adventure lovers from different parts of the country are participating in the 14-day training course, which began on January 28. Officials associated with the premier national mountaineering training institute told TOI that they are also mulling to develop Dayara meadow as a world-class snow skiing ground on the lines of Auli .

Colonel Amit Bisht , principal of NIM, said, “Besides providing training of mountaineering, sports climbing and other high-altitude adventure sports, NIM also used to organise regular snow skiing course till 2012. But, the course got discontinued in 2013, as our personnel got involved in the reconstruction work of Kedarnath valley post the flash floods disaster. Now, we have once again restarted the course from the last week of January and will organise it on a regular basis.”

“To tap into Uttarkashi’s tremendous adventure sports possibilities, we are now aiming to develop Dayara meadow as a world-class snow skiing ground on the lines of Auli in Joshimath . Besides, NIM will also use these training courses to form Uttarakhand’s state skiing team, which will compete in national and international-level events,” he added.

Meanwhile, local villagers expressed happiness over the re-launch of the snow skiing course. Pankaj Kushwal , a tour operator in Raithal village situated near Dayara meadow, said, “The course will help in developing Dayara meadow as a winter sports destination. It will also increase the rush of adventure lovers to the largely unexplored meadow and eventually boost the local economy.”

Title: Man opens fire at forest officials inspecting mining site near Nainital, arrested
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

NAINITAL: A man, believed to be part of a local mining mafia syndicate, opened fire at four forest department officials who were inspecting a mining site in Ramnagar area of Nainital district on Monday. He was arrested by police late on Tuesday.

Police said that the forest team had gone to the spot late on Monday for inspection when the man, identified as Anand Manral , countered them. “The officials were inspecting the Kosi riverbed where they found the accused acting suspiciously. When they confronted him, at first he tried to fight but seeing himself getting overpowered, he opened fire at them and fled,” said Ramnagar station house officer Ravi Saini .

Saini added that the team included a forest inspector and his three associates. “Fortunately no one was injured in the firing but as the officials filed a complaint, a case was registered and we conducted raids at certain locations. We arrested the accused on Tuesday from Tehsil Gate area and presented him before the magistrate who ordered his custody,” Saini said.

This is not the first instance in which people suspected to have connections with mining mafia have threatened government officials. In 2015, a trainee IFS officer was attacked in Ramnagar when she was conducting a raid on illegal mining while in 2017, a forest beat watcher was killed when he was run over by a tractor by members of mining mafia. The incident also took place on the Kosi riverbed near Ramnagar.

Saini meanwhile said that they have started the investigation and are questioning Manral about his connections with illegal mining syndicates.

He added that the accused has been booked under sections 186 (obstructing public servant in discharge of public duties), 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from his duties), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of peace) and 506 (criminal intimidation) of Indian Penal Code.

Title: Maharashtra: One held, two booked for theft, issuing threats
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The MIDC Bhosari police arrested a man and booked his two accomplices for robbing a gold chain from a 30-year-old man on Telco Road on Tuesday morning.

Telco road resident Prashant Balasaheb Landge (30) lodged a complaint with the MIDC Bhosari police, stating that the suspects forcibly entered his house around 11 am and robbed his 50g gold chain worth Rs 1 lakh.

The suspects then ransacked his home. They damaged his sofa, bed and electronic goods, police said.

When Landge put up a resistance, one of the suspects fired in the air. No one was injured, police said.

Earlier in the morning, the trio had threatened a woman at her home with dire consequences on Dighi road in Bhosari. A separate offence has been lodged against the suspects by the Bhosari police.

The 20-year-old woman lodged a complaint with the police, stating that the trio knocked on the door of her house around 6am on Tuesday. When she did not open the door, the suspects hurled abuses at her and threatened to kill her husband.

After hurling abuses at her and her husband, the suspects left the spot. Police said the suspects had picked up a quarrel with her husband over a trivial issue a few days ago and wanted to teach him a lesson.

Title: Run for Merit on Sunday
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Aurangabad: Advocacy group Save Merit-Save Nation has organised a mini-marathon: Run for Merit in the city on February 9.

The event aims to reach out to the public and increase support for the movement against the alleged excess reservation in Maharashtra.

“The Run for Merit is one of our attempts to promote our movement. A large section of people from the society are dissenting against the new social reservation in Maharashtra, but do not know how to voice their anger. The proposed mini-marathon aims at uniting different sections of the society who are against excess reservation,” the organisers said

The event will be held in two categories — three-kilometer and five-kilometer. The reporting time will be at Aurangabad divisional sports complex at 6 am. ‘Save Merit Save Nation’ has also organized a similar ‘Run for Merit’ in cities like Mumbai and Solapur on February 9.

The state-wide public movement has started against alleged excess reservation in Maharashtra in the wake of newly-introduced quotas for economically weaker sections and Maratha community had resolved for invoking the NOTA option during the recent assembly elections.

A state-level delegation on behalf of the movement had also met then Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis to raise issues related to excess reservation.

Title: Coronavirus scare grips Bhopal
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: In a first major scare of Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection here in the state capital, a 31-year-old man suffering from acute respiratory syndrome was admitted to AIIMS on Wednesday.Institute officials confirmed that the man had a recent travel history to China and his samples have been sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune.Meanwhile, test reports of four suspected patients sent from AIIMS, Bhopal are still awaited and no positive cases of 2019-nCoV has been yet reported in Madhya Pradesh though there are around 26 suspected cases of the deadly virus.According to AIIMS Bhopal officials, the 31-year-old patient who is in a serious condition was admitted to the hospital on Wednesday. He has been placed under quarantine. The patient, who is a businessman by profession, has a severe respiratory infection along with fever, cold, cough and is also diabetic. He had visited China three weeks back and returned to Bhopal recently. His family and relatives are also being screened for the suspected infection.The current coronavirus outbreak was initially noticed in a seafood market at Wuhan city in Hubei province of China on December 12, 2019, and has spread across China and many countries, including India.Internationally, approximately 24,000 confirmed cases of 2019-nCoV have already been reported with a death toll nearing 500 – a 2.07% fatality rate.The health ministry has informed that the number of airports screening passengers for symptoms of 2019-nCoV infection has also been increased as a precautionary measure.Coronaviruses are respiratory viruses and broadly distributed in humans and other mammals. Rarely, animal coronaviruses can evolve and infect people and then spread between people such has been the case with SARS.Although most human coronavirus infections are mild, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) — have caused more than 10,000 cumulative cases in the past two decades, with mortality rates of 10% for SARS-CoV and 37% for MERS-CoV, as per the Union health ministry guidelines on prevention of 2019-nCoV.

Title: Optometrist loses eye in road rage attack; 3 held
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

PUNE: An optometrist lost his left eye after he was brutally assaulted by three men in a road rage case at Mundhwa chowk in the wee hours of Sunday. The three men were arrested on Tuesday night while an accomplice of their is on the run.

The optometrist, Satish Wankhede (24) of Aurangabad , also suffered injuries on his shoulder and back. He has been admitted to Noble Hospital at Hadapsar.

“We had to remove his left eye as it was badly damaged. He has suffered multiple injuries, including on the scalp and in the abdomen. He has been shifted to the general ward from the intensive care unit,” Noble Hospital medical director Dilip Mane told TOI.

The three arrested men, Yogesh Hanmate (24) from Solapur, and Ritesh Jadhav (21) and Avinash Gaikwad (22) from Keshavnagar, have been remanded in police custody till Saturday.

Wankhede was riding pillion on the motorcycle of his civil engineer friend Akshay Jadhav (24), also from Aurangabad. They were heading towards the new Hadapsar bridge via Mundhwa chowk.

Assistant inspector Prasad Lonare of the Hadapsar police station said, “As they reached the chowk, Wankhede chided the driver of a car for staying too close to their motorcycle. Angered at this, the car driver chased the motorcycle over 1.5km and intercepted it near a hotel at Hadapsar. The driver and the three occupants of the car attacked Wankhede with sharp weapons before speeding off. Jadhav rushed Wankhede to hospital and registered an FIR.”

Lonare said, “Jadhav had not noted down the car’s registration number but told us that the vehicle bore a Maharashtra State logo. A police team under senior inspector Ramesh Sathe and inspector Humraj Kumbhar checked CCTV cameras in the area and identified the routes used by the assailants. They zeroed in on the car and arrested the three men.”

“Investigations have revealed that Hanmate and Jadhav grabbed hold of Wankhede while Gaikwad and the absconding assailant attacked him with sharp weapons. Wankhede and Jadhav had come to Pune searching for jobs and are currently staying at Handewadi,” Lonare said.

The Hadapsar police have registered an offence under sections 307 (attempted murder), 325 and 326 (voluntarily causing grievous hurt with deadly weapons) and 34 (common intention) of the Indian Penal Code against the assailants. “Hanmate and Gaikwad work as cab drivers while Jadhav has studied up to standard XII and is currently unemployed,” the police said.

Title: ASI staff keep close watch on devotees
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Thanjavur: The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has deputed more than 70 of its employees to keep the structures, inscriptions, sculptures at the Big Temple without getting damaged, as thousands of devotees have converged during the consecration ceremony of the temple. It was a step to ensure that none of the historical structures are damaged by anyone.

The ASI took up the renovation of the Brihadeeswarar temple at a cost of Rs 50 lakh. Though it was a periodic maintenance work carried out by the ASI, it coincided with the consecration of Big Temple.

The ASI has done chemical cleaning of sculptures, inscriptions and structures including all the gopurams and vimanam of the Big Temple.

An official from the science branch of the ASI, Purasoparaj, told TOI that chemical cleaning was done by adopting four steps such as chemical cleaning, consolidation, bio side treatment and preservation.

On the steps taken to keep the structure intact, conservation assistant of ASI S Shankar said that they have entrusted the responsibility with 70 people, including 15 regular ASI staff. “Our people are taking utmost care by resisting devotees if they knowingly or unknowingly do any harm to the structure, sculpture and inscriptions,” he added.

Garbage gathered on the temple premises would be cleaned during night hours. Mass cleaning would be done along with municipal corporation workers, Shankar added.

Title: Man held for setting woman on fire in Aurangabad
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The victim's house in Andhari village

AURANGABAD: A 40-year-old man has been arrested by Sillod police for forcefully entering the house of a woman and setting her on fire by pouring kerosene following an argument in Andhari village on Sunday night.

Hearing the woman’s cries for help, her daughter and son-in-law — who live nearby — rushed to her rescue and took her to Aurangabad ’s Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), where she is battling for life with over 70% burns, said police on Wednesday.

The suspect, identified as Santosh Mohite (40), was arrested and produced before a local court that remanded him in six-day police custody. Mokshada Patil, superintendent of police (Aurangabad rural), on Wednesday said police have gathered all the evidence and the seized material has been sent for chemical analysis (CA).

“Our Inquiry is complete and we are waiting for the CA report. Charge-sheet in this case will be filed within 15 to 20 days,” she said.

“One of the victim’s relatives said that the man was known to the victim and both were comfortable with each other. It is a serious crime and we have left no stone unturned to make a tight case against the culprit,” Patil added.

Meanwhile, police sources said that Mohite operates a bar in the village. “The complainant has stated that she was alone in the house when the suspect knocked at the door. As soon as she opened the door, the suspect entered the house. The woman objected to it and said visiting her at odd hours would bring her disrepute.”

The source added, “The suspect took offence to the victim’s statement and started assaulting her. He then threw kerosene at her and threw a match stick. The woman’s saree caught fire following which she started crying for help. Her daughter and son-in-law rushed to help and doused the flames before taking her to the hospital.”

Title: Grand consecration at Big Temple after 23 years
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Thanjavur: Thousands on Wednesday witnessed the grand consecration at the Brihadeeswarar Temple (Big Temple) in Thanjavur, conducted after a gap of 23 years. As per court order, the ceremony was performed in both Tamil and Sanskrit.

A group of Odhuvars recited Thirgnanasambandhar’s Thirumurai before pouring holy water on the ‘Kalasam’ erected atop the Vimanam (temple tower) of the Big Temple at 9.21 am on Wednesday after vedic hymns were recited in Sanskrit by priests.

The events began on January 27. Poorvanga puja and eight Kala Yaga pujas were held on February 1, and the event concluded with the final phase of eight Kala puja on Wednesday early morning. Later, holy water brought from Ýaga Salai was taken to the temple tower in a procession.

P Maniarasan, coordinator of the Big Temple Rights Retrieval Committee who had initially demanded that the ritual be conducted in Tamil, said, "Our efforts to bring Tamil in the forefront during the consecration have succeeded. Not only the Big Temple but all the temples, whether owned by the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments (HR&CE) or private parties, Tamil should be the main language during rituals. We want to conduct ‘kumbabishekam’ (consecration) in all the temples in Tamil."

Meanwhile, several departments of the state government along with the HR&CE made elaborate arrangements for devotees to have a hassle-free darshan.

District collector M Govinda Rao participated in the event. Hundreds of police personnel have been deployed at the temple. Inspector general of police (central zone) A Amalraj supervised the security arrangements.

Title: Tamil Nadu: This 93-year-old devotee never missed a consecration
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

M Natarajan

THANJAVUR: For 93-year-old M Natarajan, visiting temples carrying his handheld fan (Saamaram) made of peacock feather during consecrations is a usual practice. He would participate in the temple procession waving the fan. During the consecration of the Big Temple, he told TOI that he has been doing this for the past 53 years as a ‘Kaingaryam’ (service).

Natarajan, a native of Madurai, has dedicated his entire life for rendering service to the god. “Wherever there is a consecration, I will be there and wave the fan for the deity, even though there is no invitation. I have never missed the ‘Nei Abishekam’ at Sabarimala during Margazhi. Serving god is the meaning of my life, nothing else”, he said.

Meanwhile, a group of young musicians comprising college students and private company employees attracted the attention of the devotees by performing various musical instruments including conch, kombu, brahma thalam and udukkai during the consecration.

P Deepak Akash, 18, a first-year BCom student of a private college in Chennai, performed ‘S’ shaped ‘kombu’, a woodwind instrument. A native of Karanthai, he is a member of a troupe of a 15-member musicians. “One of my relatives used to play ‘kombu’ and I love to play the instrument. So, I joined the troupe last year. Whenever there is a function at the Big Temple, we will be there without fail,” he said.

G Sugumar, head of the troupe, said they perform conch, thiruchinnam, S-shaped kombu, ekkalam, brahma thalam, udal and udukkai. These are all called ‘Siva Vathyam’ (instruments of Shiva).

Title: Delhi elections: AAP forms 272 teams to check flow of cash, liquor
Content:
Representative image.

NEW DELHI: Two days before Delhi goes to polls, AAP on Thursday formed 272 teams , one in each municipal ward, to check on money and liquor being distributed to influence voters . The chief electoral officer of Delhi has already put in place an elaborate mechanism to check cash and liquor flow during the elections. AAP’s teams will work as vigilantes against opposition parties.AAP MP Sanjay Singh said the party had received information that money and liquor were being distributed in some areas, so the teams were formed to keep a track on such incidents.“All teams are equipped with mobile phones to record distribution of cash and liquor. Anyone who comes across such incidents, where money or liquor is being distributed by any political party, can send us evidence over WhatsApp on the number 9355015501,” said Singh.Meanwhile, AAP lodged a complaint with the Election Commission on Thursday after it learned that “many BJP MPs were staying in different constituencies from February 4 to 8.” This is an open violation of the model code of conduct because after the end of campaigning, no MP or cabinet minister can stay in Delhi, unless he is a resident of the city. “We met EC and requested it to ask them not to stay in Delhi,” Singh said.

Title: Devotees excited as Odhuvars recite Thirumurai in Tamil
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

THANJAVUR: More than 50 Odhuvars from across the state recite Thevaram, Thirumurai at Yagasalai puja during the consecration. They expressed happiness and wished this be followed at all the temples. Devotees and general public were excited to hear the hymn and puja in Tamil during the consecration of Big Temple in Thanjavur .

Following various petitions filed before the Madurai bench of the Madras high court, the HR&CE authorities were ordered to hold various rituals and pujas in accordance with the agama principles and Tamil should also be given due importance by chanting Thirumurai in the language.

As per the directives, more than 50 Odhuvars were engaged in Thirumurai recitation during the consecration ceremony. Senior Odhuvars from across the state including Muthukumaran from Madurai, Kumaraswaminathan from Karur , Swaminathan from Tiruthani, Shanmugasundaram from Palani , Sivakumar from Mayiladuthurai recited Thirumurai from Yaga Salai puja till the beginning of the consecration ceremony.

During the eight Kala puja at the Yaga Salai, two senior Odhuvars presented Thirumurai songs. They also recited Akhanda Parayanam. Another group of Odhuvars presented Panniru Thirumurai Mutrothal at the Yaga Salai. On the day of consecration, the Odhuvars presented Akhanda Parayanam altogether in front of the shrine.

S Mangai, 65, from Kumbakonam who participated in the event was excited after hearing mantras being recited in Tamil during the ceremony. “I have never heard Tamil in temples during consecration. This is the first time that I heard Tamil. I am so happy. We need not neglect any other language. But if Tamil is going to play a major role, everybody can understand it well,” she said.

R Vijayan, 22, an employee of a theatre in Thanjavur, said he had heard Tamil hymns recited by Odhuvars at the temple. But, it was the first time he had the opportunity to hear Tamil during the ceremony.

Meanwhile, few devotees opined that as per the agama principles hymns should only be recited in Sanskrit. “Since it is the practice for years, we should not change it all of a sudden,” K Manoharan of Karur said.

Title: Collector who conducted first consecration seeks more funds for Big Temple
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

THANJAVUR: Besides stressing on various issues to the government with regard to Big Temple, people should ask for more funds to develop the Unesco heritage site in a better way, said T Gangappa, the collector of the erstwhile integrated district of Thanjavur , who conducted the first consecration of Big Temple after Independence.

As per Hindu custom, consecration of a temple should be performed once in 12 years. Sources from the HR&CE department said that the Big Temple had consecrations in 1010, 1729, 1843, 1980 and 1997.

Of the few consecrations, the one held in 1980 was the first consecration performed after the Independence, Gangappa said. He was the district collector of the integrated districts of Thanjavur, Nagapattinam and Tiruvarur between June 1979 and April 1980.

In March 1980, he conducted mahamaham in Kumbakonam followed by the consecration of Big Temple in April, he said. “Unlike now, crowd management was not that difficult then. Devotees were self-disciplined. During both events, not even a single incident of a pickpocket was reported. Now the situation has entirely changed. Despite scores of challenges, district collector Govinda Rao has done a good job,” he said.

He also participated in the consecration held in 1997 as a devotee, where more than 40 devotees died in a fire accident, he said.

“There may be several issues with regard to conducting consecration. But as a Tamil, we the people of Tamil Nadu should focus our target for the development of Big Temple. It lacks several facilities as a Unesco heritage monument. We should try to get more fund from the government and should take the fame of the historic temple to the nook and corners of the world,” he added.

Title: Madhya Pradesh becomes sixth state to pass resolution against CAA
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

BHOPAL: The Kamal Nath-led cabinet in Madhya Pradesh passed a resolution against Citizenship Amendment Act on Wednesday morning, becoming the sixth state and fourth Congress-ruled government to do so. The resolution will now be forwarded to the Narendra Modi-led Union government, said law minister P C Sharma.

“The Madhya Pradesh government, in order to ensure equality to all sections of people before law, as intended and provided in the Indian Constitution, urges the government of India to repeal Citizenship (Amendment) Act 2019,” says the resolution.

Punjab, Bengal, Kerala , Rajasthan and Chhattisgarh have passed similar resolutions. “The MP government also urges the Government of India not to seek new information for updation of National Population Register (NPR) 2020 from people so that apprehensions in the minds of citizens is dispelled and only after this NPR updation work is undertaken,” it adds.

Secularism is a fundamental percept of the Constitution, and it cannot be changed, the resolution says. “Preamble of the Constitution clearly mentions that India is a secular nation. Besides, Article 14 of the Constitution guarantees equality to all sections of people without discrimination. This (CAA) will threaten the very secular fabric and spirit of tolerance in the country,” it says, arguing that CAA 2019 is discrimi natory as it grants citizenship on grounds of religion.

“It is not in keeping with the secular character of Indian Constitution. After the Constitution came into effect, it is for the first time that a law has been enacted that discriminates among people on the grounds of religion. This will jeopardize the secular character of the nation and its belief in communal harmony,” the resolution warned. The Kamal Nath government wonders why CAA was enacted at all.

Title: AAP starts a web campaign to hit back at BJP claims
Content:
Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal and his deputy Manish Sisodia.

NEW DELHI: On the last day of election campaign AAP launched a satirical web offensive titled Amit Shah Ka Ulta Chashma to “combat the lies” being spread by BJP about AAP government. A website, amitshahkaultachashma.com, was also started to convey pictorially the “reality” of governance in Delhi before and after AAP came to office.The website has seven images in “before and after” format. Through these pictures, AAP has sought to convey what the situation in Delhi was before AAP formed government and how things changed thereafter with launch of mohalla clinics and improvements in night shelters and playgrounds. There are also visuals of government schools and other initiatives.Over the last few weeks, BJP has criticised the performance of Kejriwal government and claimed that it had failed on all counts. “The fact is that AAP has not only fulfilled the 70-point manifesto as promised in 2015, but also delivered much more,” AAP said in a statement on Thursday.A party source said the idea behind the satirical campaign was that BJP was unable to see the development outcomes delivered by AAP because its “glasses are tainted.” This campaign suggested that despite the fact that AAP delivered on its promises, BJP was insistent on a negative campaign against it, they said.The AAP campaign seeks to depict that it has worked hard to develop government schools by upgrading infrastructure, introducing a happiness curriculum and taking other initiatives, apart from creating a positive educational environment. The visuals showed how the “one-of-its-kind” mohalla clinics had brought about changes in the health infrastructure, besides communicating the initiative to increase streetlight cover in the city. It also talked of the endeavour to make Delhi a dark spot-free city and enhance the security of women, an AAP source said. Lastly, the visuals depicted the story of how AAP government had developed night shelters where the poor and homeless could comfortably spend nights, instead of sleeping in the open in the winter and rains, another source added.

Title: Centre, states in talks over CAA, NPR: Govt
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NEW DELHI: The government on Wednesday told the Rajya Sabha it was in discussion with the state governments having concerns with regard to implementation of the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), besides preparation of the National Population Register (NPR).

States like West Bengal , Kerala as well as many Congress-ruled states have voiced their reservations to CAA, alleging that it discriminates on grounds of religion. In written reply to a question, minister of state for home Nityanand Rai said central government had received resolutions adopted by legislative assemblies of certain states such as Rajasthan. He added that Kerala government had also filed an original suit in the Supreme Court under Article 131 of the Constitution.

“The government is in discussion with the states having concerns in regard to the preparation of National Population Regisiter (NPR) and implementation of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA),” Rai said but did not give any details as to the level and nature of such discussions.

Meanwhile, in reply to another question, Rai informed the Elders that 2,668 Pakistan were granted Indian citizenship in the last five years since 2015, apart from 15,012 Bangladeshis and 665 Afghanistan citizens.

Title: Coronavirus in Mumbai: Coronavirus testing kicks off in Mumbai, Navi Mumbai resident given clean chit
Content:
Representational Image

MUMBAI: Testing for the 2019 Novel Coronavirus began in Mumbai on Wednesday, with a 29-year-old Navi Mumbai resident showing up negative for the virus at the BMC’s molecular diagnostic laboratory located at Kasturba Hospital near Saat Raasta.Since the coronavirus scare began in mid-January, eight others were placed in quarantine at the BMC-run Kasturba Hospital but discharged after they tested negative for the virus.On Wednesday, the Navi Mumbai man was kept in Kasturba Hospital’s isolation ward as he has fever. “We tested his swab sample for the novel coronavirus at the Kasturba PCR lab, and it was negative,” said additional Mumbai municipal commissioner S Kakani. This is the first test for 2019 nCoV in Mumbai. The BMC plans to send his blood sample to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune to be “doubly sure”.According to Government of India rules, only NIV can perform blood tests for the novel virus while a dozen newly identified laboratories across the country can do the swab test. Rajiv Gandhi Medical College in Nagpur is the second laboratory in Maharashtra to start the test.Incidentally, the BMC on Tuesday earmarked Rs 2 crore for the upgrade of the molecular laboratory in its latest budget. Budgetary allocation has also been made for the hospital, which has six cubicles in its ward number 30, also known as the isolation ward, to get 145 more beds as a special quarantine facility.The Navi Mumbai resident, who works with a shipping company, had travelled to Nantong in China between January 22 and February 3. As he developed fever, he came to Kasturba Hospital and has been tested for other conditions such as H1N1 viral infection as well. Three others were placed in isolation at the state-run Government Medical College in Nagpur.Meanwhile, the state health department said 12,799 passengers were screened at Mumbai airport for nCoV viral infection between January 18 and February 5. Of these, 119 who had a travel history to China were from Maharashtra. Giving a breakup of the passengers, the state health update said 21 of them were placed in quarantine and had tested negative and were discharged. The Navi Mumbai resident is the ninth passenger to be placed in isolation so far, said Kakani. Forty of the 119 travellers completed their 14-day home surveillance, said officials.
