Title: Goa: urvey skips state of economy, data riddled with inaccuracies
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Goa chief minister Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: On the eve of the state budget , the economic survey for 2019-20 tabled by the government on Wednesday is strangely silent on how Goa’s economy performed in the current financial year.

The survey itself is full of errors and appears disconnected from ground reality with government officials blaming lack of data forcing them to calculate even the growth by taking an average projected growth rate of the past five financial years.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant , who also holds the finance portfolio, will present his maiden budget on Thursday as the state reels under mining shutdown, fewer footfalls from tourists, lower GST collections and a sluggish economy.

Government officials told TOI that Goa’s economy is expected to grow at around 6%, if one removes inflation, in 2019-20, while the nominal growth is likely to be a shade higher at 9.5%.

The state’s gross state domestic product (GSDP), according to the economic survey, grew by 17.65% at constant prices in 2018-19, the year when mining came to a standstill and private sector investments dried up.

This number is expected to come down in the coming months as data comes in, said government officials.

Real growth is calculated at constant prices as it accounts for the changes in prices of all goods and services produced in the state and provides a more accurate estimate of economic growth compared to nominal growth which is measured at current prices.

The economic survey said Goa’s economy grew at 9.82% at current prices in 2018-19 and the slowdown has been attributed to the ban on mining.

The economic survey did not give sector wise contribution to the GSDP for 2019-20. An official with the directorate of planning, statistics and evaluation said data for 2019-20 was dropped at the last minute on the instructions of the government.

Academicians from the field of economics said that nominal growth (current prices) is usually higher than real growth (constant prices), but the economic survey shows an inverse trend.

Another discrepancy seen in the report is in the public debt estimates with the economic survey pegging the state’s debt at Rs 15,008.66 crore, while documents released in the ongoing state legislative assembly session peg the total debt at Rs 20,411.61 crore.

The survey report also said that tax revenue for 2019-20 shows a 10.1% increase as compared to the previous financial year of which the state’s own tax revenue shows a growth rate of 9.1% and share in central taxes at 12%.

The survey projects that non-tax collections for 2019-20 will stand at Rs 3,100 crore.

Title: Notice issued to 14 power plants a month after deadline expires
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Fourteen coal-based power plants in the country are set to face severe action for defying the deadline set for installing environment protection measures. In show cause notices sent on January 31 – a day before the Union budget – the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) sought an explanation from the plants why they should not be closed down and environmental compensation be imposed.

Significantly, the board sent the letters exactly a month after the second deadline (December 31, 2019) expired for emission reduction that was submitted in the Supreme Court. Continuous attempts by TOI throughout January asking what action was being planned did not elicit information from the body.

On January 19, TOI had reported that the operation of plants post the deadline was in violation of the Centre’s promises made in the apex court.

Among the designated plants – which totally produce around 16.41GW of power – 5 are in Haryana, 3 in Punjab, 2 each in Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, and 1 in Tamil Nadu.

While announcing the Union budget on February 1, finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman stated that old plants not meeting emissions norms will be closed. Show casue notices issued the next day have granted power plants a time period of 15 days to submit their responses.

Speaking to TOI, CPCB’s member secretary Prashant Gargava said that the board will be reviewing individual progress made by all the plants. “While we have issued similar show cause notices to all units which failed to comply with our directions, different actions will be taken as the plants are at different stages of installing pollution control equipment. Some have initiated the bidding process, some are expected to comply with the emissions in a month or two,” he said.

According to the notices, different plants have failed in complying with emission targets of different pollutants including sulphur dioxide, particulate matter and oxide of nitrogen. All the 14 plants have failed to retrofit flu-gas desulphurization (FGD), a technology to control SO2 emissions.

Welcoming the step taken by CPCB, environment experts stated that strict action should be taken to set a strong precedent for other power plants. “Units which are yet to make significant progress should be shut down and penalized heavily. To ensure that the other plants having 2020 and later deadlines do not meet the same fate, CPCB should set interim targets and milestones,” said Sunil Dahiya, analyst at the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA).

In a notification issued by the Union environment ministry in December 2015, all coal-fired power plants were first directed to install pollution-control technologies by December 2017. The plants failed to do so.

The deadline was then extended to December 2019 after the ministry of power and central electricity authority (CEA) submitted a new phasing plan in the Supreme Court in 2018.

The ministry submission came during a hearing related to extension of deadline for implementing emission standards as part of the MC Mehta case.

Title: Women plant 5,000 saplings of 70 species in Latur under plantation drive
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Women, including school teacher and college professors, took part in the drive organised under the aegis of th... Read More

AURANGABAD: As many as 500 women from rural and urban areas of Latur planted 5,000 saplings of 70 different species under the plantation drive on Tuesday.

Women, including school teacher and college professors, took part in the drive organised under the aegis of the Mission Green Earth, the Art of Living (AOL) and International Association for Human Values at Nagzari village and Manjara River Rejuvenation Project.

Mahadeo Gomare, state project director of the Art of Living, said that “As the world reels under devastating effects of climate change, with Australian bushfires claiming billions of animal lives and the Amazon losing critical biodiversity, people are looking at solutions to combat and reverse these effects.’’

One powerful way in this fight against climate change is by planting more saplings to increase the green cover, and support agroforestry that has far reaching environmental and economic benefits for everyone, and particularly for farmers, he said.

“Rural women are the key to supply food, water, nutrition and everything necessary to sustain their village. Their role within the community is indispensable. They are the most affected by the reduction in rainfall, depleting soil nutrients and low-quality food. With this programme, we want to bring women belonging to different walks of life together to plant trees and be an agent of change for securing food, nutrition and water for the community, “ said Gomare.

Gomare said that due to the changing climate patterns, the cultivation of plants in Marathwada and Vidarbha is the only option to maintain economic stability in the region. Tree plantation helps farmers earn extra income. Farmers will be able to thrive and can gain economic stability. Plantation helps to increase the rainfall, maintain it consistently and increase the water turnover in the soil.

He also said an International Women’s Conference will be organised between February 14 and 16 in Bangalore, where 500 women leaders from across the globe will take the Mission Green Earth forward by pledging to plant 10 million saplings in the next two years.

Title: 12 city traffic cops booked for graft in 5 years, state tells HC
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Mumbai: A dozen city traffic constables were booked under Prevention of Corruption Act in the last five years, the state government told Bombay high court and listed steps taken to ensure smooth traffic. An affidavit was filed in 2018 in a PIL filed in 2017, alleging rampant corruption in traffic police department, which was disposed of on Monday as the department had shown compliance to earlier orders.

With the matter not reaching final hearing for two years due to lack of time, public prosecutor Deepak Thakare pointed to affidavits of 2018 before a bench of Justices Ranjit More and S P Tavade. In the last order in February 2018, a bench of Justices S C Dharmadhikari and Bharati Dangre had expressed “hope and trust’’ that the joint commissioner of police (traffic), who had filed an affidavit, and deputy police commissioner (traffic), would spread public awareness on where to complain about “traffic police seeking bribe from drivers of two and four wheelers or heavy vehicles’’.

“It is unfortunate that our time is wasted in reminding officials… that this court expects them to work sincerely and diligently,’’ the bench had said in its 2018 order. “We are not saying that… traffic congestion can be eliminated suddenly given the number of vehicles and increasing population, but such incidents can always be minimized,’’ said the HC, telling police to take a leaf from densely populated cities abroad.

“If sincere efforts are undertaken, and on par with thickly populated cities in India and abroad, such issues can be tackled. We hope and trust that beyond these affidavits, the data will be placed before us and concrete action is taken,” it said.

The HC had in 2018 said people could complain about traffic police talking over the phone instead of assisting motorists and also about those not towing away vehicles parked illegally.

The PIL, filed by policeman, Sunil Toke, said his lawyers, Pradeep Havnur and Datta Mane, sought to raise a larger concern against corruption by traffic police. The traffic police said that in compliance with the 2018 directions, they had issued more than 3.75 lakh in six months for illegal parking and towed away almost 1.5 lakh vehicles. They also recruited over 1,100 traffic wardens and received 165 email complaints, of which 52 pertained to bribes being sought. Fifteen turned out to be baseless, but in 25 cases, allegations were prima facie true; four police personnel were suspended, eight issued show-cause notices, and 13 transferred to non-executive posts.

Police said they had 213 handheld breathalysers since 2017.

Noting lack of parking space around schools, police requested some schools to ensure buses are made compulsory, with Cathedral school having agreed to participate in a pilot project.

Title: Coronavirus News: Coriander and garlic pod not effective cure for coronavirus
Content:
Representational Image

MUMBAI: There is no truth in the rumour that garlic pods, corinander leaves or cow’s urine are effective against the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV), said the state government's health officials on Wednesday.“There is no scientific basis for such rumours. The health ministry hasn’t endorsed such views,” said state health minister Rajesh Tope.There is no specific medication to treat the novel coronavirus but Chinese doctors have reported success with off-label use of certain drugs.Earlier, the AYUSH ministry clarified it didn’t claim “effective treatment” for the new coronavirus, which has killed 490 in China so far and affected 24,324 others; of them, 3,219 are severe. The ministry had put out an advisory suggesting “preventive management steps,” including some herbs.

Title: Bamu departments still await academic audit
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: While Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University ( Bamu ) has ordered mandatory academic audits for affiliated colleges, different university departments are yet to undergo such exercises.

The university has 43 departments on its campus along with nine departments located at the Osmanabad sub-centre, taking the total number of departments to 52.

Meanwhile, the university has extended the last date for submission of proposals by affiliated colleges for conducting the academic audit till February 10. The earlier deadline of January 31 was postponed further due to requests from colleges, Bamu authorities said.

Student activist Tukaram Saraf said Bamu must order academic audit of its departments also along with the affiliated colleges.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: All 9 isolated travellers test negative twice, discharged in Maharashtra
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The civic-run Naidu hospital has discharged all the nine isolated patients after their throat swabs tested negative for the novel coronavirus infection twice.“Now, we don’t have any new admission to the isolation ward. All the isolated travellers were discharged after their throat swab samples tested negative for the virus ,” Ramchandra Hankare, chief of the health department at Pune Municipal Corporation, said on Wednesday.Even as the threat of infection has been put to the rest in the city for now, four more travellers in Nagpur and Mumbai were isolated on Wednesday after they complained of minor illness.Their throat swab samples have been sent to the Pune-based National Instiute of Virology (NIV) to rule out the novel coronavirus infection. “Three travellers have been quarantined at a designated isolation centre in Nagpur and another traveller has been isolated in Mumbai. All of them recently returned from coronavirus-hit China. We will get the result of their throat swab tests on Thursday,” a state health official said.A total of 12,799 passengers returning from China and other affected countries have so far been screened at the Mumbai’s Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport since January 18. Of them, 119 travellers, who are residents of Maharashtra, are under surveillance.“Of the 119 passengers, 44 have completed the 14-day surveillance period. The remaining travellers who are unsymptomatic are being followed up about their health telephonically,” the official said.Earlier, travellers with a travel history to China were kept under observation for 28 days as there were doubts about the exact incubation period of the virus. “Now, there are enough information that suggests that a person after being exposed to virus may develop illness within 14 days. Hence, travellers who returned from China on January 15 and onward are being followed up for 14 days now,” the official said.Meanwhile, Mumbai’s molecular diagnostics PCR laboratory at Kasturba Hospital and Indira Gandhi Medical College in Nagpur have been shortlisted to share the burden of coronavirus testing with the Pune-based NIV.Garlic pod, coriander not effective cure: OfficialsThere is no truth in the rumour that garlic pods, coriander leaves or cow’s urine are effective against the novel coronavirus infection, the state government’s health officials said on Wednesday. “There is no scientific basis for such rumours. The health ministry hasn’t endorsed such views,” state health minister Rajesh Tope said.There is no specific medication to treat the novel coronavirus but Chinese doctors have reported success with off-label use of certain drugs.Earlier, the AYUSH ministry had clarified that it didn’t claim “effective treatment” for the newest coronavirus. The ministry had put out an advisory suggesting “preventive management steps,” including some herbs.(With inputsfrom Mumbai)

Title: Marathwada witnessed over 700 forest fires in last 4 years
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

According to official data, forest fires in Marathwada have increased since 2017 with a slight dip in the figu... Read More

AURANGABAD: Marathwada , a region having the lowest forest cover in Maharashtra, has witnessed as many as 696 forest fire incidents in the past four years. These calamities have destroyed 2,598 hectare forest cover in the region, further reducing the forest cover.

Coinciding with the ongoing forest fire prevention week being observed in Maharashtra by the state forest department, authorities have brought to public notice that those who are responsible for causing such disaster can be subjected to imprisonment of upto two years, besides getting slapped with a fine of Rs 5,000.

Chief conservator of forests (territorial), Aurangabad , P K Mahajan on Wednesday said that locals dwelling around forest areas as well as tourists visiting the forests must ensure that no man-made activity on their part triggers forest fire.

“Stringent laws are in place to deal with the incidents of forest fire arising due to man-made causes and persons involved it. Forest fire destructs local biodiversity and such harm can by irreversible. It is collective responsibility of people to ensure that such untoward incidents do not occur,” he said.

Aurangabad forest circle, which consists of three territorial divisions and three independent sub divisions, has total forest cover of 2882.78 sq km. The area deals with all reserved, protected and unclassified forests, among other areas, except the areas included in Gautala Autramghat Wildlife Sanctuary, Jaikwadi Bird Sanctuary, Painganga Sanctuary, Naigaon Peacock Sanctuary and Yedshi Ramling Ghat Sanctuary.

According to official data, forest fires in Marathwada have increased since 2017 with a slight dip in the figures last year.

Forest department authorities said that “unknown persons” are responsible for around 99% fire incidents by and large. “It is difficult to trace people who are responsible for triggering forest fires as it is an open territory. Proper awareness about the ill-effects of such fires on local biodiversity and humans as a whole can contain the incidents of forest fires,” authorities said.

Wildlife expert Hemant Chhajed said the that the forest department must adopt zero-tolerance policy while dealing with the incidents of forest fires.

“Besides enabling provisions of the Indian Forest Act, 1927, the government agencies are empowered with Wildlife Protection Act, 1972, Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, 1967, The Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, 1984 and Biological Diversity Act, 2002 to deal with the culprits associated with forest fires. These legal tools must be used to take the investigation in the incidents of forest fires to the logical end and punish the guilty,” he said.

Citing an affidavit submitted by the Centre in the Supreme Court in one of the environmental cases, Chhajed said that a forest land of around one hectare is worth around Rs 1.62 crore. “The damage caused by forest fires in Marathwada in the last four years runs into crores of rupees, besides inflicting harm upon the wildlife and biodiversity,” he said.

Experts have also stressed on the need for focussing on preventive measures such as taking ‘fire line’ in the protected and reserved forest areas, ensuring sufficient availability of the fire-fighting equipment and proper training to forest department staffers to reduce the number of forest fires.

Title: In Goa, 1 vehicle for every person
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose.

PANAJI: Vehicle density in Goa stands at one vehicle per person. The economic survey 2019-20 states that 14.5 lakh vehicles have been registered in the state as on December 31, 2019, even as provisional figures of the Census 2011 places Goa’s population at just about 14.5 lakh.

On an average, 80,500 vehicles are registered in the state every year, according to the latest economic survey of the state. The number of vehicles registered during the financial year 2019-20, up to December 31, 2019, is 46,352.

Figures for the distribution of vehicles in the financial year 2018-19 indicate an increase in registration of transport vehicles.

With taxi registrations going up drastically, and goods vehicles and hire motorcycles rising slightly, it could be a likely contributing factor for increased vehicle population in the state.

Compared to 1,269 taxi registrations in the financial year 2016-17, there were 116 more registrations in 2017-18 with a total of 1,385 taxis registered. This further increased to 3,024 taxi registrations in 2018-19.

Figures indicate an overall drop in non-transport vehicles with only 75,085 registrations in 2018-19 as opposed to 86,119 in 2017-18.

Even two-wheelers, the most preferred mode of transport in the state, saw a fall with motorcycle and scooter registrations reducing by nearly 9,500. A total of 50,209 were registered in 2018-19 as opposed to 59,734 in 2017-18 and 56,926 in 2016-17.

Motorcycles for hire on the other hand escalated to 1,986 registrations in 2018-19 as opposed to 1,566 the previous year. These fall under the transport vehicles category. A total of 7,282 vehicles sum up transport vehicles, like motorcycles for hire, goods vehicles, taxis, buses and mini buses (including those of the Kadamba Transport Corporation), and auto-rickshaws.

The purchase of private cars and jeeps have shown a slight drop compared to the last financial year with 17,414 registered in 2018-19 compared to 20,990 in 2017-18 and 18,267 in the financial year prior to that.

Title: Growth rate of agriculture sector on a decline, Goa minister tells House
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose.

MARGAO: Despite the state government’s “efforts” to promote agriculture in the state, the growth rate of Gross Value Added (GVA) for the sector is on a steep decline.

This was evident from a written reply tabled in the House by agriculture minister Chandrakant Kavalekar , to a question posed by Margao MLA Digambar Kamat pertaining to the rate of growth of agriculture.

While in 2017-18, GVA figures stood at Rs 2,09,344 lakh, posting a growth rate of 12.93%, 2011-12 being the base year, the figures slumped to Rs 1,88,958 lakh in 2018-19, reflecting negative growth at a rate of 9.74%.

A separate written reply tabled by Kavalekar in the House to a question raised by St Andre MLA Francisco Silveira also points to the decreasing area of land under paddy cultivation, and falling rice production in the state.

In 2018-19, the estimated total area of land under paddy cultivation was approximately 27,219 ha during the kharif season, while it was 11,301 ha for the rabi crop. In 2019-20, however, the area under paddy cultivation decreased to 24,411 ha. As the rabi season is currently under way, the figures for this crop weren’t made available.

Meanwhile, another written reply tabled in the House by Kavalekar stated that the agriculture department disbursed Rs 90 lakh to farmers whose fields were damaged owing to inundation during the 2019 monsoon from its own budgetary allocation. The farmers were also compensated through chief minister’s relief fund, it was informed.

Kavalekar further said in his written reply that minor maintenance works of bunds and sluice gates were tendered and “accordingly, the minor breaches have been plugged on an emergency basis to avoid further damages”. The reply also stated that minor maintenance works of the bunds and the sluice gates due to damages caused by heavy rains were carried out by the respective tenants’ associations under the 50% subsidy scheme as per the direction of the concerned mamlatdars and as per the provisions of the Goa, Daman and Diu Tenancy Act, 1964.

The agriculture department has also prepared detailed estimates for strengthening of bunds after the damages which have been submitted to Water Resources Department (WRD) for accord of technical sanction. “Presently, the estimates are being scrutinized by WRD and after accord of technical sanction, the works will be tendered, after obtaining administrative approval,” Kavalekar said in his written reply.

Title: In 100% ODF Goa, govt admits that not all houses have toilets
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose.

PORVORIM: Goa has been declared open defecation-free ( ODF ) but that does not mean all houses in panchayat areas have toilets, panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho said in the House on Wednesday.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant , too, admitted that people who had applied for bio-toilets were yet to receive them and assured that the government would supply toilets to all applicants by May.

When opposition leader Digambar Kamat asked the state government if there were any cases of open defecation despite the state being declared 100% ODF, Godinho, in a written reply, only accepted that the state had been declared ODF.

“Since the date of declaration of Goa as ODF, no work orders for construction of toilets have been issued by the Goa Waste Management Corporation , which is the executing agency,” Godinho said.

When asked if all houses in panchayat areas have toilets, Godinho replied in the negative, but did not elaborate any further. The department also chose not to provide panchayat-wise details of homes with open toilets and those that lack toilets.

In a separate reply to a question tabled by Congress Ponda MLA Ravi Naik, chief minister Sawant said contractors had already been appointed to construct bio-toilets and that the same contractors would ensure the toilets were maintained for the next three years. Naik had stated that people from the Curti-Khandepar village panchayat had made payment but had failed to receive their bio-toilets.

“The state has been declared ODF, but we are aware that there are individuals who are yet to get toilets. We will try to finish all work by May and provide toilets to them before this monsoon,” Sawant told the House.

He further said that the state had received a total of 18,518 applications for installation of bio-toilets.

“Four contractors are on board and will take care of the construction of toilets in all 12 talukas. Work on 472 bio-toilets is in progress,” Sawant said.

Elaborating on the cost, he said a toilet for individuals from the general category, including other backward classes (OBC), was Rs 2,500 while those from the scheduled castes (SC) and scheduled tribes (ST) categories will have to pay Rs 1,000. Each toilet costs Rs 58,184, he said.

Title: Goa: Opposition MLAs give power panel memoon billing change
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

MARGAO: Opposition MLAs on Wednesday jointly submitted a memorandum to the chairman of the Joint Electricity Regulatory Commission (JERC), Panaji , demanding that the petition by the state electricity department proposing a “change in billing approach” be rejected.

The memorandum states that the public notice inviting response published in local dailies was “misleading as it shows that the existing tariff for low tension domestic consumers for 2019-20 and the proposed tariff for 2020-21 as the same”.

“Though the fine print proposes a change in the billing approach for 2020-21 and in another paragraph explains the proposed non-telescopic billing approach, it is highly likely that the public will be misled and will not consider approaching the JERC as the perception would be that the tariffs have not changed,” the memorandum reads.

Stating that the public notice also points to the revenue gap of Rs 296.8 crore that is sought to be met through budgetary support by the state government, the opposition MLAs have demanded that, “the power department should provide evidence that it has taken all necessary and possible steps to plug transmission and distribution losses, loss of revenue due to theft of energy and non-billing and non-recovery of arrears from consumers”.

Power minister Nilesh Cabral described the MLAs’ representation as drama and said the power tariff is not hiked.

Title: Why can’t a tiger be punished for eating a cow, asks Goa ex-CM Churchill Alemao
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Former chief minister of Goa Churchill Alemao

PANAJI: While the House went back and forth on what measures could be taken to ensure the safety of tigers in the state, former chief minister Churchill Alemao raised the need to safeguard the lives of humans as well. Alemao asked when humans are “punished” for “eating cow meat” can a tiger be spared for the same offence?

In true Alemao fashion, he raised the need for the government to be more humane in its approach. “Can a tiger eat a cow and there be no punishment for him?” he said on Wednesday.

While the statement drew scoffs from members of the House, Alemao made a case for protection of all— cow, man and tiger. The lone NCP MLA said, “This a serious matter, don’t laugh at me.”

Last month, four tigers—three cubs and a tigress— were killed in the state. He said that as per the forest act, tiger tops the list, while for humans the cow is more important. Alemao said poor villagers who lost their cows to tiger attacks, also lost their source of livelihood. “If a poor man loses his cow, his source of livelihood is destroyed. What if he has done something to the tiger, will he (man) be punished? Isn’t there any value for human life?” he said.

The former minister pointed out that even stray animals are tended to and cared for. “Former Union minister Maneka Gandhi wanted to do something for stray dogs. I see people sleeping on road and there is no one to look after them,” he said, urging the government to look at issues on “humanitarian grounds”.

The government must take steps to ensure that such incidents do not happen while also protecting villagers staying close to wildlife sanctuary, he said.

Five suspects arrested in connection with the poisoning of the tigers have been released on bail. The Goa government has faced flak for its lapse in protecting wildlife.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant told the House that an investigation is under way and that they are awaiting the reports of the viscera samples sent to four different laboratories in the country.

Earlier, former deputy chief minister Vijai Sardesai demanded a CBI probe into the incident.

Title: Central Vista plan: DDA to start two-day hearing today
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

DDA has also approved the change for six other plots spread over 86 acres in the Lutyens’ Bungalow Zone

NEW DELHI: The Delhi Development Authority ( DDA ), which has received more than 400 objections to the proposed change of land use of different plots in central Delhi for the proposed Central Vista redevelopment project , is going to hold a public hearing on Thursday and Friday before finalising the move.

In December, the authority changed the land use of different plots, including that of a 15-acre plot on Dalhousie Road near South Block, from recreational to residential. This is the location where a new Prime Minister’s residence has been proposed. DDA has also approved the change for six other plots spread over 86 acres in the Lutyens’ Bungalow Zone.

The approvals include the change of land use from public and semi-public to government offices for plots where Vigyan Bhavan, National Archives and Raksha Bhavan are located. The land use for a 9.5-acre plot has been changed from recreational to Parliament House.

The changes were put in the public domain for 30 days and a board of inquiry will now take up the suggestions and objections, following which the Union housing and urban affairs ministry will come up with the final notifications. DDA has received various objections, ranging from questioning the need for the project to its impact on environment and traffic. A DDA official, however, said most of the submissions were repetitve and overlapping.

Title: Chandrakant Patil tells Maharashtra government to prepare for next quota hearing
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Chandrakant Patil

Title: AICC secy takes veiled jibe at Rajini over Periyar row, supporting BJP on CAA
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Villupuram: Srivella Prasad , secretary of All India Congress Committee, in a veiled barb hit out at actor Rajinikanth for spreading misinformation about Dravidian leader Periyar and for backing the BJP on CAA , NPR and NRC on Wednesday. He attended a Congress Villupuram central district general body meeting at a guest house here.

“One cinema actor who wants to transform himself as a politician and is trying to taint the history of Tamil Nadu and great Dravidian leaders like Periyar who stood for secularism. It is apparent that the actor follows the ideology of BJP by supporting CAA, NRC and NPR in a recent media interview,” Prasad said.

Strongly criticising the AIADMK government for backing the BJP in the Centre whose main agenda is to “destroy democracy and constitution of the country with its anti-people policies, including CAA”, he said that it should give a clear explanation for backing the BJP.

“It is a general perception that only the ruling party will get a majority in the local body elections, but DMK and Congress coalition broke it in the recent local body elections in Tamil Nadu. Today’s meeting seeks to come up with a strategy to prove the majority of DMK and Congress alliance in the pending local body elections,” he said.

Prasad said secularism and democracy is under threat for the past six years under the BJP regime and that the rate of unemployment is very high in the country. The recent budget failed to offer a solution to socio-economic issues, he said.

The BJP government is least bothered about the development of the country and its main agenda is to transform India into a ‘Hindu Rashtra’ advocating the ideologies of Savarkar, a Hindu nationalist who formulated the Hindutva philosophy, added Prasad.

Title: Gujarat: Gauge conversion spurs worries about lion safety
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

AHMEDABAD: The Union Budget for 2020-21 has sanctioned gauge conversion of 71km of track between Talala and Visavadar, at a cost of Rs 460 crore. The track cuts through the heart of the Gir Sanctuary . Wildlife experts believe this conversion will prove harmful to lions.The railway ministry also approved the gauge conversion for 70km of track connecting Talala and Delwada, passing through Jamwala.Railway officials said that in 2018, the Union government decided to exempt a few metre-gauge lines from conversion to broad gauge due to their tourism and heritage appeal. These routes included the metre-gauge train between Veraval and Amreli, which passes through Gir sanctuary.The Talala to Visavadar stretch was soon to be declared a heritage line. The proposal to preserve it as a heritage route meant that the line passing through the sanctuary was never be converted to broad gauge.A senior railway officer said the heritage route project was shelved as local politicians wanted the track to be converted to broad gauge. Politicians claimed that the train’s speed limit could be limited 20km per hour despite conversion into broad gauge.Wildlife experts say the conversion could prove dangerous for lions, as a broad-gauge train will move at a minimum speed of 50km while a metre-gauge train will have a minimum speed of 30km per hour.Lion experts said that when the Kodinar track was converted to broad gauge, several lions were killed on the track by speeding goods trains.The officer said the metre-gauge train connecting Veraval and Amreli makes four trips a day, two up and two down trips. The train travels 18km inside the sanctuary, entering it at Sasan and leaving its limits near Kansiya Nes.In the sanctuary, the train reduces its speed to less than 20km per hour. Fortunately, there has been no lion death on these tracks so far, the officer said.

Title: Goa: No plans on future of sugar factory despite annual losses of Rs 25 crore
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: The state is still uncertain whether the Sanjivani Co-operative Sugar Factory, if repaired, will generate profits or not. Presently though, the government bears an annual loss of Rs 25 crore, including expenditure on subsidies, chief minister Pramod Sawant told the state assembly on Wednesday.

“Of 25,000 tonne, most of the sugarcane from the farmers has already been accepted by the factory. Only Rs 4,000-5,000 tonne remains. We are releasing payment to the factory after which that produce, too, will be accepted. The main concern of the farmers was if they should cultivate sugarcane (in the following season) or not. We have told them to go ahead and cultivate for now. We have not taken any decision on Sanjivani as of now,” Sawant said.

While Sanguem MLA Prasad Gaonkar said the government should think in the interest of the farmers more seriously, Sawant said, “One also needs to see that for many years now, they are showing three trucks for one truck (of cane). There are some. We have to see that too.”

Curtorim MLA Aleixo Reginaldo Lourenco said the chief minister should look at taking action against such fudging of records.

Title: Badarpur MLA, now candidate of BSP, attacked
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

New Delhi: Outgoing Badarpur MLA Narayan Dutt Sharma , contesting this assembly election on a BSP ticket , was allegedly attacked by armed goons early on Thursday when he was returning from campaigning in his constituency. His car was also damaged.

Dutt, who won the Badarpur assembly seat in 2015 on an Aam Aadmi Party ticket, claimed that after wrapping up his campaign, he had just reached the lane near his house when a group of four-five men forced his driver to stop the Scorpio and smashed its windscreen with sticks. When Dutt and his aide tried to stop the attackers, they allegedly attacked the MLA too. A case of assault and criminal conspiracy has been registered at the Badarpur police station on the basis of Dutt’s complaint.

Dutt told the cops that around 1am, he was returning with his driver and one of his aides when the attackers drove past his car and blocked his way with their vehicle. They came out of the car with sticks and baseball bats and started hitting the windscreen. One of them also damaged the windowpane on his side, injuring him on the face and the head, the candidate claimed. His driver and aide were also injured. The attackers ran back to their car after vandalising the Scorpio and fled, Dutt told police.

“As none of them had covered their face, I can recognise them if I see them again. They seemed to have planned to kill me but couldn’t succeed as none of us got out of the car,” said Dutt, who was hospitalised for a few hours after the incident. The MLA shifted to the Bahujan Samaj Party after having been denied a ticket this time.

DCP (Southeast) R P Meena said police had found some clues and were questioning a few people to identify the accused.

The aide who was travelling with the candidate claimed that the attack might be linked to a monetary scam that Dutt had exposed. “We have requested police to check this angle,” he said.

Title: CM Arvind Kejriwal invites Amit Shah for debate before polls
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Arvind Kejriwal welcomed PM's announcement of a Ram Temple Trust, saying there was no bad timing for good work

NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Wednesday invited Union home minister Amit Shah for an open debate after BJP ignored a “1pm deadline” set by him to reveal its chief ministerial candidate for the Delhi elections. “Amit Shah ji should come and debate with us at a place and time of his choosing. I will debate with him on every issue he wants to talk about,” Kejriwal said.

He said the people of Delhi had a lot of questions on their minds. “Let us have an open and honest debate. Debate is good for democracy. There will be one anchor from our side and another from yours,” Kejriwal proposed.

He said BJP should at least declare the likely candidates for the chief minister’s post. “If you can’t tell who your chief minister face is, at least announce your likely candidates. Whether it’s Vijay Goel, Manoj Tiwari, Hardeep Singh Puri, Harsh Vardhan ji, or Smriti Irani... people should know before they cast their vote,” Kejriwal said.

The AAP national convener also wondered why BJP did not clear the roads near Shaheen Bagh , where a public protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act was on for nearly two months, and said the party was doing “dirty politics” over the issue to grab power in the capital. “The entire country is watching that for the sole aim of winning the elections, you have inconvenienced the people living there,” he said.

Responding to media queries on the alleged links of Shaheen Bagh attacker Kapil Baisla’s with Aam Aadmi Party, the CM said: “If the attacker is found to have links with AAP, he should be punished with 20 years of imprisonment and not 10. Don’t play dirty politics over national security. People understand your intentions.”

On the Prime Minister’s announcement of a Ram Temple Trust just ahead of polls in Delhi, Kejriwal said: “I welcome this development and congratulate the people of India. There is no bad timing for good work and I don’t object to its timing. Make more good announcements.”

Talking about BJP’s election campaign, the CM said that India could never develop by playing Hindu-Muslim politics. “We want to make a 21st-century India. Our country has all the resources, but our system and politics are wrong. Education and infrastructure (development) is the only way forward. India can never develop by doing Hindu (politics).”

In a dig at Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath who had claimed that Kejriwal was now reciting Hanuman Chalisa as he feared losing the elections, the CM said: “BJP should also chant Hanuman Chalisa... if they do it regularly, they will get peace of mind...”

He slammed Shah for seeking votes in Delhi by claiming that Bharatiya Janata Party had abrogated Article 370 in Jammu and Kashmir and paved the way for the construction of Ram Temple in Ayodhya . “They have already received votes for these issues in the general election. What did they do for Delhi in the last five years? Why should people vote for them in Delhi?” he asked.

He also questioned BJP’s performance in the corporations in last the 15 years. “Why are they against the free services being provided to the people of Delhi and why do they want to end them?” he asked.

The chief minister said BJP called him a terrorist, but didn’t give any proof. “How is this son of Delhi a terrorist? Prakash Javadekar says he has proof... bring it out in public domain,” he retorted.

Title: Students get answer key on scholarship mock test day
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The students of Zilla Parishad schools in the district attempting the practice paper for the middle (Standard V) and high school (Standard VIII) scholarship exams received the question paper as well as its answer key on January 31.

As per practice, the ZP conducts mock tests for students before the examination. It is conducted in schools taluka-wise. On January 31, the exams were conducted in the Mulshi and Maval talukas when the incident occurred.

One of the teachers realized the mistake and notified the Zilla Parishad (ZP) education office, following which the exam was stopped.

The Shiv Sena leader at Pune ZP Devidas Darekar raised the issue with the ZP CEO Ayush Prasad. He said, “The question papers distributed to the students were of 15 pages and the answer keys were printed on the 16th page. The format was such that if the answer to a question was the “a” option, then the answer keys had the correct answers printed on the page for all the 75 questions in the papers. The CEO has promised to take action.”

Prasad said the question paper and answer key are sent to all panchayat samitis by email. “They take printouts and distribute them among the students. The printouts of the answer keys were also distributed by mistake. We have conducted an inquiry into the matter and have also sent memos to the exam supervisors as they should have realized the error. These exams are conducted on a weekly-basis so we will re-conduct another mock test this week.”

The scholarship examination, conducted by the Maharashtra State Council of Examination, will be held on February 16.
