Title: Maharashtra: Man kills wife, her uncle, bodies rot for two days
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The reason behind the murder is still unknown, but sources said that family disputes might have led Jayant to ... Read More

NAGPUR: The semi-decomposed bodies of a 55-year-old woman and her maternal uncle were found in their flat on the first floor of an apartment on Wednesday in Dattatray Nagar. The bodies were lying in a pool of blood with stab marks on the bodies and ligature marks on the necks.

The deceased have been identified as Manjusha Natekar, 55, and her maternal uncle Ashok Kate, in his 70s. Sakkardara police have registered a case of murder and arrested Manjusha’s husband Jayant from Nagpur railway station within five hours of the incident coming to light.

The reason behind the murder is still unknown, but sources said that family disputes might have led Jayant to kill the duo.

Family members of the deceased told TOI that Manjusha, headmistress at a primary school in Subhedar Layout, used to live with her husband and maternal uncle in the flat. Kate, who was unmarried, had shifted to live with Manjusha after his sister died around one-and-a-half years ago.

Manjusha and Jayant regularly used to get into fights over family issues. On Monday too the couple had got into a fight.

A neighbour told TOI she heard Manjusha screaming for help several times on Monday morning at around 11. “We went to see what was happening but Jayant sent us away, saying it was their household matter. So we went away. They had also kept the TV on, so that no screams could be heard outside. At around 2.30pm on Monday, Jayant locked the door and went away on his two-wheeler. After that we did not heard anything from the house till Wednesday,” the neighbour said.

Sources from the police claimed that Jayant initially strangled Manjusha in the bedroom before stabbing her, and then strangled Kate before stabbing him too.

Since Manjusha did not go to school for two days, the school officials tried calling her. When they did not get any response, they called Manjusha’s brother Rajesh and informed him about her absence.

Rajesh went to Manjusha’s house and found the door locked. He opened the door with a spare key, and found Kate and Manjusha dead, and a stink spreading in the house. He raised an alarm and summoned the neighbours. One of the neighbours informed Sakkardara police. The crime branch cops too reached the spot.

Commissioner of police BK Upadhyay, Additional CP Shashikant Mahavarkar, DCP Chinmay Pandit, and DCP (crime) Gajanan Rajmane also visited the spot. Upadhyay directed cops to nab Jayant as soon as possible and also appointed five teams.

Cops conducted the spot panchanama and sent the bodies to Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), where the post mortem will be conducted on Thursday.

Cops later nabbed Jayant from the railway station but were yet to officially place him under arrest.

Title: Kerala: Two held with 15kg of gold in Kasaragod
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Customs officials retrieved gold chains and bars hidden in the vehicle’s secret chambers.

KANNUR: Two men were arrested with 15.525 kg of gold worth Rs 6.2 crore in their possession at Bekal in Kasaragod on Wednesday .

Both the men were from Sangli, Maharashtra, customs commissioner Sumit Kumar said, adding that their identities would be revealed later.

The seizure, by the Kasaragod customs preventive unit, was the biggest in Kannur division after 1988, when 1,600 gold biscuits were seized at Irrikur in Kannur, according to customs assistant commissioner E Vikas.

“The accused have said that the gold was smuggled into India in paste and powder form. We suspect the involvement of Kasaragod-based smuggling mafia in the incident,” Kumar said.

The accused, aged 30 and 26, were travelling in a Maharashtra-registered SUV, and the customs officials had been shadowing it from Thalassery , based on a tipoff.

When the SUV crossed Kanhangad and stopped at a toll plaza at Bekal, the officials intercepted the car, and found the golden chains and bars hidden in the vehicle’s secret chambers.

The accused, arrested under the Customs Act, 1962, reportedly told the officials that they were carrying the gold to Mumbai. The suspected carriers would be produced before the chief economic court in Kochi .

Title: Governor gives go-ahead for probe against Ebrahim Kunju
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Governor Arif Mohammed Khan has given sanction to investigate into the allegations of corruption against former PWD minister V K Ebrahim Kunju in the Palarivattom flyover scam . The decision will help end vigilance’s three-month wait to probe the role of former PWD minister in the scam.

The vigilance had in October last year sought the clearance of the state government to carry out an investigation into Ebrahim Kunju’s role in the flyover scam. Following this, the state government sought the governor’s permission and handed over the vigilance letter to the Raj Bhavan.

“As per new regulation from the Supreme Court, the sanction of a governor is required to carry out an investigation against former ministers. The prosecution permission is given only after the investigation is complete and the FIR is registered,” the governor’s office said.

The governor had sought legal opinion from the advocate general before taking a decision. Now the vigilance can go ahead with the investigation against Ebrahim Kunju. Kerala high court had earlier given permission to vigilance to probe into the former minister’s role in the alleged irregularities in the construction.

Ebrahim Kunju was under the scanner for allotting funds to the bridge builder way above the permissible limit. The vigilance wanted the former minister’s role probed as he had issued the order to give advance funds for the construction. The vigilance is also of the view that Ebrahim Kunju could not shy away from the responsibility in the alleged conspiracy. Former PWD secretary T O Sooraj, who was arrested for his involvement in the scam, had also raised allegations against the former minister.

The vigilance report said an amount of Rs 8.25 crore was paid as advance to the company at a meagre interest of 7%. This resulted in a yearly loss of Rs 57 lakh to the state government.

The flyover was opened to public in 2016. However, after cracks were detected on the pillars, various agencies had pointed out the inadequacies in the construction and it was closed for traffic in May 2019. A probe was subsequently launched to look into the likely irregularities that led to the faulty construction.

The probe was also extended to examine the role of certain political leaders in the scam. T O Sooraj, Sumit Goel, managing director of RDS Projects Ltd which constructed the flyover, and M T Thankachan, former additional general manager of RBDCK, were arrested earlier in connection with the scam and granted bail with strict conditions last year.

Title: Many gaddas sell drugs, run by goons: Mauvin
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Porvorim: Calling for a check on the increasing number of gaddas (food kiosks/carts) in villages, panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho said the gaddas at some places sell drugs and are operated by anti-social elements. “Some gaddas even sell drugs — you can verify with the police. They are operated by goons ,” he said. Godinho said most gaddas— as many as 95 % of them—are rented out by Goans to outsiders, without even checking their antecedents.

The panchayat minister said he would introduce a policy within three months, to crackdown on gaddas indulging in illegal activities,and also shabby-looking kiosks that “spoil the image of the state”.

“A hawkers’ zone needs to be created and the gaddas should be made uniform in design,” Godinho said.

Title: PMC Bank Scam: BJP neta’s son, 6 others named in Rs 6,700 crore PMC fraud chargesheet
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Policemen stand guard outside a branch of PMC Bank in Mumbai (File Photo)

MUMBAI: The city economic offences wing (EOW) on Wednesday filed a 12,000-page supplementary chargesheet in the Rs 6,700 crore Punjab and Maharashtra Cooperative (PMC) Bank loan fraud case against former BJP MLA Sardar Tara Singh’s son, Rajneet Singh, and six others. In December, police had filed a 32,000-page chargesheet against five accused in this case.

HDIL group directors Rakesh Wadhawan and son Sarang are accused of fraudulently availing more than Rs 6,700 crore loans from the bank and defaulting on repayment. Both were allegedly assisted by the bank’s former chairman Waryam Singh, managing director Joy Thomas and director Surjit Singh Arora. All five accused were earlier chargesheeted.

“We have filed the supplementary chargesheet before the court and are continuing our probe,” said Rajvardhan Sinha, EOW chief.

Those chargesheeted on Wednesday include four bank directors—Singh, Trupti Bane, Mukti Bavisi and Jagdish Mookhey—and three auditors—Ketan Lakdawala, Jayesh Sanghani and Anita Kirdat.

All 12 accused are in jail. “It is revealed that one of the major drawbacks in the functioning is inadequate due deligence on part of the concurrent and statutory auditors of the bank. The auditors have not performed the task of auditing the financials of the bank during 2008 and 2019 actively in tune with RBI, ICAI and other guidelines in this regard. It has transpired that the auditors have deliberately overlooked the huge advances portfolio and liabilities of the HDIL group companies in the bank and have not followed it up with either officials or board of directors,” read the chargesheet. It further stated for the past seven years, the concurrent audit of the bank’s Sion branch, where maximum loan accounts of HDIL group companies were being held, was with Kirdat.

Police sources said the accused hatched a criminal conspiracy to conceal the material position of long-pending dues of loan facilities to HDIL and to create a favourable environment within the bank for its group companies. The accused misappropriated bank funds for their personal gain (acquisition of properties in the country and abroad), causing wrongful losses to the bank, sources added.

The auditors are also accused of being hand in glove with Singh, Thomas and the Wadhawans to hide the 41 loan accounts where funds were diverted. Police will record statements of four witnesses before a magistrate so that they could be used as evidence during trial.

While Bane is a gynaecologist, Bavisi is a chartered accountant and Mookhey (72) is a tax consultant. “No diversion of funds to the accused directors’ accounts or siphoning of funds by them has been found yet,” said an EOW police officer. The forensic audit was done by Grant Thornton and a special investigation team is carrying out the probe. The state has appointed Ajay Misar as special public prosecutor. Mookhey was a member of the bank’s audit committee since 2005 and Bane a member of the recovery and loan advances committee. Singh was director in the recovery committee. One of the witnesses, a bank official who acted as whistleblower, had threatened to commit suicide if Thomas and others did not inform Reserve Bank of India about the hidden accounts.

Title: Rajasthan: Buy a bike, get helmet free from April 1
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

JAIPUR: In a move to promote road safety especially of two-wheeler riders, the state government on Wednesday declared to distribute free helmet with the purchase of two-wheelers from April 1.

These helmets would be distributed on every purchase of scooters and motorbikes by the dealers across the state. The announcement came while the state government is on the verge of implementing the Amended Motor Vehicles Act, 2019 in the state with increased penalties.

State transport minister, Pratap Singh Khachariyawas held a meeting with the automobile dealers along with the officials of his department.

“Any person buying a new motorcycle, scooter or any other two-wheeler in Rajasthan would be provided ISI-marked helmet free by the dealers of motorbike and scooter. We had a meeting in this regard in which all the dealers have given their consent to it,” Khachariyawas said while talking to TOI.

Khachariyawas added that this has been made mandatory for the dealers of two-wheelers.

“The number of persons getting killed while driving two-wheelers without helmet is very high and is a big matter of concern for the government. We are aiming at reducing these accidents and this will also help us to ensure 100 per cent compliance of wearing helmets by two-wheeler riders across the state,” he added.

All representatives of automobile dealer companies were present in the meeting chaired by the minister and officials including transport commissioner Rajesh Yadav and others at Transport Bhawan.

Title: Quarrel erupts between paying guests, residents
Content: Ahmedabad: A ruckus between students living at a paying guest facility at Godrej Garden City in Chandkheda and other residents was reported late on Tuesday night. The matter reached the Chandkheda police station, where the residents and students struck a compromise and no FIR was lodged.According to police inspector B K Gamar of Chandkheda police station, the cops reached the spot as soon as the residents dialled 100. “Both parties were brought to the police station and their statements were recorded. Neither of them lodged an FIR,” added Gamar.Gamar said a group of about 25 to 30 students were celebrating the birthday of one at about 12.30am. “The students were bursting crackers, which the residents objected to, triggered the dispute. The students called friends of theirs, who allegedly arrived at the spot armed with sticks,” said a police official.One of the residents dialled 100 and a police control room (PCR) vehicle soon arrived. The cops calmed down both parties and brought them to the police station.“We allowed them to go and took assurances from the students that such type of things wouldn’t happen again,” said a senior police Chandkheda police official.

Title: Senthil Balaji: Madras high court refuses to interfere with search warrant against ex-minister Senthil Balaji
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Senthil Balaji

CHENNAI: In a setback to former transport minister Senthil Balaji , the Madras high court on Wednesday refused any relief against a warrant issued by a magistrate for central crime branch (CCB) to search his residence.

Justice P D Audikesavalu, refusing to entertain an urgent mention made by the ex-minister’s counsel, said such relief could not be sought in an anticipatory bail application. “If you are aggrieved by the warrant issued by the magistrate, you have to challenge the order through a separate petition. Such relief cannot be ordered in a bail application,” the judge said.

The issue pertains to a complaint lodged against the former minister with the CCB alleging that when he was transport minister he duped people of Rs 2.31 crore along with his associates promising jobs in the state transport corporation. In connection with the complaint, CCB conducted raids at the residence and other premises of Balaji. Therefore, apprehending arrest, Balaji moved the anticipatory bail application. Admitting the application and as an interim relief, Justice Audikesavalu orally instructed the CCB not to harass Balaji.

On Wednesday, when the court commenced proceedings post lunch, advocate A Saravanan made a mention before Justice Audikesavalu saying police are taking coercive steps by affixing search notice in his residence, directing him to appear before the investigating officer on February 6 and to open the lock of his Chennai residence. Even after the high court ordered authorities not to take any coercive steps against the DMK MLA, police are not obeying the direction, he complained. Public prosecutor A Natarajan, however, submitted that CCB had obtained appropriate order from the jurisdictional magistrate to conduct the search.

Title: Two youths & auto driver save injured woman’s life in Jaipur
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Nitin Gurjar (L) and Arun Sharma at the hospital on Wednesday

JAIPUR: With government-run ambulances on strike, two youths and a autorickshaw driver turned out to be life saviours for an elderly woman who was bleeding and unconscious at MD Circle on MD Road .

Twenty-six-year-old Arun Sharma and 21-year-old Nitin Gurjar , who were on their way to distribute Sharma’s wedding cards, spotted a woman lying unconscious with injuries.

“When we were passing through MD Circle, a vehicle hit an elderly woman and fled. She was bleeding profusely. There was no one helping her. We tried calling 108 ambulance service repeatedly, but we did not get the response. We thought that the woman would have died, if she did not get treatment on time. We decided to rush her to the hospital on our own,” said Gurjar, a self-employed youth.

Since the 108 ambulance service employees (drivers and nursing staff) were on strike due to non-payment of their salaries, the duo stopped an autorickshaw and rushed the unknown elderly woman to Institute of Traumatology and Orthopaedics of Sawai Man Singh Hospital.

“I am getting married on February 18 and it was important for us to distribute the invitation cards. But it was even more important for us to help the unknown elderly woman, lying on the road and needing immediate treatment,” said Sharma, a jeweller from Vaishali Nagar area.

He said that there were a lot of people surrounding the elderly woman but nobody was ready to help her.

Even the autorickshaw driver did not charge any money for transporting the elderly woman.

The two youths admitted the unknown woman to the hospital and made sure that her treatment started, before leaving from the hospital.

Title: NWR’s centralised traffic system in Phulera soon
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

JAIPUR: The north western railway (NWR) has got a capital outlay of Rs 6,408.92 crore to carry on its various projects for 2020-21. The budget also has provisions to come up with a centralised traffic control system to be set up at Phulera (Jaipur-Ajmer rail route) and provisions have also been made for a few new lines and to enhance amenities.

This was revealed in the pink book uploaded on Wednesday, having the finer details on the rail budget for the year 2020-21 for NWR. A special focus has been given to the passengers’ amenities. “Also, there is an expectation of investment of nearly Rs 1,000 crore through partnership and CSR activities, to be utilized for the restoration and further development of various railway stations,” said Abhay Sharma, chief public relations officer, NWR while sharing the finer details. A provision has been made for the construction of railway over bridge and railway under bridge.

Title: Woman in burqa causes scare at Shaheen Bagh
Content:
Gunja Kapoor, who was released after questioning, is a YouTuber who calls herself a curator of 'right narrative' on Twitter

I am safe & sound. Thank you everyone for your prayers and support. I am overwhelmed by it. Special thank you & gra… https://t.co/NpAk9LNcMd — Gunja Kapoor (@gunjakapoor) 1580913965000

NEW DELHI: A burqa-clad woman caused panic at Shaheen Bagh when she started asking the protesters irrelevant and uncomfortable questions. He real identity was revealed when she was found talking to someone on the phone stating that there were fewer women protesters than usual.As the woman started getting surrounded by people, the protesters shielded her and took her near the medical room. Police soon arrived and took her away from the protest site. She was later released after questioning.Nusarat, one of the protesters at the site, said, “We have no problem with anyone coming here. But the woman started asking questions like “kaun kaun se Hindu loag aaye thhe” and other irrelevant questions. At one point when she remarked “Hey Ram”, we realised something was amiss.”Since the incident, women have set up a second frisking station. Before entering and sitting in front of the stage, now all women are being frisked.Identified as Gunja Kapoor , the women called herself a YouTuber. On her Twitter bio, she describes herself as curator of “right narrative” and an analyst. She is followed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi Upasna Sharma, one of the organisers who interacted with Kapoor, said when she asked the women her name, she replied, “Barkha”. “She lied about her name the first time. Asked why was she wearing a burqa, she said she was scared to come here. I told her I am also Upasna Sharma and I have been here since the first day of protests. She shouldn’t have come if she was scared,” she added.Another protester claimed, “Wearing a burqa, she could have done anything to implicate the other women. So many things have occurred in the past few days and people want to defame the protest, so we have to be careful.”Kapoor didn’t respond to TOI’s messages on different social media platform. However, around 8.15pm she tweeted, “I am safe & sound. Thank you everyone for your prayers and support. I am overwhelmed by it. Special thank you and gratitude to @DelhiPolice.”Before the incident, the area was filled with revelry as around 450 farmers from Punjab had reached the protest site. They had come on Tuesday night, but were taken to a gurdwara by police.Sudhger Singh, their media representative, said, “We are farmers from Bathinda and Moga. We will be here till February 8. We are here to show solidarity and send a message to the government for trying to divide the country.”With most farmers being aged 60 and above, they will be spending the night at Al Habeeb Masjid, which is close to the protest site. On Wednesday, singers Prateek Kuhad and Anushka Manchanda also joined the protesters.In Video: Police detain burqa-clad political analyst in Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh

Title: West Bengal: Dakshineswar Metro line to hike rider count by 50,000
Content:
The run time between Noapara and Dakshineswar will be about eight minutes and officials have calculated that 2... Read More

TimesView Thousands of citizens will benefit if these projects can gather a little more pace. Together, all the Metro corridors have the potential to change commute as we know it in Kolkata. All government agencies must work together to take advantage of the release of funds and speed up work.

KOLKATA: Metro Railway expects a hike in passenger volume by nearly 50,000 after the north-south network is thrown open till Dakshineswar in July this year. That is the time when Metro plans to resume 300 services. The number of services was reduced in December 2018 after Metro realised that it didn’t have adequate rakes.Metro Railway general manager Manoj Joshi told TOI that sufficient rakes will be available by July to run all the services.“The Medha rakes from ICF, Chennai, are arriving as scheduled. All issues with these rakes have been resolved. Performance trials of the Dalian rakes are also in progress and should be completed by March. An entire team of technicians from China is camping in Kolkata to study the results of the trials and take necessary measures. We shall have adequate number of rakes by the time the Dakshineswar link is commissioned,” Joshi said.The run time between Noapara and Dakshineswar will be about eight minutes and officials have calculated that 24 rakes would be required if every second service is to go up to Dakshineswar. Two rakes will be kept on standby. Necessary work is also on at the Noapara yard to allow easier movement of rakes to Dakshineswar. This is necessary as rakes can’t be parked at Dakshineswar.“We aim to complete work of the Dakshineswar stretch by June. I have asked additional teams of Rail Vikas Nigam Ltd (RVNL) officials to oversee the progress of work along that stretch. We realise the problems being faced by people of that area due to the closure of the Tallah Bridge. The Metro link will be a boon for many people who now have to spend a lot of additional time in commuting. Office goers and students will be the most benefitted as they have to reach their destinations on time,” Joshi added.After taking over, Joshi had also inspected work at the 32-km New Garia-Airport (via Rajarhat) stretch. According to him, the stretch is tricky due to the large number of canals where pillars have to be constructed.“We are continuously discussing issues with all agencies concerned. We have plans to start truncated services for the nearly 5km stretch between New Garia and Hemanta Mukherjee (Ruby) stations. However, there are three discontinuities in this stretch as well. There is a canal that needs to be spanned. Some land also needs to be acquired. RVNL engineers are working on that stretch to sort out issues,” the Metro GM said. Joshi will also be visiting the Joka-BBD Bag stretch soon and review the progress.

Title: 12,000 cops, 370 CCTVs at jatara
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Director general of police M Mahendar Reddy said 12,000 police personnel were deployed at Medaram. Seventy women sub-inspectors of SHE teams were also part of the arrangements. “We have also taken steps to prevent stampede-like situations. For parking, 32 spots have been designated,” he said.

Police said 370 CCTV cameras had been installed to monitor movements of devotees continuously. Drone cameras were also being used. “Feed from the cameras will be monitored from the command and control centre at the venue,” a senior cop said.

Mahendar, chief secretary Somesh Kumar and senior officials took stock of the arrangements at Medaram on Wednesday.

Title: Popular citizens engagement initiative award for Happy Streets
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Nagpur: Happy Streets, organized by The Times of India and Maharashtra Times in association with the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC), was chosen by Ready 2 Innovate WorldWide (R2iW) in the Popular Citizens Engagement Initiative category. In its first edition, awards were given in ten categories (details on page 4).

Mayor Sandip Joshi and Karlsruhe (Germany) mayor Frank Mentrup presented the award at a programme held at an auditorium in Civil Lines on Wednesday.

R2iW, an NGO-cum-private limited firm, constituted the award as part of its constant efforts to showcase and promote disruptive innovations towards enhancing the quality of life in cities.

Happy Streets was held on four Sundays — from December 22, 2019 to January 12, 2020 — on West High Court Road between Law College Square and Laxmi Bhuvan Square. Over 20,000 people turned up in the event which facilitated various fitness, recreational and non-motorized transport activities.

Ajay Gondane, ex-India High Commission to Australia, and R2iW team — deputy controller and head Pankaj Borkar, co-founders Yogita Kasture and Dyaneshwar Kamble — were present on the dais.

R2iW has taken up the initiative in collaboration with NMC, Smart City SPV NSSCDCL, Neeri, Nagpur First, IEEE Nagpur, VED Council and others. Innovations from industry and academia were showcased during the event.

Reminding sister-city collaboration with NMC two years ago, Mentrup hoped for new initiatives between Karlsruhe and Nagpur. He stressed the need for citizen participation in the growth of any city.

Stating suggestions and ideas for more development of city are always welcome, Joshi said, “Smartness is a human characteristic and technology can increase efficiency. Citizen’s participation is a must for accommodating growth in cities and for cost optimization.”

Title: Nirma wins salty trademark suit
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Ahmedabad: Nirma Ltd won a trademark case against a Rajasthan-based salt company and a local court restrained the latter from selling its products under the brand ‘Neema Sudh Iodised Salt’ and under a label with mark similar to it.

A city civil court restrained Pawan Salt Suppliers last week based on a 16-year-old suit filed by Nirma Chemical Works Ltd and Nirma Ltd. They claimed that they have been marketing various consumer products and iodized salt under the trademarks Nirma and Nima for many decades and have acquired a reputation and goodwill for their products across India.

Pawan Salt is a partnership firm from Nawa City in Nagaur district in Rajasthan. It is engaged in marketing of iodized salt. Nirma learned that Pawan Salt was selling its product under the name of ‘Neema Shudh Iodized Salt’. Nirma’s representatives approached Pawan Salt in 2004 and were promised by the Rajasthan company that it would not use the name for its product. One of the partners of Pawan Salt also wrote a letter to Nirma with this assurance.

However, Pawan Salt continued to sell its product under the same name. This brought Nirma to court, alleging infringement of its trademark rights. It complained that Neema Shudh is written in the style Nirma uses Nirma Shudh for its iodized salt and this caused confusion and deception in the market.

Nirma contended that it got the trademark and label registered in Class 30 in 1969 and its registration for salt products is still subsisting, valid and in force. Any deceptive name and label by Pawan Salt amounts to infringement on its intellectual property rights and thus the Rajasthan company was earning money illegally by passing off its product.

After hearing the case, judge S H Patel ordered Pawan Salt not to sell its salt under the name of Neema Shudh Iodized Salt.

Title: Funding for panchayat bldgs up by Rs 1 crore
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Porvorim: Panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho told the Goa legislative assembly on Wednesday that the government wants to increase funds allotted for construction of panchayat ghars from Rs 2.5 crore to Rs 3.5 crore. However, financial assistance would not be extended to build more than one panchayat ghar in each constituency, he added.

Admitting that there have been some financial “problems”, Godinho said “out of the box ideas” will have to be implemented to address the problem, while replying to the question tabled by St Cruz MLA Antonio Fernandes. He said he will be meeting the central minister for panchayat Raj to seek more funds for the state.

Fernandes said the panchayat structures in his constituency were in bad condition, and they need to be rebuilt. He sought to know if the panchayat minister would offer help.“All three panchayat buildings are in bad shape,” said Fernandes.

Godinho said his ministry will only be able to sanction funds for one panchayat ghar in a constituency. Till date, he said 50 new panchayat ghars have been built across the state with government funds. A provision has been made for their maintenance, he added.

Title: Madurai: 13 tonne used oil collected from FBOs in a month’s time
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

There is a bigger scope for RUCO scheme in Madurai as more number of FBOs would be brought under the fold soon... Read More

MADURAI: Food safety officials from Madurai have collected around 13,000 litres of used oil from eateries, bakeries and hotels under the Repurpose Used Cooking Oil (RUCO), an initiative of Food Safety and Standards Authorities of India (FSSAI), to prevent used oil from getting into the system again, as they can cause health risk to consumers.

Although the initiative was inaugurated in October, 2019, collection picked up only around a month ago. In the first phase, around 250 food business operators (FBOs) - big hotels, snacks factories and bakeries - were targeted. Many of them purchase more than 50 litres of oil. Officials said that oil can be used only for three times for frying as the total polar compound gets more than maximum prescribed limit of 25%. Using of oil beyond it would increase the risk of various health problems like hypertension, liver diseases and even cancer.

Designated officer for food safety Dr S Somasundaram said that Madurai is a frontrunner when it comes to implementation of RUCO scheme. Around 13 tonne of used oil has already been collected in just a month’s time.

FBOs have been distributed with containers as per their requirement and the oil is collected at regular intervals. Soon, the collected oil will be sent to the designated place, where it will be converted into biodiesel.

There is a bigger scope for RUCO scheme in Madurai as more number of FBOs would be brought under the fold soon. Once expanded, monthly collection could go up manifold.

Officials said that FBOs too are equally enthusiastic in the implementation of the scheme as they are paid Rs 25 per litre, the same amount they could get if they sold it outside. Stickers are pasted on the premises’ of the FBOs stating that oil used there is changed periodically. It helps to assure customers on the safety of food they consume, officials said.

Officials said that by removing used oil from the system helps environment too, as one litre of used oil can pollute thousands of litres of water.

Mostly, waste oil is being dumped into drains, which reaches nearby water bodies, resulting in pollution.

Title: Cluster bus rams SUV at Kashmere Gate, 1 dies
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

New Delhi: A man was killed while three others were injured when a cluster bus rammed their XUV500 near Kashmere Gate on Wednesday night. Police said that the impact of the accident was such that the car toppled on one side. All the four men were taken to a nearby hospital where one of them was declared brought dead. The bus driver was arrested later.

It was reported that the four men — Mangal, Sanjeev, Nand Lal and Mahender Sahu — were on their way back home towards Rohini. When they reached Kashmere Gate ISBT, the cluster bus coming from Tis Hazari rammed the SUV from the left side. A case was registered based on Sahu’s statement, who told police that the SUV was being driven by Mangal and he was sitting next to him. “The bus driver, after hitting the SUV, came close to the vehicle and saw the damage. He then fled towards Mori Gate. I managed to note down the number of the bus. Meanwhile, Mangal, along with help from locals, managed to catch hold of the driver and informed police,” said Sahu.

Locals said the bus was moving at a high speed and the driver, Vinod, could not control the vehicle even after spotting the SUV. Police said that Sanjeev, sitting on the rear left side of the car, succumbed to the injuries on his head.

Police said that all of them own wholesale businesses selling dry fruits at Peeli Kothi of Lahori Gate. On Wednesday night, they had shut their shop and were heading to Sahu’s house for a party. Police have charged Vinod under sections of causing death due to negligence and negligent driving. Sanjeev’s body was handed over to his family after autopsy.

Title: Madurai man riding bike runs into parked truck, dies
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A 26-year-old youth from Madurai died after the two-wheeler he was riding hit a truck parked on the roadside in four-way road connecting Madurai and Trichy, behind the Madurai bench of the Madras high court, on Tuesday night.The youth was identified as K Nagaraj from Mahatma Gandhi Nagar in Melamadai. Nagaraj hit a truck which was stopped by a police team from Othakadai for document verification. Nagaraj suffered head injuries and died on the spot, despite him wearing a helmet, his relatives said.

Traffic police officers from Madurai city visited the spot and conducted an inquiry. While post mortem was conducted at Government Rajaji Hospital on Wednesday, his family members and relatives staged a protest in front of the hospital refusing to receive the body. They demanded action against the police team for conducting vehicular check up on the busy road putting lives of the road users at risk. They also demanded compensation.Nagaraj’s brother K Karthickumar petitioned Madurai city police commissioner seeking an inquiry into the death. He also mentioned that the truck which was involved in the accident was made to leave the spot.

Title: Delhi Elections 2020: Pehle AAP? Delhi’s Muslims look to pick side to cancel out BJP in polls
Content: NEW DELHI: In polarised times, three is a crowd. Fully aware of the perils of a triangular contest, the capital’s 25 lakh Muslims who want to hold back BJP know they have to choose between AAP and Congress .“Sabka apna rujhan hota hai, but the wave seems to be for AAP,” says 70-year-old Mohammed Tehsin, a vendor from Mustafabad in northeast Delhi. He has voted for Congress his whole life, including in the last Lok Sabha election, but most of the neighbourhood is voting for AAP, he says. “It is difficult to choose in the voting booth, ungli dagmaaga jaati hai, but it is important to make a clear decision,” he says.Two boys on a bike speak up loudly for Congress, pointing out that the candidate’s father, Hasan Ahmed, had built these roads and the nearby graveyard, and had worked hard. But they also admit they would probably persuade their families to vote for AAP so that the community’s vote could be ektarfa. Last time, BJP had coasted to power with 58,388 votes in the constituency, which was split between Congress at 52,357 and AAP at 49,791.While Congress has leapt in to defend Muslims in the CAA-NRC resistance and police excesses, AAP has steered largely clear of the issue.Even at Batla House chowk near Jamia Millia Islamia, one of the epicentres of the recent violence, there is more vocal support for AAP. While Nasim Ahmed, a Congress supporter, claims that his candidate, Parvez Hashmi, “has never lost an election from here, and has done most of the work to build the area”, he is outnumbered by the others, who say that Congress has not put up a damdaar CM candidate this time. “In the 2015 elections, when AAP won, it was all decided in the last three days, paasa palat gaya. This time though, the leher is clearly with Arvind Kejriwal,” says Aas Mohammed. Many of these men used to work at a 30-year-old steel fabrication business that shut down, because of GST and rising costs.Voters are eloquent on the dangers of NRC and CAA, of Modi government’s economic record, its sale of PSUs, and so on. This, however, is an existential crisis, they say. “It is only the bhaichaara of old that now sustains us, the nai fasal does not seem to understand that,” despairs Aas Mohammed. But this struggle for the Constitution, it is larger than the Delhi elections, he says.Sitting on the steps of Jama Masjid at a protest against CAA-NRC, 34-year-old Nida (who doesn’t want to share her last name), says: “Matia Mahal will see a sweep for jhadoo — I say this with 98% confidence.”AAP candidate Shoaib Iqbal has just hopped over from Congress and commands great clout in the area, having won every election (except the last) under various party banners. “My father is a kattar Congressi, but even he understands, why waste a vote this time,” she says.In nearby Ballimaran, AAP MLA and minister Imran Hussain, a businessman who was an independent councillor before joining the party, is visibly popular. His office handles Aadhaar cards, ration cards, caste certificates and other paperwork, hospital referrals, and so on. “We have a daily footfall of 300-400 people here, and 10 staff members. Meanwhile, Congress candidate Haroon Yusuf (former minister and party heavyweight who had been elected five times from Ballimaran) does not even have an office in the neighbourhood,” claims AAP councillor Mohammed Sadiq.He is dismissive about BJP’s polarisation campaign. “Delhi is the heart of India. People from all over the country, of all religions and castes and backgrounds live here. These issues of dharm and jati don’t impact Delhi, what matters are real issues”. AAP volunteers claim to have constructed 100 borewells, and replaced 80% of the sewerage network in the area. There is a mohalla clinic close by, and three schools are being built. “The borewell work began with Haroon Yusuf, he has also worked. But with him, ek- zamana-tha wali baat ho gayi — I think he should have sat out this election,” says Mohammed Asif, who runs a spectacles shop in Ballimaran.He makes a clear distinction between the Lok Sabha election, where “bigger internal and international issues matter”, and this one, which is about service delivery, about gullies and sewers, water and electricity, schooling and health. AAP has worked hard on all fronts, he says. Fees have been waived for minority students who can produce an income certificate, says Nazma Bari, an ad hoc teacher in a municipal school in Matia Mahal.For many voters, it is not just a tactical choice between the Lok Sabha and Vidhan Sabha, there is a genuine satisfaction with AAP’s redistributive work. The slashing of electricity and water bills means more to the poor than abstract “development” work like flyover-construction that Sheila Dikshit used to talk up, they say. “I used to pay Rs 1,000-1,200 for electricity, Rs 2,500-3,000 sometimes for water. Now, it is nothing. I also got my GPS SIM free,” says Zamir Ahmed, an auto driver.Meanwhile, an e-rickshaw driver, Mohammed Salim says that his 80-year-old mother sends duas for Arvind Kejriwal. “He won my heart when he spoke about getting corrupt officials suspended. He gets the pain of ordinary people.”In northeast Delhi’s Seelampur, young Mohammed Javed, a tailor, says there is no contradiction between supporting Congress and AAP — “this time, it’s definitely Kejriwal for many of us”. His friend, Amit Verma, is an ardent BJP supporter, and they rag each other mercilessly over politics. “He’s a worm, but I love him,” says Javed. “We don’t fight, only stupid people are made to fight over religion and politics,” says Verma.

Title: Timetable software works fine, East-West Metro ready for first run
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The commercial run of the first phase will start 18 months after the first trials took place in July, 2018.

KOLKATA: The last trials for commissioning the first phase of East-West Metro took place successfully on Wednesday. Eight days later, railway minister Piyush Goyal will unveil the 5km stretch between Sector V and Salt Lake Stadium .

The commercial run of the first phase will start 18 months after the first trials took place in July, 2018. Along with the trial runs, another mock exercise was held on Wednesday at the behest of Metro Railway general manager Manoj Joshi. This one was to ensure a flawless inauguration ceremony on February 13.

Joshi’s visit was meant to ensure that everything would be in place when the railways minister inaugurates Kolkata’s Line 2 next Thursday. Manas Sarkar, MD, Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation (KMRC), was also present at the trial run on Wednesday. While East-West Metro is being implemented by KMRC , Metro Railway, which runs the north-south line, will be in charge of operations.

On Wednesday, the GM reached Sector V station at 10.30am. Officials from both agencies were already there by then. The GM saw locations where the dais would be put up and the place where the dignitaries would be seated. The timetable trial had started half-an-hour ago. Even as Wednesday’s dummy run was only for two hours, it was very significant since the final timetable was assessed through it.

On an average, the East-West trains will take 13 minutes to cover the 5km distance, stopping for 20 seconds at each station. A rake will take another three minutes for the changeover. In all, there will be 37 services during weekdays, with trains running at 20-minute intervals. On Sundays, there will be 25 services. All these specifications were fed into the system as the timetable software was loaded into the operations control centre (OCC), which is the control room that will automatically run the trains from the Central Park depot.

The software has been prepared by Ansaldo, the company that has provided software integration between the trains, signalling system, tracks and platform screen doors. While the system absorbed the timetable during the two-hour trial, a dress rehearsal for Thursday’s function was happening at the behest of the Metro Railway GM. Along with officials of Metro and KMRC, Joshi took a ride from Sector V till City Centre. The railway minister will be taking the same ride after flagging off the first train around 5pm next Thursday. He would get off at City Centre, where he would address the media. The inauguration ceremony would be aired on giant screens outside the East-West Metro stations.

Title: Insurance woes unite hospitals
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Ahmedabad: To collectively raise and represent issues plaguing hospitals and nursing homes, a group of doctors and nursing homes in Ahmedabad have jointly formed what is known as Ahmedabad Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association (AHNHA). One of the key issues highlighted by the association was about issues faced by these hospitals with insurance companies and third-party administrators (TPAs).

“The rates offered by insurance companies to member hospitals are too low, which make it unviable to offer quality services to patients. Moreover, the charges have not been revised from many years, which make sustaining operations a challenge,” said Dr Bharat Gadhvi, president of the association, while briefing the media, on Tuesday.

AHNHA members also mentioned that there is no standard criteria for empanelling hospitals. “The association is also opposed to the General Insurance Public Sector Association (GIPSA) Preferred Provider Network (PPN) packages and describes them as unrealistic. AHNA will also represent to the government for providing a single window for issuance of new licences as well as renewal of licences,” said one of the members.

Title: Jaipur: Coronavirus prevention and control cells in districts soon
Content:
Instructions have been sent to all the districts to remain alert

JAIPUR: In the wake of three confirmed novel coronavirus (nCoV) cases in Kerala , health authorities in the state have stepped up measures to activate nCoV outbreak control and prevention district cells in each district.Instructions have been sent to all the districts to remain alert. So far, 5,927 passengers who arrived in the state by 41 international flights have been screened. So far, no confirmed cases of nCoV has been detected.“In all, 44 samples of suspected nCoV cases have been sent to laboratories for tests. Out of those, 26 cases have tested negative, while reports of 18 persons are awaited,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (health), health department.Control room call centres will be set up in the districts as well. The health department has started taking measures for developing infrastructure in each district for at least 50 patients for quarantine facilities, a dedicated team in each district, training the team and other health functionaries and for ensuring strict protocol of infection control.There will also be a team that will compile data regarding the general public visiting private hospitals from all districts to identify suspected cases.Directions have also been issued to ensure that vehicles should be available round-the-clock in the district for transportation of patients. Facility will be developed to manage post-traumatic stress related events and stress during quarantine.The state level nCoV control room teams will also be formed for surveillance, call centre management, training and awareness generation, infrastructure management, documentation, private hospital surveillance and psychological support teams.The health department officials said the symptomatic patients admitted at isolation wards of hospitals are being closely scrutinised. Those patients discharged from hospitals are being monitored by field workers in their corresponding areas. Those asymptomatic travels/contact in home isolation are being monitored for 28 days by field workers and reporting it on daily basis.

Title: Resident doctor found unconscious in washroom with sedative injections
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

JAIPUR: A resident doctor doing his PG in neurosurgery was found unconscious in a washroom of a ward of Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital on Wednesday morning.

Injections of sedatives have also been found from the washroom. It was not the first time he was found unconscious. He has been saved twice within a month by hospital staff. However, the cause of his alleged attempt to end his life has not been ascertained yet. The incident happened around 9.30am when he went missing from the neurosurgery ward, where he was posted. After searching for him for more than an hour, he was found in a washroom of a neighbouring ward. The hospital staff rushed him to neurosurgery ICU and put him on ventilator support.

The doctors resuscitated him and his condition improved by the evening and he was taken off ventilator support, said hospital sources. The family of the doctor reached the hospital and looked worried. SMS Hospital medical superintendent Dr DS Meena said, “It is not for the first time he has been found in such a situation.

Earlier too, he was found unconscious. We are trying to find out the cause.” According to hospital sources, he was found unconscious on January 14 and at that time the doctors thought that he might have seizures. At that time too, he was admitted to ICU. In July 2019, a first-year postgraduate student of medicine had allegedly committed suicide in her hostel at Mahila Chikitshalya in the city. The 25-year-old from Punjab was specialising in gynaecology at the city’s Zanana Hospital.

Title: Telangana: 17-year-old dies while taking holy dip
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

MEDARAM: The mega four-day Medaram Jatara started on a sombre note, on Wednesday, after a 17-year-old devotee died while diving into the Jampanna Vagu, for a holy dip. The teenager was identified as Venugopal, a resident of Autonagar in Warangal (urban) district.

Officials said that the boy had successfully completed five dives into the Jampanna Vagu. On his sixth dive, he hit his head on something and suffered a grievous injury. “When he didn’t come out of the water for a long time, we realised something was wrong. Later, expert swimmers deployed around the Jampanna Vagu, retrieved his body from the water,” said a devotee, adding, “His family members were present near the site, taking bath under the taps there.”

Venugopal’s body was shifted to Mulugu government hospital for post-mortem. This is the third death reported from Medaram in the last 24 hours. On Tuesday, two devotees died at the same place. While 24-year-old Battu Vinay, from Marredpally, drowned in the Jampanna Vagu, 22-year-old Tama Vinod, from Dummugudem mandal in Bhadradri Kothagudem, district passed away after suffering convulsions while on his way back from there. Local police officials said he was epileptic.

Title: Mangaluru: Man sexually assaults boy
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

MANGALURU: A man has been booked under the Pocso Act for sexually assaulting a schoolboy in Vittal police station limits on Wednesday.

According to police, the incident took place on Sunday. The accused, a daily wage earner, lured the boy with eatables, took him to an isolated place, and sexually assaulted him. The boy disclosed about the incident on Monday when he was unwell. A case has been registered, and the police are on the lookout for the accused.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect his privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Let Supreme Court decide on CAA: Guv
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Thrissur: Governor Arif Mohammed Khan, on Wednesday, has put the onus of deciding over Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ) on the Supreme Court .

Addressing the media in Thrissur, the governor said that he had earlier expressed his stand on CAA and he would never change it.

“The Supreme Court has sought a report from the Centre based on the state government’s petition against CAA. The court has not sought a report from me,” the governor said.

Hold onto the value of life and try to be innovative, was the governor’s message to students, after inaugurating the centenary celebrations of Thrissur Sacred Heart School on Wednesday. “Computer chips with artificial intelligence would soon be available in the market at cheap rates,” he said.

“Germany has already reduced the size of MRI scanning machines to just that of a suitcase. It will not take more than five years to reinvent it to that of a tablet’s size as technology is changing at a rapid rate,” Khan said.

“The future would be in the hands of a group of young people who come up with innovative ideas. However, ideas will keep changing,” he added.

The governor was all praise for Kerala’s education sector and said that it could serve as a model for the entire nation.

“As rural areas of the country lack proper educational facilities, it is the responsibility of each citizen to extend a helping hand for such less-privileged people,” the governor said.

Title: Chennai: Drunk man throws stone at biker, hits judge’s car
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A stone thrown at a biker on Tuesday smashed into the car of a judge near Thousand Lights, damaging the vehicle’s window. Police said the accused identified as Karthik of Tiruvannamalai works in a helmet showroom on Anna Salai near Gemini bridge. Around 9pm, Karthik was returning home after consuming liquor in a bar.

When he was walking near Spencer Plaza, a two-wheeler grazed against him in which he lost balance and was about to fall. An angry Karthik threw a stone at the biker, when a car belonging to a high court judge took a turn and the stone hit it damaging the window glass. The judge’s wife was said have been travelling in the car.

However, she was not hurt, police said. A constable in the car, who stopped the vehicle, nabbed Karthik and handed him over to the Thousand Lights police. Police claimed the biker was driving properly and it was Karthik’s mistake. Investigation revealed that Karthik was drunk.

Title: Brimming tank to make float festival a grand event this year
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Workers erecting the float on the Mariamman Teppakulam tank.

MADURAI: The float festival of the Sri Meenakshi Sundareswarar temple to be held on February 8, promises to be one of the best in recent years, as the tank is brimming with water and people are working round-the-clock to erect the float.

Thanks to the efforts of the corporation commissioner, S Visakan, joint commissioner of the temple, N Natarajan and the public works department (PWD), the Mariamman Teppakulam has received water from its traditional supply channels which used to bring water to it for over 400 years from the Vaigai river, after more than 40 years. The high court too had directed that steps be taken to fill the tank through its traditional channels. Previously, the temple used to pump water from the Vaigai riverbed to the tank through pipes, which resulted in sewage too being pumped when the water level was low.

However, this year, there was a copious flow in the river, and the construction of a check dam on the riverbed helped the tank receive water without any hindrance. At present, the tank is holding 14ft of water.

Workers from Kumbakonam are in the process of erecting the float this year. S Suresh, of Kumbakonam, who comes from a family of traditional temple decorators, and who has decorated the yagasala at the Thanjavur Big Temple for its consecration is also in charge of the float of the Meenakshi temple. The float will be of 32x32ft dimension and 32ft tall. “The deities Sri Meenakshi and Lord Sundareswarar will be put on a pedestal which will be 12ft tall, which will help people from many feet away to see the deities clearly this year,” said Suresh.

It will be pulled around the tank twice in the morning, and once in the evening. Joint commissioner of the temple, N Natarajan said that all precautions including rescue personnel from the fire service, NCC cadets would be deployed near the tank, for additional security this year. Life jackets are also being kept ready in the event of any emergency. The entire festival would be monitored with the help of drones.

His friend, Amit Verma, is an ardent BJP supporter, and they rag each other mercilessly over politics. “He’s a worm, but I love him,” says Javed. “We don’t fight, only stupid people are made to fight over religion and politics,” says Verma.

Title: 2 poachers arrested with leopard skin in Dehradun
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

DEHRADUN: Dehradun police on Wednesday arrested two members of inter-state wildlife poaching and smuggling gang and seized one leopard skin from them.

Acting on a tip-off provided by wildlife crime control bureau, a team of Dehradun police nabbed the smugglers, identified as Dharam Singh and Chandar Singh Chauhan , both residents of Dehradun. According to senior superintendent of police Arun Mohan Joshi , “Both were arrested from Anaarwala area of the city with a 8-ft-long leopard skin. Both confessed of killing the leopard near Chakrata last month. They said that they brought the skin to Dehradun for sale.”

Title: Announced by FM in Budget, smart power meters unavailable in market
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Nagpur: Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced in the Budget last week that all existing electricity meters will be replaced by smart ones within three years. However, MSEDCL’s experience shows that they are not available in the market.

MSEDCL had floated a tender for purchasing pre-paid smart meters worth Rs160 crore in the second half of 2017. So far it has not been able to purchase a single meter despite re-tendering several times.

A company spokesperson said, “We are unable to get offers for smart meters that meet our specifications. We will purchase meters only when they meet our specifications.”

The target for the discom was to replace 4 lakh meters in 10 cities where infrastructure augmentation works under Integrated Power Development Scheme (IPDS) had been carried out.

According to the MSEDCL tender, the meters should download the energy consumption data every 15 minutes. The meter will also have to record whether the meter has been tampered every 15 minutes. Bill history and load survey have to be uploaded every 45 days.

The data read by the smart meter should be available at MSEDCL data centre at any moment. For this purpose the supplier has to install his own data collection software at the data centre and integrate it with MSEDCL software. There are several other requirements, which are technical in nature.

The spokesperson said that the company was installing radio frequency (RF) meters in high loss areas. “The RF meters are also smart meters although not as advanced as the ones we want to purchase. Thousands of RF meters have been installed in high distribution loss areas especially those coming under Jalgaon, Latur and Nanded circles.”

He further said that large number of incidences of power theft had come to fore after installation of RF meters.

The Tariff Policy formulated under Electricity Act, 2003, in January 2016 envisaged replacement of all existing electricity meters by smart ones in high loss areas. The amended Policy formulated in 2018 envisaged replacing all existing meters by smart ones all across the country but priority is to be given to high loss areas. The FM has therefore announced a goal mentioned in the Tariff Policy.

Title: Combined transport authority to be revived in Chennai
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Aerial view of Chennai

CHENNAI: The state government has decided to dust off plans for an agency covering all modes of transport in the city. A year after notifying rules for the Chennai Unified Metropolitan Transport Authority ( Cumta ), steps are now being taken to give more teeth to the authority. The development comes in the wake of the World Bank stressing that the multi-department body be converted into a single window agency for infrastructure projects .

Officials in the housing and urban development department said the aim was to integrate multimodal transport. “The prime responsibility of Cumta is to design all infrastructure projects including metro rail alignment, flyovers and laying pipelines. Unfortunately, it operates only as a coordinating agency as independent departments continue to execute infrastructure projects (like in the past),” an official said. This has rendered the authority toothless, he added. A World Bank team that had met state government officials last year stressed that Cumta be a nodal agency for all infrastructure projects executed in the Chennai Metropolitan Area (CMA) which could then be financed by the funding agency. “They have reiterated it during their meeting in January this year that things should be in place by March. We wanted to transform Cumta into a statutory body where any work or project carried out on roads are executed through it and it serves larger sections, instead of showcasing a particular department’s project,” the official said. The revival includes design and funding for projects. “Anything done on the road from replacing signals to building flyovers and coming up with metro rail alignment would come under the purview of Cumta that would be strengthened with more powers,” an official privy to developments said.

As per the plans, the Cumta chairman, who is the transport minister according to the Act, will be replaced by the chief minister. While an IAS officer would be appointed as member secretary, the authority will be based at Chennai Metropolitan Development Authority (CMDA) office. Currently, a chief planner of CMDA holds charge as member secretary of Cumta. Transport department sources said amending the Act was under discussion.

Urban development experts said it was need of the hour because various departments were carrying out their own projects and the whole development process lacked larger vision. Former professor of urban engineering at Anna University K P Subramanian said a single agency would help implement infrastructure projects effectively. “Countries like Singapore are implementing it such a manner,” he said.

Title: Goa: Discussion on Merces panch case disallowed
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Goa assembly speaker Rajesh Patnekar

PORVORIM: Goa assembly speaker Rajesh Patnekar on Wednesday disallowed a calling attention motion on the death of Merces panch Prakash Naik. Patnekar said that since there was a court hearing in the matter on Wednesday, it may be prejudiced by the discussion in the House.

“There is a hearing in court today (Wednesday) and the hearing shouldn’t be prejudiced by the discussion in the House, so it is disallowed as of now,” he said.

Former deputy CM Ramkrishna Dhavalikar pressed for the calling attention to be taken up, stating that the issue in court was “quite different” from the subject of the calling attention motion. Patnekar, however, stood by his ruling.

The motion was called for by opposition leader Digambar Kamat along with GFP MLAs Vijai Sardesai, Jayesh Salgaonkar, Vinod Paliencar, independent MLA Rohan Khaunte, MGP’s Dhavalikar and Congress MLA Aleixo Reginaldo Lourenco.

Title: Walled City on verge of losing its iconic ‘wall’
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Encroachments in Walled City have become a major problem

JAIPUR: Amidst elation over getting the World Heritage Title by UNESCO for the ‘Walled’ City, not much seems to have been done to conserve its iconic heritage wall.

As per the report of the Indian National Trust for Art and Culture Heritage ( INTACH ) in 2015, only 25% of the wall in the Walled City is remaining. Due to rampant encroachment in the Walled City, the iconic wall may not last long if not preserved by the authorities.

While proposing Jaipur to be tagged as World Heritage site, government had promised to remove encroachment from the wall. No such step has been taken in the last six months since the heritage tag was received, while people have built their houses adjacent to the wall.

Near Sikar house, there are parts of the broken wall from where people have constructed their houses. Near Chaughan stadium, a lane named Hathiyon ki Thant is built around the heritage wall. Elephants were kept in this lane before independence and the royal family used to visit Chaughan stadium to witness the elephant fight . It used to be a popular sport in those times.

Today, the wall is encroached as people have constructed houses adjoining to it. Rajnath Chauhan , a resident of the area said, “Our family was given title by the durbar. However, most of the people living around the wall do not have ownership and have constructed houses illegally. There are two Bhurj on top of the wall – Chini ki Bhurj and Moti Bhurj and you can find people living inside the wall where there is a room for stairs going towards the Bhurj. They have made adjustments as per their requirements and authorities have done little to change it.”

With the World Heritage tag, the government has now been asked to remove all the encroachment and restore the remaining wall by the end of this year. If the criteria are not fulfilled, Jaipur may lose the title.

Title: K Laxman raps govt on facilities in Medaram
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

HYDERABAD: BJP state president K Laxman on Wednesday said the TRS government has failed to make proper arrangements for lakhs of devotees thronging the Medram jatara.

Addressing a press conference here, Laxman said chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao had promised to provide Kumbh Mela-type facilities to the devotees. “KCR is not only deceiving people of the state, but he is also deceiving gods and goddesses by making false promises,” he alleged.

Laxman sought to know as to why the government did not make any serious attempts to get the Centre declare Medaram jatara as a national festival.

Welcoming the decision to form a trust for construction of a Ram temple in Ayodhya, he said KCR should welcome the announcement of Prime Minister Naredra Modi made in Parliament. “He (KCR) always claims himself as a real Hindu and organises yagams. He should make his stand clear on Modi’s announcement on construction of the temple,” he said.

Title: Remove squatters or see you on March 16: HC to UDH secretary
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

JAIPUR: Rajasthan high court on Wednesday expressed its disappointment over inaction on the part of authorities in removing encroachments in Walled City areas. The court asked UDH secretary to be present in court on March 16 if it failed to act on it.

The division bench of Justice Sangeet Lodha and Justice Mahendra Goyal issued the order on a suo motu petition seeking the removal of encroachments.

Vimal Chaudhary who appeared for the petitioners informed the court that the JMC had so far only issued notice to encroachers, but no action was taken so far.

The corporation after a survey found that 19 properties require complete demolition and accordingly the court in its September 2019 order directed it to carry out the demolitions within three months.

The court had formed a committee under principal secretaries of UDH and law department.

But so far, the authorities had only served notices and no action taken. The UDH department on Wednesday sought four more weeks to act said, Yogesh Tailor, another counsel from the petitioner’s side.

Title: Psyched out man assaults his wife
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Ahmedabad: A 30-year-old woman from the Mithakhali area of the city on Tuesday filed a complaint with Navrangpura police alleging that her husband beat her often and taunted that because she was a psychology student, she appears mentally ill.

In her FIR, the woman, who was married on March 3, 2018, stated that her husband and in-laws, residents of Fatehwadi, began seeking dowry a month after the wedding.

They had first asked for a scooter and when she denied, her husband and in-laws had beat her. “They used to taunt me for having short height and said I should have brought more dowry to make up for my height,” stated the woman in FIR.

“My husband, father-in-law and mother-in-law used to call me a mad woman and said I looked like a mad woman as I studied psychology.”

The woman said that she tolerated the harassment to save her marriage. “They beat me even when I was four months pregnant,” she stated in the FIR. In October 2019, the woman was again asked for more dowry, and then beaten and abandoned when she refused.

Title: Forest department rescues 12-foot-long python in Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The python was rescued by forest department with the help of a volunteer and was later released in the Thatcha... Read More

TRICHY: A 12 feet-long python was rescued from a residential locality in Alampatti village of Manikandam in Trichy district on Tuesday.

The python was rescued by forest department with the help of a volunteer and was later released in Thatchankurichi reserve forest. Indian rock pythons are protected under scheduled – I (Part II) of the wildlife protection Act 1972.

The incident happened on Tuesday night when Alampatti villagers alerted Manikandam police station about the movement of a python in their locality. The information was passed on to forest department, which arrived at the village with snake catching equipment. Honorary district animal welfare officer G Ramakrishnan from animal welfare board of India (AWBI) that carried out the rescue mission said that he had carried five such missions in this locality over the last two years. The villagers said that there is a lake near the village and pythons were often spotted there feeding on fish in the lake. Occasionally, they ventured into the residential areas in search of prey.

The python that weighed 6.5 kg was found in good health.

Title: Jaipur: Social mapping of households to be done
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

This mapping will include types of houses, alleys, number of residents, income levels, institutions and types ... Read More

JAIPUR: Every single household in Walled City of Jaipur will go through social mapping as part of the Unesco heritage site task aiming to create the site sustainable and friendlier to its residents.

The mapping includes—type of houses, alleys, number of residents—age-wise, gender and occupation, income levels, institutions and types of vehicles. The central aim of the mammoth exercise is to ascertain that socio-economic impact of the heritage site on its residents. The completion of the mapping is among the six tasks which needs to be ended before the end of 2020.

“Every house in the Walled City will be taken into account for the survey. Minor details like how many members to number of vehicles they owned and from traffic situation to livelihood issues involving the residents will be collected. It aim is to achieve multi-fold objectives like improving the socio-economic conditions of the residents living in the heritage site and to make the site sustainable to preserve it for generations to come,” said Sikha Jain , a Cultural Heritage expert in UNESCO World Heritage Committee.

The walled city area is spread in 9 square kms. It has close to one lakh houses with a population of 6 lakh. The local administration has commissioned the mapping to several agencies including Unesco office in Delhi which will hold workshops by the experts. Further disclosing the details of the mapping, Jain noted that it will also help in determining the socio-economic needs of the residents including artisans and others living inside the area. “The data will help in preparing a special area plan which will act like a manual for the heritage site," said Jain.

Title: Airport intruder sent to Gwalior mental hospital
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The accused in police custody in Bhopal on Monday

BHOPAL: Doctors on Wednesday recommended sending Yogesh Tripathi — who breached the Raja Bhoj airport security and vandalized a chopper at the state hangar and blocked a plane — to Gwalior ’s mental hospital .

He will be sent to the mental hospital from Bhopal jail at night.

During the check-up of the 22-year-old, Hamidia hospital doctors found that he was suffering from acute psychosis. Psychosis is characterized by an impaired relationship with reality. It is a symptom of serious mental disorders. People who are experiencing psychosis may have either hallucinations or delusions. The person experiencing psychosis may also have thoughts that are contrary to actual evidence.

Realizing his situation, doctors recommended sending him to the mental hospital. After discharge from hospital, Tripathi was taken to Bhopal central jail, from where he will be sent to Gwalior mental hospital . Bhopal jail superintendent, Dinesh Nargawe, told TOI that formalities have been completed and Tripathi would be sent to Gwalior by midnight.

The youth was admitted to Hamidia hospital on Tuesday after his condition deteriorated in Gandhi Nagar police custody. Doctors kept him under observation for 24 hours to assess his mental condition. The accused had even turned violent when he was being taken to hospital and tore the uniform of a policeman and allegedly bit some other cops.

In a major security breach at Raja Bhoj airport on February 3, the 22-year-old college student — who allegedly wanted to play commando — sneaked into the state hangar, vandalized a parked helicopter and blocked a SpiceJet flight that was moving for takeoff.

After the incident, CISF personnel arrested Tripathi, who sports a crew cut and goatee and wore camouflage trousers. Yogesh told security personnel that he breached airport security because he “wanted to get into commando training”.

His family was bewildered by this claim and says he had never shown any inclination for military service. The accused entered the state hangar through the gate before committing the crime.

Title: CM repeats call for joint fight against CAA
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Reiterating the government stand for a joint fight , including open demonstrations and agitations, by the LDF and UDF against the CAA (Citizenship Amendment Act), chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan has urged the IUML leaders to persuade the Congress into such a fight “as the secular credentials of the country were at stake”.

Hinting at the “unfortunate stand” taken by the KPCC leadership on such a joint agitation, the CM, while making his concluding remarks during the discussion on the motion of thanks to the governor’s address in the assembly on Wednesday, said the ruling and opposition parties should come together to spread the message among people.

“The IUML, however, seems to have taken a stand favourable for a joint fight. Now, they need to persuade the Congress leadership to shed their party politics and join the fight against CAA,” Vijayan said.

The CM also clarified that a joint electoral fight at the national level against the BJP was not possible now as the Congress had no alternative to the economic policies being implemented by the Modi-led government. “Such an opposition needs not just strength, but also alternative policies. Unless Congress rectifies its economic policies, it cannot be an alternative to the BJP,” he said.

Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala later told reporters that Vijayan was playing a political game in the name of fighting CAA. “The UDF is not for making any political gains, and will strengthen its fight against the CAA,” he said.

Taking part in the discussions, Chennithala said the LDF government was giving mere promises in the name of Rebuild Kerala Initiative (RKI). “The CM made 13 foreign trips during his tenure and none of it was beneficial for the state,” he pointed out.

The motion of thanks to the governor’s address was later passed by the assembly.

Title: Walled City flouts Unesco heritage norms
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Choti Chaupar's shape has been changed by the Jaipur Metro Rail Corporation

JAIPUR: The shape of iconic 18th century Choti Chaupar , a public square built over an underground water tank, has been changed to a circle by the Jaipur Metro Rail Corporation (JMRC) in violation of the state government’s commitment to the Unesco.

The Walled City was listed in the Unesco site in 2019 with the commitment to preserve its cultural and architectural heritage. The blatant change of its shape from a square to a circle in the presence of Heritage Technical Committee questions the seriousness of the state in sticking to its commitments.

Expressing concern over tampering of the Chaupar, Shikha Jain , a cultural heritage expert in Unesco World Heritage Committee who prepared the dossier for the heritage site said, “I am disheartened to see the change in the independent structure (Chaupar), which doesn’t go well with the commitments made to Unesco. I came to know about the change last week and informed the authorities to take note of it. I hope the shape will be restored it at the earliest,” said Jain.

The tampering with the historical site has been made to give way to the entry gate and lifts for the newly built underground metro station as well as to create more space to de-congest traffic at peak hours.

Besides the Chaupar, several other heritage sites in the Walled City have been tempered with. In the last six months, the authorities have tampered with temples built at least 200 years ago, have alterated havelies that are mapped as cultural centres, allowed mass private constructions and permitted non-adherence to the city’s identity—the pink colour/paint— in violation of the commitments made to the international body.

The steps of Laxmi Narayan Temple at Badi Chaupar were partially demolished to give way for an entry gate of metro station, while several old wooden gates with rare carvings were replaced by modern iron gates. Inconsistency in the pink hues in the markets can be seen in the same lane.

Over the years, hardly any clarification has been made by the authorities about the specific type of pink colour required to be painted.

In the official document to UNESCO, the architectural heritage of the Walled City Jaipur is divided into three types based on the time period. It says that even the restoration and conservation work should be done causing minimal damage to the actual site.

Title: Unesco chief Audrey Azoulay tours Amber fort, meets girl students
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Unesco director general Audrey Azoulay during her visit to the city on Wednesday

JAIPUR: In her maiden visit to the city, Unesco director general Audrey Azoulay on Wednesday went to the Walled City , a world heritage site .

The director reached historic Amber Fort around 9:30 am and stayed for an hour touring it. Her tourist guide Narendra Chitawa told TOI, “She really enjoyed the tour and particularly liked Amber Fort. She also spoke about promoting indigenous arts and culture as she herself has keen interest in it.”

She then went to a girls’ school there. While interacting with the students, Azoulay encouraged them to contribute to the country with their education and skills.
