She took photographs with the girls, talked to them about education and later saw their classrooms. The students performed a self-defence demonstration on the occasion.

“Congratulations to all of you, teachers, pupils and families. Girls' education is the cause of our century. Girls, we need you!” Azoulay wrote on a photo frame prepared by the students. The girls had placed Azoulay's photo on one side of the frame and left a blank space for her comments.

After spending nearly 40 minutes in the school, she left for the iconic Hawa Mahal where she unveiled the World Heritage city engraved stone plaque. On the way, she briefly halted at Jal Mahal Ki Paal and took pictures.

The Walled City of Jaipur, known for its iconic architectural legacy and vibrant culture, was recognised as a Unesco world heritage site in July last year.

Title: Finance min likely to bet on KIIFB again
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: In 2019, finance minister T M Thomas Isaac was on a difficult mission: finding funds for the ambitious Rebuild Kerala programme to reconstruct a flood-ravaged state. Faced with a dip in revenue receipts amid mounting debts, it was practically impossible to ensure budgetary allocation for the project. In the end, he chose KIIFB (Kerala Infrastructure Investment Fund Board) to finance the project.

Isaac, who is facing a tough situation on the financial front this time, will once again be forced to depend on KIIFB to initiate major development works in state. The budget, which he is set to present on Friday, is unlikely to spring major surprises as he has a task at hand: complete the projects taken up by KIIFB.

With LDF entering its last year in power, no major development projects can be expected in the budget. But there are several projects that were taken up and left incomplete; most of them are infrastructure projects.

After the state government started totally depending on KIIFB for funding projects, all departments are now relying on it. KIIFB has given tenders for 347 projects at an estimated cost of Rs 13,616 crore. Till date, works started in 269 projects for which Rs 10,581 crore is the total outlay.

But mobilizing funds for KIIFB was not an easy task for Isaac. Though Pravasi Chitty was a concept to mobilize funds, it was not a success. The aim was to mobilize Rs 1,000 crore, but only Rs 135 crore could be raised using this plan.

Critics rate KIIFB as a bubble which will burst any time. With limited funds in its kitty, state government is going to struggle to repay the bonds it has taken and clear bills for the works it has sanctioned. However, Isaac has no worries since the repayment question will come into play only after May 2021.

Title: NSUI burns Bhoj univ V-C’s effigy, demands ouster for graft
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NSUI plans to file a complaint in Raj Bhavan and EOW, Lokayukta office along with all the evidences against So... Read More

Bhopal: Students, under the banner of NSUI, on Wednesday burnt the effigy of Bhoj University’s vice-chancellor, Jayant Sonwalkar, demanding his ouster. Sonwalkar has rubbished the allegations, calling them baseless.

NSUI’s spokesperson Vivek Tripathi alleged that the university had hit a low during the regime of V-C Sonwalkar. “Illegal appointments have been made by him. Rules and regulations were never followed while making such appointments that included teaching faculty also,” said Tripathi.

He added that contracts are being given out by the vice-chancellor without adopting the tender procedures, which has reportedly caused huge financial loss to the university and the government. “His (Sonwalkar’s) nexus with private institutions is something which needs to be probed,” added Tripathi.

“Appointments were made on the basis of fake papers, which are under investigation,” said Tripathi. Court orders have been continuously not followed in his regime,” said Tripathi.

When contacted, V-C Sonwalkar said, “I have never received any such complaints. No one has ever come to me with such allegations. What should I respond over such baseless claims?”

He said some students had come to him over PhD issues. “I have never done any wrong. Atithi Vidwans were appointed following all norms and regulations,” said Sonwalkar.

NSUI plans to file a complaint in Raj Bhavan and EOW, Lokayukta office along with all the evidences against Sonwalkar.

Title: Company owner booked for illegal dumping of toxic waste
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Ahmedabad: A few kilometres away from the state capital, tonnes of toxic hazardous waste, packed in HDPE bags was dumped at a private plot near an industrial estate by a tractor trailer. The local crime branch (LCB) of Gandhinagar had been tipped off on January 24 about the illegal toxic waste dumping that was to take place the same day. The waste originated at Virat Alloys Pvt Ltd located within the Dhanot GIDC complex. Police lodged a complaint against the owner of the company and the owner of the plot.

Police caught a tractor trailer and an earthmover from the open plot between Dharti-Apollo Industrial estate and Somany Ceramics near Kalol in Gandhinagar district. The Gandhinagar LCB in its FIR estimates that 20 tonnes of dark brown toxic acidic waste was packed in 15x5-foot high-density polyethylene bags, to be buried at the site.

Police informed the Gujarat Pollution Control Board (GPCB) and requested it to run scientific tests to ascertain the nature of the substance. The waste turned out to be effluent treatment plant (ETP) sludge, which had to be handled by a certified waste processing agency. The police and GPCB team visited the premises of the company in Dhanot GIDC and found some 40 tonnes of ETP waste waiting to be disposed, with another two tonnes of pickling waste lying unattended. Police booked the owner of Virat Alloys Pvt Ltd and the owner of the private plot.

Title: Medaram Jatara begins, tribal deity arrives from village temple
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Thousands of devotees descend on Medaram

MEDARAM: The 4-day Sammakka-Saralamma Jatara , or Medaram Jatara , got underway on Wednesday with the arrival of tribal deity Saralamma from Kannepally village. Tribal priests performed rituals at Kannepally village for about three hours, before stepping out of the temple with the deity — a casket of vermillion — in the presence of thousands of devotees on Wednesday evening.

The 4km road from Medaram from Kannepally was packed with devotees, waiting to catch a glimpse of the Goddess.

It became tough for the police to control the sea of devotees, who jostled with each other to touch the priests involved in the procession. Many devotees, especially those suffering from illnesses, were also seen rolling on the road with folded hands, wishing that the priests carrying the Goddess would walk over them. This ritual is known as ‘varam’ pattadam’. The procession started at 4pm and continued till 9pm.

Tribal priests had also reached Medaram with Saralamma’s husband, Govindarajulu and placed him alongside Saralamma. Govindarajulu who is in the form of ‘Pagida’ was treated as a groom ready for the wedding.

They also carried Pagididdaraju and placed him alongside Saralamma and Govindarajulu. Later, the rituals for the celestial wedding of Sammakka with Pagididdaraju began, which will end on Thursday after the arrival of Sammakka from Chilakalagutta.

Though the Jatara commenced formally on Wednesday, pilgrims have been thronging the shrine since a month now. On Wednesday, chief secretary Somesh Kumar and DGP M Mahender Reddy also inspected the arrangements at the jatara site, as directed by chief minister K Chandrashekhar Rao.

Title: Red Cross will launch help desk at Wenlock Hospital
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Shantharam Shetty, chairman, Dakshina Kannada branch of Indian Red Cross Society, addresses a press meet on We... Read More

MANGALURU: The Dakshina Kannada district branch of Indian Red Cross Society (IRCS) as part of centenary year celebrations of Red Cross has decided to launch socially oriented programmes as part of the same. Setting up a help desk at Wenlock Hospital , inauguration of Prime Minister Jan Aushadi Kendra licensed to the district branch, strengthening of taluk units of the society and Youth Red Cross units in educational institutions are on the anvil.

S A Prabhakar Sharma, honorary secretary of the district branch told reporters that a 50-strong volunteer team, consisting mostly of senior citizens, will man the help desk at the Wenlock Hospital starting February 11. This facility is the need of the hour to guide patients and their attendants and direct them to the speciality department concerned, a need even deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh, also president of the district branch, felt, he said.

A PM Jan Aushadi Kendra set up at Padavinangady under licence given to the district branch has been operational for some time now. With physicians coming forward to prescribe medicine available at the kendra, Sharma said this will immensely help people for the generic medicines dispensed here are available at 80% less than the market price. This kendra will be formally dedicated for public use at a simple ceremony to be held shortly, he said.

Shantharam Shetty, chairman of the branch, said a major project envisaged to mark centenary year is the construction of a Red Cross Bhavan. The DC has allotted 25 cents for this project on the DC office premises, he said, adding the branch with help from well-wishers and donors and from CSR funds, will start work on it at the earliest. This bhavan will help the branch to give greater thrust to the myriad activities that it undertakes, he noted.

The branch has started a Red Cross Clinic in association with NMPT at Panambur to help the unorganised labourers. Free consultation and medicines are made available to beneficiaries at this clinic. The branch has set a target to take the number of its life members from the present 2,100 to 2,500 and patron members from 29 to 100 during the centenary year.

Title: For second time, EC bans Parvesh Verma from campaigning
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Parvesh Verma

NEW DELHI: The Election Commission (EC) on Wednesday banned BJP functionary Parvesh Sahib Singh Verma from campaigning for the second time ahead of the Delhi assembly elections.

In a statement, the EC said that a 24-hour campaign ban was imposed on the BJP MP for his “terrorist” remark against CM Arvind Kejriwal . The ban came into force at 6 pm on Wednesday. Verma will not be able to further campaign for the polls as the electioneering ends at 5 pm on Thursday.

“Verma made vitriolic aspersions against Arvind Kejriwal, CM of Delhi, which violates the model code of conduct,” the Election Commission said in the statement.

Earlier, the election panel had issued a show-cause notice to Singh in the wake of his terrorist remark against the CM. “Verma submitted his reply on January 31 denying the allegations levelled against him,” the EC stated. However, “after scrutiny of the video, it was found that he had cast vitriolic aspersions on the chief minister,” the EC added in its order.

The ban also bars Verma from making public utterances for the print, electronic or social media in connection with the ongoing assembly elections.

Earlier, on January 30, the EC had barred the MP from campaigning for 96 hours following his remarks against anti-CAA protesters in Shaheen Bagh and his statement on removing mosques at a public meeting in Vikaspuri .

The EC also slapped a notice on BJP spokesperson Sambit Patra for prima facie violating the poll code with a remark that had the potential to disturb communal and religious harmony. It has sought an explanation from Patra by 5 pm on Thursday. The BJP leader had made the controversial remark at a TV show after which AAP lodged a complaint with the CEO office.

Title: Discontent over CP Yogeshwar’s likely induction forced Karnataka CM to change tack
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Cars with fancy numbers personally chosen by the 10 MLAs to be sworn in as ministers on Thursday, lined up at ... Read More

BENGALURU: Faced with the difficult task of pleasing both disqualified MLAs and BJP loyalists when he set out to expand his council of ministers, chief minister BS Yediyurappa eventually decided to side with the turncoats whose ‘sacrifice’ brought his government into existence.

Failing to strike the desired balance, he preferred to repay those who made him CM and keep loyalists on hold. Thus, instead of inducting 13 (10 turncoats plus three loyalists) into his cabinet as he originally intended, Yediyurappa decided only 10 of the 11 disqualified legislators, who won assembly bypolls on BJP tickets, will take oath on Thursday.

Having promised the disqualified MLAs who won the bypolls ministerial berths, Yediyurappa simply did not have the space to manoeuvre since only six vacant spots remained. There was speculation that he would induct 10+5, but that quickly died out.

As reported, Mahesh Kumatalli will be the lone turncoat to miss out on a berth, but Yediyurappa also decided to keep former MLA CP Yogeshwar’s elevation on hold. Yogeshwar had lost the 2018 assembly elections and is not a member of either house.

Yogeshwar’s name in the list had brought dissidence in the ranks to the fore, especially since Kumatalli — who is from the politically dominant Panchamasali sect of the Linagayat community — was denied a berth. Yogeshwar is a Vokkaliga.

Shorpur MLA Narasimha Nayak or Raju Gowda as he is popularly known opposed the inclusion of Yogeshwar, even as several Lingayat leaders expressed displeasure over Kumatalli being snubbed.

"Isolating Kumatalli alone would definitely send the wrong signal, but the inclusion of only a few from the old guard would have created greater trouble. So, the chief minister’s decision to go with turncoats alone for now seems pragmatic. It serves interests of the party," said former minister Murugesh Nirani, a Panchamasali Lingayat.

Another factor that dogged the CM’s expansion plans was the lack of representation from the coastal belt. Although the names of Angara S (Sullia) and Halady Srinivasa Shetty (Kundapur) cropped up, their inclusion was not practical at this point.

"Striking a fine balance between regions and giving equitable representation to communities was a concern. The decision to postpone the induction of BJP loyalists was good in this sense," said Lahar Singh Siroya, senior BJP MLC.

Now, with six vacancies in hand, Yediyurappa will have more space to manoeuvre when he expands his cabinet to the full quota — perhaps in July. By then, he can drop a handful from his cabinet and make further room for newcomers, while using the existing vacancies as a carrot to dangle before aspirants to keep them calm.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: ‘Paperless’ elephants spend the night at police station
Content:
One of the elephants at Gotegaon police station premises

BHOPAL: A lack of some documents led to cops at Narsinghpur’s Gotegaon police station entertain some unusual guests on Sunday night. Guests who made them go fetch sugarcane. These visitors — two elephants — were found wandering in Gotegaon town and were kept overnight at the police station until their owners presented relevant permit documents.Two elephants were seen in Gotegaon on Sunday. When police came to know about it, their mahouts were quizzed about elephants’ identification and transportation permits. When they said they did not have the required documents, cops brought both the elephants to Gotegaon police station at around 5pm.Speaking to TOI, Gotegaon police station in-charge Prabhat Shukla said that like cattle, special chips are placed in the ears of elephants for identification. “Besides, special permits are also required for their transportation,” Shukla added. “When we enquired from the mahouts, they did have any documents. Thus, the animals were brought to the police station. However, the elephants had to be fed as well. So when we asked the mahouts about their eating habits, they informed us that they either eat specially-cooked food or tree barks or sugarcane. Since we could not prepare something special like large rotis for them, sugarcane was the option as it is found in abundance in Gotegaon,” he said.He added that one of the elephants belonged to a native of Chhatarpur while the other was owned by a person from Narsinghpur’s Tendukheda. “When the owners provided necessary papers for transportation and identification, the animals were released on Monday at around 11am,” he added. Speaking in a lighter vein, Shukla said, “This way we also got a chance to serve animals.”Police also conducted the medical tests of the animals after they were brought to the police station.

Title: Statements of women IAS officers recorded
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

AJMER: The city police on Wednesday recorded statements of three women IAS complainants in a case against Congress leader and advocate Rajesh Tandon for allegedly posting an absurd post on social media. The post mentioned about a woman IAS officer posted in Ajmer district but did not name her.

Police have not disclosed the names of the officers who have filed FIRs against Tandon. Earlier in the day, a group of lawyers asked the president and secretary of Ajmer BAR association to suspend the membership of advocate Tandon for his alleged post on social media.

Tandon, too, with another bunch of lawyers approached president of Ajmer BAR association and demanded that advocates should stand with him since the IAS Association has come out against him and he may not get justice.

Police investigating the case against Tandon will try to locate the video clip that he allegedly claimed in his social media post. The post of advocate Tandon allegedly claimed that there was a pornographic video in which a woman IAS officer in Ajmer was found in compromising state.

“No such video has surfaced so far and the post was based on rumours to degrade the dignity of women officers,” said a police source source.

Even accused Tandon accepted before media that he had not seen the video and wrote his post only on rumours.

Police sources said that Tandon has removed all such posts from his Facebook account but the cops were trying to recover these. Police will investigate the intention of the accused for writing such a post against woman IAS officer on social media.

Title: Gold imports plunge to a five-month low
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Gold imports fell sharply from 2.56 metric tonnes in December 2019 to merely 0.92 MT in January

AHMEDABAD: Wedding season gold purchases have lost their sheen this January. Gold imports fell sharply from 2.56 metric tonnes in December 2019 to merely 0.92 MT in January, registering a decline of 64%.

“Geopolitical factors caused an increase in gold prices which touched record high levels breaching the Rs 42,000-mark for the first time. High prices in a slowdown situation are always a deterrent for gold purchases. Moreover, the Kamurta period till January 13 is considered quite inauspicious for gold purchases, as a result of which gold buying remained muted during the wedding season,” said Haresh Acharya, director, India Bullion and Jewellers’ Association (IBJA).

Analysts also said that several investors, jewellers as well as stockists were in wait-and-watch mode for purchases, in the wake of the Union budget announcement. “Industry stakeholders were hopeful of a cut on customs duty on gold from the existing 12.5% in the Budget announcement. This is why many deferred purchasing gold,” said Acharya.

Jewellers said that while the Kamurta period affected demand for gold jewellery, high prices led to a lot of purchases being made by exchanging old gold. “Most customers come with a fixed budget and come with old gold to be exchanged for purchases. This brings down the overall volume of gold traded,” said a senior member of Manek Chowk Choksi Mahajan.

Jewellers also said that the unseasonal rainfall had affected rural incomes to a great extent and as a result, gold demand from rural customers, which accounts for some 60% of the total demand, went further down.

Title: Ahmedabad: Anti-CAA protester held for taking part in rally at Rakhial
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Rakhial police on Wednesday arrested Sufiyaan Rajput, 25, a resident of Rakhial, for taking part in a rally of about 500 people held to protest against the CAA and the NRC, on January 19. Police sources said that Rajput was shouting slogans in the rally which did not have police permission.

“We have arrested him for violating Sections 143 and 144 imposed through a notification issued by the police commissioner,” said a senior police official. “We are searching for more participants of the rally. An offence was registered against about 500 people.”

Police sources said violence had broken out in Shah-e-Alam area of the city and several policemen had been injured in stone-pelting. On that day, the rally was organized in Rakhial. The organisers of the rally had sought permission for the rally which was denied.

CCTV footage was collected from cameras installed in shops on the route of the rally. “Rajput was identified from the footage,” the police official said. Demonstrations have been under way since January 14 near Ajit Mill and for about eight days at Morarji Chowk in Rakhial.

Title: Kumbh less than a year away, mela area still encroached
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Encroachment is rampant in the mela area's Bairagi camp

HARIDWAR: With less than a year to go for the Kumbh Mela to commence, the administration is still shying away from taking measures to remove illegal constructions by individuals and institutions on the mela land. While efforts are underway to include additional space in the existing mela area in view of increased land requirement cited by akharas, it seems that a blind eye is being turned on encroachments, an official who had been associated with Kumbh 2010 told TOI.

“This is a huge area of concern and raises doubts regarding timely completion of the mela arrangements,” the former official added. In the Bairagi Camp area alone, there are about 1000 pucca houses besides 40 ashrams illegally constructed on the mela land, Kamaleshwar Mishra , a retired BSNL officer residing in the area alleged.

A few months ago, chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh had also pointed out during a meeting that large-scale encroachment on Kumbh mela land in Haridwar is a problem that must be addressed on a priority basis.

However, precious little has been done towards this end. A few minor drives are occasionally carried out as was done earlier this week when a team of officials from the irrigation department and Haridwar Roorkee Development Authority went to Bairagi Camp. “All they did were demolish a few pillars and stopped construction of a cowshed in an ashram. In the vicinity, there are dozens of ashrams including Sadhana Sadan, Uma Maheshwar Ashram, Mauni Baba Ashram, Akiya Dham and Sachidanand Ashram, besides hundreds of houses of individuals situated on encroached land but no action was taken against them,” a resident of the area told TOI.

When queried about the issue, additional mela officer Harvir Singh said, “The construction which had recently been started, has been stopped. For removal of other encroachments which are already identified, a team will be constituted.”

Arun Manav, a local resident, alleged that the administration must act swiftly especially against ashrams that have been built on the land allotted to seers for camps in Kumbh 2010. “Forget opposing permanent construction illegally done on the mela land, seers are demanding more land in the mela area for the forthcoming Kumbh.”

‘Committee to be set up for inter-departmental co-ordination to speed up Kumbh work’

Haridwar: At a Kumbh 2021 review meeting held at the Central Control Room (CCR) in Haridwar on Wednesday, Garhwal commissioner Ravinath Raman told officials that efforts be made to complete permanent works related to the mega festival by October-November. He added that a committee will soon be set up for inter-departmental co-ordination. Speakinjg to TOI, Raman said that in certain departments, re-tendering has been necessitated due to contractors refusing to do the work allotted to them whereas in some others, officials have been asked to increase supervision in view of complaints regarding work quality. “Due to Char Dham and kanwar yatra, there will be big challenges before the Kumbh administration. But it should be their endeavour to ensure that neither is any inconvenience caused to the pilgrims, nor does the Kumbh work suffer,” he said.

Title: 950 dumper-loads of waste cleared from Jayanthi nullah
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The overflowing sewage causes pollution in the Panchaganga river

KOLHAPUR: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has removed 950 dumper-loads of waste material from the Jayanthi nullah in the past three weeks.

The KMC officials said that the capacity of the nullah to hold sewage has been increased by 1 million litres. The work to remove the solid waste was initiated after there was an overflowing of sewage from the check dam located at the Khanvilkar Petrol pump.

The overflowing sewage causes pollution in the Panchaganga river. The experts suggested the removal of solid waste from the nullah so that the overflowing of the waste water can be stopped.

The capacity of the pumping station has been the same for many years and it also requires an upgrade to ensure that every drop of waste water flowing into the longest nullah is diverted for treatment at the plant located at Kasba Bawda.

R K Patil, the deputy hydraulic engineer of KMC said, “Usually the nullah overflows during the rainy days as the quantity of waste water entering the nullah from its catchment area increases. We were reported that a huge quantity of solid waste is thrown in the nullah. The action against those dumping the waste will be taken.

The nullah’s capacity to store the waste water has increased. A huge amount of solid waste is thrown in the nullah only at some stretches. We are putting the boards displaying messages not to throw the waste into it. Also, the health department is going to ensure that adequate bins are placed along the nullah stretch.”

The KMC is also going to clean some stretches of Gomati nullah which joins Jayanthi nullah at Hutatma Park.

The Gomati nullah which originates at Shivaji University is also loaded with solid waste especially when it passes through the industrial areas of Udyamnagar. An appeal will be made to people to participate in the drive to clean Gomati nullah.

Title: Police notice to 50 protesters at Shaheen Bagh
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NEW DELHI: Fifty protesters at Shaheen Bagh have been issued notices by police under CrPC sections 105/151 for disrupting peace and tranquility of the area during the anti-CAA protests. They will have to appear before a magistrate and explain their position.

Police sources said “binding down” notices under CrPC sections 107/150 have also been issued to 2,539 people across the city for creating a ruckus. “Some people issued the notices have already appeared. People are bound down in the area to ensure peace and good behaviour from them so that no untoward incident occurs,” said a police officer.

Delhi Police had requisitioned for 18,000 personnel from central forces to be deployed across the city along with nearly one lakh policemen from Thursday till the end of the elections on Tuesday. Apart from policemen on poll duty, Delhi Police will deploy all personnel from the PCR and communication units on the roads. In all, 20,000 additional personnel from reserve battalions will be deployed for law and order duties.

Sources said special focus will be on areas where anti-CAA protests are taking place. Security forces have been put on alert to thwart any protests near the polling booths. A total of 837 people with criminal records have been put under preventive custody. More than one lakh people have been booked under Delhi Police Act for defacement and creating a nuisance.

Sensitive and hypersensitive zones were demarcated using previous records of violence after consultation with the Election Commission. Some of the hypersensitive booths are in Seemapuri in Shahdara, Seelampur in northeast Delhi, Adarsh Nagar and Bharat Nagar in northwest Delhi, Karol Bagh, Patel Nagar and Chandni Mahal in central Delhi, and Najafgarh, Mundka, Sultanpuri and Nangloi in outer Delhi.

Patrolling has begun in crowded markets like Chandni Chowk and Paharganj. The eyes-and-ears scheme, involving locals in policing, has been activated. “Multiple checkposts have been set up across the city to prevent hooliganism or threats to voters,” said a police officer.

A meeting was held with candidates and election managers of all parties to ensure workers do not clash.

Title: State wakes up to online sexual abuse of the young
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Chennai: “We have lost the battle". The frustrated cry of activists battling to stem the tide of child sex abuse material (CSAM) online tells the story in a nutshell. From images of a sexually abused newborn with umbilical cord intact to a 16-page manual by a father on how to rape his daughter, the online onslaught is distressing even for internet watchers authorized to track the web for disturbing content.

What’s worrying is that the infection is spreading closer home. And, India has only just begun the battle. Countries like the US, UK and Canada have already taken the deep dive into the dark depths of the digital world. Last September, Interpol stepped in to alert India about Tamil Nadu and Kerala ranking high, along with Delhi, Maharashtra, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and West Bengal, in the number of people watching obscene content involving children online. One of the recent CBI investigations began after information about a German national Sasche Treppke being convicted in that country for distributing CSAM among 29 WhatsApp groups. Seven Indians, including two from Chennai, were members of these groups.

On November 15, the CBI set up a specialised unit to tackle the problem of CSAM. Following a Supreme Court order, Tamil Nadu too constituted a special wing for crimes against women and children. The state was divided into regions headed by three officers. The special wing, headed by nodal officer V Jayashri, was given the task of cracking down on those who possess or manufacture offensive material. "Child sex abuse material has been circulated since the dawn of internet. But only now we have created the cyber wing," admitted ADGP M Ravi, who heads Tamil Nadu’s special wing to fight crimes against women and children. Cyber cells have been created in every district of Tamil Nadu to coordinate better. But, resources available are pathetically meagre to tackle the task in hand.

Though there have been a few arrests of people downloading and sharing sexual images of children, Tamil Nadu has a long way to go. "Most people don’t know that the offence comes under sections of the IT Act as well as Pocso now," said Jayashri.

While information exchange with international agencies is giving a fair idea of the nature and extent of the problem, arrests on the ground are hardly enough. In January, the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, a US-based NGO, alerted the Union ministry of home affairs (MHA) about more than 25,000 cases of suspected abusive content being uploaded across social media platforms in India in the past five months. Though the MHA launched www.cybercrime.gov.in to encourage people to report CSAM and rape images, the complaints went into the regular policing slot and proved to be just another cog in the wheel.

"A lot of pictures of girls in Kerala are uploaded. And, it takes a lot of effort to get to the victims," said Kerala additional director general of police Manoj Abraham, nodal officer of the state police cyberdome, leading ‘Operation P Hunt’ to zero in on child sex offenders. "Complaints don’t come. We tracked some of the offenders after we noticed a Malayalam Manorama calendar and a Malayalam magazine in the offending visuals," said the officer. Last October, 22 men were picked up by Abraham’s team for using WhatsApp, Facebook and Telegram groups to share CSAM.

Realising that collaboration with multiple agencies is key to tackling the issue, the Kerala government recently inaugurated a dedicated centre to tackle online sex abuse of children that will work with agencies like Interpol, The International Centre for Missing & Exploited Children, US, and the NCRB. The more chilling aspect is the self-generated images by children, coerced or unwitting, and the challenges this present to cyber forensics in the country.

Further, a person viewing and sharing obscene images of children is not always part of organised gangs, which need to be prosecuted first. "Arresting and prosecuting a couple of people will not really make a dent, but might lull society into thinking the situation is safer," said Vidya Reddy of Tulir, a centre for the prevention and healing of child sexual abuse. Apart from a legislative framework, psychological counselling too plays a role to deter the crime. "With the mandatory reporting under Pocso, it is hard to assist those who may have sexual interest in children, to seek help before they actually abuse children," said Vidya.

Title: VK Sasikala: Rajinikanth type relief eludes VK Sasikala, I-T refuses to withdraw case
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

VK Sasikala

CHENNAI: About a week after the income tax department withdrew its case against actor Rajinikanth , who had been imposed Rs 66 lakh penalty, expelled AIADMK leader V K Sasikala failed to earn a similar reprieve from the department.

On Wednesday the income tax department refused to withdraw an appeal pending against Sasikala in the Madras high court, though the value of the appeal was below Rs 1 crore.

Recently, the department chose to withdraw a similar appeal pending against Rajinikanth citing a circular issued by central board of direct taxes (CBDT) dated September 8, 2019, directing the department to not go on appeal in cases valued below Rs 1 crore. The department was also instructed to withdraw all such pending appeals in various courts across the country.

However, tax department counsel T R Senthil Kumar informed the high court on Wednesday that Sasikala could not seek relief under the circular since prosecution had already been initiated in her case. “Though the circular provides for withdrawal of appeals valued below Rs 1 crore, it would not apply to cases in which there is an objection raised by the revenue audit or prosecution has been already initiated,” Senthil Kumar said.

Recording his submission, a division bench of Justice Vineet Kothari and Justice R Suresh Kumar directed the department to file a report on the status of the prosecution in two weeks.

The issue pertains to returns filed by Sasikala for assessment year 1994-95 for Rs 28.86 lakh. Subsequently, a raid conducted by Directorate of Vigilance and Anti-Corruption (DVAC) found that she had concealed purchase of 80 acres of land during the assessment year. Therefore, based on the DVAC report, the income tax department passed an order dated March 14, 2002, demanding tax to the tune of Rs 48 lakh.

Aggrieved, Sasikala challenged the order before the income tax appellate tribunal (ITAT) which quashed the assessment order. Challenging the tribunal’s order, the department moved the present appeal in the high court.

When the plea came up for hearing, Sasikala’s counsel contended that she is entitled to relief in view of the CBDT’s circular.

Title: IIT-Roorkee, BEL to develop security system
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

DEHRADUN: Indian Institute of Technology , Roorkee (IIT-R) and aerospace and defence company Bharat Electronics Limited (BEL) have collaborated to develop a ‘Security Surveillance System’ which is a system of various cameras/videos fitted in a building to record movement of a person on the map along with time. On Wednesday, IIT-R director Ajit K Chaturvedi announced the institute’s collaboration with BEL for the security device.

According to Chaturvedi, the USP of the Security Surveillance System would be detecting abnormal human behaviour, face identification, fetching data from database in the form of person coordinates and track where every person moves in the premises, among others.

Title: State govt grants Rs12 lakh for Ankita’s treatment
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Wardha: The state government on Wednesday granted 12 lakh compensation to Ankita Pisudde, a 25-year-old college teacher who was set ablaze by a stalker in Hinganghat on Monday. Wardha district administration on Wednesday transferred 4 lakh to Orange City Hospital and Research Institute (OCHRI) towards her treatment.

Ankita’s condition remained critical on Wednesday but her vitals are stable. She underwent second debridement and dressing, as per the hospital.

According to Wardha district collector Vivek Bhimanwar, a provision of around Rs12 lakh has been made as per estimates given by the hospital. “Rs4 lakh have been deposited in the hospital’s account, which should be enough at this stage,” he said.

Apart from staging protests in Hinganghat over the incidents, people are also praying for well-being of the victim. Prayers were organized in temples on Wednesday.

Vaishali Bhute, resident of Sayaji Nagar in Hinganghat, said that all women from her colony prayed for improvement in Ankita’s condition. “Her condition is very critical. We are chanting Mahamutranjay Mantra with a belief that the almighty will save her,” she said.

Giving a political twist to the case, state vice-president of BJP Chitra Wagh said the state government delayed the compensation. “The amount was given after efforts taken by BJP,” she claimed.

The accused, Vikesh Nagrale, is in Hinganghat police custody till February 8.

Vivek Timande of Daroda village from where Ankita hails, said that Nagrale was warned by her parents several times. “They were friends a year ago but since then she had been avoiding him,” he said.

On Wednesday, Nagpur divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar, Dr Sanjeev Jaiswal, Nagpur division deputy director health services, Sanjay Bhargava, on behalf of Bajaj Foundation Wardha, Aparna Kolhe, Nagpur district women’s & child development officer, and Rupali Chakankar, women state president, NCP, visited OCHRI to enquire about the status of the patient.

Title: Govt to waive loans of STs
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Bhopal: State cabinet headed by chief minister Kamal Nath on Wednesday approved to promulgate the Madhya Pradesh Scheduled Tribe Rinn Vimukti Ordinance, 2020. State law minister PC Sharma said, “Under this, all loans taken by members of the tribal community till August 15, 2019 will be waived. The decision has been taken in the cabinet meeting.”

The minister claimed all loans, irrespective of their nature or amount, will be waived. These include loans taken from both nationalised and private banks.

This loan waiver is in addition to the announcement made by chief minister Kamal Nath on the occasion of International Day for Indigenous People on August 9 last year. Back then, the CM announced in Chhindwara that a law would be enacted to annul all loans taken by tribal community members from private non-licenced moneylenders in the 89 tribal blocks. No one needs to back loans taken from private moneylenders, not even the state government, chief minister Nath had said.

The Kamal Nath government had waived-off the loans taken from non-licenced moneylenders through an amendment made in the Anusuchit Janjaati Sahukar Viniyam (Scheduled Tribes Moneylenders Regulations, 1972).

Cabinet also decided to implement the ‘Madhya Pradesh Hybrid Renewable Energy and Energy Storage Policy’ for development of renewable energy projects in the state. This will include electricity generation from two or more renewable energy sources at a project site.

Government also endorsed the amendment of Indira Gandhi Samaj Seva Puraskar 1992 to increase the amount of the award from Rs1 lakh to Rs10 lakhs for the award to institutions working for the poor and the differently-abled in the social sector.

In another decision, council of ministers increased the limit of voluntary grants given by ministers from Rs20,000 to Rs40,000. Cabinet also approved continuation of the scheme for expansion of state assembly building and MLA rest-house under the Urban Development and Housing Department.

The Cabinet endorsed the proposal for amendment of probation period, pay scales and reservation rules in the Rajya School Shiksha Seva (Education Cadre) Conditions and Recruitment Rules, 2018, under the department of school education. Similarly, it was also decided to make an amendment in the Madhya Pradesh Tribal and Scheduled Caste Education Cadre, Service and Recruitment Rules, 2018.

Council of ministers decided make amendment regarding the recruitment process in the State Service Examination Rules 2015 related to the State Service Examination conducted by Madhya Pradesh Public Service Commission.

Approval was given to make appointments on 31 posts on contractual basis for the period from April 1, 2020 to March 31, 2023.

Title: ASI held for taking bribe in Kota
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

KOTA: The Anti Corruption Bureau of Baran on Wednesday arrested an assistant sub inspector posted in Chipabarode police station for allegedly accepting bribe of Rs 5,000 for dropping the name of an accused from a case.

The ASI had already taken Rs 70,000 but demanded another Rs 5,000 following which the complainant, identified as Vinod Kumar Nagar of Chipabarode town, approached the ACB and lodged a complaint against the ASI.

ACB, following verification of the complaint on Tuesday, laid a trap at Chipabarode police station on Wednesday and arrested ASI Ramesh Chand Verma after he had allegedly accepted Rs 5,000 bribe.

Verma was arrested after he had allegedly accepted a bribe of Rs 5,000 from one Vinod Kumar Nagar, said ACB Baran inspector Gyanchand Meena.

The ASI had taken the bribe for dropping his mother’s name in a case against his family members, the ACB inspector said and added the accused further demanded Rs 5,000 following which Nagar approached ACB.

The ASI would be produced before ACB court in Kota on Thursday.

Title: CAIT draws govt attention to piling litigations over cheque dishonour
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Nagpur: Confederation of All India Traders ( CAIT ) in a communication sent to Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman has drawn the attention of government over rapid increase in number of dishonoured cheques.

Traders of the country are perturbed over frequent instances of cheque dishonouring and the long time it takes to get justice after that. CAIT has suggested for setting up of fast track courts to deal with cheque bounce cases.

CAIT national president BC Bhartia drew Sitharaman’s attention towards the 213th Law Commission Report which says that about 40 lakh cheque bounces cases are being heard in the courts. This makes it clear that the single category of cases constitute a major portion of all pending litigation in the judicial system, said the CAIT letter.

A Supreme Court bench headed by Justice Adarsh Kumar Goel observed on June 20, 2018, that more than 20% of the cases in subordinate cases were related to cheque dishonour, says the CAIT letter.

Title: No plan to keep bars open on first day of month: Min
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Excise minister T P Ramakrishnan said in the assembly that the state government has not considered a proposal to keep bars and beverage outlets open on the first day of every month. The minister rubbished reports on government plans to open the bars and outlets on dry days .

While reiterating that total prohibition is not the policy of the government, he said government is aiming at bringing down the liquor consumption. Even when bars were shut down during the UDF rule, the consumption had not come down.

During 2014-15 when the bars were closed, the sale of liquor was 220.58 lakh cases in the state. However, during 2018-19 it was 216.34 lakh cases, said the minister. The government has decided to start deaddiction centres in all taluks. At present, deaddiction centres have been set up in all 14 districts. This will be increased to 20 centres. The deaddiction centres are having a bed strength of 10 each said Ramakrishnan.

Online trade of narcotics

The minister said there are plans to constitute a high-tech cyber cell to check online trade of narcotic substances. The excise commissioner has submitted a proposal for setting up a cyber cell exclusively for this. There are reports of a thriving online business of narcotic substances in the state.

Over 7,600 inmates in jails

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan informed the assembly that in the 55 jails, including the central prisons, of the state there are 7,653 inmates. Of this 174 are women. He said there are more inmates than the capacity in a few jails.

Title: Man fakes mom’s death for dead father’s money
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: A man in Anuppur district allegedly faked the death of his own mother and got a death certificate issued from the civic body in order to withdraw money deposited by his late father in a bank account whose sole nominee was his mother.

The accused, who was arrested by Anuppur police on January 29, was presented in court which later rejected his bail.

Incident took place at ward number 6 of Bijuri town of Anuppur district.

Accused Vinod Kumar Pandey, 58, a resident of ward number 6 in Anuppur district’s Bijuri town, was arrested by police following a complaint by his younger brother Pradumn Narayan Pandey.

Speaking to TOI, Bijuri police station head constable Istiyaq Khan said, “A complaint was received from the accused’s brother who stated that he had made a fake death certificate of their mother. Detailed investigations were carried after which the allegations were found to be true. A case was registered against the accused under sections 467 ( forgery for purpose of cheating) and 468 (forgery of valuable security, will, etc) and he was arrested on January 29 and produced before court.”.

He added, “The court rejected his bail and later another bail petition before higher court of sessions judge was also rejected. He is in jail now”.

Khan said there had been some dispute between the brothers. The accused somehow managed to make a fake death certificate of his 80-year-old mother who is still alive. “However, he had not used the certificate to withdraw money or anything else,” Khan said.

“Pandey’s younger brother came to know about this and lodged a complaint alleging that he had made a fake death certificate to withdraw their father’s money. The allegations about fake death certificate were found to be true,” Khan added.

Title: Ration racket: 1,100 fingerprint casts found
Content: Ahmedabad: In their investigation into stealing of food grains from the public distribution system by fair price shop owners, the cybercrime cell of Ahmedabad police has found more than 1,100 casts of beneficiary fingerprints made on some silicone-like material. The modus operandi used by the racketeers is shocking as a fingerprint cast can be used to endorse any document, open locked apps and mobile phones and bypass bio-metric barriers that depend solely on fingerprints.In pursuit of the trail they have been following since December 2019, police have till date arrested 40 persons, with the last six arrested since Monday, January 3, said Rajdeepsinh Zala, DCP, cybercell. The mastermind behind the racket, Bharat Chaudhary of Banaskantha, had been arrested last December.The six arrested most recently are Shabbir Khatai, 45, of Gir-Somnath, Sandeep Kariya, 40, of Veraval, Manharsinh Dabhi, 26, of Amreli, Amit Vithlani, 35, of Veraval, Pancha Pamar, 43, and Aakash Marvadi, 46, of Ahmedabad. Bharat had made four applications for making fingerprint casts from soft copies and Manharsinh Dabhi used to act as a go-between with fair price shop owners for the gang, said an investigator.Sources said Chaudhary and his gang held soft copies and associated data of nearly 2,500 fingerprints.Corrupted fair price shop owners used to provide the fingerprints and data to Chaudhary, who used to take Rs 1,000 to prepare each fingerprint cast from scans. The fingerprint casts were then used to imprint fingerprints of poor people and siphon off their ration from the public distribution system. The food grains and other material were then sold in black in the open market with fair price shop owners pocketing the difference.“We still don’t know the material of the fingerprint casts. We have submitted some of these samples to the forensic experts to ascertain which material was used to embed fingerprints on it from a soft copy,” said a cybercrime cell official.Fingerprint casts - a Pandora’s box- Bogus documents can be validated- Pay apps locked by fingerprints can be accessed.- Imprints left by fingerprint casts can be used to frame people in crimes- Biometric locks and doors can be opened- Phones and apps locked with fingerprints can be unlocked- Anything requiring fingerprints including sim cards can be obtained- Transactions based on fingerprints, including bank withdrawals can be doneCan be disastrous for national interest: Jhala“This is a huge scam spread across states like Haryana. It is not only fair price shop owners who can misuse the fingerprint casts, it can be disastrous for national interest. Imagine your fingerprint being with someone. What may not he do in your name with that? More people may be arrested, and from other states,” said DCP Rajdeepsinh Jhala, cybercrime cell, Ahmedabad

Title: Hyderabad News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

With officials claiming that the Anandbagh RUB will be open to public this year, TOI asked readers if the RUB will put an end to traffic woes

Do you think the RUB will help ease traffic woes in Anandbagh and adjoining areas?

While there is no doubt that the RUB (if at all completed) will ease traffic congestion. As a senior citizens I wonder if I will be able to see the RUB open for public within my lifespan!

Kasturi Rangan

Proper planning should go into all aspects of the RUB. A flyover or RuB made for present vehicular volume may not be able to handle the load five decades down the line. A more constructive study is needed to build the RUB to ease traffic at Anandbagh and adjoining areas. A wider one would be must sustainable keeping in mind the ever growing traffic menace of the city. More funds should be diverted to construct a big and wide RuB so that the money, time and labour being invested is worth it. All land acquisitions and demarcation for wider RuBs should be done so that authorities are prepared for widening of RuB. Encroachments should be strictly contained.

Deepesh Surana.

Yes, the Anandbagh RUB will definitely help ease the traffic woes in the area. It is high time that the authorities completed the RUB that has been stalled for far too long. The officials should address the concerns of the people and also collaborate with experts to ensure that the RUB is effective.

Venkat

The RUB was planned several years ago to ease the traffic. We need to ask why it has been in the backburner for so long. The traffic congestion in most of the areas in Secunderabad is very severe. GHMC and R & B should worl together to evolve a long term plan to ease the traffic. The issue is that the volume of traffic is going to increase while the width of roads are going to remain the same. Unless government takes up road widening work or alternative measures such as FOBs, fly overs and RUBs, we will not be able to control the traffic snarls.

Dr GV Kumar

The density of traffic in Anandbagh and its surroundings is very high throughout the day and as a result, one witnesses frequent traffic snarls. The RUB work was taken up in 2014 but laxity on the part of GHMC officials, the task has been left incomplete, defeating the very purpose of the RUB. Due to this, the traffic woes have only multiplied leaving the residents fuming. However, once the RUB is thrown open, certainly it would be to able to solve traffic woes to a large extent.

Srinivasan Ramaswamy

Title: Man who returned from China isolated at Trichy's MGMGH
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: A 38-year-old man who had returned from China has been quarantined at the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Government Hospital (MGMGH) in Trichy on Tuesday after he developed symptoms of novel coronavirus - fever and sore throat.Sources said the man hailed from Pudukottai district and was employed in a company in China. He returned to his native place through the Trichy International Airport on January 31.Since he had no symptoms of the disease on the day of his arrival, the health department officials allowed him to go home. Two days later, he developed fever and sore throat following which he came forward to admit himself at MGMGH, a tertiary care centre for Trichy and neighbouring districts, on Tuesday night.The doctors took his blood sample and sent it to King Institute in Chennai to check whether he was infected with nCoV. Dean of MGMGH Dr K Vanithamani said on Wednesday evening that the patient was stable in the isolation ward.The hospital administration also heaved a sigh of relief after a 27-year-old man of Madurai tested negative for nCoV, following which he was discharged on Wednesday. He had been admitted to the hospital as he had fever when he landed at the Trichy airport from Singapore in the early hours of February 2.“He was discharged from the hospital since he tested negative and had no symptoms of nCoV. Public need not panic as proper and early treatment in the isolation ward at the government hospitals will completely cure the patients. But we have no positive cases of novel coronavirus so far,” said the dean.In another case, a 32-year-old man of Tiruvarur who wanted to go back to China for work was admitted to the Tiruvarur GH as his company in China laid down a condition that he can join duty only after producing a ‘no objection certificate’ from the health officials in India that he was not infected with nCoV.“He had no symptoms, but as he wanted to get a diagnosis done, he was admitted to the hospital. His blood sample has been sent to the King Institute,” said dean of Tiruvarur Government Medical College Hospital Dr J Muthukumaran.A 35-year-old man from Needamangalam was also admitted to the hospital with fever and cough on February 3. Working as a cook in China, he returned home on January 31 with no symptoms. But later he developed fever and was admitted to the hospital. Doctors are awaiting his blood test reports.

Title: Two dead in road accident in Nagaur
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

AJMER: Two persons were killed and six injured when their vehicle collided with a truck trailer at Kuchera in Nagaur district on Wednesday. The collision was so drastic that police had to use cutters to bring out bodies.

According to police, nine people were travelling in a vehicle from Bargana village , near Didwana, to Botati Dham, a religious place. Near Khajwana cross road in Kuchera, the vehicle collided with a truck trailer. Police took almost four hours to bring out the bodies.

The deceased were identified as Govind Ram (48) and Bhanwarlal (42). The injured were shifted to a government hospital in Nagaur.

Title: Churu police arrest two Iranians for stealing Rs 50,000
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

JAIPUR: Churu police arrested two Iranians who had stolen Rs 50,000 from the complainant in Ratangarh on pretext of wanting to see the Indian currency. The accused were arrested from Karnataka and were brought to Churu on Wednesday.

The accused were identified as Mehraj and Hadi , and both hail from Iran . “On January 6, the accused came to Ratangarh and got into a conversation with the complainant and expressed a desire to see Indian currency. The complainant showed them Rs 2,000 and Rs 500 notes, then kept them back. While one of the accused kept him busy in the conversation, the other accused quietly took the money. Both of them then absconded with the money,” said an official of Ratangarh police station.

After the case was lodged, the police started a search for the accused and checked the veracity of the complaint by looking at the CCTV footage. A team was constituted which started a search for the foreigners.

“We started tracing their movement and went to Delhi, Mumbai, Haryana and Karnataka. Through sources, we confirmed their location in Karnataka and arrested them from Karwar police station area,” added the official.

According to police, the accused had assumed that cops were not on their trail. “The accused had rented a car from Delhi for travelling around the country and had assumed that they would not be traced. If they had tried to hide then it would have been difficult. We are questioning them to find out if they were involved in other cases too,” a police officer said.

Title: Manish Sisodia: Honest government worked day and night for you
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Manish Sisodia campaigned along with Bhagwant Mann, AAP MP from Punjab's Sangrur, at West Vinod Nagar

NEW DELHI: Even BJP workers accept that children in Delhi government schools are getting the best education , deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia claimed on Wednesday while addressing a public meeting at West Vinod Nagar falling under his assembly constituency, Patparganj .

“A prominent BJP worker, who had been campaigning against AAP’s education initiatives, recently took out his daughter from a private school and got her enrolled in a Delhi government school,” said the education minister, who was campaigning along with Bhagwant Mann , the party MP from Punjab’s Sangrur.

Crediting school teachers and the education team for the improvement, he said, “Even at private schools, we never allowed any fee hike. In comparison, the fees at Noida and Ghaziabad schools are way higher.”

On the development work in his constituency, the MLA said there was not even a single stretch in Patparganj that was not carpeted in the past five years. “Due to the rebates in electricity and water bills, 72,000 households are getting zero electricity bills here.”

While earlier development work used to get delayed due to a corrupt system, “an honest government is now working day and night for the city”, Sisodia said, adding that he felt proud to be part of a government working for the uniform development of society.

“This election is not about any particular party or candidate but about the kind of development and governance model people want to see in future,” the minister said while urging the crowd to vote for AAP if they wanted the government’s welfare schemes to continue.

Mann also requested people to choose the real issues over the politics of polarisation. “I am sure the people in Delhi will vote for development over those trying to divide society on the basis of slogans.” Slamming BJP’s politics of arrogance, Mann said the election commission even had to act against some BJP’s functionaries. “Senior BJP MPs have only one issue — Shaheen Bagh. When your government has brought this law, it is your responsibility to find a solution.”

Reminding the crowd that BJP is calling a chief minister who has worked hard a terrorist, Mann said, “February 8 is an opportunity to give answers to such people.”

Title: Services defeat Uttarakhand within two days
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Dehradun: Uttarakhand lost their Ranji encounter against Services by 10 wickets at the Rajiv Gandhi International Cricket Stadium on Wednesday. Services won the toss and chose to bowl first on a seaming wicket. Uttarakhand has now lost six of the eight matches in the current Ranji season. It stands at the bottom of the Group C table and is likely to relegate back to the Plate Group in the next season, in which they played during the 2018-19 season. Uttarakhand’s last Ranji match this year is on February 12 against Maharashtra.

Title: Man falls to death at film producer’s house in T Nagar
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A 44-year-old man fell to his death from the third floor of a film producer’s house in T Nagar on Wednesday.

The deceased Velmurugan is said to have been working as an electrician with film producer Kalpathi Agoram of AGS Cinemas for more than a decade. The incident happened in the morning on Habibullah Salai when Velmurugan tried to climb a water tank using steel stairs to check the motor. He lost balance and fell. “He did not have any grip to cling on to,” said a police officer. Moreover, with water overflowing, the tank was slippery, police said. Quoting eyewitnesses, police said Velmurugan usually climbed using the same steel stairs.

One of the security guards who heard a loud noise, came running to check and found Velmurugan bleeding. He was rushed to the nearby hospital where he was declared brought dead. On information, the Teynampet police registered a case of accidental death. His body was sent for a postmortem examination to Government Royapettah Hospital.

Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

Title: Karnataka: KPCL to fund construction of IIIT Raichur
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: The state government has decided to build the International Institute of Information Technology in Raichur on a public private partnership (PPP) model, but rather than partner with a private player for the purpose, it has decided to rope in Karnataka Power Corporation Limited (KPCL), its wholly owned subsidiary.

KPCL MD V Ponnuraj confirmed the corporation’s involvement and said it is likely to front Rs 19 crore. "KPCL has a considerable presence in the district and it was decided that our involvement in setting up a world-class institute would be ideal," Ponnuraj told TOI.

Based on recommendations of the state government, which pushed for a world-class institution in Kalyana-Karnataka, a backward region, the Union ministry of human resources development sanctioned the IIIT in Raichur in January 2018.

However, two years on, the first batch of students is working out of the IIT campus in Hyderabad as there is no sign of the Raichur campus. Earlier this year, the government decided to move the college to a newly constructed block on the government engineering college campus in Raichur.

"We have almost completed the new block exclusively for the IIIT, but it will be a temporary one," said Raichur deputy commissioner R Venkatesh Kumar. He said 65 acres has been allotted to the IIIT trust.

The problem for the state has been funding. It would require about Rs 75 crore to establish the new IIIT and the cash-rich KPCL will be the government’s industry partner.

Ponnuraj said KPCL will provide assistance in civil engineering and other aspects and in return it will be accommodated on the IIIT Raichur board. Meanwhile, the state will contribute Rs 45 crore over a period of four years beginning next fiscal and will allocate Rs 11 crore in the first year. The project is expected figure in the state budget to be presented on March 5 by chief minister BS Yediyurappa.

Title: Coronavirus in Kolhapur: Sangli man’s swab tests negative for coronavirus
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The swab sample of the person from Sangli, who was suspected to be infected with coronavirus , tested negative.The Sangli health department authorities heaved a sigh of relief on Wednesday morning as the samples sent to the National Institute of Virology, Pune, earlier this week, came in negative.Sangli district civil surgeon Sanjay Salunkhe told TOI that they have already arranged for a four-bed isolation ward for the suspected patients. The tracing is also active for them and so far, no new cases have been identified.“The screening of the suspected patients is underway across major airports in the country, hence we will get an idea of the suspected patient beforehand,” he said.Meanwhile, the Kolhapur health department authorities said that they are planning extensive awareness campaigns across the district and few emergency meetings have been called.Yogesh Sale, the district health officer of Kolhapur zilla parishad, said that they are waiting for the swab sample of the suspected patient from Kolhapur. However, there is nothing to worry as he seems fine and the sample was collected as a precautionary measure, said SaleHe said that he has called in a meeting of the primary health centre (PHC) and sub-centre officials on Friday, February 7 to execute the awareness campaign ideas“We want to use every medium, every resource to spread information about coronavirus in school to gram panchayats. Even if there are remote chances of the infection in our region, we do not want any misleading information among the residents,” he said.“The handbills, posters, and other information will be prepared in the coming week and will be placed in the prominent areas of the city, towns, villages, and schools,” he said.Experts say that Novel coronavirus (nCoV) is a large family of viruses including SARS, MERS that causes illnesses ranging from the common cold to acute respiratory syndromes. The virus has emerged from a seafood and animal market in China’s Wuhan.

Title: Brahmpuri SHO suspended
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The station house officer (SHO) of Brahmpuri police station was suspended on Wednesday after an elderly man complained that the police officer had refused to lodge his case. The matter came up during public hearing taken by UDH minister Shanti Dhariwal a day earlier. In the hearing, industries minister Parsadilal Meena informed Dhariwal that an elderly man’s daughter was found dead at her residence in Jaisinghpura Khor few days back but when he tried to register a case at Brahampuri police station, SHO Bharat Singh allegedly refused to do so by claiming that the matter was not of his jurisdiction. UDH minister then directed police to immediately get FIR lodged.

Title: Delhi Election 2020: Rookies looking to break new ground in CM Arvind Kejriwal’s den
Content: NEW DELHI: Since 2008, the winner of “New Delhi” has gone on to become the chief minister. Before the constituency was carved out in the 2008 delimitation exercise, it was known as Gole Market seat, which elected Sheila Dikshit back to back from 1998 to 2003. Dikshit held on till 2013 when she was upstaged by Arvind Kejriwal.Kejriwal won the seat in 2015 as well. This time around, both BJP and Congress have fielded rookie candidates against the AAP chief and, in the unlikely event of either of them causing an upset, the chances of their becoming the CM are next to nothing.Though tiny compared with other constituencies in terms of area, New Delhi is no less diverse, as it covers the entire Lutyens’ zone, which includes Rasthrapati Bhavan , the residences of PM and other union ministers and Parliament, as also happening markets like Khan Market and Connaught Place, besides upscale colonies and government quarters.The parties need to reach out to not just the affluent voters of Golf Links and Jor Bagh, but also the slum patches of Laxmi Bai Nagar and Peshwa Road. Throw colonies like Kaka Nagar , Sarojini Nagar and Sunder Nagar in the mix, and you have a potboiler. The constituency has a combination of castes and communities and the familial backgrounds are as diverse as the income groups.BJP’s candidate, Sunil Yadav, lost his father at a very young age and was raised in the slums by her mother who worked as a maid in different bungalows of Lutyens’. Immediately after BJP sprung a surprise by fielding him in New Delhi, Yadav mobilised the network of his childhood friends in the slums to mount an aggressive campaign.AAP, on its part, has launched a massive outreach programme with even the CM’s wife and children going door to door with the government’s report card. Kejriwal claims that his government has delivered so much in the last five years that even BJP workers will vote for it. He has cited installation of CCTV cameras, free rides for women in buses and several welfare schemes among the government’s achievements.Yadav, however, is confident of playing the party pooper. He starts his day early and moves around, with folded hands, from one area to another — in slums and upscale colonies alike. “I grew up playing in the slums here... the people are going to vote for me,” he said.Yadav said Kejriwal had fooled the people of the constituency by calling himself “aam aadmi” . “When Kejriwal came here (New Delhi) to fight election, people thought he would listen to them. But after five years, we hear he is a high-profile politician,” he claimed.Romesh Sabharwal of Congress, too, is a largely unknown face. He invokes the memory of Sheila Dikshit as a three-time CM of Delhi. Sabharwal takes AAP head on. He says: “Kejriwal has done nothing here. He has betrayed the voters’ trust and they are waiting to teach him a lesson. People will vote for Congress.”While improving sanitation, tackling pollution, greater CCTV coverage, smooth traffic and law and order are key poll issues here, people are largely satisfied with the services.
