Title: Here is a hero stone, for a teacher in 1960s
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Elders of Tidiyan village in Usilampatti say the two-foot tall sculpture of Packya Nathan and his wife was ere... Read More

CHENNAI: Tamil Nadu has a vibrant tradition of erecting memorial stones for heroes. The memorial stones with Tamil Brahmi inscriptions found in Pulimankombai and Thathapatti are considered the oldest (300BC) in the region.

Memorial stones with figures have been discovered from many parts of the state, but a rare modern one for a teacher and his wife found abandoned near the Sonaimuthaiah temple at Tidiyan village in Usilampatti points to the fact that the tradition existed till the 1960s.

"The people today don’t know the significance of the stone. The elders said it was erected in memory of a great teacher and his wife. This shows that the tradition of erecting hero stones existed till the 1960s," said K T Gandhirajan, a rock art expert who recently documented the memorial stone in Tidiyan.

Memorial stones broadly refer to the various kinds of monuments erected in remembrance of the dead (hero stones, religious commemoration and nisitikai).

Hero stone refers only to those erected for people who contributed to the welfare of or sacrificed their life for society or community.

It is believed that the two-foot-tall sculptures of teacher Packya Nathan and his wife were erected by his relatives and villagers for the good work he did by providing education to children from poor families. "Hero stones are found in many sizes and styles. They talk about a lot of cultural significance of the period they belong to. This is the first time we came across a memorial stone for a teacher and that’s why it is unique," he said.

The Sangam literature talks a lot about memorial stones as ‘nadukal’ (planted stones).

"This memorial stone is significant because we believe the tradition was lost in the beginning of the 20th century. We need to study in detail to know more about this piece," said K Bhoopathy, a retired history professor based in Madurai.

"The hero stones were erected in memory of heroes who laid their life, defending their territory or making some form of supreme sacrifice for the sake of the community or the region," he said.

More than 2,500 such hero stones have been discovered in many parts of Tamil Nadu, but they have not been documented by the state archaeology department or the ASI. Many face threats from vandals because of lack of protection.

Title: Coronavirus in Chennai: Europe, Middle East more favoured as fear of virus makes SE Asia unpopular
Content:
Tourists with protective face masks at Merlion Park in Singapore

CHENNAI: Southeast Asian countries seem to have fallen out of favour among travellers planning trips for the Valentine’s Day weekend, Holi holidays and summer vacation because more cases of novel coronavirus have been detected in Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand — among the most popular destinations from Chennai. Instead, the Middle East and Europe have emerged as alternative destinations.This has begun to reflect on airfares. Return fares to Southeast Asian countries have begun to decrease but fares to the Middle East have started to rise for bookings in March.One-way fares on the Chennai-Singapore route are hovering in the range of Rs 5,000–Rs 7,000, while fares to Dubai are in the range of Rs 7,000–Rs 10,000 for travel in March and April. Fares on the Singapore route are expected to decrease further in the coming days.Travel and tour companies too have begun suggesting alternative destinations for travellers because panic has gripped authorities in Singapore after around 18 coronavirus cases were detected.The virus has also begun spreading in Macau, Thailand, Philippines, Vietnam, Hong Kong and Japan which have emerged as new destinations in the last few years for those who have visited to Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore. There is more concern among the tourists over visiting these countries because they get many travellers from China.This will be the first time, travellers would be moving away from Southeast Asian nations for summer vacation travel.Basheer Ahmed of Metro Travels said: “Leisure travellers, who used to visit Singapore on weekends have stopped travelling. Only traders and those who have relatives there are travelling. Many who have not booked trips are considering the Middle East and Europe. Europe is an expensive destination.”Anand Menon, brand leader, Travel Tours of FCM Travel Solutions, said that Bhutan, Sri Lanka, Abu Dhabi, Dubai and Bali because of their proximity and various experiences they offer make for great holiday getaways. Europe could be expensive but group tours may be an option. “Group tours are a great way to holiday especially when you’re going to a place for the first time and want to keep it cost effective.”Since India is the third source market for tourists after China and Indonesia, Singapore Tourism Board has sent out a communication to travel and tour operators and hotels in India highlighting the steps being taken to safeguard people against novel coronavirus to assure them that all measures are being taken at hotels, business venues, cruise terminals and airports.

Title: Trichy: Cancer survivors share memories of mental well-being
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Commemorating World Cancer Day 2020 with the theme ‘I am and I Will’, survivors shared their memories of will power and consistent medication to defeat the disease, here on Wednesday.

Indian Medical Association – Trichy branch, Dr G Viswanathan Group of Hospitals, Dr G Viswanathan CBCC Centre and Dr K Shantha Breast Cancer Foundation, Trichy jointly observed World Cancer Day at the IMA hall Trichy. The doctors honoured the cancer conquerors to spread the message that most cancers can be conquered if detected early.

A 91-year-old man who was diagnosed with stomach cancer and survived 14 years, also participated in the event along with 19 cancer conquerors. A 19-year-old young man diagnosed with cancer in the head and neck and survived four years, spoke on how it can be conquered and how mental well-being was important to conquer cancer.

A woman diagnosed with a bilateral breast cancer, conqueror for the last 10 years spoke the path she walked after diagnosing.

Pink balloons were released by the cancer conquerors during the event.

This year’s theme for World Cancer Day 2020 “I am and I will” highlights the value of every individual to fight against cancer. Doctors said that cancer occurs due to uncontrolled abnormal growth of cells in the tissue or organs of the body.

They also expressed concern about the growing number of cancer patients across the world. In India, almost 12 lakh are diagnosed every year and out of which, 50% of the cancer patients do not survive. It was the second leading cause of death globally. The most alarming fact about cancer is that it takes a toll on children and young adults.

Title: Role reversal: Students turn HM for reciting multiplication tables
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

S Janani functioning as one hour principal on Wednesday

TRICHY: Sitting on a headmaster’s chair was something that 11-year-old S Janani of class V had only dreamed about. But on Wednesday, she was not only occupying the chair for an hour but was also functioning as a headmistress.

A student of Panchayat union primary school (PUPS) in Lingathur village near Thanthoni of Karur district , she was rewarded for successfully reciting a multiplication table till 9 in the classroom without stammering.

The school had announced that students memorizing multiplication tables will be given an opportunity to become headmaster/mistress of the school.

While the activity was given last Friday, three students of Class V were successful in reciting the tables on Monday. S Lokesh and C Sathyapriya too had this opportunity on Monday and Tuesday respectively.

On Wednesday, it was Janani’s turn who said that she always wanted to know how it feels to occupy the headmaster’s seat. More exciting was the fact that the headmaster was sitting opposite to her and taking instructions as an advisor.

She was busy giving homework to her fellow classmates and students of lower classes apart from making corrections to the homework done by the students. “I am happy that I could occupy the seat, but I want to occupy the district collector’s seat,” said Janani though she could not explain the reason for developing that interest.

“We were evolving ways to make students memorize multiplication tables. Our objective was to create an excitement among students so that they go for it with interest,” said headmaster Baranidaran.

“While all the eight students in class V attempted, only three could make it. We expect that they will be able to do it in the coming days,” he said.

To ensure that it should not be a mere ritual, Baranidaran said even if the chief education officer visits the school when children are functioning as headmaster/ mistress, they will be introduced as such.

PUPS Lingathur village is one of many schools in the state run by just two teachers. With a strength of 25 students, Baranidaran could manage the classes in the absence of his colleague who is away for a training.

Title: Firing incident at anti-CAA protest site figures in Rajya Sabha
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

NEW DELHI: Four days before Delhi goes to polls, concerns over the firing incident at Shaheen Bagh figured in the discussion during Zero Hour in Rajya Sabha . BJP member Bhupender Yadav sought action against those “criminalising Delhi elections”.

Soon after ministers tabled listed papers, member Vijay Goel (BJP) tried to raise the issue of firing in Shaheen Bagh and those behind the incident. This was strongly opposed by some of the Congress members. However, chairman M Venkaiah Naidu did not allow Goel to proceed with his arguments and asked members to raise permitted issues for Zero Hour.

Later, BJP MP Bhupender Yadav, as part of his Zero Hour mention, referred to the coming Delhi assembly elections and without naming any party or place referred to the firing incident. RS chairman made it clear that no references to any party or person will go on record.

“The Delhi elections are being watched with much interest not just nationally but also internationally. People were astonished by the fact that in Delhi, where elections are known to happen peacefully, suddenly at a certain spot incidents of firing were reported,” Yadav said.

He went on to say that when the police released the photograph of the person who indulged in firing, a political party held a press conference and issued a statement saying that a legal notice will be issued to the police.

Yadav said if administration and police were doing their job, then it is important for all political parties to follow the instructions of the Election Commission and not talk of issuing legal notices to police officials.

Title: Unesco vows to preserve Jaipur’s cultural heritage
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Unesco director general Audrey Azoulay (C) hands over certificate to ministers Shanti Dhariwal (L), Vishvendra... Read More

JAIPUR: Eight months after Pink City was included in the list of World Heritage Sites, the city received the Unesco certificate at Albert Hall here on Wednesday.

The twilight setting with a bit of chill in the air was perfect for the occasion as Unesco director general Audrey Azoulay handed over the certificate to the state government.

Speaking on the occasion, Azoulay said, “I came here from our headquarters in Paris with a message and recognition of the international community to the people of Jaipur for their outstanding efforts to preserve and conserve the cultural heritage for a sustainable future. Unesco is very proud to have the Walled City of Jaipur in the list of World Heritage Sites. Jaipur is already an iconic city because of its heritage and has a special place in the world. This inscription goes further and is a joint commitment to protect and preserve this heritage for the future.”

“Unesco and India have a history of strategic partnership based on cultural diversity, on the legacy of Mahatma Gandhi and on our joint commitment for education,” she said.

Emphasizing the importance of certification, the DG said that this recognition would help in developing responsible tourism.

In July 2019, Jaipur was included in the heritage list at the 43rd session of the World Heritage Committee(WHC) at Azerbaijan’s Baku. The city, founded by Sawai Jai Singh II in 1727, is the second Indian city to feature on the prestigious list.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot , who missed the ceremony due to ill health, tweeted, “Delighted and proud that Jaipur has got the Unesco Heritage Certificate. I dedicate the honour to people of Pink City and state. Jaipur is one of the most well planned and beautiful cities of the world. Let us preserve the heritage of the capital city.”

A state government source said the World Heritage Committee (WHC) had outlined six points to be followed by the state government. On implementing the same, UDH minister Shanti Dhariwal said, “A state-level committee, headed by the chief secretary, was constituted by the state government. All concerned departments were given responsibility to maintain the heritage as per special area plan. We have carried out 360-degree videography and prepared three dimensional map of the Walled City area using drones to maintain our heritage record.”

Title: ‘Eco-sensitive areas’ not to affect lives around wildlife sanctuaries
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Forest and wildlife minister K Raju assured the House that the proposed demarcation of ‘ eco-sensitive areas ’ around wildlife sanctuaries would not hinder the normal life and agriculture activities of people near the sanctuaries and other forest areas in the state.

Replying to a calling attention motion by C K Saseendran in the assembly, the minister said the proposed eco-sensitive area would be maximum of up to 1km radius from wildlife sanctuary borders. “It would have a radius of 0 to 1km. This would only affect red industries in the area and operation of saw mills would be banned. There would be no hindrance for any other ongoing activities. The proposal in this regard has been submitted to the central government for approval,” Raju said.

In view of the natural calamities the state witnessed in recent years, the government was not in favour of further reducing the size and reach of eco-sensitive cover around wildlife sanctuaries. “The area has been defined following directives from the Supreme Court. The eco-sensitive area is applicable only to places around wildlife sanctuaries. Government is ready to convene a meeting of MLAs to clear doubts and allay fears on the formulation of eco-sensitive areas,” K Raju said. tnn

This story is from February 6, 2020

Nirbhaya’s parents have been trying to fast track the process ever since SC confirmed the death penalty (ANI p... Read More

Title: Cong may spring a surprise in capital, claims Surjewala
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Randeep Surjewala

New Delhi: Congress functionary Randeep Singh Surjewala on Thursday said Congress may “spring a surprise” in the capital, just like it did in the elections in Haryana last year.

While other political parties have dismissed Congress from the contest, Surjewala, while addressing a press conference, said the results would be surprising for everyone. “Some news channels were giving us just two seats in Haryana, but we won 31. It is going to happen again,” he said.

Congress had failed to win a single seat in the 2015 assembly elections, while it managed eight in 2013. The party, however, did reasonably-well in terms of vote-share in the 2019 Lok Sabha polls by bagging over 22% of total votes polled.

Accusing Aam Aadmi Party-led Delhi government and BJP-led central government of failing in areas of health, pollution mitigation, education, clean drinking water supply and public transport in the capital, the AICC media in-charge said only Congress was capable of providing good governance.

“AAP wants dangal (confrontations) wali Delhi and the BJP wants dangon (riots) wali Delhi,” Surjewala claimed, while stressing that Congress wants “dil walon ki Dilli”.

Reacting to BJP’s blitzkrieg campaign that saw an army of workers and functionaries campaign in Delhi for 15 days, Surjewala said senior functionaries of the saffron party had “panicked” as they felt this time BJP may not win even three seats that it had won in the 2015 polls.

He alleged that BJP and AAP tried to hide their failure and distract people’s attention from issues of development in the city by raising the noise of “hatred and abusive language”.

Title: Coronavirus in Tamilnadu: Plan to speed up security check at Chennai airport hit
Content:
Chennai airport

CHENNAI: The Airports Authority of India’s (AAI) plan to speed up security check by installing an automatic tray retrieval system at Chennai airport’s domestic and international terminals by February or March is set to be delayed because of the spread of coronavirus in China.A Chinese company was selected to supply six conveyor machines that will remove and bring back trays used by passengers to place electronic items and wallets for scanning at security check and two machines have been installed at two security check counters at the domestic terminal as a pilot project, but AAI officials now feel the rest may not arrive before the deadline of March.An official said that one of the machines, put up under the pilot project, is helping speed up security screening that used to be delayed. The queues became lengthier as the CISF personnel on duty took time to bring back the empty trays. Under the new check rules, which mandate wallets and belts being placed in plastic trays in addition to electronic items, almost every passenger has to use a tray.Sources said the decision to install more machines was made after a study showed that passengers cleared the check-in process fast, but were getting stuck at slow security check counters. This gave them very little time to spend at retail shops, including food outlets, in the security hold area. The new machines help CISF personnel scan 800-900 cabin bags an hour compared to the 400 bags per hour that are cleared by scanners that do not have the automatic system.“The number of pieces of cabin baggage screened is high at the domestic terminal and passengers often reach the check-in counter an hour before departure. We found that most of these passengers get stuck at security check and in most cases hardly spend any time in the security hold area where retail and food outlets are located. This is going against the concept of airport retail by which passengers are supposed to spend time shopping before boarding flights,” said an official.

Title: Semester system to resume in Madhya Pradesh from next session
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

BHOPAL: Semesters will be back in Madhya Pradesh from the next academic session.

Higher education minister Jitu Patwari confirmed this to TOI on Wednesday, and said: “The previous BJP governments’ scrapping of semester system was against students’ welfare. We will resume it.”

The BJP administration had taken the state back in time in 2016 when it did away with semesters and brought back annual pattern of exam in colleges. Majority of academics had criticised the government then, pointing out that semesters were the norm, worldwide .

Talking to TOI, Patwari said, “Semester system is in vogue across the world. Ending it was against students’ interest and pushed them behind at the national and international level.”

Unlike the previous government, he is not in a rush to end the annual pattern, he said. “We will resume semester system gradually. The earlier government scrapped semester in one go, which put students in trouble. A draft has been prepared and we are studying ways of resuming semester system without undue hassle to students., The transition must be smooth.”

NSUI spokesperson Vivek Tripathi said the erstwhile BJP government’s decision to end semester system put students at a disadvantage. “It created an adverse impact on students as they have become casual towards attending classes, thinking that the examination will be held after a year. This is not good,” said Tripathi.

After the Congress government came to power, NSUI spoke to students in this regard, he said. “We have involved students, teachers and educationists to take their views on ending the annual pattern,” said Tripathi, adding that the semester system should be resumed gradually. “It is obvious that ending anything in one go left several voices unheard. To avoid such a situation, it will resume in phases,” said Tripathi.

Title: Protests in Sikar village after death of minor raped a wk ago
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Jaipur: Following the death of a 14-year-old girl, there was a complete shutdown in Kanwat village in Sikar on Wednesday, with local administration having to deploy additional police force.

The minor, who was raped and strangled by a neighbour, had died in JK Lon Hospital on Tuesday.

Local residents staged a protest demanding quick trial of the accused who raped and strangled the girl on January 27, resulting in her death more than a week later. The family along with the locals also staged a sit-in protest outside the local police station. The family alleged that the accused had raped the minor.

Title: BDU vice-chancellor agrees to revise pay of guest faculty
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

BDU vice-chancellor P Manisankar has assured a delegation of association of university teachers (AUT) on Monda... Read More

TRICHY: Around 350 guest lecturers working in 10 constituent colleges under Bharathidasan University (BDU) may have their salaries revised soon.

BDU vice-chancellor P Manisankar has assured a delegation of association of university teachers (AUT) on Monday that they would seek finance committee approval to raise the salaries of these ad hoc teachers working in 10 of its constituent colleges.

There are three types of teachers working on ad hoc basis apart from regular faculty members in the constituent colleges.

This includes guest faculty members on consolidated pay, teachers paid on hourly basis and teachers hired under parent teacher association (PTA).

While there aren’t any PTA teachers from this year, there are about 350 guest faculty members and 230 hourly-basis teachers.

As per UGC directive, institutions must not have more than 20% ad hoc teaching staff.

However, 80% of staff in these 10 constituent colleges are ad hoc. Four of these colleges were recently converted into government colleges. But salaries of guest faculty members are still paid by the university. They are paid a meagre Rs 10,000-13,000, while many of them are working for more than a decade now.

In 2011, UGC had fixed the pay scale for guest faculty members at Rs 25,000. While most of the institutions including BDU ignored it, qualified ad hoc teachers were asked to be paid Rs 50,000 as per Seventh Pay Commission last year.

State universities like Alagappa and Madurai Kamaraj have passed resolutions in their syndicate to pay Rs 25,000 for their ad hoc teachers, but BDU was silent so far on the salary front.

General secretary of AUT, M S Balamurugan said that Manisankar was positive and assured to give a decent hike for the guest faculty.

“We have asked the VC to consider further hike for those working from as early as 2006 for a maximum of Rs 13,000 per month,” he said.

Intellectual exploitation of hourly basis staff is further intense, who had tough time getting even experience certificate to apply for the direct recruitment of assistant professors in government arts colleges recently.

The vice-chancellor has assured to change the nomenclature of hourly basis teachers to guest faculty members.

This would help them apply for regular positions in colleges and universities, he said.

Title: Experts share innovative ideaswith citizens to make smart city
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Dignitaries at the panel discussion

Nagpur: Innovation and creativity have reached dizzy heights after citizens have become aware and responsible towards the decaying condition of the globe.

At a programme held at the Rajiv Gandhi National Institute for Intellectual Property Management (RGNIIPM) on Wednesday, ‘Ready to innovate worldwide forum’ came up with many methods to reduce the operating cost of the cities. Experts from various sectors, including the environment,

shared their solutions for the numerous problems and the best part was the participation of citizens in the dialogue which was healthy and constructive.

Rajendra Ladhkar talked about patented projects that are in use to make a city better and smarter. In his presentation, Ladhkar listed methods like upgraded road dividers which can detect and trap a terrorist vehicle. The device can also be used to divert traffic. It is cost effective and durable.

A hanging road divider was another tool suggested to bring down the operational cost of cities. The device will help in reducing road accidents which mostly occur due to unseen dividers. With this device, the divider will be easily seen, said the expert, who impressed the audience with his unique innovations.

Dnyaneshwar Kamble, co-founder of ‘Ready to Innovate Worldwide’, conducted the panel discussion. He welcomed the four panellists — Vishakha Rao, expert in market research, JS Pandey, an expert in climate change from NEERI, Dr Amol Deshmukh, founder of HERD Organic Farms and Pooja Maulikar, an examiner of patent and design.

When Rao was asked to define a ‘smart city’, she said, “When we talk about smart city, it doesn’t mean digitalization only. It also signifies a citizen’s role, like how he responds to a project of change.”

On the other questions like how can citizens ensure what they want and what can be done, Deshmukh and Maulikar said, “Maharashtra is turning into a state with the highest number of patents and only the ones concerned should be well educated on the subject.”

Regarding air pollution and the role citizens can play to check the menace, Pandey said, “Citizens must know the issue in depth and must stop falling prey to environmental problems. The environment and the ecosystem work like a human body in which the temperature rises with the probability of something wrong likely to happen. It is therefore mandatory to fear the rising change.”

The programme concluded with a ceremony in which awards were presented to eight individuals for their innovation and creativity.

Dr Ajay Gondane, a former high commissioner of India to Australia, was the chief guest, while Ravindra Thakre, collector, Nagpur district, was the guest of honour. Mayor Sandip Joshi and Mayor of Karlsruhe (Germany) Dr Frank Mentrup were also present.

Title: Delhi: Girl raped at US embassy staff quarters, driver held
Content:
Representative image

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

NEW DELHI: A minor was allegedly raped by a 25-year-old driver working with the US embassy at the staff quarters on its premises in Chanakyapuri . Police said they have arrested the accused.Around 9.30am on Saturday, the girl was playing outside her house when the accused, who also stays there, lured her to his house on the pretext of giving her some goodies and raped her. After some time, he let the girl go but threatened her not to tell anybody about the assault.The survivor’s mother, who also worked at the embassy, told police that on returning home from duty, she found her daughter in a state of shock and tried to speak to her. Soon the girl broke down and confided in her mother, who told cops that she had fainted after hearing her daughter’s ordeal. The next day she narrated the incident to her senior at the embassy, following which police were informed and the statements of the survivor and the mother were recorded. The mother told the cops that the accused would some times visit their family.A police team arrested the driver from his quarter, who confessed after initially denying any role in the crime, said a source. The cops have seized the accused’s mobile phone to find out if he had also filmed the girl during the sexual assault. The girl’s father also works with the embassy.A case has been registered under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act and under IPC sections of rape at Chanakyapuri police station. A medical examination of the girl at a hospital confirmed the sexual assault, a police officer said. The girl has been discharged from the hospital.In a statement, the US embassy said, “We were deeply disturbed by the alleged misconduct. We promptly took action when we were informed about the allegation, and brought this matter to the attention of police. We are fully cooperating with them.”In Video: Delhi: 5-yr-old girl raped outside US Embassy staff quarters, driver held

Title: Coronavirus in Chennai: No clear instructions from government, say doctors’ bodies
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Doctors’ bodies, including the Indian Medical Association and other organisations, said they have not received clear instructions from the government on the protocol to be followed if any of the passengers on home quarantine come to them with symptoms of novel coronavirus At least five private hospitals in the city said they have no information on how or when they should notify the government. So far, the Indian Medical Association has not received any information from the health department, said IMA state president Dr C N Raja.“Most doctors know how to medically handle such cases since clear protocols are listed out by organisations like World Health Organization. We are planning to meet health officials for more information on state protocol,” he said. The most common questions the association has been facing from doctors are — ‘Do we notify them when we have patients with symptoms or after they test positive? How should we send samples for tests? Can we continue to treat patients if tests confirm the viral infection?’Senior infectious diseases doctors said treatment for the virus is not clear yet. Morbidity is higher in patients with extremes of age, uncontrolled diabetes or blood sugar and among patients with other co-morbid infection.“But the viral infection has been declared as a pandemic. Kerala has declared it as an emergency. If the public health department is using its powers to restrict treatment at government hospitals we cannot violate it,” he said.Director of public health K Kolandaisamy said the state did not have any objection on patients getting admitted in private hospitals as long as they have adequate quarantine facilities and are equipped to handle infectious diseases. “We have not sent any instructions because we have not made any restrictions,” he said. The aim now is to prevent the virus within the state, he said. “Adequate precautions are being taken to prevent the spread of the disease within the state. We are keeping passengers in quarantine only to prevent transmission of the virus from one person to another. We expect medical teams to do the same,” he said. The health department said samples should be lifted by microbiologists or physicians in consultation with district surveillance officer Dr P Sampath, public health lab deputy director Dr S Raju and King Institute of Preventive Medicine director (incharge) Dr P Kaveri.Earlier, health secretary Beela Rajesh said the state has procured 5,000 additional personal protection equipment for its doctors, nurses and other healthcare workers. “We have also purchased disinfectants for hospitals and public places. Quarantine facilities in the hospitals are fumigated after patients are discharged even if they do not test positive for infection,” she said.

Title: Chained madrasa kids flee, rescued by cops
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

ALWAR: Police rescued three children trying to flee from a madrasa in Bharatpur, whose hands were tied using a chain.

The police handed the kids over to the district child welfare committee. The case is related to Machhi Mohalla in the Mathura Gate police station area of Bharatpur district . The three children studying at the madrasa had escaped at around 5 am on Tuesday. The children ran away after they were harassed, according to police. Children told the Child Welfare Committee that they do not want to study at the madrasa but want to be enrolled in a government school. They complained that teachers at madrasa used to beat them up.

District collector Nathmal Didel has constituted a committee to investigate the matter. The facilities at the madrasa were found to be minimum. The kids study and sleep at the same place.

Chairman of Bharatpur Child Welfare Committee Gangaram Parasar said that the children do not want to study at the madrasa.

Title: RSS chief youth urges youth to promote social equality
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

BHOPAL: Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) chief Mohan Bhagwat urged youth to encourage people to spread awareness on social equality and united family.

Addressing Vibhag Pracharaks (publicity in-charges) on Wednesday, Bhagwat said, "There is a need to spread the message of social equality and help eliminate caste-based inequalities. Sangh members should develop the organisation like a family and make efforts for ensuring social equality and harmony by instilling feeling of affection and affinity in the society," Bhagwat said.

According to regional publicity in-charge (Madhya Bharat region) Om Prakash Sisodia , the RSS chief also reviewed the activities undertaken by the regional bodies during the last one year and discussed plan to promote social harmony in the society. Bhagwat also talked about involving women from various social and cultural organisations to create awareness on developing an ideal family system through active participation of couples.

"What is an ideal Hindu family? How much time family members should spare for each other and how to establish family values are some of the issues that workers should discuss and share their thoughts with the families they contact. This would encourage families to participate in seminars and discussions on family values," the RSS chief said.

Bhagwat is on a four-day tour to the state capital for holding discussions with pracharaks from MP and Chhattisgarh. He reportedly emphasised on strengthening the saffron base in rural areas through dedicated volunteers and also to create awareness on CAA and Article 370 among public.

The RSS chief took feedback from the youth about the ongoing agitations against the new citizenship law. More than 100 pracharaks of Madhya Kshetra are taking part in the four-day meeting which began on Sunday at Saraswati Shishu Mandir's Sharda Vihar. The RSS chief will hold talks with functionaries of RSS affiliates, including the Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) and BJP during the coordination meeting on February 6.

Title: Odisha gets Rs 4,373 crore in rail budget
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The Centre has reduced Odisha’s rail budget allocation by nearly Rs 1620 crore. Against last year’s budget of Rs 5,993 crore, the state has been allocated Rs 4,373 crore this time, revealed the data shared by East Coast Railway (ECoR) here on Wednesday. The Naveen Patnaik government had asked for around Rs 6,000 crore for the development of railways in the state.

Ever since the Narendra Modi government came to power in 2014, the state has witnessed a steady rise in its rail budget allocation. From Rs 3,712 crore in 2015-16, it grew to Rs 4,682 crore in 2016-17, Rs 5,102 crore in 2017-18 and Rs 5,252 in 2018-19. But this fiscal’s allocation is lower than that of 2016-17.

“Last year, National Thermal Power Corporation (NTPC) had invested Rs 1400 crore in the Jharsuguda-Barapali coal corridor project. It had increased Odisha’s budgetary allocation to Rs 5,993 crore,” the ECoR stated.

A senior railway official, though, said the allocation will not affect ongoing projects. “All major projects have got significant increase in allotment. We are ready to complete one of the oldest projects — the 82-km-long Haridaspur-Paradip new line — this year,” the official said.

One of the important pending projects — the Khurda Road-Balangir (289 km) new line — got Rs 520 crore as against last year’s Rs 350 crore. The project, conceived in 1995, will connect western Odisha with the coastal part of the state. Only 92 km of the total project has been commissioned so far.

Another project — the 98.7km new line between Angul and Sukinda Road — has received budget grant of Rs 450 crore against last year’s Rs 250 crore.

Another recent project, the Jeypore-Nabarangpur (38 km) new line, got Rs 20 crore allocation against last year’s Rs 10 crore. But the Talcher-Bimalagarh (154 km) new line got Rs 10 crore less than last year’s Rs 150 crore. Similarly, the Jeypore-Malkangiri (130km) new line got Rs 33 crore against last year’s Rs 70 crore.

There is significant increase in allotment towards doubling work, especially Sambalpur-Talcher, Sambalpur-Titilagarh, Titilagarh-Rayagada and Titilagarh-Raipur. Indian Railways has given priority for electrification work of Khurda Road-Balangir and Lanjigarh Road-Junagarh Road rail line, said a railway source.

A new project — the Sambalpur-Gopalpur new line — has been sanctioned this year with a token amount of Rs 1 lakh. Wagon repair workshop at Maneswar in Sambalpur received allocation of Rs 20 crore.

Barring this new line, the Centre has not sanctioned any other new lines. The state had asked for new lines between Puri and Konark, Jajpur-Dhamra and Bargarh-Nuapada and rail lines in Mayurbhanj.

EoM

Title: Centre’s nod to Sambalpur-Gopalpur new line
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The Centre has sanctioned the Sambalpur-Gopalpur new line in this year’s rail budget. A token amount of Rs 1 lakh has been sanctioned for this 241-km-long project.

East Coast Railway (ECoR) sources said the project has been sanctioned at a cost of Rs 2957 crore subject to final approval of Niti Aayog. “The project will start after it gets Niti Aayog approval,” said a senior railway official.

This new line via Phulbani in Kandhamal district will connect western Odisha with southern Odisha. After completion of the project, industries in Sambalpur will be able to use Gopalpur port in Ganjam district.

Sambalpur BJP MLA Jayanarayan Mishra welcomed the decision and said the new line will benefit the people of Odisha. “The project will connect an industrial area with the port town. This is a good step taken by the Centre,” Mishra said.

Chatrapur BJD MLA Subash Chandra Behera said the state government is planning to make industrial development in Chatrapur and the new project will help in this endeavour. “Hope the project gets approval from Niti Aayog. The railways should start the project without delay,” he added.

However, Koraput Congress MP Saptagiri Ulaka raised question mark about the railway’s intention to take up new projects in the state. “We had similar declarations in the 2017-18 Budget for Gunupur-Therubali rail line, but since then the railways has backed out citing poor rate of return. It may happen to this project as well,” Ulaka cautioned.

Some other projects also got token amount. Naupada-Gunupur extension up to Theruvali (79.4 km) and Talcher-Angul new line with Y-connection at Talcher (14.5km) got Rs 1 lakh each in this Budget. Setting up of an electric engine overhauling workshop at Kalahandi got Rs 1 crore token money. Similarly, the Angul electric loco shed augmentation project received Rs 4 crore.

To enhance safety, elimination of level crossings by constructing of road over bridges (ROBs) and road under bridges (RUBs) have been given top priority and projects worth Rs 1165 crore have been sanctioned in this regard, said an ECoR source.

EoM

Title: Authorities were sleeping after SC confirmed death sentence, says HC
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

The court also pointed out that Mukesh Singh and Vinay Sharma filed curative plea after a gap of 550 and 549 d... Read More

NEW DELHI: Critical of the delay in the Nirbhaya case , Delhi high court on Wednesday said “authorities concerned were sleeping” after the Supreme Court confirmed death sentence of the four convicts in May 2017.

“I have no hesitation in saying that after dismissal of the special leave petition (SLP) by the Supreme Court in May 2017, nobody took steps for issuance of death warrants for their execution,” Justice Suresh Kait observed.

Listing how each of the convicts adopted “delay tactics” the high court noted that Mukesh Singh filed a review against the apex court’s dismissal of his appeal after a lapse of 186 days, while Vinay Sharma and Pawan Gupta moved a similar plea after a lapse of 225 days. Fourth accused Akshay Thakur took the most time, seeking review plea after a delay of 950 days.

It said even after the reviews were dismissed by SC the state’s authorities “waited for reasons best known to them” till December 2019, to approach trial court and seek a black warrant.

The Delhi government had moved the court for death warrants nearly two years after SC had dismissed the appeals against confirmation of death penalty. Before the government and Tihar Jail administration acted, Nirbhaya’s family moved the trial court in February 2019, seeking a date of hanging to be fixed. The high court also pointed out that Singh and Sharma filed curative plea after a gap of 550 and 549 days, respectively, from the date of dismissal of their review pleas.

On Wednesday, high court also plugged a loophole in Delhi jail rules, making it clear that Tihar and other jail authorities in the capital can now move to execute death warrants as soon as a death row convict loses the criminal appeal before the apex court, instead of waiting till review or mercy plea is filed.

Removing the confusion created by 2018 revised Delhi Prison Rules that led to crippling delay, the court interpreted these to hold that the bar on separate hangings exists only till the time appeals in Supreme Court are pending.

Title: Fort trip for visually impaired students
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Nagpur: To commemorate the 25th foundation year of the project ‘Madhav Netrapedhi’, Samadrishti Kshamata Vikas Evan Anusandhan Mandal (SAKSHAM) is organizing an unique expedition in collaboration with the Rotary Club of Nagpur Downtown wherein visually impaired students will be taken on an expedition to visit 13 forts in Vidarbha.

The foundation year also coincides with Golwalkar Guruji’s Jayanthi. He is the former sarsanghchalak of RSS.

The event aims to boost the confidence of visually impaired students. The organizing committee is striving to inculcate interest in the ‘History of Vidarbha’ and also to create awareness about the need for eye donation.

Commencing on February 9, the tour will end after 11 days. Mayor Sandip Joshi will flag off the event at the SAKSHAM office, Devdutta Bhavan at 7am. Collector Ravindra Thakre will be the guest of honour.

The expedition will end on Shivaji Jayanthi which is on February 19.

The 1905km journey will cover forts, namely Mahurgad fort, Sindkhedraja – Rajmata Jijau Mahal, Balapur fort, Narnala fort, Gavilgad fort, Anchalpur fort, Amner fort, Nagardhan fort, Ambagad fort, Pauni fort, Chandrapur fort, Vijaasan caves (Bhadravati), Markandeya Mandir, Navargaon caves, Gad mandir, Kalidas smarak and more.

Special training has been given to volunteers regarding how to handle these children and conduct a proper tour for them. The only aim of this ‘Journey to experience’ is to bring happiness to the visually impaired students.

It is for the first time that an educational tour like this has been undertaken for visually impaired students. 20 students are going to be a part of this expedition.

After every visit, a public programme is scheduled where these students are expected to give presentations based on their experience about the forts they visited. The programme will leave a cultural mark as local artistes would perform in the presence of dignitaries.

The expedition is expected to be supported by the directorate of information, the department of tourism, Maharashtra, the forest department and the directorate of archaeological survey of India, defence services and the curator of central museum, Nagpur.

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: Tara Tarini temple facelift on the anvil
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Chief minister Naveen Patnaik on Wednesday approved a plan to redevelop the periphery of Tara Tarini temple, the famous shrine in Ganjam district, to make it one of the famous religious places in the country.

A presentation on the facelift of the shrine was made before the chief minister at the secretariat. On January 31, 5T secretary V K Pandian visited the famous shrine to discuss the development plan.

It plan includes renovation of Singhadwar entrance with amenities for pilgrims, pathways with drinking water facilities and beautification of the hilltop, where the temple is located.

There will be many new additions which include prasad sevan hall, interpretation centre, rest shed, food kiosk, drinking water facilities, shoe stand, foot wash, waiting area, barrier-free accessibility, sitting benches, watch tower, police outpost and first-aid centre, said an official statement issued by the chief minister’s office. There will be one meditation hall and view point over the hill top behind the temple.

Collector (Ganjam) Vijay Amrut Kulange said a detailed estimate regarding requirement of funds would be made for the shrine redevelopment plan. As the temple is one of the oldest Shakti Pithas of India, the state government plans to make it one of the most attractive religious tourism sites of the country. It will be developed keeping in view the Kalinga architecture style.

Title: Goa: BJP spokesperson files complaint against Porvorim MLA
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Porvorim MLA Rohan Khaunte

PANAJI: BJP spokesperson Premanand Mahambre on Wednesday filed a complaint with the assembly speaker and Porvorim police alleging that he was heckled by Porvorim MLA Rohan Khaunte in the assembly complex for addressing a press conference earlier in the day against the Independent MLA.

Addressing a hurriedly-called press conference late evening, BJP state president Sadanand Shet Tanavade demanded necessary action against Khaunte.

Mahambre, who had addressed a press conference earlier in the day making allegations against Khaunte, said that the Independent MLA, on seeing him in the corridors of the assembly complex after the day’s proceedings were over, got into an altercation with him. “I went and briefed the chief minister who advised me to file a complaint,” Mahambre said.

Mahambre said at a press conference he had tried to “expose the double standards of Khaunte” who has been active in the opposition during the ongoing budget session.

Tanavade said party workers in the Porvorim constituency were at the receiving end when Khaunte was minister for revenue and IT. He indicated that the party couldn’t do much in the past as it didn’t have the numbers and was dependent on allies to run the government.

While Tanavade said Khaunte is frustrated as he is out of power, the Porvorim MLA said BJP is frustrated as he and other opposition members had exposed the BJP government on various issues, including the mismanagement of the state’s finances. “These are the old tactics of the BJP to level false allegations against opponents and to pressurise them into silence,” Khaunte said

Title: Kochi: District authorities bank on residents, eye better ranking
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

KOCHI: With the ministry of housing and urban affairs (MoHUA) announcing its next edition of the Ease of Living Index (EoLI) by incorporating a citizen perception survey to rank 114 cities in the country, district administration along with the Cochin Smart City Mission Ltd (CSML) and Kochi corporation have appealed to the citizens to participate in the survey and give good ranking to the city.

District collector S Suhas on Wednesday sent out a public appeal asking people to participate in the citizen survey to rank the city. CSML managing director Alkesh Kumar Sharma said: “Kochi city is way ahead of many others in the country in most of the parameters that are being assessed in the survey. I hope that the residents of the city will participate in large numbers so that we get the ranking we deserve.”

EoLI is an initiative of the urban affairs ministry to help cities assess their livability in relation to global and national benchmarks and encourage cities to move towards an ‘outcome-based’ approach to urban planning and management. The ministry launched the citizen perception survey on Saturday and the window for rating the cities will be active till February 29. The survey aims to record perception of residents on 49 parameters such as governance, health, cleanliness, water supply, safety and security, economic opportunities, availability of affordable housing, power supply, transportation, recreation, environment, public service and lifestyle. The 49 indicators will later be captured through 97 data points. Based on these indices, the cities will be ranked.

In 2018, the survey was based on the reports submitted by the local bodies and there were a lot of objections to the methodology. In that year, when scaled along with 111 cities in the country on its livability index, Kochi city stood at the 45th position while Thiruvananthapuram was ranked 71.

However, there is also a growing opinion that Kochi city should not take such surveys beyond it’s face value. “I think we should not get trapped into this ranking business as cities are not comparable for historical, social and administrative reasons. These rankings give some insights but should not be used to compare cities,” said centre for public policy research chairman D Dhanuraj.

“The ground rule is that ranking is not going to make any impact on funding agencies. When international agencies come in, ranking won’t help. Ground realities do,” he said.

“We are far ahead in terms of education, health, governance and several other parameters when compared to most of the cities. Last time, there was some confusion on methodologies but this time it is going to be even tough because Malayalis have a habit of measuring our standards with the West,” said Rajan Chedambath, director, centre for heritage, environment and development (c-hed), an institution under Kochi corporation.

Title: Two cops suspended in Churu after rape accused escaped
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

JAIPUR: Two policemen were suspended for dereliction of duty after the accused in the rape of a 10-year-old girl in Churu managed to escape from their custody. Although the accused was rearrested after two hours, officials took action against the cops.

The suspended police officers were identified as Girdhari and constable Balbir of Rajgarh police station in Churu district.

Churu SP Tejaswani Gautam told TOI, “The police personnel were suspended as they failed to do their duty. The rape accused was detained for questioning and the sentry was supposed to keep a watch on him when the investigating officer just stepped away for a while. The accused jumped from the window and fled. The two cops responsible for this carelessness have been suspended.”

Accused Akram Khan had abducted the 10-year-old girl following which he took her to a secluded spot and raped her. He also attempted to kill her. The rape survivor is undergoing treatment at a hospital in Jaipur. Khan was produced in court and sent to judicial custody.

On Wednesday, traders shut their shops and educational institutes remained closed in Rajgarh area of the district. They were protesting against the rapidly increasing crimes against women. The traders' association had called for a shut down on Wednesday and they took out a silent rally. Later, they also submitted a memorandum to the sub-divisional magistrate demanding death penalty to the accused.

Title: TISS student’s bail rejected in sedition case
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

MUMBAI: A sessions court on Wednesday rejected the anticipatory bail plea of a 22-yearold student of Tata Institute of Social Sciences (TISS) booked for sedition. Urvashi Chudawala was booked for raising slogans in support of JNU student Sharjeel Imam , arrested for sedition, at the LGBTQ Pride March at Azad Maidan onSaturday.

Rejecting the plea, judge Prashant P Rajvaidya said: “Even though this court is not dealing with the matters of crime allegedly committed by Sharjeel Imam, ultimately the intent of the statement uttered by the applicant (Chudawala) in supporting Sharjeel Imam, in my opin ion, prima facie, attracts the ingredients of Section 124A (sedition) of Indian Penal Code which attracts life imprisonment. Hence, the offence is serious in nature.”

Opposing the student’s plea, chief public prosecutor Jaisingh Desai said Sharjeel’s statements were against the country, he is an enemy of the country and Urvashi had supported such a person.

The slogan raised by the accused showed that the student wanted to get together and fulfil Sharjeel’s dreams as he is in custody. He added that before registering the FIR, cops had repeatedly called the student but she didn’t cooperate. Defence advocate Vijay Hiremath submitted that for sedition, there should be a call for violence.

“Was the line, said only once for two seconds as shown by the video, do any harm? It does not create any hatred towards the government, any community or individuals. It was in the intensity of the continuous sloganeering for 10 minutes. One line was said, and it was only against his arrest,” he said, adding that Chudawala was not connected to Imam. But the court said the material prima facie supported allegations that on her Facebook account, Chudawala had liked a photo of Sharjeel, where it was mentioned, ‘Release Sharjeel Unconditionally”.

Title: Jamia Protest: Jamia students to change protest site
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Jamia students and local residents have been protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act for almost two m... Read More

NEW DELHI: Responding to an appeal by the Jamia Millia Islamia administration , the joint coordination committee has decided to stop protesting near gate number 7 for two days in view of elections. This is being done to ensure that voters do not face any problems in entering and exiting the polling station, said a member, adding that they will cooperate fully in the free and fair conduct of the elections.

However, the protesters will return to gate number 7 on February 9, a day after the polls, the member clarified.

Jamia Millia Islamia administration had on Wednesday issued an appeal to the students to stop protesting near gate number 7 in view of security concerns and elections. A day before, Delhi Police had written to the university authorities to ask students to stay away from the protest and vacate the stretch near gate number 7. Upender Singh, SHO, Jamia Nagar, had written the letter to the varsity registrar stating that the law and order situation in Jamia Nagar area was very critical.

“Some students, old students and localites are sitting at Okhla road outside the gate number 7 of the university, protesting against CAA and NRC. The road from Holy Family hospital to Jamia Millia metro station has been blocked. In past, firing incidents occurred in the area of New Friends Colony and Shaheen Bagh. A case of attempt to murder and arms act has been registered as well,” the letter added.

“In view of the Delhi elections on Saturday and to avoid any untoward situation, you are requested to remove the protesters from the road,” the letter urged the registrar.

In its appeal to the students, the varsity administration stated that the dharna was happening on Maulana Mohammad Ali Jauhar Marg and that the “university was responsible for the safety and security of its students within the domain of the campus and could protect the students and staff when they as a group are independent of the crowd which was not a bona fide part of the university.”

The administration requested students not to be a part of an agitating crowd on a public road. “The parents were being approached and their support in personal capacity was also solicited to guide their wards in adhering to basic precautions,” it stated.

Title: Four-day desert festival begins at Pokhran today
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Officials take stock of situation in Jaisalmer on Wednesday

JAISALMER: The four-day Jaisalmer Desert Festival will begin at Pokhran on February 6 and conclude at Sam sand dunes on February 9 where singer Richa Sharma will perform and more than 1,000 folk singers will present a desert symphony aiming to create a world record.

District collector Namit Mehta on Wednesday visited various areas such as Pokaran, Jaisalmer, Khuhadi, Sam and Kuldhara to check the preparations. When Mehta went to see the road from where the shobha yatra will start, he was disappointed and expressed his resentment on water flowing on the road. He instructed officials to clean up the mess on the road before the festival.

Mehta also instructed officials to remove encroachments from road sides. He visited Union Circle and asked shopkeepers not to dump waste on the roads. He also asked officials to illuminate the roads properly.

He requested organisers to include new and attractive programmes to make the festival more colourful and memorable.

Tourism officer Bhanu Pratap said the procession will start at Pokaran where several programmes such as mehndi, mandana, rangoli, drawing competition, kabaddi match and tug-of-war will be held.

At Gadisar Lake in Jaisalmer, deepdan, heritage walk and a laser show in Sonar Fort will be held at night. The formal inauguration will take place in Jaisalmer by taking out procession on February 7. On the same day, a turban tying competition for Indian and foreign tourists will be held. In addition, a moustache competition, Miss Moomal and Mr Desert will also be organized along with cultural programmes at night. On February 8, a camel decoration competition will be held on Dedandar ground.

Title: Gujarat: Permit scam hits prohibition department
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

GANDHINAGAR: A liquor permit scam, involving the sale of liquor from a licenced shop in the Mundra Special Economic Zone (SEZ), has rocked the state prohibition department. Senior officers have been issued show-cause notices, after it was found that the liquor shop owner not only sold liquor to persons outside the SEZ, he also evaded VAT on liquor sold to persons outside the SEZ.

The Gujarat home department has cancelled the liquor sale license of M/s Planet F&B, one of the biggest liquor shops in Mundra SEZ, which was found to be involved in large-scale irregularities.

A senior government official said that according to the SEZ Act, liquor shops can sell alcohol within the SEZ without any tax liability. “Selling any kind of liquor outside the SEZ without a licence is illegal. It was found that M/s Planet F&B sold more than 46,000 bottles of liquor without due process and without paying tax to the government,” the official stated.

The role of senior officials of the prohibition department in this scam is also being investigated. The official said, “A departmental inquiry has been initiated against senior officials of the prohibition department, who are alleged to have allowed the illegalities. The unauthorised sale outside the SEZ amounts to a lapse on the part of the officers.”

He added that the licence of M/s Planet F&B, granted in 2015, has been revoked and legal action has been initiated against the company.

Officials said M/s Planet F&B also caused a loss of Rs 54 lakh to the exchequer by not paying supervisory fees, which was fixed at Rs 1.50 lakh per month. “Liquor shop permits are normally granted to posh hotels, but as a special case, this agency was granted the licence based on an assurance of paying supervisory fees of Rs 1.50 lakh per month. However, in connivance with local department officials, the licensee did not pay Rs 54 lakh in supervisory fees,” the official added.

M/s Planet F&B had been granted a licence to sell liquor only in one of the four segments of the SEZ, but investigations revealed that it had been selling liquor in other segments too.

Title: ‘Government saved Rs 2,000cr through reverse tendering’
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Vijayawada: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy on Wednesday reiterated that the state has saved Rs 2,000 crore through reverse tendering and clarified that the tenders of the previous government were cancelled due to irregularities.

Speaking at an education conclave, the chief minister once again sought to allay the fears of investors by justifying the reverse tendering as a profitable exercise. “In Polavaram alone we have saved Rs 830 crore. To put it simply, the same work was done for Rs 830 crore less than what was agreed to under the previous regime. In the TIDCO housing scheme, we could save Rs 400 crore,” Jaganmohan Reddy explained.

He also expressed confidence that the reverse tendering would help bring down cost and infuse competitive spirit among bidders. Replying to a question during the conclave, Jaganmohan Reddy spoke about judicial preview and announced that it will scrutinise the the tenders above Rs 100 crore and put them in the public domain for suggestions. “Once the bids are closed, only the amount of the lowest bidder would be on the website and if anyone quotes a lesser price it will be considered. It is a part of the initiative to provide transparent and corruption-free governance,” Jaganmohan Reddy added.

Meanwhile, during a review meeting on Wednesday, the chief minister revealed his future plans for village and ward secretariats and said that a standard operating procedure would be put in place to ensure that welfare programmes reach the people. He said a process has to be maintained by the secretarial staff and volunteers while implementing the new welfare programmes. The chief minister directed officials to maintain an attendance register for the volunteers.

He said since each volunteer was entrusted with 50 houses, there should not be any scope for delays in implementation of any scheme. As the system was introduced to take administration to the doorsteps of the people, there should be no scope for corruption, he said, adding that monthly review of the secretariates’ performance can help.

Title: Minister talks tough against management
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: If Muthoot Finance management continues to stick to its defiant attitude towards conciliatory talks aimed at settling the ‘serious labour issues ’ in the company, the government would explore all available legal options to rein in the private finance institution, labour affairs minister T P Ramakrishnan told the assembly here on Wednesday.

Answering to a submission by M Swaraj in the assembly, the labour affairs minister said the Muthoot Finance management’s refusal to stick to the tri-partite agreement, reached on the basis of the recommendations of Kerala high court, was the reason for the current spate of labour agitation.

“Following a complaint of non-banking and private finance association (CITU) against the management’s attempts to retrench a number of employees and close down branches, contrary to an agreement reached with the employees’ association, the labour commissioner invited both parties for talks. But the management said it was not ready to roll back the decisions of retrenchment of staff and closure of branches. Following this, a meeting chaired by the labour affairs minister came to a conclusion that the management has violated the agreement. Muthoot Finance managing director was also asked to show reasons for the violation of agreement. In view of the ongoing strike, subject to the orders of the high court, labour commissioner held further meetings on January 14, 20 and 29. The meeting held in the presence of the high court nominee on January 29 asked the management to take back the retrenched employees. The company management is yet to respond,” the minister said.

Title: One arrested for poaching leopards, bears
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

CHANDRAPUR: Forest officials on Wednesday arrested a person in connection with poaching of leopard and bear pairs a few days ago in DSC Colony area under Ordnance Factory Chanda, near Bhadrawati.

Two bears and two leopards were electrocuted by live wire laid in a forested patch close to the residential area. Poachers were suspected to be after wild herbivore, but the four animals came in contact with the live wire and died.

Forest officials started looking for suspects with the help of CCTV footage and had rounded up four on Tuesday. Three of them turned out be innocent. The fourth suspect Ravi Chetti, 40, was arrested.

Later, the accused was remanded in judicial custody after he was produced before the JMFC court. Chetti has several cases of poaching against him. More arrests are likely in the coming days, said sources in the department.

Title: Hall ticket distribution for SSC exam commences
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Kolhapur divisional board of Maharashtra State Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education (MSBSHSE) in a circular has notified the schools to download the Secondary School Certificate (SSC, class X) hall tickets, which are available on the MSBSHSE website.

According to a circular from the Kolhapur divisional board secretary, the school authorities can check the website www.mahasscboard.in to download the hall tickets.

An official from the Kolhapur divisional board said that there are over 2,000 schools across Sangli, Satara, and Kolhapur districts, which falls under this division, from which around 1.30 lakh students will appear for the Class X exam this year. The schools have been asked to download the hall tickets and distribute to the students without any extra charge.

The circular stated that if there are any corrections in the hall ticket regarding the medium of instruction or the subject, then the schools must approach the divisional board office for changes, while the corrections in regard with the photo, signature, student’s name, place of birth or birth date should be made by schools on their level and a copy of it should be submitted to the divisional board office.

It further said, “If the hall ticket of a student gets misplaced then those student can be given another copy of hall ticket and it should be marked as duplicate. In case of an error in the photograph, a new photo can be glued on the hall ticket with the stamp from the headmaster of the respective school.”

The schools have been advised to contact the board office in case they encounter any kind of technical difficulties while downloading the hall tickets.The Class X exam will commence from March 3 across the state .

Title: Odisha government plans six more projects worth Rs 900 crore for Puri
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Odisha CM Naveen Patnaik

Bhubaneswar: The state government has planned six more projects worth around Rs 900 crore for Puri under the ABADHA scheme as part of its efforts to transform it into a world-class heritage city.

Earlier, the state government had already approved 15 projects worth Rs 2,300 crore under the Augmentation Basic Amenities and Development of Heritage and Architecture (ABADHA) scheme, named after the temple Mahaprasad.

The government had already made an allocation of Rs 730 crore for them in the supplementary budget in November.

“The six new projects are apart from several other projects sanctioned earlier, including the heritage corridor project around the Puri Jagannath Temple . The official announcement of the new projects would be made soon,” said a senior government official.

The new projects include, among others, a street façade improvement project that has been planned to give a heritage look to the structures on the Badadanda (Grand Road). Around 250 crore will be spent on it.

Earlier, the housing and urban development department had asked house owners, mutt authorities, dharmasalas, hotels and commercial establishments to apply a uniform colour on the buildings along the Grand Road.

The state government has also decided to develop the pleasure garden of the Lord located at the Jagannath Ballav Mutt with an investment of Rs 80 crore. According to the Jagannath Temple administration, the mutt supplies flower-ornaments like tilak and jhumpa for Baddasinghara Besha of the Lord.

As the temple city has several spots of heritage significance, the state government has decided to develop the heritage paths with better road connectivity and develop other basic infrastructure. Under the ABADHA project, around Rs 360 crore will be spent on this project.

The sea beach in Puri would soon become a centre of attraction for people visiting the pilgrim town. Plans are afoot to develop the beach front from the Banki Muhan till the Sterling Resorts. “A master plan is being prepared for the beach front development with focus on beautification, greenery, strengthening roads and developing public amenities,” the official said.

Development of resort, wellness centre, exhibition space-cum-interpretation centre, public park, illumination, parking space and handlooms and handicrafts centre will be covered under the beach road development plan. The state government plans to spend around Rs 180 crore on it.

The development of Gundicha temple, believed to be the birthplace of Lord Jagannath, Lord Balabhadra and Devi Subhadra, is also part of the ABADHA project. Around Rs 5 crore will be spent for the purpose.

Similarly, a Gurukul project with an investment of Rs 25 crore will also be taken up under ABADHA scheme to groom young servitors.

The ABADHA projects will be implemented over a period of three years from 2019-20 to 2021-22. Significant allocation is expected for these projects in the forthcoming state budget for 2020-21 fiscal year, the official said.

Title: Economic survey teams ‘attacked’ in UP
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

BIJNOR: Teams conducting the government ’s economic survey faced stiff resistance and were even “manhandled” in some parts of UP’s Bijnor amid a charged atmosphere against CAA and NRC.

On Wednesday, economic census enumerators in Bijnor shot off a letter to the district magistrate narrating the difficulties they are facing in some parts “due to misinformation”.

According to district economic and statistics officer Harendra Malik , “Our teams are facing protests in minority-dominated areas as people are linking it to NRC. Some team members were manhandled. We have now asked village heads to help our teams in the survey.”

Title: Coronavirus Delhi: Five more with travel history to China admitted at RML Hospital
Content:
The total admissions for suspected coronavirus infection at the nodal centre rose to 12

NEW DELHI: Five persons with history of travel to China were admitted to Ram Manohar Lohia (RML) hospital on Wednesday, taking the total admissions for suspected coronavirus infection at the nodal centre to 12. Only persons with symptoms of the viral infection, including fever and cough, are being admitted to the hospital. The rest are being quarantined at other facilities like isolation units set up by the Army and Indo-Tibetan Border Police (ITBP), and even homes, officials said.“The test samples of all admitted persons have been sent to National Centre for Disease Control and National Institute of Virology, and reports are awaited,” said an official.Among those admitted to RML hospital are two 23-year-old men and a woman who returned from China last week.Five evacuees, who were being quarantined at the Indo-Tibetan Border Police (ITBP) facility, were shifted to Safdarjung hospital on Tuesday. “Among those shifted are three men and two women. The five have been shifted as a precautionary measure after they showed basic symptoms like cough and sneezing. Some had a medical history,” said a doctor.A total of 406 people have been quarantined at the ITBP facility in Delhi’s Chhawla area since the last week after they were brought in two batches from Wuhan onboard separate Air India flights.

Title: Disaster management training for representatives from flood-hit villages
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Training sessions will be mandatory for the representatives and the ones abstaining from the training will be ... Read More

KOLHAPUR: The Sangli district administration will begin with the disaster management training for the sarpanch, gram sevak, and talathis of 104 flood-affected villages from February 10.

District collector Abhijit Choudhary said that attendance for training sessions will be mandatory for the representatives and the ones abstaining from the training will be liable for action as per the Disaster Management Act, 2005. Choudhary has asked the officials to appoint nodal officers to get the desired response.

Choudhary said that there will be a separate village disaster management plan for each village. Experts from the respective fields have been roped in for the same and the initiative will assist in preparing such a plan.

The co-ordination has to be looked after by the district disaster management officer, he said, adding that the reason why the training session has been made mandatory is that in case of disaster-like situation, we will have trained fleet available, including trained leadership.

The training has been arranged according to the respective taluka. The village representatives from the Miraj, Palus, Walva, and Shirala will be part of the said initiative.

In December last year, Sangli district collector had organized a similar activity for youths from the flood-affected villages. The initiative had received a phenomenal response.

An official from the district administration said that there are over 100 villages situated near the Krishna river. These villages face severe threats during floods which is why an initiative like this one is extremely necessary.

Title: Dharma Reddy takes charge as SVBC MD
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Tirupati: Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams additional executive officer AV Dharma Reddy assumed charge as the managing director of Sri Venkateswara Bhakti channel on Wednesday.

TTD’s 24-hour devotional channel has been in the news following an audio leak involving the then SVBC chairman Prudhvi Raj speaking inappropriately with a woman employee of channel.Following the episode, Prudhvi Raj stepped down from SVBC chairmanship immediately.

In order to streamline the functioning of TTD’s devotional channel, TTD chairman YV Subba Reddy appointed additional EO AV Dharma Reddy as the MD of the channel.

After assuming charge as the SVBC MD, Dharma Reddy told reporters that his focus would be to enhance the spiritual aura of Lord Venkateswara by designing and promoting spell-binding programmes on SVBC.

“Streamlining the administration is one aspect while providing quality spiritual content to the viewers who are all devotees of Lord Venkateswara is another important aspect which I would focus my attention on,” he reiterated.

Title: Amended marine fisheries regulation Act in the offing
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The state government is planning to amend the AP Marine Fisheries Regulation Act (MFRA) of 1995, which has become obsolete. The upgraded MFRA, which will take the recommendations of scientists from Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute (CMFRI) and Central Marine Fisheries Technology (CIFT), will focus on sustainable and eco-friendly fishing techniques.

The new regulations will also focus on regulating uncontrolled fishing, species diversification, cutting down on optimal fleet size, limiting craft and mesh size, conversion of trawlers to tuna liners, prohibition on catch of endangered and protected species, improved surveillance and vessel monitoring system etc. After decades of research, a group of scientists from CMFRI have compiled a study — ‘Policy Guidance on Sustaining Marine Fisheries of Andhra Pradesh’ — based on which recommendations have been made to the state government to amend the MFRA on those lines.

Subhadeep Ghosh, principal scientist in-charge at CMFRI who is among the authors of the study along with Muktha Menon, A Gopalakrishnan and others, feels the existing MFRA is poorly implemented and monitored. “We have suggested a separate enforcement wing for the state fisheries department besides marine fisheries surveillance units when the Act is updated. There is also a need to regulate uncontrolled fishing efforts such as an optimal fleet size of 1,300 mechanized fishing boats. The state presently has around 1,600 such boats and the fishing capacity is nearly 62% in excess,” he said.

“Boats over 15 years of age should be replaced, engine power should be reduced to below 300 horsepower, and high-powered crafts should be restricted from trawl fishing and diverted to deep sea long-lining and gillnetting. Conversion of shrimp trawlers to tuna liners has already been advocated in the state,” Ghosh added.

CMFRI scientists have also recommended regulating mesh size in the trawl cod ends to reduce juvenile fish from getting caught and advocated wide use of by-catch reduction devices. Other recommendations include restricting the number of ring seines (nets), strict enforcement of 60-day fishing ban, creating a reserved zone for traditional fishers up to eight kilometres from the shore to prevent indiscriminate exploitation of brooders and juvenile fish. The also want minimum legal size (MLS) of fish landed or caught to be implemented as a control measure, which will enable most fish to spawn at least once before being caught.

Title: Accept GST returns sans late fees till February 12: HC to Centre
Content:
This story is from February 6, 2020

Representative Image

JODHPUR: The Rajasthan high court has given big relief to the taxpayers to file GSTR 9 and 9C without late fees and has directed the Centre to file a detailed reply by February 12 about its preparedness and GSTN filing capacity of the server.

The court has also directed the Centre to accept GSTR 9 and GSTR 9C returns without charging any late fees till February 12.

The Tax Bar Association , Jodhpur , had moved the high court through a PIL with regard to the technical glitches being faced by taxpayers in filing GSTR 9/9C on the GSTN portal, which rendered the extended time for filing returns useless.

Arguing in the court, petitioner’s counsel Rahul Lakhwani stated that repeated attempts by taxpayers to file tax returns on the portal during the extended period failed time and again.
